Civic Forum and the Green Party issued a joint communique that called on local party chapters and members to ``pursue ... relations of partnership and cooperation based on the similarity of common objectives.'' Civic Forum led the peaceful popular uprising that toppled the hard-line Communist regime of Milos Jakes last year and is so far the strongest contender heading into the country's first free elections in four decades. The campaign formally begins next week for the elections on June 8 and 9. The Greens, although previously unknown in Czechoslovakia, are also high in the polls with an estimated 11 percent of the population ready to support them.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats at Odds Over Spending Blueprint
DOC.NOTE: EDS: House meets 11 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders tout their budget as a forward-looking alternative to President Bush's plan, but conservatives within their party say it's equally lacking in political courage. ``I am angry,'' said conservative Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., as the House began debate Wednesday on the $1.2 trillion blueprint for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. ``It is another example of dodging important issues.'' The leaders' budget would cut $8 billion from the president's $303.8 billion Pentagon spending request for next year, and put most of that money toward domestic programs such as space, AIDS research and education. ``It is time we rebuild America, restore our economic leadership in the world and begin to address unmet needs,'' said Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., principal author of the plan. The House planned today to debate two Republican alternatives to the Democratic plan, one a partial freeze on spending at current levels and the other to cut red ink through the use of gold-backed bonds to refinance the national debt. Final action on the House budget is planned next week. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Wednesday he was confident the leadership plan would prevail. But McCurdy said he ``wouldn't count those votes yet.'' With Republicans unified in their opposition, it was possible conservative Democrats could sink the plan. But Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, said that while his fellow conservatives were frustrated, most would stick with the leadership in order to move things toward a budget summit with the White House. Panetta conceded more needed to be done to reduce the deficit than the $36 billion in claimed savings in his plan. But he said that without Bush's leadership it couldn't pass. ``There is a difference between posturing on tough choices and getting the institution to adopt tough, hard choices,'' he said. In the Senate, the Budget Committee was scheduled today to continue work on its version of the budget. Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., has been struggling to find consensus among his Democrats without success. The budget plan that finally emerges will be the basis for individual spending bills for government programs later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Drug `War Bond' Bill Attacked by Democrats
DOC.TEXT: A popular Republican plan to finance the drug war with tax-deferred savings bonds is under attack by Democrats who call it another step away from pay-as-you-go government. Senior Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee complained that if the drug war is so important, Republicans should be willing to raise taxes to pay for it rather than passing the cost to future generations through borrowing. ``There's another addiction occurring in this country _ an addiction to debt,'' Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said Wednesday as the committee heard testimony on the drug-bonds bill. ``If the war on drugs, the education deficit we have, the war on crime are truly national priorities, we should be honest and pay for them,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the committee. Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., chief sponsor of the bonds bill, defended it as a practical way to get Americans _ especially school children _ directly involved in fighting drugs. As important as it is to reduce the budget deficit, Lewis said, ``The No. 1 priority ... way ahead of anything else, is drugs.'' Lewis' bill, cosponsored by 249 of the 435 House members, would authorize the Treasury Department to issue up to $4 billion in savings bonds. As with present savings bonds, taxation of interest could be delayed until they were redeemed. The bonds would pay for education, building prisons and other anti-drug programs. A key part of the proposal would allow children to save their nickels and dimes to buy 25-cent savings stamps. A filled stamp book could be exchanged for a savings bond, in much the same way that Americans helped finance World War II. ``Isn't it better to interest students in fighting drug abuse and saving for their future in the second grade, before they are hooked by crack in the sixth grade?'' Lewis asked. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., who chairs the House Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, questioned whether ``we should be borrowing from our children to teach them the dangers of drugs'' when many of the most vulnerable children are the poorest. Endorsing the bill were representatives from the Elks and the General Federation of Women's Clubs. So did television cop Dennis Franz of ``Hill Street Blues'' and ``Nasty Boys.'' The National Beer Wholesalers' Association announced its support and pledged to buy the first $100,000 in bonds. Roger Chapin, president of Citizens for a Drug-Free America and an author of the bond proposal, said the nation does not want a protracted state-federal battle over who should command the drug war. ``The fact is that we taxpayers are going to wind up paying the bill in any case, and we don't much care what portion comes out of our right pocket to pay the IRS or out of our left pocket to pay the states,'' he said. Rep. Fortney Stark, D-Calif., contended the bond bill is part of a larger plan by some Republicans and conservatives to force sterilization of drug-addicted mothers and set up ``Nazi-like prison camps'' where guards ``can beat some sense into offenders.'' Lewis denied any such intent. However, Chapin recommended the bonds be used for ``a demonstration work-study `boot camp' that would not only shake up young adult offenders, but more importantly, shape them up with the education and skills necessary to a productive, trouble-free life.'' The Treasury Department spoke against the bill, as it does against most proposals to issue bonds for special projects.

DOC.HEAD: Smallest Army Since Before World War II Could be in Store
DOC.TEXT: The United States could have its smallest Army since 1940 if troop cuts under study by top Army officials are enacted. Army Secretary Michael Stone says some one-third of the Army's soldiers could be removed from the ranks over the next five or six years if budget pressures continue. ``We think the Army is going to come down somewhere in the neighborhood of 200,000 to 250,000 people from a baseline of 750,000'' active-duty soldiers, Stone told a Pentagon-sponsored panel this week. Stressing that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney hadn't made the final decisions, Stone said such cuts ``would mean that the Army is going to be something around one-third lower than it is today in force structure by the time that we get to ... 1995 to 1996.'' Stone made the comments in a speech Monday evening to the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services. A tape of his remarks was made available by the Army. The Army has the largest segment of the nation's 2.1-million-strong military force, and thus is the biggest target for possible budget savings. Army officials acknowledge that they are being forced to look to personnel cuts to salvage money for training and other accounts that would leave them with a smaller, but what they believe will be an effective, fighting force. Telling his audience ``there are three stages of force reduction that we're looking at,'' Stone described proposals Army officials have been mulling over in response to budget pressures and the apparent lessened Soviet threat. In response to a request last year from Cheney, the Army made plans in its current budget to cut about 135,000 troops by 1994, Stone said. Additional cutbacks are being reviewed to strip an additional 50,000 from the Army in a second-stage cutback, he said. The decisions will be made ``in the next few months'' as Cheney reviews the military services' five-year budget plans. Pentagon sources reported two weeks ago that the Army was planning such cuts, which would bring the Army to a low of 580,000 troops by Oct. 1, 1996, the beginning of the 1997 fiscal year. At the end of January, the Defense Department's count of soldiers stood at 760,818, and the preliminary headcount for the end of February was 755,164. There were 269,023 people in the Army in 1940. The number skyrocketed to 8.2 million in 1945 at the end of World War II and dropped to 554,030 by 1948. There were 780,000 people in the Army in 1986, Stone said, adding ``we've come down a fair chunk'' in a short time. The cutbacks, he said, are coming at a time when the threat is uncertain. ``All we know is, there is a lot of uncertainty.'' Stone said the discussion of the troubles afflicting the Soviet economy reminds him of ``what happened in Germany in the early 1930s, when out of the economic chaos ... arose somebody we've learned a great deal about _ Mr. Hitler.'' ``Instability can produce some things that are pretty difficult to handle,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Bill to Combat Drug Money-Laundering
DOC.TEXT: The government could close banks convicted of money-laundering under a House-approved bill that critics contend still leaves a giant loophole for drug kingpins to hide their illicit earnings. On a 406-0 vote Wednesday, the House approved a bill that, for the first time, would let regulators revoke the charters and deposit insurance of banks and savings and loan institutions convicted of money-laundering. However, under intense opposition from the Bush administration, the Federal Reserve and the banking industry, the House refused to take the first step toward making banks keep detailed records on the source and destination of wire transfers through which most drug profits are funneled. The House defeated, 283-127, an amendment by Rep. Esteban Torres, D-Calif., to establish a pilot program in drug center cities that would require banks to keep records of the names, addresses and account numbers of parties on both sides of a wire transfer. Opponents of the amendment, including most members of the House Banking Committee, contended it would impose a burdensome new record-keeping requirement on banks and thrift institutions. ``A misstep here could cost hundreds of millions of dollars,'' said Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga.. ``While very well-meaning, this amendment is overkill.'' Barnard, a former banker, said the amendment could lead to adding a $10 to $15 paperwork cost to each of the 100 million wire transfers handled by U.S. financial institutions annually. Supporters of the amendment, however, contended the bill is a ``bucket without a bottom'' for snaring launderers of drug money if there is no way to trace the source and destination of wire transfers. ``I hope we come to the day sometime when all of us are against the drug traffickers more rather than concerned about how much of a burden we're placing on our banking friends,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics. ``If you don't think the banking industry doesn't know what these drug traffickers are doing _ and are not making a big profit off of it _ you're putting us on,'' Rangel said. The bill is aimed at addressing the $110 billion in U.S. cash drug transactions that the Treasury Department estimates are laundered through the world financial system every year despite laws to thwart it. ``We put the street dealer in jail and we put the drug kingpin in the penitentiary, but no one has found a way to imprison a bank,'' said the bill's chief author, Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill. ``When you consider that a money-launderer can earn $10,000 laundering just a single day's take for a drug dealer, you realize just how inadequate mere fines are,'' he said. ``The provisions hold out the death penalty for any financial institution convicted of money-laundering.'' As originally introduced, the House bill would have required regulators to lift the charter and deposit insurance of banks convicted of money-laundering. Because of opposition from the administration and the bank and thrift lobbies, it was weakened in the House Banking Committee's financial institutions subcommittee. However, the bill does mandate hearings on revoking the charter and deposit insurance of a bank or S&L within 30 days after the institution and two or more of its senior officers are convicted of money-laundering. In the hearings, regulators would have to consider the extent of involvement in money-laundering by senior managers of the bank or S&L, the institution's cooperation with law enforcement officials and steps it had taken to prevent the practice. In addition, the bill would prohibit anyone convicted of money-laundering from working in a financial institution again and would raise from $500 to $5,000 the possible fines for civil violations. Similar legislation in the Senate is awaiting action by the Senate Banking Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Musician Graham Nash, who has been collecting photographs for nearly 20 years, had only 28 left after auctioning off 1,800 for hundreds of thousands of dollars. ``I've never really owned them. How can you own beauty?'' Nash said during the sale at Sotheby's on Wednesday. ``It was time to let go.'' There was one photograph Nash wouldn't give up: it shows Marilyn Monroe ``when she was 16 years old, unravaged by time and fame. ... It cost me $20. It's priceless to me,'' he said. But Nash already is starting to collect new prints _ he bought three during his visit to New York. ``I find it addictive,'' he said. Nash, of Crosby, Stills & Nash and other groups, started collecting in earnest in 1971, when he purchased ``Child With a Toy Hand Grenade in Central Park,'' by Diane Arbus. ``The moment is chilling; the madness of war seemed to crystallize in that photograph,'' Nash wrote in the auction catalog. That photo sold for $46,750. The auction included three photos by Paul Outerbridge that sold for a total of $264,000; a rare signed Ansel Adams print titled ``Moonrise, Hernandez, New Mexico,'' for $49,500; an Edward Steichen portrait of Gloria Swanson in a black veil, for $16,500, and ``Charlie Chaplin on the Set of Limelight,'' by W. Eugene Smith, for $6,050. Nash, who lives in Los Angeles, said he would donate some of the proceeds _ no total was immediately available _ to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Golfer Muffin Spencer-Devlin was disqualified from today's Ford Classic Golf tournament after storming out of a pre-tournament dinner over an argument about seating. Joe Flanagan, executive director of the Women's European Tour, said the golfer from San Francisco was barred from the $68,000 match for ``bringing the tour into disrespect.'' Spencer-Devlin, 36, refused a request that she sit with the rest of the U.S. players at Wednesday's dinner. After an argument with tournament director David Parkin, she walked out. ``She made an entrance and exit in the grand manner, dressed like a '20s cabaret star'' Flanagan said. Giving her account of the incident, Spencer-Devlin said: ``Parkin said, `You are to sit here'. I slammed my fist down on the table twice, said I am an American and I am not to be treated this way. Then I walked out.'' Spencer-Devlin, who has finished second and third in the British women's Open, earlier this season was fined $300 for throwing a container at her caddie.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Heavyweight champ James ``Buster'' Douglas, who dethroned Mike Tyson in a fight that rocked the boxing world in February, is going to be in the movies. Douglas and junior welterweight champion Julio Cesar Chavez have been signed to make their acting debuts in ION Pictures' ``The Honored Society.'' They will play boxers oppressed by unscrupulous promoters, ION Pictures said. Danny Aiello, an Oscar nominee for ``Do The Right Thing'' and himself a former boxer, will direct their boxing sequences and coach the fighters on their acting.

Author Jay McInerney and his wife have settled their divorce, averting a court date that promised a roster of celebrities as possible witnesses, an attorney says. McInerney, 35, whose book ``Bright Lights, Big City'' was made into a film, and Merry McInerney, a University of Michigan graduate student, declined to disclose terms of the agreement. Kenneth Prather, McInerney's lawyer, said the divorce became final Monday. Merry McInerney, 30, claimed in the divorce papers she had taken jobs to support the couple while McInerney was a budding writer and that she helped him write parts of his first book. The list of possible witnesses in the case had included Michael J. Fox, who starred in ``Bright Lights, Big City,'' and authors Norman Mailer, Bret Easton Ellis and Tama Janowitz. The McInerneys married in 1984.

Prince Charles, saying he's worried that something is missing from the lives of young Britons, is launching a Volunteers program to channel their energy into community projects. ``We need to recognize the youthful urge for adventure and aggression and find better ways to channel it, otherwise too much talent goes to waste,'' he said. He says 1,000 people ages 18 to 24 will start work in the fall on community projects around the country. By the end of the decade as many as 100,000 youths could be involved. Charles did not say what kind of work the youths will be doing. Singer Phil Collins donated $810,000 from his concert tour to the Prince's Trust for the program.

Game show host Bert Convy was admitted to Cedars Sinai Medical Center for observation after collapsing while visiting his mother at the hospital, a spokesman says. Convy was in the room of his mother, Monica, on Sunday, when he ``took a hard fall,'' hospital spokesman Ron Wise said Wednesday. ``We're not sure about the cause.'' His mother has been hospitalized for a stroke, Wise said. The 50-year-old host of ``Win, Lose or Draw'' was listed in fair condition.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Includes Everything From Noriega Court Costs to Fish Farming
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate convenes 9:30 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: A $3.4 billion spending bill in Congress includes everything from former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega's court costs to money for fish farming and a war on grasshoppers. Through the magic of amendments, President Bush's $870 million aid request for Nicaragua and Panama has multiplied along its route to the Senate, which begins debate on the measure today. The add-ons include such items as: _$185 million to build an automated fingerprint identification laboratory planned in Clarksburg, W.Va., the home state of Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. _$7.4 million to cover increased court expenses in Florida, Georgia and Alabama, which have handled not only Noriega's case but an influx of other extradited drug suspects. Noriega is awaiting trial in Miami. _$8 million for the Agriculture Department to combat grasshoppers in the state of committee member Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., as well as in South Dakota and Minnesota. _An order for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to begin building a fish farming experimental laboratory at Stuttgart, Ark. Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., is a member of the appropriations panel. Supplemental appropriations bills, regarded as ``must-pass'' measures because they are requested by the president, each year become vehicles for pet projects of lawmakers. The bill began as an $870 million request from Bush to pay for three items not envisioned in the 1990 budget: $300 million in aid for Nicaragua, $500 million for Panama and $70 million for refugee programs. When the House took it up, the measure grew to $2.4 billion with the addition of disaster relief for flooding in the Southeast (House Appropriations Chairman Jamie Whitten is a Mississippi Democrat); low-income energy assistance for the Northeast (senior committee Republican Silvio Conte is from Massachusetts); money for veterans' health care and pensions, food stamps and Forest Service firefighting. There was no controversy over the $300 million for newly democratic Nicaragua. But other congressional initiatives were causing headaches at the White House. A fight appeared certain, for example, over language added by Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., that would allow the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. Bush vetoed other bills twice last year that contained similar abortion language, and administration budget director Richard Darman said it was ``virtually certain'' the president would do the same thing again unless the provision is dropped or changed. After winning Senate approval, the bill still faces a House-Senate conference to work out differences between competing versions before it is sent to the White House. Among other congressional riders added to the bill were: _A directive that the Department of Veterans Affairs stick to the schedule for building an addition to its medical center in Huntington, W.Va., rather than delaying construction as the department has proposed. _$7.8 million to monitor volcanic eruptions at Mount Redoubt, near Anchorage, Alaska, the state of Sen. Ted Stevens, a Republican member of the Appropriations Committee. _The transfer of a 112-foot Coast Guard ship, the Agile, from Beaumont, Texas, to the government of American Samoa to provide transportation among the Samoan islands. _$238 million to build an Army explosives plant in Louisiana, the state of Democratic committee member J. Bennett Johnston. The House had sought to eliminate money for the plant. _A special reduced interest rate for Israel for $400 million in U.S. loan guarantees to build housing for Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union. The move, sponsored by Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Robert Kasten, R-Wis., could save Israel more than $25 million in loan-servicing costs over the 30-year life of the loan. In both its House and Senate versions, the bill was being largely financed through cuts or transfers from the Pentagon's 1990 budget. The Senate bill claimed $2.8 billion in defense savings, $1 billion more than the House.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Problems Plaguing Soviet Military
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic dissension and mass defections of junior officers threaten to undermine the Soviet military, private U.S. analysts say in a view that strengthens the CIA downgrading of any Soviet threat to the West. ``The Soviet military is not growing leaner and meaner and it's not on the road to growing leaner and meaner,'' Stephen Meyer of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told the House Armed Services Committee on Wednesday. Meyer and John Hines, of the RAND Corp., provided a grim picture of a Soviet military plagued by public criticism, limited support from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and even a significant number of troops unable to speak Russian. The testimony follows U.S. intelligence reports predicting continuing instability of the broader Soviet economy despite Gorbachev's efforts to institute reforms. Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, a Soviet legislator said that if his government fails to take immediate steps to fix the economy, the system will collapse and spawn widespread discontent. Vladimir Tikhonov, an agricultural economist who is also a member of his country's Congress of People's Deputies, told the Joint Economic Committee that the Soviet economy is ``extremely ill.'' Last week's joint CIA-Defense Intelligence Agency report said the Soviets cut military spending 4 percent to 5 percent last year, strengthening the position of those in Congress calling for bigger U.S. defense cuts in response to changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Members of Congress, including Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, point to the recent reports and CIA Director William Webster's testimony as a clear argument for further reductions in U.S. military spending. Aspin asked the analysts whether the Soviet military could launch an offensive outside its borders. ``They would respond, but it would take a great deal of time, it would be a relatively ineffective force and potentially one that I think any serious commander would not want to take into offensive operation,'' Hines replied. Problems for the military include the attitude of Gorbachev, who despite pleas from military officials approved student deferments from the armed forces. ``The Gorbachev regime has a deaf ear to the military,'' Meyer said. The military leadership is alienated from Soviet society, blamed for the war in Afghanistan and the widespread economic problems that plague the country, he said. In addition, people in the military get paid less than the industrial wage, work seven days a week and, according to recent Soviet statistics, 170,000 officers and their families are without housing. Complicating the military's problems is the division between senior and junior officers. Many of the latter have sided with civilian reformers and joined informal ethnic groups, Meyer said. About 40 percent of the Soviet military are non-Russians or non-Slavics and between 10 percent and 30 percent of them do not speak Russian, he said. In one instance, Hines said, a Soviet commander complained that in his unit attached to a land-based nuclear missile project, only two of the 40 Azerbaijanis spoke Russian. The Soviet Ministry of Defense has released figures showing 40 percent to 70 percent of disciplinary violence is tied to nationalism. ``The result is a mass exodus of junior officers from the military even under substantial economic loss to themselves,'' said Meyer, who noted military personnel have to sign documents claiming they are mentally deficient or criminals to gain their release. In addition, education standards have dropped for the military, as shown by a sharp increase in the number of accidents and deaths among troops using military equipment, Meyer said.

DOC.HEAD: House Speaker Supports Bush on Response to Soviet Blockade of Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he supports President Bush's decision not to impose sanctions against the Soviet Union for blockading Lithuania. ``It might be more difficult for Gorbachev to negotiate a peaceful solution (if sanctions were imposed) because that might be seen as yielding to United States pressure,'' Foley said. The Democrat made his remarks Wednesday in response to questions following an address to the 104th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Foley's speech to the publishers focused on the need to turn from emphasis on defense to the crucial issues of education, health care, the environment and the deficit. He faulted Bush for failing to use his immense public popularity to impress on Americans the need to meet these domestic challenges. ``The president is presently popular,'' he said. ``But the president needs to engage that popularity more and challenge the country and the Congress.'' He added, ``I understand the president's reluctance to address the problem of the deficit without a relaxation of his position on taxes.'' He drew laughter and some applause when he paraphrased George Bernard Shaw and said, ``There are two types of sins in American politics. Some are committed by politicians who don't keep their campaign promises. But some more mortal sins are committed by politicians who keep their campaign promises.'' He was referring to Bush's campaign promise not to impose new taxes. Foley pinpointed education as the nation's greatest crisis. ``Our effectiveness will not be calibrated on how many missiles we have and how many silos but how our primary classrooms are performing,'' he said. Foley said U.S. students in primary and high schools consistently perform ``12th to last'' in international scholastic competitions. ``Higher education is not where the problem is,'' he said. ``Primary and secondary education is.'' In response to a question, he said the imbalance of trade with Japan is partially ``a problem of our own making,'' and he blamed poor education for leading to poor productivity by American companies seeking to compete with Japan. He said that even if Japan agreed to a totally open market, ``we would still have a very substantial trade deficit with Japan.''

DOC.HEAD: Paul Taylor Choreographs ``Of Bright & Blue Birds & the Gala Sun''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: ``Of Bright & Blue Birds & the Gala Sun'' is a full-length dance that Paul Taylor choreographed for the Paul Taylor Dance Company's 35th season. Program notes say it's an allegory. It's stunningly choreographed and danced, even for a viewer who has to guess at the allegory part. The dance, performed for the first time on Wednesday at the City Center, is Taylor's third full-evening work. The music, most of it melodic, was composed by Donald York. It's often reminiscent of the first part of Copland's ``Appalachian Spring''; sometimes it sounds like a movie score behind a scene of spring sunshine. Elie Chaib stands at the top of two steps with reeds at each side, at the beginning. Dancers _ there are 18 _ in light green, khaki and tan _ enter and do an ebullient dance. The women wear split skirts over leotards of the same color. A curtain falls and dancing in front of it is charming, to lyrical music. When the whole stage is seen again, dancers in more modern dress seem to be in a disco, dancing to a jazzy beat. Then, for a long time, everybody dances as though demented. Arms and legs flail fast; jumps are done with a grand twitch. Women pursue men, kicking out. Act 1 ends on a calm note. In Act 2, people in front of a curtain are trying to get through to people seen behind it. This may be today's generation reaching back to the previous. In the next scene, dancers are in shiny leotards, which may indicate the future. Now, the steps where Chaib stands seem a throne where he observes his people dance. Later, as he dancers walk by twos between the reeds, we could be seeing the portal to adult life. Act 2 also ends serenely. Last week, Taylor premiered a funny ballet, ``The Sorcerer's Sofa,'' a takeoff on psychiatry. The couch, ``A Chaste Lounge,'' danced on her toes by Mary Cochran in quilted blue, holding a matching bolster pillow, has more sense than the pyschiatrist. A timid young client, Thomas Patrick, lies down on the couch and tells Christopher Gillis, in long gray beard, his problem. ``The Demon Within,'' Sandra Stone, in red with spikey red hair, appears in the room. Instead of the psychiatrist exorcising her, her ``Duplication,'' Francie Huber, appears. Then seven dancers called ``A Lot More Duplications'' arrive. The couch bops the psychiatrist, lies down on the patient and is ready to take over. The demons do a kick line, but their days are numbered. The company will be at the City Center through May 13.

DOC.HEAD: Census Counters Head Into the Streets
DOC.TEXT: The census tries to overcome a deluge of criticism today, returning to its roots to count Americans door to door. Workers will hit the streets in more than 100 cities, seeking to find and count the more than one in three households that hasn't been heard from yet. The count got under way in March with the mailing of more than 95 million questionnaires. But mistakes in addressing meant that millions of people failed to get forms, and millions more haven't mailed theirs back. The problems, including large apartment buildings and whole blocks and small towns seemingly overlooked, have drawn heavy criticism for the Census Bureau. Now things are moving into the next stage, as census workers, known as enumerators, begin marching door to door. In the last few decades the system of mailing out census questionnaires and asking people to send them back has become common practice. It replaced the traditional, but labor-intensive process of having someone visit every home. Now, the door-to-door count is reserved only for sparsely populated areas and for follow-up on people who don't answer by mail. Original plans had anticipated that about 70 percent of households would mail back their forms. So far, only 63 percent have responded and the low return rate means more hiring and more costs. Originally expected to cost $1.3 billion this year, the price of counting Americans could well increase by $150 million or more, according to congressional sources. In addition to problems in the mail portion of the count, a coalition of cities and interest groups has filed suit against the Census Bureau, contending that minorities are being undercounted and seeking to force a statistical adjustment of the final figures. The work getting under way today covers more than 100 metropolitan areas nationwide, trying to track down people who either didn't get a census form or failed to mail theirs back. Individual counting expands to an additional 300 smaller communities on May 3, Census officials report. In rural areas that were not included in the mail portion of the count, personal visits by census takers have been going on since March. The official workers can be identified by their red, white and blue identification badges and satchels, the Census Bureau reported. Although the house-to-house count is now starting, government officials continue to encourage Americans to mail back forms if they have not done so. Counting Americans on their doorsteps will continue at least through June, and longer if needed, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Arrivaderci Parcells, Hello Verdi; Aida Will Be in Giants Stadium
DOC.TEXT: Stone-faced Dallas Cowboys Coach Tom Landry was the closest thing to the Sphinx ever seen in Giants Stadium _ until now. A 55-foot replica of the Egyptian wonder is coming to New Jersey in June for a spectacular $7 million production of the opera ``Aida.'' While most operas aren't over 'til the fat lady sings, this one won't be done until 1,200 cast members, a 100-piece orchestra, a menagerie of exotic animals and the eight-ton Sphinx are paraded through Giants Stadium for two nights. Promoters are hoping for 39,000 people each night for the June 1-2 shows, not including Jimmy Hoffa, the ex-Teamsters boss allegedly buried in one end zone. The promoters are also aware that a stadium off the New Jersey Turnpike, deep in the heart of Bruce Springsteen country, is not the usual spot for a musical work that premiered 119 years ago in Cairo. So they're going for the hard sell, sending costumed Egyptian wannabes to shopping malls in an effort to plug the show. Ads in the local media proclaim ``THINK SPHINX,'' while ad copy trumpets ``The Opera Spectacular.'' Twenty New Jersey malls were targeted for the blitz, with folks dressed as Aida, Radames, Egyptian soldiers and high priests spreading out from a midtown Manhattan motel and heading into the Garden State. Giants Stadium is the latest stop for the opera, which is billed as the biggest production of any opera, ever. ``Aida'' has played in Montreal, Sydney, Melbourne, Vancouver, Tokyo and Toronto in the past two years. In Japan, 102,000 people attended. But ``Aida'' is more than an opera, said Tony Attanasio, who has been training the mall roamers. Verdi wrote his grand opera with jugglers, animals and dancers, designed for grand-scale popular entertainment, the publicist said. Maestro Giuseppe Raffa, who is directing the production, said ``opera is for the people'' rather than the privileged few. Attanasio said auditions for the opera's 500 extras bear the maestro out. ``In Australia, we had the president of the government, the president of the largest company, two Olympic medal winners. Everybody tried out. Nobody has special privilege,'' Attanasio said. ``Everybody has in the back of his head the dream of being in show business once in his life.'' Casting for many of the Giants Stadium extras has already been held at Sleepy Hollow High School in Tarrytown, N.Y. Everyone chosen gets two $35 seats _ tickets also are sold at $50 and $75 _ a sweatshirt and an invite to the cast party. A May 5 audition for 200 soldiers will be held in Central Park. Raffa, 38, got the idea for the traveling spectacular after watching Italian film director Mauro Bolognini direct ``Aida'' in Giza, Egypt, with the real Sphinx and Pyramids in the background. The 1987 show inspired him to put together the financing and hire Bolognini, the set producer and the costume designer. The traveling ``Aida'' had to build sand dunes, Pyramids, the Nile and a Sphinx. They went the real thing one better, putting motors and drivers inside the 55-foot, eight-ton replica Sphinx and letting it split and show its profile on each side of the stage during the Triumphal Entry scene. After Giants Stadium, ``Aida'' will play the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum June 29 and 30, San Francisco in mid-July and possibly Washington, D.C., in September. Grace Bumbry of the United States will sing Aida, Bruno Sebastian of Italy will sing Radames and Ruza Baldani of Yugoslavia will sing Amneris. A giant screen on each side of the stage will show closeups and the words in English. A $1 million amplification system has been built in Holland. But the ``Aida'' production will not bring the only Sphinx to Giants Stadium this summer. The rock band Kiss is coming to town in the summer, and their stage show will feature a towering version of the Egyptian monument too _ one with an attitude, promised Kiss vocalist Paul Stanley. ``Ours is going to talk, and it hates opera,'' Stanley said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Committee Hails Tilt-Rotor Aircraft in Landing at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: An experimental aircraft the Pentagon wants to abandon is being touted as the passenger plane of the future. ``Welcome to the dawn of a new age in aviation,'' said House aviation subcommittee chairman Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., after he arranged for a XV-15 tilt-rotor aircraft to swoop down and land alongside the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, sending spectators scurrying up the steps. The Defense Department has spent $2 billion to develop the XV-15 and its successor, the V-22 Osprey, for military use. But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney wants to end funding in favor of conventional helicopter development. The XV-15 and the Osprey land like helicopters but fly at up to 340 mph as fixed-wing airplanes _ much faster than a helicopter. Large rotors on the ends of the wings tilt up for vertical flight and rotate forward for the long haul. Two XV-15s were made. Pentagon contracts call for six Ospreys, two of which have been delivered by a partnership between Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. and Boeing Helicopter. Oberstar told his Public Works subcommittee it took everything but a papal decree to allow the 12-year-old plane landing rights at the Capitol. Looking like a giant insect out of a science fiction movie, the XV-15 went through a series of maneuvers a few yards from the Capitol. ``This is the most significant contribution to civilian aviation since the dawn of the jet age,'' Oberstar told reporters on the Capitol lawn. Both Democratic and Republican subcommittee members blasted the fact that the Pentagon wants to stop funding the Osprey. The Marines sought the tilt-rotor for use as an assault transport to carry 24 troops or weapons and supplies from ship to beachhead in amphibious landings. But the Defense Department argues that helicopters already are doing the job and money for the Osprey can be better used elsewhere in an era of budget cuts. Committee members showed nearly unanimous support for development of the Osprey as a passenger plane to serve space-starved cities and rural communities without conventional airports. They also praised its potential for use in rescues, drug interdiction and oil spill cleanup. Of 14 committee members at the hearing, only Rep. John J. Duncan, R-Tenn., raised a negative note, asking why, if the plane has such great potential, isn't private industry funding its development. Supporters said it often is necessary for expensive new aircraft to begin as military hardware. Rep. Peter DeFazio, a liberal Democrat from Oregon, brought applause at the hearing when he said, ``I can count on less than one hand the new military weapons systems I will support, but this is one of them.'' Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., carrying a boxed plastic model of the plane, said the Japanese and Europeans will build a similar aircraft and sell it to U.S. airlines if the United States doesn't move ahead with the technology. He noted that his plastic version was made in Korea and said, ``Let the Koreans and the Japanese build the model. We'll build the real thing.'' Joseph Del Balzo, FAA systems development chief, said the Japanese are working on a tilt-wing aircraft, possibly to be built in Texas, but likely would be interested in taking up the tilt-rotor technology if the United States abandons it. A group of European countries also is working on a project to build a similar plane, he said, and Soviet aviation officials have shown some interest.

DOC.HEAD: President Won't Need Eye Drops After All, Doctors Decide
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush can discontinue twice-daily treatment with eye drops even though he has a mild form of glaucoma, the White House says after getting a second opinion on the president's eyes. Dr. Burton Lee, the White House physician, made the announcement after Bush was examined by two glaucoma specialists during an hour-long visit to Bethesda Naval Medical Center on Wednesday. Lee said the examination confirmed the finding, made by other doctors during Bush's annual checkup at the hospital April 12, that the president has ``one type of early glaucoma.'' ``Extensive testing of the eye including detailed photographs once again revealed no abnormalities and no visual loss,'' the White House doctor said. ``It was decided to stop the Betagan eye drops and follow him closely for now, on no treatment.'' After the physical exam, Bush began using the medicine every 12 hours. His doctors said he would need to take it for the rest of his life. The examination Wednesday was conducted by Dr. Richard Brubaker of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and Dr. Harry Quigley of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. ``It was the experts' opinion that the medication was not warranted,'' said Stephen Hart, a deputy White House press secretary. He said Bush had suffered no side effects from the medication. Hart said the decision to take the president off the medication was ``just simply a difference of opinion'' with the other doctors. ``There is no progression or regression'' in the glaucoma, he said. ``There is no change in his eyes.'' Bush wore dark glasses as he emerged from the hospital, and flashed a thumbs-up sign to reporters as he was driven past them in his limousine. Lee's statement said, ``The physical findings were reviewed by the consultants and the diagnosis of exfoliation syndrome was confirmed with slightly increased intra-ocular pressure noted again in the left eye, one type of early glaucoma.'' The April 12 examination was conducted by Lee, assisted by several staff doctors at Bethesda, including Capt. Ralph Sawyer, an ophthalmologist.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Senator Raps Administration Stand on Support Bill
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., says he resents Bush administration criticism of his call for a multi-year commodities support program in the 1990 farm bill. ``We have followed the administration's guidelines to develop a specific piece of legislation,'' Kerrey said Wednesday. Despite his junior status, Kerrey has taken the lead in the Senate Agriculture Committee on the commodities section of the farm bill, but finds himself at odds with another Nebraskan, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. President Bush on Tuesday dismissed Kerrey's contention that a farm crisis could occur if the government doesn't provide $12 billion annually for five years to support program crops _ wheat, corn, rice, soybeans and cotton. Yeutter, who appeared with Bush at a convention of farm journalists, said Congress should realize that besides subsidies, ``there's a market out there'' that can support farmers. ``I really resent the agriculture secretary's continued statements to the public that we don't understand the market's out there,'' said Kerrey. ``I'm alarmed at the rhetoric that's coming back from the administration.'' The administration has said that no more than $10.2 billion should be spent on the commodities programs in fiscal 1991 and the government should wait for the outcome of international trade talks before determining levels for the next four years of the farm bill. But Kerrey said a well-financed farm program will save the government money in the long run. ``I fully confess that part of my concern is based on having gone through this while I was governor,'' said Kerrey, who served as Nebraska's chief executive from 1982-86. ``I remember very vividly what can happen when the government says we are going to put together a farm bill based on budget only,'' he said in reference to cuts devised by David Stockman, who was President Reagan's budget director in the first years of that administration. ``It ended up being most expensive and destructive,'' Kerrey said. ``If you only keep the budget number down and don't understand that the program has a purpose,'' there is trouble. ``We understand there is limitation on what we can spend,'' he said. ``We have attempted to do that.'' The Senate committee has not acted on Kerrey's bill, although six of the 19 members are co-sponsors. In the House, a new spending package announced last week by Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., would hold spending on commodity programs to $9.8 billion in the next fiscal year. The House Agriculture subcommittee working on the commodities section of the farm bill has been trying for weeks to come up with a plan that satisfies budget writers.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Foreign Sugar Quota Should Help Cut US Prices
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's decision to let Nicaragua sell its sugar to the United States will aid that country's economy, but _ more importantly to food makers _ it also will help cut sugar prices here. ``The United States badly needed the sugar,'' Ken Arnold of the Sweetener Users Association said Wednesday after the administration announced it would buy more sugar from 40 countries, including Nicaragua for the first time since 1985. U.S. manufacturers of sweets have been pressuring the Bush administration to open the doors to more foreign sugar because a domestic shortage was causing prices to rise. ``The Sweetener Users Association is pleased that USDA raised the quota level by the amount we had requested,'' said Thomas Hammer, president of the association. The announcement from the Agriculture Department coincided with Vice President Dan Quayle's visit to Nicaragua for the transfer of power from the Sandinistas to the new president, Violeta Chamorro. Luther Markwart, chairman of the American Sugar Alliance, said the only way the administration could give Nicaragua back its quota was to increase the total amount allowed into the United States from other countries. ``There was no way they could take quotas away from other countries,'' he said. ``The administration does use the sugar program as foreign policy.'' Markwart, who represents American sugar cane and sugar beet producers, said consumers may see sugar prices at the supermarket drop a penny or two as a result of the quota increases. The only countries on USDA's list that were not told they could increase sales in the United States were El Salvador, Costa Rica and Honduras, which were given most of Nicaragua's quota in 1983 when the Reagan administration began cutting back on trade with Managua. The action Wednesday allows Nicaragua to export 54,328 metric tons of sugar to the United States, making it the tenth-largest foreign supplier. The highest quotas go to the Dominican Republic at 460,997 tons; the Philippines at 413,850; Brazil, 379,798; and Australia, 217,401. About 17 percent of the sugar used in the United States comes from other countries. This is the fourth time in the past eight months that USDA has increased the sugar import quota level in response to market conditions. Previous increases were made on Sept. 12, Nov. 24 and Jan. 16. Arnold said the government uses the foreign quotas as a ``spigot'' that it turns on and off to stabilize sugar prices. If there is a shortage in domestic production, the government increases the flow of foreign sugar to keep prices from getting too high. If there is an oversupply, the government can limit quotas. ``What we pay attention to specifically are the raw prices of sugar,'' said Arnold. ``Market stabilization price is the price the government wants the price of sugar to be at. ``The price of sugar has been running a couple cents above the market stabilization price. That's the first thing that sets sweetener users off that something is wrong here. ``Then the other thing we look at is wholesale refined prices. Those prices had been rising rather dramatically over the last couple of months.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim's Mother Lobbies for Spending Bill
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after a crowd of 1,500 attended AIDS victim Ryan White's funeral in Indianapolis, his mother was fighting for his memory just as she had fought for his right to be treated like any other child. ``I think it's made a big impact, me being here,'' Jeanne White, 42, said Wednesday after a round of meetings with senators to drum up more sponsors for an emergency bill providing $600 million to fight AIDS. ``I think it's different to have something on a piece of paper than to meet the people in real life and to see the tragedy and everything this disease has,'' she said in an interview. Mrs. White was continuing her round of quickly scheduled meetings today. The fresh memory of her son's lingering illness made it possible for her to gain appointments that others must wait for weeks to obtain. Keeping busy has helped ease the grief for Mrs. White, whose son's death called attention to the indiscriminate way in which AIDS strikes. Ryan was a hemophiliac who contracted the fatal disease through contaminated blood products when he was 13. He was 18 when he died April 8. The disease is spread through sexual intercourse, blood transfusions, and cuts or punctures with infected objects, including hypodermic needles and scalpels. Infected women can pass the disease along to their unborn children. The disease has struck mostly homosexual men and intravenous drug users, but Mrs. White said any family is vulnerable to the tragedy. ``It can be your brother, your sister, your mother, your father,'' she said. ``It could be a loved one, a friend. It's eventually going to hit everybody.'' ``I think AIDS is here to stay,'' she said. ``I think that, because we would all have to quit having sex completely. I think that's the main issue. The bill Mrs. White is lobbying for was passed 16-0 on April 4 by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. Ryan was in the hospital in critical condition at the time, and the senators dedicated the bill to him. The bill, co-sponsored by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, would provide $600 million a year for the next two years in emergency assistance. Ryan had hoped a cure could be found in his lifetime, and was ``just very disappointed'' that so few resources were devoted to fighting the disease, Mrs. White said. Although refraining from direct criticism of the Reagan and Bush administrations, she said: ``Ryan met Ronald and Nancy Reagan a week before he died, and I felt like Ryan made a very emotional impact on them. And I think had they maybe met him four years ago or three years ago, I think they would have related more to the issue of AIDS. It seems there wasn't anybody who met Ryan who didn't love him.'' Among those are the celebrities such as pop singers Elton John and Michael Jackson, who had befriended Ryan years before attending his funeral. She said television star Phil Donahue and his wife, actress Marlo Thomas, invited Mrs. White to their house after the funeral for a few days' respite. ``None of them was just a one-time deal,'' she said. ``Nobody did it just for attention or publicity.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl's Leading Contender Stabbed In Neck, In Serious Condition
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor was in serious condition today after a woman stabbed him in the neck during a campaign rally with a knife hidden in a bouquet of flowers, officials said. It was unclear whether 46-year-old Oskar Lafontaine, the popular governor of Saarland state and Chancellor Helmut Kohl's leading challenger, will be able to lead his left-of-center party in the campaign for Dec. 2 national elections. Interior Ministry officials said the stabbing severed a neck artery and doctores at the hospital where Lafontaine was being treated said he lost large amounts of blood. Lafontaine was attacked near the close of the Cologne rally at about 9 p.m Wednesday by a black-haired woman in a white dress who approached him on the dais seeking his autograph, witnesses and officials said. The woman stabbed the politician as he was about to sign a poetry album she presented him, police said. The ZDF television network said the knife had been concealed in the flowers. Cologne police identified the woman as Adelheid Streidel, 42, from the town of Bad Neuenahr, southwest of Bonn. The motive for the attack was not immediately known. Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the Federal Prosecutor's Office said there was no evidence the woman had a ``terrorist background.'' Today's editions of the Cologne-based tabloid, Express, said the woman was a doctor's assistant who suffered from mental disorders. The newspaper quoted neighbors as saying she was a divorcee who had asked for weapons several times to defend herself against men she believed were following her. The ARD television network showed the Social Democrat politician lying on the floor as blood poured from his neck, with several people crowded around him trying to administer first aid. The stabbing suspect was shown sitting impassively as a throng of police men screamed at her ``Who are you? Who are you? Tell us your name! Say it!'' The woman said nothing and was then hustled by police out of the Stadthalle auditorium in suburban Muelheim where about 2,000 people had gathered for the rally. Lafontaine was rushed by helicopter to the University Clinic in the Cologne suburb of Lindenthal, where he was listed in serious condition early today. The politician is an unrelenting critic of Kohl and has strongly opposed quick reunification of the two Germanys, advocating a more gradual approach. In Paris for a West German-French summit, Kohl said the attack has ``deeply shaken me. At this hour one can only hope that Oskar Lafontaine survives.'' The statement was released by Kohl's office in Bonn. Lafontaine is known for making bold and brash political statments and delighted in his role as a political gadfly. He is divorced and his active social life has received prominence in West Germany's tabloid press. The candidate's most recent liaison is with a Frankfurt hotelier's daughter whose dyed blond punk-style haircut delighted news photographers. The outspoken politician, whose party trounced Kohl's Christian Democratic Union in state elections in January, has been considered a tough opponent for the December national elections. Lafontaine, a party activist at age 21, became mayor 11 years later of Saarbruecken, capital of tiny Saarland state, which borders France. In 1987, he became deputy chairman of the Social Democrats despite opposition from the party's conservative wing, headed by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt. He strongly opposed plans under Schmidt's government in the late 1970s to station U.S. medium-range nuclear weapons in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Secrecy Accords on Hazardous Products Blasted, Defended
DOC.TEXT: Consumer advocates, attorneys and journalists say court agreements that allow companies to keep information about potential hazards involving their products secret are endangering lives and public safety. However, corporate lawyers argue that such arrangements are a legitimate part of the civil justice system, offer an alternative to lengthy court battles and help protect trade secrets of U.S. businesses and American competitiveness. ``Secrecy buries critical facts ... and the public good is ignored and damaged,'' Russ Herman, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said Wednesday at a conference on secrecy sponsored by his group. Information discovered during product liability litigation ``ought to be made available to the public so the danger isn't repeated over and over again,'' he added. In many instances that includes ``documents and decisions involving unsafe products, dangerous drugs, toxic wastes _ all with potentially devastating effect on people unaware of the danger,'' said Paul McMasters, deputy editorial director of USA Today. McMaster heads the freedom of information committee of the Society of Professional Journalists, cosponsor of the conference. Protective orders, confidentiality agreements or court sealing of files in product liability cases prohibit lawsuit participants from distributing any of the information obtained, limit what can be share with others not involved in the lawsuit or make all records in a case unavailable. One corporate defense attorney said that opening court records could violate privacy by revealing sensitive information about businesses or individuals. ``If you can summons my medical records from my doctor, my diary from my psychiatrist or records of design from a company ... privacy goes out the window,'' said James Morris III, a Virginia lawyer. Opponents to secrecy should not be allowed to use the court system to disseminate information that might not otherwise be available, Morris said. U.S. businesses are at a competitive disadvantage because international agreements don't force foreign companies to release the same extensive information, he added. ``Foreign corporations are subject to the same rules as American corporations in this country,'' countered Eugene I. Pavalon, a Chicago trial lawyer. ``For children, keeping secrets is a game ... but for public health and safety secrets can be nasty,'' said Devra Davis, a toxicologist at the National Academy of Sciences. ``The practice of secrecy in the courts can result in a failure to tell the public about proven hazards _ endangering lives, perverting science and ultimately undermining democracy itself,'' she said. Davis said that in January 1983, she suffered a nearly fatal allergic reaction to the prescription painkiller Zomax, which was eventually withdrawn from the market by its manufacturer. Later, she said, she discovered the manufacturer, doctors and other patients had known of the possible severe reaction but the information was not available because of secrecy agreements obtained in product liability case settlements by McNeil Pharmaceutical, the drug manufacturer. Davis said had she known about the possible reaction she would not have taken the drug. The opponents said they didn't oppose secrecy in all instances. Most said companies' trade secrets should be protected and in personal cases, such as divorce and some criminal cases, some information should not be available to the general public.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet, Contra Rebellion Plague New Government
With PM-Nicargua-Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The inauguration of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was hardly a solemn and decorous affair of state. The new president made her entrance in a hail of water balloons and her predecessor was pelted with watermelon rinds. Mrs. Chamorro tried to get off to a running start in her inaugural speech Wednesday, but her government ran into trouble even before she donned the presidential sash in the first democratic transfer of power in Nicaraguan history. She declared a general amnesty and proclaimed an end to the despised military draft, the dawn of peace and the rebirth of a free market economy. But she also said Gen. Humberto Ortega, one of the architects of the leftist Sandinista state that her supporters thought they had ousted in the Feb. 25 election, would remain in command of the armed forces. Key groups within her conservative United National Opposition rebelled, including two people who had agreed to serve in the Cabinet. The nation also braced for the unraveling of an accord on disbanding the Contra rebels by June 10. About 500 rebels in northern Nicaragua simply laughed when the top Contra commander, Israel Galeano, asked if they were ready to hand over their weapons to waiting U.N. peacekeeping troops. ``Nobody gives up his gun,'' they said. And as UNO supporters publicly celebrated victory for the first time since the election, the cry was as loud and clear as the crackle of the fireworks overhead and as insistent as the tropical music to which they danced in the capital's main plaza: ``Humberto Should Go!'' Mrs. Chamorro had tried to soften the blow by saying she'd serve as defense minister, the post Ortega held until the change of government. She said she chose her Cabinet with national reconciliation in mind. But neither Gilberto Cuadra or Jaime Cuadra, who had been chosen for Cabinet posts, could reconcile themselves to serving in a government that included Ortega. ``I wouldn't like to think that she feels that in her moment of greatest need, I'm not there; but I had warned her,'' Jaime Cuadra told The Associated Press. He is a coffee farmer and rancher who was to have been agriculture minister. Gilberto Cuadra, president of the nation's most important business group and a leader of the private sector that is the foundation of Mrs. Chamorro's support, was to have been minister of construction and transport. The two Cuadras, who are not related, refused the posts on the eve of the inauguration after being informed Mrs. Chamorro was keeping Ortega, a move the UNO political council opposed and something she publicly said she would not do. Until a few days ago, Ortega, the brother of former President Daniel Ortega, was one of the nine members of the Sandinista national directorate. He was the revolution's chief military strategist, oversaw the military buildup that created Central America's largest armed force and led the Sandinista army through nine years of war against the U.S.-backed Contras. Control of the armed forces is regarded as critical to Mrs. Chamorro's ability to govern, and retaining Ortega puts that control in doubt. She insisted in her inaugural speech that she _ not Ortega _ would call the shots. He was under orders, she said, to cut the budget-draining military and retrieve weapons from the thousands of civilians the Sandinistas have armed. ``We have to melt down our arms and sell the metal to buy machinery for agriculture and industry,'' she said. Both the army and the police were party organs under the Sandinistas and their loyalty is a question mark despite an accord saying they would be depoliticized. Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez has loaned Mrs. Chamorro a commando team to handle her security rather than leave it in local hands. The Sandinistas did not relinquish power gracefully. Sandinista rowdies pelted the 60-year-old widow and her escorts with water-filled plastic bags as she entered the national baseball stadium for the inaugural ceremony. When outgong President Ortega entered the stadium on foot, UNO partisans pelted him with watermelon rinds and blue-and-white UNO flags, and police quickly charged into the stands. Thousands of Sandinistas in the stands at the stadium formed a gauntlet that presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers and ambassadors had to run. Representatives of nations deemed friends of the Sandinistas, such as Cuba and the Soviet Union, were greeted with cheers and waves of red-and-black Sandinista party flags. Envoys of nations unpopular with the Sandinistas entered to catcalls, boos and insults. ``Killer, killer, killer, killer,'' the crowd chanted when El Salvador's rightist president, Alfredo Cristiani, went by. Vice President Dan Quayle got the same greeting as well as shouts of ``Son of a bitch, go home'' and ``Here, there, the Yankees will die.'' Quayle was supportive of Mrs. Chamorro's controversial decision to retain Ortega. ``It shows she is trying to reconcile the differences in her country,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,424.58, down 139.78 points, or 0.47 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Power Station Explosion Blacks Out Toronto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with power restored, EDITS to CONFORM, tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A power station exploded Wednesday night, blacking out downtown Toronto and surrounding areas, causing traffic chaos and sending thousands of people into the streets. It took two to three hours to restore power in many areas, and some looting was reported. The blackout forced management at the Eaton Centre to close down and evacuate the huge shopping mall, but police said shops had been broken into. ``Groups of people have grabbed clothing out of stores,'' said police Staff Sgt. Lou Villani. He said off-duty officers were asked to report in to help patrol the downtown area. One radio report said 90,000 homes and 10,000 businesses were affected by the power outage, which Ontario Hydro said began at about 8:10 p.m. EDT and lasted about two hours in much of downtown. In some sections of the city center, power continued to be out past 11 p.m. EDT. Subway trains ran slowly, the platforms lighted with emergency lights. Ontario Hydro spokesman Bill Friday said the power outage began after an explosion and fire at a transformer station. He said the station was shut down and evacuated. The spokesman blamed the explosion on equipment failure. Stores and restaurants downtown were plunged into darkness, and the streets filled up with rubberneckers. Traffic lights were knocked out. Pedestrians picked their way across congested streets. The emergency department at St. Michael's hospital was blacked out for more than 1{ hours, but patients and ambulances were redirected to other hospitals not affected and no one was in danger, spokeswoman Leanna Wilson said. She said the rest of hospital had power from an emergency backup system. Television stations were knocked off the air, but programming flickered back on and off. Police said most elevators had enough emergency power to get people to the ground. But a police spokesman reported: ``All traffic control signals are out. We've put every available officer to try and control traffic and other problems that go with blackouts.'' A clerk at a store in the Eaton Centre, Cary Legree, said security people quickly cleared out the mall after the blackout began, adding: ``Some idiot went running through the store saying: `It's a bomb' but otherwise it was cool. Thank God it was not busy.''

DOC.HEAD: Womens' View of Men: Not a Pretty Sight
DOC.TEXT: American women see most men as lecherous, egotistical slobs. And they don't like mother-in-law jokes, either, a survey says. The national poll, released Wednesday, found increasing numbers of women expressing annoyance at sexism and describing men as manipulative, oversexed and mean. It compared responses to identical questions asked 20 years ago. In 1970, for example, two-thirds of the women surveyed agreed that ``most men are basically kind, gentle and thoughtful.'' In the new poll, only half of the women interviewed agreed with that statement. Prurience also took a pounding. Fifty-four percent of the women agreed that ``most men look at a woman and immediately think how it would be to go to bed with her.'' That was up from 41 percent who agreed in 1970. Majorities in the new poll, conducted by the Roper Organization, also rated men negatively on their egos and domesticity. Sizable minorities went further: Forty-two percent called men ``basically selfish and self-centered.'' The reason? ``Women's growing dissatisfaction with men is undoubtedly derived from their own rising expectations,'' the pollsters reported. ```The more independent women of today expect more from men.'' The poll, financed by Philip Morris USA in the name of its Virginia Slims cigarettes, was conducted July 22 through Aug. 12 by personal interviews with a random sample of 3,000 women. The margin of error was 2 points. Respondents expressed greater awareness of discrimination against women than they did 20 years ago. But they also said overwhelmingly that women have made progress in job opportunities, fair pay and political leadership. Six in 10 of the women who work full time said juggling jobs and families puts them under ``a lot of stress,'' and nearly as many said they felt guilty about time they spend at work and away from their families. ``Their frustration comes out of trying to be superwomen,'' said Ellen Merlo, a Philip Morris vice president. ``Women are handling so many aspects of life _ trying to achieve success in careers, wanting to be a wife and a mother, run a home, and do it all well. It's a lot for anyone to handle.'' Indeed, the second-greatest cause of resentment in respondents' lives was their mates' failure to help with household duties, cited by 52 percent. Only money was a greater cause of woe. ``As women contribute more to family income, they expect a more equitable division of the household responsibilities in return,'' the poll report said. ``Women indicate that men are failing to live up to this ideal, and that their failure is a major source of irritation.'' Diapers and dishes are by no means the sole problem: Many women expressed negative views of male attitudes as well as behavior. Among the findings: _Fifty-eight percent of the women agreed that ``most men think only their own opinions about the world are important,'' up from 50 percent in 1970. _Given the statement, ``Most men find it necessary for their egos to keep women down,'' 55 percent agreed, up from 49 percent 20 years ago. _Fifty-three percent agreed that ``most men are interested in their work and life outside the home and don't pay much attention to things going on at home.'' That was up from 39 percent in 1970. The poll found similar increases in sensitivity to sexism. Fifty-three percent said they were annoyed by ``jokes about women drivers, mothers-in-law or dumb blondes,'' up from 32 percent in 1970. Sixty-one percent were annoyed by pictures of nude women in men's magazines, up from 43 percent. Eighty percent resented a woman being looked upon ``as sex symbol instead of as having sense in her head,'' up from 66 percent in 1970. And 53 percent were annoyed by men referring to them as a ``girl'' rather than a ``woman,'' up from 31 percent. The poll results indicated that men must have some redeeming factors, however. Asked their idea of the best kind of life, more than nine in 10 of the women named marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Cowboy, Newcomer Crooner Steal Country Spotlight
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Gentleman cowboy George Strait brought the night's big prize home at the Academy of Country Music Awards, but fellow Texan Clint Black, an ironworker with a hot first record, came away with the most trophies. The only other multiple winner during Wednesday's 25th anniversary awards show on NBC was Kathy Mattea, voted top female vocalist and song of the year winner for ``Where've You Been.'' But the night belonged to Black. ``It feels very emotional. It feels great. It's wonderful. It's just a big thrill. It's hard to describe,'' said Black, whose first single, ``A Better Man,'' earned him single record of the year honors. Black also took home top male vocalist, top new male vocalist and album of the year trophies. Strait, who has been named top male vocalist three times and earned best album honors once, was his unemotional, straight-faced self after accepting entertainer of the year honors. ``I thought I had as good a shot as anybody to win. I got out there and worked as hard as anybody else. To be chosen entertainer of the year is very special,'' he said. The 4-year-old Nashville band Restless Heart won best group, while Mary Chapin Carpenter was voted new female vocalist. The Judds _ Naomi Judd and daughter Wynona _ won a sixth consecutive vocal duet trophy. Top new group honors went to Kentucky Headhunters, a wild band of longhairs complete with leather and suspenders. Asked if anyone had discussed the group's image, Headhunter Richard Young said, ``Nobody ever asked us to change anything. We just be ourselves. What you see is what you have. We are on a campaign for ugly people ... but we're very nice.'' Three-time entertainer of the year Hank Williams Jr. was the sentimental favorite going into the awards show because of nominations he shared with his legendary father for ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' a duet the younger Williams made by singing along to an old recording by his father, who died in 1953. Williams went home with one trophy _ video of the year for the song _ despite nominations in five categories. But Williams heaped on the emotion during his acceptance speech by reading a letter to his father. ``Dear Daddy, we finally got to sing together and you left me such a big hit. `There's a Tear in My Beer'' was one of the biggest selling records around here in several years. `Hey Good Lookin.' `I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry.' `Your Cheating Heart.' And now after all this time you're still up there on the charts. And there's another place you'll always be and that's right here in all our hearts. From all your fans and me.'' The big surprise was Black, 28, who has performed in Houston nightclubs with his brother since he was 15. ``A Better Man,'' describing the end of an affair that left him a better man, was his first single, debuting last spring. ``It's very special to me because it's a tribute to someone very special to me _ a girlfriend of many years,'' Black said backstage. The winning song ``Where've You Been'' was also a deeply personal work, especially for Jon Vezner, Miss Mattea's husband. The song, co-written by Vezner and Don Henry, is about a wife who questions her husband's whereabouts as a young bride and then as a dying hospital patient. ``It was basically a true story about my grandparents,'' said Vezner. ``We try to write songs that come from our hearts.'' The academy's 2,500 members voted for the winners except for the video award, which is decided by a vote of the academy's Board of Directors.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Complains About New York Reactor
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group says the Energy Department is planning to install a prototype of a more powerful submarine reactor at an upstate New York laboratory. The Natural Resources Defense Council disclosed the plans, which it said it learned about through declassified records of congressional hearings, and complained Wednesday that the government is going ahead without studying the impact on the environment. The council said a prototype of the ``Advanced Fleet Reactor'' would be installed at the Kesselring site of the department's Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory near Albany and Schenectady, N.Y. The department has argued a new environmental impact statement is not required because one was performed for the site in 1972 for the reactor used to power the Trident submarines, said NRDC, which was joined in its statement by a local group, the Knolls Action Project. Three department spokesman said Wednesday night they were not familiar enough with the issue to comment. The New York Times reported in Thursday editions that the department said the core of the new reactor will be tested, not the whole reactor. The core contains the enriched uranium fuel, support elements and control rods that govern the nuclear reaction by absorbing neutrons. It will be inserted in an existing reactor during the next two years, according to the department's statement. ``No commercial utility could get away with building a new reactor in the 1990s based on an almost 20-year-old EIS on a different reactor,'' said Dan W. Reicher, a staff attorney for NRDC. The Advanced Fleet Reactor has been under development for several years. It is designed to power the Seawolf class of attack submarines when they are built in the mid-1990s. In budget documents submitted to Congress earlier this year, the department said the new reactor would ``encompass long-term developments now coming to fruition and will deliver more power, more quietly, than any previous submarine reactor _ and will do so without a commensurate increase in size or weight.'' The department quoted declassified testimony from 1988 as saying the Advanced Fleet Reactor is of the pressurized water design used by all other naval reactors and most of the nation's civilian power reactors. NRDC said the reactor most likely would be installed in a prototype plant that has no containment system, the steel and concrete structure surrounding civilian reactors to confine radioactive material in an accident. The department statement said there is a containment structure, but an NRDC expert was quoted as saying it is not comparable to one on a civilian power plant.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei, Dollar Decline
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell and ended the day with a moderate loss Thursday, and the dollar finished lower against the yen. The dollar ended at 158.85 yen, down 0.48 yen from Wednesday's close of 159.25 yen. The currency opened at 158.65 yen and ranged between 158.65 yen and 159.00 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 139.78 points, or 0.47 percent, closing at 29,424.58. The index, which rose 62.98 points Wednesday, added more than 100 points by midmorning before falling back in the afternoon. Traders said the Nikkei index rose in the early trading because of the yen's recovery against the dollar but later fell back as market players were reluctant to take positions. ``The majority of market players remained on the sidelines ahead of the Golden Week holidays, while there was no active selling,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, a stock analyst with Nomura Securities Co. A holiday week starts Saturday and continues through May 6 for the majority of Japanese companies. The stock and currency markets will close on April 30, May 3 and 4, all national holidays. An uptrend in the U.S. short-term interest rates and uncertainties over the U.S. government bond auction in May also contributed to the market's wait-and-see mood, he said. The dollar was higher from its opening in sympathy with the West German mark. The mark rose against the yen on news reports the West German central bank may raise its official discount rate shortly to help stem inflation, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Higher interest rates tend to make the respective country's currency more attractive to foreign currency investors. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 86.03 from Wednesday's close of 85.92. That dropped the yield to 7.36 percent from 7.385 percent.
