DOC.HEAD: Researchers Report Possible Cause of L-Tryptophan Illness
DOC.TEXT: A federal official says studies in two states have tied the sometimes fatal blood disorder linked to the dietary supplement L-tryptophan to a single Japanese company. ``These are the first preliminary reports linking consumption of L-tryptophan from one specific company to this syndrome,'' Food and Drug Administration spokesman Jeff Nesbit said Wednesday. L-tryptophan has been linked to 21 deaths and more than 1,500 reports of illness from a disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia, or EMS. The FDA last month declared L-tryptophan a ``major public health problem'' and expanded its recall of the supplement, commonly sold in health food stores as a remedy for insomnia, appetite control and depression. Federal researchers who conducted studies in Oregon and Minnesota presented their results at a forum at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta on Wednesday, said Nesbit. He said the studies strongly suggest something contaminated the L-tryptophan produced by the company. The Washington Post, in today's editions, quoted a spokesman for the Showa Denko Co., one of Japan's largest chemical manufacturers, as saying the studies ``showed a strong statistical association between our product and EMS.'' ``But it is important to note that the studies do not independently identify the precise cause of EMS,'' the spokesman, Bob Schwadron, told the newspaper. Nesbit said three other studies in progress are expected to be completed in a month or two. ``The first two cases made public in Atlanta do indicate that one company is responsible, but we won't know whether that will hold true for the remaining three until we're finished,'' he said. EMS is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash, fatigue, cough and sometimes fever. In some cases, victims show signs of congestive heart failure and develop a condition that causes progressive weakness and sometimes leads to paralysis.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Polio To Be Disappear From Western Hemisphere This Year
DOC.TEXT: Polio probably will be stamped out by the end of the year in the Western Hemisphere, according to public health experts who say there has been surprising progress reportged against the crippling disease in Latin America. ``At the moment we're having a hard time finding the virus at all,'' D.A. Henderson, dean of the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, said in an interview Wednesday. He credited efforts that included health workers going door-to-door with the vaccine in urban and other high risk areas. When the Pan American Health Organization in 1985 set 1990 as a goal for eradicating polio in the Americas, ``we all said this is going to be tough ... that probably is optimistic,'' he said. ``Then suddenly this program began to move and polio has vanished at a pace we could not believe,'' said Henderson, president of the Association of Schools of Public Health, which met in Washington this week.
DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Opponents Appeal to Rehnquist
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant are asking the nation's top judge to interrupt start-up of the plant pending court appeals. In a petition Wednesday to Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist, the opponents repeated arguments about the safety of the plant and the alleged inadequacy of evacuation plans. Those arguments have failed to persuade the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the U.S. Court of Appeals. A full federal appeal is scheduled for Sept. 18. But opponents argue that by that time Seabrook will be operating at full power. The petition, filed by Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, the Seacoast Anti-Pollution League and the New England Coalition on Nuclear Pollution, seeks an immediate stay on the Seabrook license granted March 1 by the NRC. Rehnquist issued no immediate response to the petition.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Asks Congress to Increase Fraud-Fighting Powers
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is asking for more authority to act against companies that abuse or defraud the Food and Drug Administration. The legislation was submitted Wednesday in response to the generic drug scandal in which drug manufacturers were found to have misrepresented their products and bribed FDA officials to win approval to market their drugs. ``We must have the legal tools to move quickly and decisively against anyone who seeks to mislead or subvert the FDA,'' said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. The measure would authorize the FDA to debar anyone the agency considered a threat to the integrity of the agency's product review process and to refuse to review or approve any products submitted by a debarred company.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Set Tough Conditions For Demobilization
With PM-Nicaragua-Future, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: Angered over continued Sandinista domination of the army and police, the Contras are defying President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's appeals to lay down their weapons and rejoin civilian life. A representative of the president, Roberto Ferrey, traveled Wednesday to a special security zone where the rebels are supposed to disband under U.N. supervision. Hours after Mrs. Chamorro was sworn in on Wednesday , he urged about 500 armed rebels seated in columns on a sunbaked slope to lay down their weapons. ``You of the resistance must understand that you are not defeated soldiers; that you are heroic combatants who, for love of your country, are willing to lay down your arms and return to civilian life,'' Ferrey said at the close of his 15-minute address through a megaphone. Previous speakers _ one a representative of Nicaragua's Roman Catholic archbishop, and the other, Arturo Garzon of the Organizaton of American States _ received polite applause. But Ferrey was met with stony silence and stares. Guerrillas who rose during the following 40 minutes to challenge and question him were heartily cheered, especially when they said they were unwilling to disband while the Sandinista army remained intact. Garzon issued what he termed ``an invitation and an exhortation'' to the Contras to avail themselves of OAS aid once they decided to hand over their weapons. Of the dozens interviewed at the assembly, however, not a single Contra said he would hand over his weapon as long as the Sandinistas controlled the army and security forces. Under an agreement signed last week by leaders of the Contras, the Sandinistas and the new government, the rebels were to begin demobilizing Wednesday. But the accord appeared headed for a breakdown because Mrs. Chamorro decided as a concilatory measure to allow Gen. Humberto Ortega, brother of former President Daniel Ortega, to stay on as head the army. Top Contra commander Israel Galeano addressed the troops after meeting briefly with Maj. Jose Luis Grazia of Spain, who was in El Destino representing the U.N. Central American peacekeeping force. The guerrillas broke out in laughter over the suggestion they lay down their arms. ``Nobody gives up his gun!'' shouted one, and all cheered. The peacekeepers have no mandate to forcibly disarm the Contras. El Destino is part of security Zone 1, which is 85 miles north of Managua and covers 174 square miles. While it is not the largest of five zones designated for the Contra demobilization, it is thought to harbor the most fighters. About 3,000 Contras are estimated to have arrived in the past week. About 9,000 Contras are to gather in the zones in coming days. The rebels in Zone 1, who roam the area at will, are unsupervised and have Soviet-made assault rifles, grenade launchers and other weaponry. Ferrey appealed for demobilization before June 10, the date agreed to in the pact signed last week by Oscar Sobalvarro, the No. 2 man in the Contra command. Several Contras, though, rose to challenge Ferrey. ``Jackson,'' a regional Contra commander, told the group: ``I'd rather take to the mountains, live in the jungle with my comrades until our conditions are met. And those conditions have not yet been met.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Liz Taylor Nearly Died Over the Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor has rallied from a near-fatal bout with pneumonia _ and even joked about coming out in her ``balcony attire'' to wave to reporters _ but is ``not out of the woods,'' doctors say. ``I believe her life was in jeopardy over the weekend and I believe that has now passed,'' Dr. Bernard Weintraub, a lung specialist treating Miss Taylor at St. Johns Hospital and Health Center, said Wednesday. The 58-year-old actress was taken off the ventilator that had aided her breathing for several days and was smiling again and ``very happy the tube was out,'' said Dr. Patricia Murray, an infectious disease specialist. ``She said she'd come out and wave to you but she's not in her balcony attire,'' the doctor said. About 80 reporters and camera crew members, along with some 100 St. Johns employees, jammed the hospital courtyard to hear the latest reports on Miss Taylor. Miss Taylor has had back troubles since she fell off a horse during filming in 1945 of ``National Velvet.'' She had to undergo a tracheotomy during a bout with pneumonia in 1961 that nearly killed her. In 1983 she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers, and her weight has been up and down over the years. In response to persistent rumors about AIDS and other illnesses, Weintraub said there was ``no suggestion of either cancer or infections commonly seen in AIDS.'' The actress had issued a statement earlier denying she has AIDS. Weintraub said the actress, hospitalized since April 9, remained in intensive care. ``She is in serious condition. She is not out of the woods,'' he said. With her were her four children from three marriages, Maria Burton-Carson, Liza Todd-Tivey and Christopher and Michael Wilding. The hospital released a statement on Miss Taylor's behalf thanking fans and friends for their cards and letters.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: It's a December-May romance _ she's 72, he's 22. But Mary and Daniel Huntley, who got married this week, think mostly about the month of March. ``We met a month ago at a country dance,'' Mrs. Huntley said. ``It was love at first sight.'' Does the age difference matter? ``Not a bit in the world,'' Mrs. Huntley said in a telephone interview Wednesday night. ``My mother didn't like it,'' said Huntley, although his wife figured out why. She was ``sore because she wasn't asked to the wedding,'' said Mrs. Huntley. ``We didn't invite anybody. We didn't have time.'' The couple, who live in the southwestern Illinois community of Pittsfield, were visiting Hardin 50 miles north when they decided to get married. He already had proposed, but no date had been set. Circuit Judge Robert Welch married them Tuesday. Mrs. Huntley's daughter, 32-year-old Becky Mielke, was maid of honor. Mrs. Huntley, a widow whose first husband died five years ago, has 11 children, 23 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Huntley, an unemployed janitor, remembers when he asked his bride to marry him, at 3 a.m. two weeks ago. ``We had been courtin' a few weeks,'' he said. ``We were drinking coffee and listening to Hank Williams Jr. on the radio. I turned and said, `Mary Alice, will you marry me?''' She did not hesitate. ```I do,' I answered. I meant, `I will.' I was a little nervous,'' Mrs. Huntley said.

DOC.HEAD: Jazzman Dexter Gordon Dead at 67
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Saxophonist Dexter Gordon, who had dazzled jazz audiences since the '40s with his complex be-bop stylings and lumbering yet dignified stage presence, is dead at 67. He died Wednesday of kidney failure at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, where the New Yorker had been admitted March 18 with cancer of the larynx, said Don Lucoff, spokesman for Blue Note Records in New York. Gordon helped define be-bop in the '40s and he was the last in a line of saxophone geniuses that included Lester Young, Charlie Parker and John Coltrane. He reached a new audience as the Oscar-nominated star of the 1986 film ``Round Midnight,'' and recently finished filming the movie ``Awakenings,'' with Robert De Niro and Robin Williams. ``It's very, very difficult to even contemplate that we've lost such a great master of his instrument and incredible human being,'' said guitarist George Benson. ``He was one of the true giants of the tenor saxophone,'' fluegelhorn player Art Farmer said from his home in Vienna. ``He was an inspiration to me, although I didn't play saxophone, going back over 40 years.'' Drummer Art Blakey, performing in Seattle, said he and Gordon played together in one of the early Billy Eckstine bands, and he played on one of Gordon's last albums. ``He called me last week, wanted me to see him. I thought he was coming back to New York,'' Blakey said. ``Gonna miss him.'' Gordon's style was his own but his life bore tragic similarities to the other jazz greats: exile, bouts of drug and alcohol abuse, a stint in prison on drug charges. Gordon combined Young's melodic approach with the hard-driving sound and complex harmonics of Coleman Hawkins and Parker. At a set's end he would hold out his horn as if presenting it to the audience for a share of the applause. Gordon went to Europe in 1962 for a three-month tour and ended up staying for 14 years, first in Paris, then Denmark. ``I met him in Europe in a jazz club in Copenhagen,'' Benson recalled. ``They called him, I think it was correct, King Gordon Dexter. ... His music was always par excellence.'' It was those years as an expatriate that led director Bertrand Tavernier to cast Gordon in ``Round Midnight,'' the bittersweet tale of an American jazz musician in Paris and an admiring French fan. The film was loosely based on the life of pianist Bud Powell but had many parallels with Gordon's _ and with those of many jazz artists who fled bigotry and rough times in America for Europe in the 1950s and '60s. The 6-foot-5 Gordon, who dominated the film with his smoky voice, smooth sax playing and world-weary yet regal bearing, was nominated for an Academy Award _ a first for a musician. ``The story is so personal. I don't mean Dexter Gordon, but this long line of musicians who have been under-appreciated and ... swindled,'' he said in 1986. The film sparked new interest in his career, which began in the 1930s when he went to jazz concerts with his father, a Los Angeles physician whose patients included Duke Ellington and Lionel Hampton. Gordon performed in clubs as a teen-ager and soon played with the big bands of Hampton, Louis Armstrong and Eckstine. His mentors were Young and Herschel Evans, and he refined the innovations Parker had laid down. Gordon, in turn, helped shape the style and music of Coltrane and Sonny Rollins. He left Eckstine to work on 52nd Street _ the jazz capital in New York _ performing with Parker, Miles Davis, Powell and Max Roach, and recording with Dizzy Gillespie. By the late '40s, he was fronting his own groups. He and his style of music faded from view in the '50s, during which he served two years in prison in California on drug charges. After prison, he recorded five acclaimed albums for Blue Note from 1961 to 1965. Among his more highly regarded albums are ``Long Tall Dexter, The Savoy Sessions,'' ``Doin' Alright,'' ``Dexter Calling,'' ``Our Man in Paris'' and ``A Swingin' Affair.'' Gordon was survived by his wife, Maxine; two daughters and three sons. A memorial was planned for May 6 in New York, Lucoff said.

DOC.HEAD: Baskin-Robbins Strikes Sweet Deal With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Baskin-Robbins Inc. will build a $30 million ice cream plant near Moscow, sweetening the deal with a new flavor called ``Gorba Chocolate.'' The factory, to open in 1992 in the suburb of Ostankino, will be a joint venture with a Soviet trade ministry. About 100 Soviet workers will be employed at the plant, said William I. Savel, Baskin-Robbins president and chief executive. Its yearly production of 8 million gallons will begin with 10 kinds of ice cream, far fewer than the company's famous 31 flavors. It's a lot more than Muscovites are used to, though. Only chocolate and vanilla are now available in the Soviet Union. ``Their ice cream is good, but our ice cream is better and we have a greater variety,'' Savel said. The Glendale-based franchiser, a subsidiary of Britain's Allied-Lyons PLC, reached the Soviet agreement Tuesday. It said it will inaugurate the deal with its new Gorba Chocolate flavor, a white and dark chocolate concoction. The ice cream initially will be sold at thousands of government-managed food stores in the Moscow area, Savel said. Baskin-Robbins hopes to expand its selection and markets for nationwide distribution. ``If they go into private ownership, we could sign on franchisees there too,'' Savel said. Baskin-Robbins, which has sold ice cream at the Rossiya Hotel in Moscow since 1988, will generate hard currency by selling about 10 percent of its product at Soviet stores that cater to tourists and accept only convertible currency. Non-convertible rubles from the food stores will be used for plant supplies and expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei, Dollar Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell moderately today, and the dollar declined against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 139.78 points, or 0.47 percent, closing at 29,424.58. The index, which rose 62.98 points Wednesday, had added more than 100 points by midmorning Thursday before falling back. Traders attributed the decline to caution ahead of a long holiday period as well as concern over U.S. interest rate movements. ``Nobody wants to buy issues ahead of long holidays, especially when they are discouraged by the recent uptrend in the U.S. interest rates,'' said a Nomura Securities trader, speaking on condition of anonymity. Japan's Golden Week series of holidays starts Saturday and continues through May 6 for most Japanese companies. Next week, the stock and currency markets will be open only on Tuesday and Wednesday. The trader said the index rose in early trading following the yen's recovery against the dollar, but then fell back as market players took to the sidelines. Today's trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 550 million shares, down from Wednesday's 700 million. Meanwhile, the Tokyo Stock Exchange announced that arbitrage trading for the previous week amounted to 57.9 million shares worth $503 million. Arbitrage selling totaled 22.4 million shares worth $195 million. Arbitrage selling, to take profits on price gaps between the spot and the futures markets, has been cited as one cause of the market's plunge since the beginning of this year. It was the first time the exchange announced arbitrage figures, a move intended to reduce investors' uncertainties. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 158.77 yen, down 0.48 yen from Wednesday's close of 159.25 yen. It opened at 158.65 yen and ranged between 158.65 yen and 159.00 yen. Dollar-yen dealing was inactive ahead of the holidays, said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Predicting a strengthening of the yen after the holidays, Hanada said: ``Considering the higher nominal interest rates in Japan, whose long-term interest rates have stayed above 7 percent, it is about time for investors to shift their interest to the yen.'' The dollar gained in early trading as market players bought West German marks for yen on news reports that the West German central bank may raise its official discount rate shortly to help stem inflation, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to foreign currency investors. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 86.09 points, up from Wednesday's close of 85.92. The yield slipped to 7.350 percent from the previous day's 7.385 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We have to melt down our arms and sell the metal to buy machinery for agriculture and industry.'' _ Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the new president of Nicaragua.

``We have witnessed a remarkable transformation in Japanese public attitudes about its protectionist trade policy.'' _ U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, objecting to calls by industry groups and members of Congress to cite Japan for trade barriers.
``My guess is that Congress will lead if the president does not.'' _ Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., calling for action against the Soviet Union's crackdown on Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: First-Ever Prosecution of Child-Protection Workers Fails Again
DOC.TEXT: The acquittal of a former foster care counselor marked prosecutors' third defeat in three attempts to hold social workers responsible for the death of a toddler dunked headfirst in a toilet for soiling his pants. Shirley Duboise was acquitted Wednesday on a misdemeanor charge stemming from the death last year of 2-year-old Bradley McGee. Ms. Duboise and three other Health and Rehabilitative Services workers were the first state workers ever charged with neglecting to report suspected child abuse. So far two of the workers have been acquitted, charges were dropped against a third, and the last is awaiting trial. ``I think it's political,'' defense attorney Nat White said of the prosecution. ``At the time Bradley died, everybody was outraged. The public wanted some heads and the State Attorney's office delivered.'' Bradley, abandoned as an infant, was in foster care most of his life until he was returned to his parents two months before his death. He died July 28 after being dunked headfirst in a toilet during potty training, authorities said. Bradley's mother, Sheryl Coe of Lakeland, was sentenced last week to 30 years in prison after pleading guilty to murder. The murder trial of her husband, Thomas Coe, is set for July. Bradley's foster mother, Pam Kirkland, testified that the boy had returned upset from an unsupervised visit with his parents April 26, 1989, with cuts on his hand, a cigarette burn and a red mark behind his ear. She said she showed the marks to Ms. Dubois, who testified she took no action because all she remembers was little more than a splinter on the boy's finger. The trial evolved into a question of who the jury believed, the 43-year-old defendant or the foster mother. After barely an hour, the jury returned its innocent verdict. ``We were frankly a little surprised the judge didn't dismiss it right after the prosecution brought out its case,'' said jury foreman Hazen Kelley. ``We felt we would be doing a disservice if our decision made people scared they would have to call the HRS every time they see a scratch on a child.'' Mrs. Dubois, who could have faced up to 60 days if convicted, said Assistant State Attorney John Aguero ``should have owned up and been a man and dismissed all these cases when he realized he didn't have anything.'' Aguero refused to comment. The last worker to face trial is Bradley's caseworker, Margaret Barber, who in addition to the misdemeanor of failing to report suspected abuse is charged with child abuse. If convicted, she could face up to 5 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Cartel Leader Intensifies After Bloody Bombing
DOC.TEXT: After at least six people were killed by a bomb police said drug traffickers hid in a dump truck, police helicopters dropped leaflets on Medellin seeking help in capturing Colombia's top cocaine lord. Authorities blame Pablo Escobar, the leader of the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel, for Wednesday's bombing and hundreds of other attacks in response to the government's 8-month-old war on drugs. ``It is easy to see that Pablo Escobar is behind all of these violent, criminal actions,'' said Interior Minister Horacio Serpa. ``We have to say frankly that Pablo Escobar is Colombia's public enemy No. 1.'' Authorities intensified the search for Escobar in this cocaine center and nearby towns. Police patrols swept neighborhoods where he was suspected of hiding, and the city's army intellegence unit said it was ready to check any leads from citizens. The bomb, packing more than 400 pounds of dynamite, exploded Wednesday morning as a vehicle full of elite anti-narcotics police passed by. Two police officers and four civilians were killed, including three women and a child. Scores of people were injured, including many aboard a bus. Commuters, their clothes torn and their bodies bloodied, pleaded for help as they crawled from the bus' shattered windows, witnesses said. The explosion severely damaged many buildings and homes in the middle-class neighborhood in west Medellin. ``I'm furious and scared,'' said a toy shop owner, who identified herself only as Claudia. ``It's one thing when you see this kind of thing on television. It's another when the bomb goes off on your doorstep.'' She said two of her female employees were killed as they walked from a nearby cafeteria to open the shop. The truck bombing was the second blast this month targeting anti-terrorist police in Medellin. On April 11, a car bomb exploded on a busy highway, killing 20 people, including eight members of the special anti-narcotics police unit. Since then, police have sent thousands of reinforcements to the area to search for Escobar. On Tuesday night, President Virgilio Barco put the military in charge of two towns near Medellin, Bello and Estrella, and scores of troops and armored cars mounted with cannons moved into the towns. Another nearby town, Envigado, was put under military rule last month. Authorities blame the Medellin cartel for the deaths of 60 Medellin police officers this year. The cartel has offered to pay $4,300 for each policeman murdered. The terrorism campaign began in August after the Barco government intensified a war on the country's cocaine cartels, based in the cities of Medellin and Cali. Medellin's mayor, Juan Gomez, said in a televised interview that bombers should ``quit damaging the city.'' He has called repeatedly for government negotiations with traffickers to end the violence. The Barco administration has said it will never negotiate with the cocaine cartels. ``I don't know why we have to put up with a mayor that wants to talk to these monsters,'' said the toy shop owner. But a neighborhood resident, Francisco Alvarez, said he was angry at the Barco administration. ``The government says it is fighting with the drug traffickers, but it is the common people who are dying,'' he said. ``The only way to stop this insanity is through a dialogue with the drug mafia.'' The traffickers demand that the government stop extraditing drug suspects to face trial in the United States. Colombia has extradited 15 alleged cartel middlemen since the crackdown began.

DOC.HEAD: Sotheby's Buying Out Gallery For $142.8 Million
DOC.TEXT: Sotheby's, departing from its role as an auction house, is financing the $142.8 million purchase of the contents of a distinguished New York art gallery. Sotheby's has agreed to finance the purchase of the Pierre Matisse Gallery, one of the foremost inventories of 20th-century art, in an agreement with art dealer William Acquavella, said Diana C. Brooks, president of Sotheby's in North America. The gallery was founded by Pierre Matisse, the son of painter Henri Matisse. Its inventory has 2,300 works by artists such as Joan Miro, Marc Chagall and Alberto Giacometti. Acquavella will be managing partner of the joint venture company, which will be called Acquavella Modern Art, The New York Times reported today. Acquavella said he plans to sell the paintings privately over a period of time. Until now, Sotheby's has represented sellers and has not owned most of the works it has sold. But with this move, Sotheby's acquires a substantial inventory of artwork and enters the gallery business. Sotheby's has expanded its operations in the art world since real estate tycoon A. Alfred Taubman bought it in 1983. The auction house in 1988 started Sotheby's Financial Services, a subsidiary that lends money to sellers, buyers and owners of art. More recently Sotheby's has offered guaranteed minimum prices for consigned pieces of art, even if the work does not sell at auction. ``I think once more it is another confirmation that Sotheby's has really become an art dealer,'' David P. Tunick, a New York art dealer and board member of the Art Dealers Association of America, told the Times. ``To any longer describe themselves as an objective middleman is wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: State Defends Decision to Release Accused Gunman
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's human resources chief says a state mental hospital followed procedure in releasing a man who shot and killed someone at a shopping mall the next day. James Ledbetter, commissioner of human resources, said psychiatrists determined James Calvin Brady, 31, was no danger himself or others when he was released from Georgia Regional Hospital in Atlanta on Monday. Brady on Tuesday killed one person and wounded four in a shooting rampage, police said. ``It's a very difficult decision to predict future behavior, and that's essentially what our staff is called on to do,'' Ledbetter siad. ``We are not perfect.'' A court hearing was scheduled today to determine which hospital records should be turned over to the public defender's office and police. Ledbetter said Gov. Joe Frank Harris asked him to review the decision to release Brady. ``When I looked at it, I just didn't find the weaknesses that the tragedy would suggest,'' Ledbetter said. ``I believe that the decisions that were made were consistent with standard medical procedure and with the policies of the department.'' The gunman, smiling and wearing a gray suit, fired a handgun into a lunch-time crowd at Perimeter Mall. After throwing his gun into a trash can, Brady surrendered just outside the main entrance, police said. Brady told authorities his attack was motivated by revenge against people in California who, seeking to control him, had implanted a mechanical device in his body. Brady has been charged with murder in the death of Michael Gregory Musick, 24, and four counts of aggravated assault. He was taken to a state mental hospital in Milledgeville to a await a preliminary hearing May 1. Two of the victims remained hospitalized, one in serious condition and another in fair. Before the preliminary hearing, psychiatrists will attempt to determine whether Brady is competent to stand trial, said his lawyer, public defender Larry Schneider. ``Obviously when he walks in and shoots a bunch of people before 200 witnesses you think about an insanity plea,'' Schneider said. DeKalb County police said the gunman carried documents from the hospital in Atlanta indicating he had been diagnosed as having homicidal tendencies. But Harris said, ``I think you'll find when the information comes out that that's not exactly the case.'' Police said Brady bought the revolver and 12 rounds of hollow-point ammunition, a type designed to expand on impact and cause particularly severe wounds, for $139 Monday at a pawn shop in an Atlanta suburb.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Siege Ends; Dispute Erupts Over Decision Not To Use Force
DOC.TEXT: After the last five rebellious inmates surrendered at Strangeways prison, debate began immediately over whether authorities should have used force early on to end what became a 25-day standoff. Today's headline in the Daily Mail newspaper, which supports Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government, said: ``Prison farce ends at last.'' ``The inmates ... have strutted, simpered and snarled at the ... TV cameras,'' said an editorial. ``The Home Office its ministers and its prison service have been humiliated repeatedly and publicly.'' But the secretary of the Home Office, which is in charge of prisons, said after visiting Strangeways on Wednesday night: ``I think the end result justified the tactics employed.'' Secretary David Waddington denied suggestions at a news conference that the decision not to use force had made the prison service a laughingstock. ``I ask you to examine your conscience and if you would be making the same criticism of me if the prison had been stormed and five officers killed,'' he said. The defiance at Strangeways, in the northern city of Manchester, prompted copycat trouble at more than a dozen other prisons. The siege at Strangeways ended Wednesday when the last five inmates were lowered at their own request from the roof of the prison chapel to the courtyard 150 feet below in a hydraulic lift. The trouble began April 1 at Sunday services in the chapel. About 300 inmates overpowered guards, stole their keys and got into other parts of the prison. Other inmates joined what became a riot, starting fires and destroying large areas of the prison, but most surrendered within days. A prisoner awaiting trial on charges of sexually assaulting children died of injuries suffered at the hands of other inmates. Prisoners' relatives told of overcrowding in the prison, which was built in 1868 to house 970 men and held 1,648 when the rioting erupted. During the siege, prison authorities used sirens and firecrackers to deprive the rebellious inmates of sleep and try to wear down their resistance. Other tactics included spraying jets of water to drench the prisoners and put out fires they started. The inmates responded by hurling roof tiles and bricks and shouting abuse at guards. They danced on the roof for scores of TV and press cameras as relatives and supporters gathered to cheer them on. On one occasion, TV viewers saw one inmate appear on the roof, bawl out ``Good morning, Manchester'' and do exercises. On Wednesday morning, 100 guards in riot gear moved into the prison, trapping the five on the prison chapel roof. But again, no violence was used. The renegades had armed themselves with crudely fashioned weapons and erected barricades and booby traps, and authorities feared loss of life or injuries in force was used. News reports indicated some anxiety among Mrs. Thatcher's governing Conservatives over possible harm to their image as the party of law and order. The party is already in deep political trouble with voters over an unpopular new tax. The liberal London newspaper The Guardian quoted rank-and-file Tory legislators as saying only the party's electoral fragility had prevented an explosion of indignation over how the standoff was handled. John Bartell, chairman of the Prison Officers' Association, the guards' trade union, also criticized the way the siege was allowed to continue.

DOC.HEAD: Urine Test Negative For Northwest Pilot Who Demanded Test After Joke
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines pilot who insisted on urine and blood tests after a passenger questioned his sobriety tested negative for alcohol, the airline says. ``That's the end of it, as far as we're concerned,'' Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said Wednesday. A Northwest flight from Detroit to Atlanta was delayed four hours last week when the pilot, whom Northwest refused to identify, confronted a woman who had suggested he was delayed because he was ``partying.'' The woman, Ann Beaver of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said Saturday she was only joking, but the pilot took her seriously. The pilot had been assigned to the flight after the scheduled pilot was delayed. After the pilot left the plane for the tests, the flight was further delayed while the airline sought another substitute pilot. When the plane finally left, Beaver and her husband stayed behind because other passengers were furious with them, Northwest said. The couple took a flight Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sentenced to Life on Cocaine Charge is Freed After 8 Years In Prison
DOC.TEXT: A woman sentenced to life in prison for a first-offense cocaine conviction was freed by a judge who ruled that her defense was incompetent and the jury stacked. She had served 8{ years in prison. Deborah Pilchak, 37, tearfully embraced her mother after her release became official during a brief hearing in federal court Wednesday. The state said it would appeal Ms. Pilchak's release, but U.S. District Judge Joseph E. Stevens ruled that she deserved to be free until her case is decided. Ms. Pilchak said she planned to spend her first day of freedom ``eating and shopping.'' ``I am very happy, I feel so free,'' Ms. Pilchak said. ``I can't really describe how good this feels.'' Stevens ruled last month that Ms. Pilchak received an unfair trial for cocaine charges in Cole County Circuit Court. He gave the state 30 days to set aside the conviction and release her or set a new trial. Ms. Pilchak's court-appointed attorney was suffering from Alzheimer's disease and had not prepared a defense, Stevens said. The jurors came from a pool selected by the sheriff, a common practice, but in this case the sheriff had investigated the case. Ms. Pilchak said she was not angry about the way the case had been handled. ``It was extremely unfortunate that this happened to me,'' Ms. Pilchak said. ``I'm mostly sad about it. I hope it doesn't happen to anybody else.'' She was arrested in Jefferson City in December 1981 and charged with aiding and abetting her boyfriend in the sale of 26 ounces of cocaine to an undercover drug agent. Her sentence came although she was a first-time offender. A few months after her trial, it became known that her attorney, J. Paul Allred Jr., was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. And a lawyer in another case discovered after Ms. Pilchak's trial that the jury pool was chosen by the sheriff who investigated the case. Ms. Pilchak's boyfriend, Gary McCaw, was tried separately and sentenced to life in prison. A judge ruled that the jury selected in that case also was flawed and ordered a new trial. McCaw pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 26 years in prison. He has since been freed. Ms. Pilchak has two children, a 20-year-old son and an 8-year-old daughter. The younger child has been in foster care and a hearing is scheduled May 4 to determine whether Ms. Pilchak's parental rights should be terminated. Steve Hawke, of the attorney general's office, said the state would contend in its appeal that a state court had found allegations about the improper defense and stacked jury to be groundless. Under her original sentence, Ms. Pilchak could not have been released from prison until December 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Holds Arizona Health Director in Contempt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers say they will ignore a judge who found the state health chief in contempt for failing to provide money for mental health programs. Superior Judge Bernard Dougherty on Wednesday gave the Department of Health Services Director, Ted Williams, 15 days to request an additional $45.2 million from the Legislature, which would provide it. Legislators said Dougherty's order is meaningless and predicted that it would be ignored. They said the money requested is not available. ``The judge is in never-never land,'' said House Appropriations Committee Chairman John Wettaw. Doughterty did not say what action he would take if Williams failed to seek the additional money, or if the Legislature refused to provide it. The battle over funding for the chronically mental ill began with a class-action lawsuit against the state in 1981. Dougherty ruled in June 1985 that the state had to fully fund programs mandated by the Legislature for people with chronic mental illness, and the order was affirmed in March 1989 by the Arizona Supreme Court. An advocacy group, the Center for Law in the Public Interest, sought contempt sanctions against Williams and Gov. Rose Mofford, contending neither had sought adequate funding to comply with the order. The center argued that the state would have to spend an additional $45.2 million next year to begin implementing the order, while Williams sought only $12.3 million in his budget request to the governor, and Mrs. Mofford asked the Legislature for only $1.6 million. The state Supreme Court dismissed the proceedings against Mrs. Mofford on grounds that she was not a party to the original suit, and that her actions are protected by the state constitution. But the high court allowed the case against Williams. Beryl Dulsky, an assistant state attorney general who represented Williams, said no decision had been made on an appeal. Vada Manager, a spokesman for Mrs. Mofford, said ``we are exploring the options.'' Lawmakers were skeptical that Dougherty's order will result in a substantial increase in funding for the chronically mentally ill. ``The Legislature does not respond very well to judicial threats,'' said Senate Majority Leader John Mawhinney. Wettaw said lawmakers would ``do our best'' to provide additional funding for mental health programs, but that it would not be anywhere near $45.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Power Outage Blackens Much of City
DOC.TEXT: A blackout plunged much of this city of 610,000 people and its environs into darkness for several hours, and traffic chaos downtown gave way to a big street party. The power outage occurred about 8 p.m. Wednesday after equipment failure caused a transformer at a midtown station to explode and catch fire, Ontario Hydro spokesman Bill Friday said. Several people reported seeing a fireball after the blast, but officials said there were no serious injuries at the plant, which was evacuated. The fire was out by 10 p.m. ``Everything was back on as of 1:10 a.m.,'' Friday said today. ``Ninety percent of the people affected had their power back by 11:30 p.m.'' Police staff Sgt. Lou Villani said about 175 gallons of liquid containing cancer-causing polychlorinated biphenyls spilled during the fire but were contained inside the plant. Hydro spokesmen said the liquid did not pose a danger because the PCB levels were well below provincial standards. At the height of the blackout, about 90,000 homes and 10,000 businesses were in the dark in Toronto and parts of suburban Scarborough, East York and North York. Downtown stores closed, but there were reports of young looters carrying leather jackets and stereos out of the Eaton Centre, Villani said. Security staff sealed off the huge four-story mall and no arrests were reported. Wednesday was the city's hottest April 25 on record _ 86 degrees _ and thousands of people strolled along Yonge Street, the main thoroughfare, reveling in the disorder and giving the street the good-time, chaotic energy of a Saturday night. ``We're having an amazing time,'' said 19-year-old Michelle Em, who took a break from her job at a leather goods store to cruise the streets with two friends in a rented rickshaw. ``We've seen people preaching and singing. You name it, they're doing it,'' she said. Police officers mixed with the crowds and cruisers joined the traffic on the street. For several hours, pedestrians and drivers had to guess each others' intentions before proceeding. Off-duty officers eventually were asked to direct the busiest intersections, particularly around the SkyDome where more than 30,000 people poured out of a Toronto Blue Jays game. The stadium did not lose power. At the King Edward Hotel, some guests were led to the lobby by staff and treated to tea, coffee and pastries. Another staff member played the piano. The show never started at the Pantages Theatre, where ``The Phantom of the Opera'' was to have been performed. ``The bar was open,'' said theater-goer Dorothy Lillie. ``People bought drinks and watched the beautiful people go by,'' she said as she joined hundreds of others strolling along Younge Street. Joe Luciano of the Big Slice pizzeria moved a table onto the street and hawked slices of pizza and soda. Gordon Miller, 64, who served in World War II, said it was ``just like London in the Blitz.''

They said the market was waiting for the release Friday of U.S. preliminary first-quarter gross national product data. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed at 158.77 yen, down 0.48 yen from Wednesday's close. Later it was quoted in London at 158.88. DOC.HEAD: Fighting Between Christian Rivals Kills 22 in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's militiamen hammered each other with artillery and tank fire overnight, and police said 22 people were killed and 40 wounded. Several apartment buildings, service stations and warehouses were set ablaze by the 14-hour shelling duel that marked a sharp escalation of the power struggle for mastery of Lebanon's Christian enclave. The latest casualties raised the overall toll to 916 killed and 2,441 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved to crush Geagea's 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia that posed the main challenge to his authority in the enclave. Police said Lebanese Forces' gunboats and multibarreled rocket launchers blasted a makeshift harbor for Aoun's 19,000 troops in the coastal town of Dbaye north of Beirut, setting its installations afire. Aoun's mountain-top artillery positions struck at Geagea's military headquarters in east Beirut's seaside Karantina district, the adjacent Beirut port and the residential district of Ashrafiyeh, police said. The fighting tapered off to sporadic sniping at daybreak.

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 Expected For Shuttle Landing Sunday
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: NASA expects up to 20,000 spectators to watch Discovery return from space Sunday, a fraction of the number that greeted the early shuttle flights but far more than have seen the last three landings. The shuttle is scheduled to land at 6:49 a.m. PDT Sunday, winding up its five-day mission to deploy the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. The last time the public was invited to view a shuttle landing was on Oct. 23, when 20,000 people watched Atlantis return. Because heavy rains had flooded the unpaved public viewing site, NASA discouraged spectators when Columbia landed Jan. 20. Only about 1,000 to 2,000 showed up for the 1:35 a.m. landing. The other two shuttle flights in recent months, Discovery's flight that ended with a Nov. 27 landing and Atlantis' flight that wound up March 4, were classified military missions and the general public was barred. Crowds of up to 500,000 people have greeted shuttles in the past. NASA spokeswoman Nancy Lovato said she expected only 15,000 to 20,000 people Sunday because shuttle landings are becoming routine again. Difficulties getting to the site also may decrease the number of spectators. The main access road from the south is closed for resurfacing, and would-be spectators driving from Los Angeles will be forced to approach take a detour that will add about an hour to the usual 2{-hour drive, Lovato said Wednesday. The public viewing site will open 24 hours before Discovery lands.

DOC.HEAD: Most of the Nation Gets Fair Weather
DOC.TEXT: Fair weather prevailed across most of the nation early today, after a day of record-breaking high temperatures. Rain fell in the Midwest and Southwest. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms from Texas to the upper Great Lakes, showers in the Dakotas and Northern Rockies, and more severe weather in north-central Texas, where tornadoes forced at least 150 people from their homes. Colder weather was expected to bring snow to the Oregon Cascades today. On Wednesday, thunderstorms ranged from Texas across the Deep South, the Midwest and desert Southwest. Showers were scattered across the Pacific Northwest. Two dozen high temperature records were broken or tied from the central Atlantic states into the upper Mississippi Valley, including 90 in Alpena, Mich., breaking a record of 86 set in 1982. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 98 at Palm Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Plane Crash in Philippines Kills Six
DOC.TEXT: A DC-3 plane on a domestic flight crashed and burned in a rice field on an army base near Manila today, killing at least six people and injuring 16, officials said. The twin-engine, propeller plane narrowly missed a row of houses for soldiers and their families at Fort Bonifacio, headquarters of the Philippine army and located in the Manila suburb of Makati. Officials said all of the dead and injured were aboard the plane, which burst into flames after the crash. The plane, owned by Manila Air Transport System, was carrying 22 passengers and crew members. The company said it would issue no statement on the crash pending an investigation. Diosdado Santarin, a spokesman for the Manila airport emergency services department, said the plane had just taken off for Roxas, 250 miles to the south, when the pilot reported engine trouble. Jaime Cruz, manager of the emergency services department, said pilot Anastacio Maravilla tried to ditch the plane in a rice field near the fort's Heroes' Cemetery but the right wing struck an electricity post. The plane then slammed out of control into the field, Cruz said. Survivors scurried from the wreckage before it exploded in flames, he added. Officials said the dead were charred beyond recognition and included a 2-year-old boy. Cruz said the plane crushed a bicycle-driven cab, but the driver and his passenger were able to run away before impact. Maravilla, who suffered minor injuries, told radio station DZBB his left engine began losing power seconds after takeoff. He said the plane was losing altitude so fast that he decided he could not make it back to the airport. Pacita Sarte, 32, the passenger who abandoned the cab, said the plane was so low that she could hear passengers screaming in terror. ``It's normal to see planes come and go in the area, even low-flying ones,'' said the cab driver, Reynaldo Portuguez. ``But I knew the plane was in trouble when I saw one of its engines smoking.''

DOC.HEAD: Bronx President Burned Up Over `Bonfire' Filming
DOC.TEXT: The Bronx is getting burned by Hollywood's portrayal of the New York City borough in the film ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' the borough president says. ``The city and this borough do not have an obligation to help a company make a motion picture that goes out of its way to denigrate the Bronx,'' Borough President Fernando Ferrer told reporters Wednesday. The Warner Bros. film, now in production, is based on Tom Wolfe's scathing best seller of the same name, which tells the story of a high-powered Wall Street executive who becomes entangled in the city's Kafkaesque court system. Parts of the film, which features Tom Hanks, Bruce Willis and Morgan Freeman, were shot at the Bronx County Courthouse. Ferrer asked Warner Bros. to run a 55-word statement at the end of the film stressing the borough's positive aspects and ending with the words: ``Bronx neighborhoods are home to cultural institutions attracting more than 2,000,000 visitors a year.'' In response, Warner Bros. offered to run this statement: ``This film is a work of fiction and is not intended to reflect actual events or conditions in the localities portrayed.'' Ferrer claims the film company also offered to donate $10,000 to the charity of Ferrer's choice. ``I not only find that offer strange, but frankly bordering on the improper,'' the borough president said. The Mayor's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting said the idea for the contribution had come from Ferrer's office, but Ferrer said the idea came from either that citywide office or Warner Bros. Fred Caruso, the film's co-producer, said the charity donation ``was not something generated or offered by us.'' One of the scenes Ferrar found objectionable was between two Bronx district attorneys: ``He pulled a knife on a 70-year-old lady, robbed her, raped her and then shoved her in a garbage can,'' one says. ``Jesus,'' the other replies. ``Welcome to the South Bronx,'' laughs the first one. Said Caruso: ``The movie is not derogatory toward the Bronx, nor is it a racist film.'' Ferrer's criticism was reminiscent of a furor raised over the 1981 film, ``Fort Apache: The Bronx.'' That film triggered protests and a boycott. Ferrer suggested a similar boycott might be warranted against ``Bonfire.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Mark Chernobyl Anniversary With Protests, Strike, Telethon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with today's protests, strike, new figures for telethon, background and detail, new quotes. No pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: After years of state-encouraged passivity, Soviets today marked the fourth anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster with widespread protests, a 24-hour telethon and a strike at a major factory. It was the biggest national commemoration yet of the 1986 tragedy, the world's worst nuclear power acccident. ``We have been silent too long,'' said a reporter on the TV news program Vremya, which focused its afternoon show on Chernobyl reports. Officially, 31 people were killed when one of four reactors at Chernobyl caught fire and exploded on April 26, 1986, about 90 miles north of Kiev in the Soviet Ukraine. Unofficial reports say at least 250 died. The blast spewed radioactive cesium, strontium and plutonium isotopes across much of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. For the first two days after the accident, the Soviet Union refused to report it to the outside world and withheld information from its own people. Only last year did officials admit the full scope of the contamination and decide to resettle 100,000 more people. The official willingness to play up the Chernobyl anniversary today appeared to reflect both the growing awareness of the catastrophe's aftermath and the pro-democracy views of many newly elected local governing councils. Residents in the southwestern Soviet regions most contaminated by the blast organized protests to demand better medical treatment, protection from radiation and punishment for the officials who covered up the accident's effects, activists said. In the Byelorussian city of Gomel, most of the 35,000 workers of the GomselMash industrial complex walked out on a daylong strike, said Alexander Korniev, a plant worker. Strikers were demanding better medical care and wanted all officials who participated in the cover-up brought to trial, he said. The Chernobyl Telethon, one of the Soviet Union's first experiences with television fundraising, collected $38 million, organizers announced. The live broadcast, originating in Moscow, interspersed singing groups and interviews with tragic footage showing Chernobyl rescuers and children in the contaminated zone suffering from radiation-caused cancers. Along with money, pledges to the telethon center included donations of radiation-free fruit and even 1,100 pounds of honey for children in the contaminated area. CNN showed live scenes of the telethon to American viewers. Many of the donations came from the United States, Japan and Western Europe, the Soviet news agency Tass said. The Ukrainian legislature declared today ``Chernobyl Tragedy Day'' and its Byelorussian counterpart passed a similar measure. Other government bodies in the affected areas sanctioned widespread demonstrations. On the eve of the anniversary, the Soviet legislature adopted a $26 billion program that would involve resettling an additional 200,000 people from irradiated areas. The program was adopted Wednesday even though many members of the legislature, the Supreme Soviet, criticized it as inadequate to deal with the health, agricultural, economic and environmental aftermath of the accident. After a day of debate, including charges of an official cover-up of the disaster and bungled evacuations, legislators endorsed a program for dealing with Chernobyl from 1990-1992, Tass reported. About 180,000 to 200,000 people still living in contaminated areas four years after the accident are to be resettled. In the months after the accident, 116,000 people were evacuated, and some Soviet scientists and politicians have been campaigning since then for further resettlements. They say 4 million Soviets are living on contaminated land. The $26 billion is a major increase in spending on the Chernobyl aftermath. It is twice the level spent in the four years since the accident but still short of the $405 billion legislator Yuri Scherback has estimated is needed over the next 10 years. Many Chernobyl-area residents have complained of inadequate medical care and cases of anemia, leukemia and cancers have been reported rising among people living on irradiated land. Many residents still eat irradiated food because alternatives are not available. Dealing with the larger questions posed by Chernobyl, the Supreme Soviet directed the government to draft a bill on the use of nuclear energy and nuclear safety, and to phase out the Chernobyl power plant. The three reactors not involved in the accident are still operating. The Ukrainian legislature wants the plant closed by 1995. Several other nuclear power projects around the country were canceled because of the heightened safety concerns generated by the Chernobyl accident. Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union will not phase out nuclear energy altogether, but it will improve safety systems.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Killed, 120 Reported Wounded in Gaza Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with 120 Palestinians wounded, seven soldiers injured, worst uprising violence in nearly a year. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed two Palestinians and wounded about 120 today in the worst violence in the uprising in nearly a year, hospital officials and Arab witnesses said. The clash began as thousands of Moslem worshipers were passing an army base in the Gaza Strip en route to a cemetery for a religious holiday to honor the dead, witnesses said. An army spokesman who demanded anonymity said some of the Palestinians started to throw rocks and bottles at the soldiers. The soldiers, concerned about the potential danger to their lives, responded with tear gas and later various types of ammunition, the spokesman said. The army confirmed two Palestinians had been killed. It said about 50 Arabs and seven soldiers were injured by stones in the clash, which occurred on the Moslem holiday of Id al-Fitr that celebrates the end of the month of Ramadan. According to witnesses interviewed in Gaza City hospitals, the clash began as 4,000 Palestinians left two mosques after prayer services in the crowded Jabaliya refugee camp, where the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began more than 28 months ago. The army imposed a curfew on the camp of 53,000 residents and declared the entire Gaza Strip a closed military zone, a move that bars journalists from entering the area. Doctors said 61 gunshot victims were treated at Ahli hospital, 39 at Shifa hospital and 20 at U.N. clinics. More than 15 received injuries from rubber pellets or were beaten with nightsticks. Jorgen Rosendal of Denmark, administrator of Al Ahli Arab hospital, said it was the worst violence since three Palestinians were killed and about 50 wounded during the Id al-Fitr holiday on May 6, 1989. The casualties represented one of the largest tolls of wounded from a single incident since the uprising began and contrasted with the low level of conflict in recent months. An unemployed street vendor who was wounded in the right arm told a reporter that soldiers fired tear gas when crowds chanting ``Allahu Akbar!'' or ``God is great!'' approached a fenced-off army encampment en route to a cemetery to honor the dead in accordance with Moslem tradition. The vendor, who gave only his first name, Ahmad, and other witnesses said about 20 Israeli soldiers watching the crowd apparently became alarmed and fired tear gas. ``We were heading to visit our dead people and then they started shooting tear gas at us,'' Ahmad, 25, said. ``I think the army thought we wanted to attack them after they saw such huge crowds heading towards them. But if they hadn't fired tear gas nothing would have happened.'' After the tear gas was fired, Arab witnesses said scores of Palestinians hurled stones at the army camp. Then a dozen border police jeeps, several armored personnel carriers and a helicopter came to the help the soldiers. Army spokesmen in Tel Aviv said the crowds ``interfered'' with army activity but gave no details of why the soldiers started firing. They said senior officers were investigating. Killed in the clash were two camp residents: Awadallah Ibrahim Awadallh, 25, a laborer who was shot in the chest, and Khaled Musa Aswad, 35, a mosque prayer caller who was shot in the stomach. Today's deaths brought to 678 the number of Palestinians killed in clashes with Israelis since Dec. 8, 1987, when the uprising began against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In addition, 209 Palestinians have been killed by other Palestinians, most accused of collaborating with Israeli authorites. Forty-three Israelis have died in the clashes. Israel seized the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: With New Selection System, Ole Miss Picks First Black Student Editor
DOC.TEXT: A black student will run the University of Mississippi school newspaper for the first time. Lee Eric Smith was named editor Wednesday by a selection committee set up last month after protesting campus journalists complained that the traditional election process picked politicians _ not journalists. ``The accomplishment is I'm the first selected editor _ not that I'm the first black editor,'' Smith said Wednesday. Smith, 20, a junior journalism major from Holly Springs, was named editor of The Daily Mississippian over three other candidates, all of them white. He was chosen by a board of students, professional journalists and staff, said Samir Hussni, journalism professor and chairman of the selection board. For 50 years, the editor of the Daily Mississippian was elected, sometimes after spending hundreds of dollars on posters and fliers. Critics said fraternities and sororities controlled the annual elections, turning them into popularity contests. This year, the newspaper staff and other students launched a protest, including producing an edition containing the U.S. Constitution in place of the usual stories and another with several blank pages. Some students upset by the protest responded by scrawling obscenities on copies of the paper and scattering hundreds of issues across campus. But in March, the student government voted to do away with elections and create the selection committee. ``I'm happy that we selected the right person for the job,'' Husni said. ``He won by a large margin. The fact that he's black had nothing to do with it, but now it's a historic decision.'' About 10,000 students are enrolled at the antebellum campus, the site of race riots in 1962 after a court ordered that a black student be admitted. About 20 students work on the editorial side of the 10,000-circulation paper.

DOC.HEAD: Rioters Clash With Police in Southern Town: 4 Killed, 28 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas and birdshot today at a crowd of 2,000 people who rioted after officers blocked their traditional Moslem feast march. At least four people were killed and 28 wounded, police said. Maj. Gen. Mahmoud el-Fakharany, security chief for Assiut Province, said the riot occurred in the town of Manfalut, 25 miles northwest of Assiut, after morning prayers celebrating the feast. Police arrested 18O rioters. The provincial capital, Assiut, 235 miles south of Cairo, has been the scene of frequent violence by Moslem fundamentalist militants. They seek immediate implementation of Sharia, Islam's legal and ethical code which includes harsh criminal penalties. But el-Fakharany said the militants did not engineer today's disturbance. He said activist Islamic groups denounced the riot and denied involvement. ``Most of the rioters were drug addicts, thugs and unemployed people who were bent on troublemaking,'' el-Fakharany told The Associated Press. Today was the first day of Eid al-Fitr, also known as Bairam, which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan when Moslems fast from dawn to dusk. Security and civic authorities decided to prevent a street march this year because marchers previously had damaged shops and other property, el-Fakharany said. After Bairam prayers this morning, he said, about 2,000 people gathered in a square and prepared to march despite the ban. ``They did not heed police warnings to disperse and hurled stones and pieces of wood at security forces at first,'' el-Fakharany said. ``Then some people in the crowd shot at the forces with firearms they carried.'' He said police initially used tear gas ``but switched to plastic and then lead birdshot after rioters began using firearms. The crowd then dispersed.'' Police suffered no casualties, el-Fakharany said.

DOC.HEAD: LaFontaine Recovering from Stab Wound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD details on Lafontaine's condition, police resuming questioning of suspect, attack most serious on a West German politician, tightens and edits to conform. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DUS1
DOC.TEXT: Opposition politician Oskar Lafontaine was in satisfactory condition today, one day after being stabbed in the neck, and a party leader said Lafontaine would probably remain a candidate for chancellor. The Social Democrat, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's leading challenger in the December delection, lost a lot of blood in Wednesday's attack, but friends who visited him today said he was able to get out of bed and crack jokes. Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democratic Party chairman, said in an interview with Deutsche Welle Radio that Lafontaine intends to ``remain the chancellor candidate.'' Lafontaine, 46, the governor of tiny Saarland state, is one of West Germany's most colorful, acid-tongued, and popular politicians. He was rushed to the University Clinic of Cologne in critical condition after being stabbed with a butcher knife at a campaign rally by a woman who repotedly had a history of mental problems. The candidate underwent two hours of surgery late Wednesday. Doctors upgraded his condition overnight, and he awoke at 5 a.m. ``Considering the circumstances, his condition is satisfactory,'' said Dr. Heinz Pichlmaier, the head of the team of physicians treating Lafontaine. Vogel, who rushed to Cologne after the attack, said the knife missed a main artery by just a ``couple of milimeters.'' ``Otherwise, we would be mourning,'' he said. The knife cut a vein in Lafontaine's neck, but not one of the two carotid arteries that carry blood to the brain, said Joachim Hofmann-Goettig, a Saarland state spokesman. Hofmann-Goettig said that Lafontaine could be released from the hospital as early as this weekend, but added that it was too early to tell whether he would be able to challenge Kohl. ``We'll have to see how things go politically after he has completely recovered physically and psychologically,'' Hofmann-Goettig said. It was the most serious attack on a top-ranking politician in West Germany's 41-year history, and was likely to result in a review of security measures as the election campaign intensifies. Police this morning resumed questioning the woman arrested in the stabbing attack. Lafontaine was attacked near the close of campaign rally in Cologne at about 9 p.m. by the black-haired woman in a white dress who approached him on the dais seeking his autograph, witnesses and officials said. The woman stabbed Lafontaine with a butcher knife as he was about to sign a poetry album she presented him, police said. The ZDF television network said the knife had been concealed in a bouquet of flowers. The ARD television network showed Lafontaine lying on the floor as blood poured from his neck, with several people crowded around him trying to administer first aid. He was rushed by helicopter to the hospital. The motive for the attack was not immediately known. Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the federal prosecutor's office, said there was no evidence the woman had a ``terrorist background.'' She was identified as 42-year-old Adelheid Streidel of Bad Neuenahr, southwest of Bonn. News reports said she had a history of mental illness. After the attack, the woman sat impassively as a throng of policemen screamed at her ``Who are you? Who are you? Tell us your name! Say it!'' But the woman said she was refusing to make any statements, and police hustled her out of Stadthalle auditorium in suburban Muelheim, where about 2,000 people had gathered for the rally. ZDF said she was convicted of arson in 1986 and had been sent to a psychiatric institute. The Cologne newspaper Express said that she suffered from a ``persecution complex'' and quoted neighbors as saying she had repeatedly sought to obtain weapons to defend herself from men she thought were pursuing her. Reinhard Klimmt, the Social Democratic member of the Saarland state parliament, said after visiting Lafontaine that he was weak but ``mentally alert'' and cracking jokes. Vogel told colleagues Lafontaine had ``found his usual humor again.'' Lafontaine is known for making bold and brash political statments and has delighted in his role as a political gadfly. The outspoken politician, whose party trounced Kohl's Christian Democratic Union in state elections in January, has been considered a tough opponent for the December national elections.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Makes Emotional Visit To His Old Village
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela made an emotional pilgrimage today to the tiny village where he grew up, saying the poverty of rural blacks in South Africa makes his heart ``very sore indeed.'' The African National Congress leader greeted old friends, reminisced about his youth and tossed sand on the graves of his parents in a traditional act of reverence during a walk through Qunu, part of the Transkei homeland in South Africa. ``I have found many changes,'' said Mandela, released in February after 27 years in prison. ``Many villages which I see today were not here'' when I was growing up, and new roads have been built. Mandela paid a 15-minute visit Sunday to Qunu, his first since 1956. He spent several hours today speaking with virtually all of Qunu's 1,000 or so residents. The villagers slaughtered two oxen to celebrate Mandela's return. Qunu is a typical rural village in South Africa, made up of a few hundred mud-and-thatch huts and free roaming goats, chickens, sheep and cattle. Most of the residents are women, old men or children. Almost all of the men of working age have left the village for jobs in the cities or on the country's gold and coal mines. ``My heart becomes very sore indeed because the poverty that was here when I last visited this place, that poverty is still there staring me in the face,'' said Mandela, who once worked on the mines before becoming a lawyer. Mandela urged the children to do well in school and recalled that he failed classes one year in his early teens. ``I wasn't very bright then,'' he said. Mandela, smartly dressed in a suit and tie, said he wore only a sheepskin blanket to school to ward off the cold on winter days. The hut were Mandela grew up is no longer standing, and his closest relatives in Qunu are cousins. Mandela was accompanied today by his wife, Winnie, and two of his sisters who now live elsewhere. Mandela is the son of a chief of the royal Tembu clan of the Xhosa tribe. His father was adviser to the paramount chief and Mandela was raised as an aristocrat. Mandela, the ANC's deputy president, has spent all week in the southeastern homeland, one of 10 black tribal reserves in South Africa. The ANC opposes the existence of the homelands, which they see as an attempt to deny blacks political rights in South Africa. However, the organization has begun to work with several young homeland leaders who are sympathetic to the ANC and its idea of re-incorporating the territories into a united South Africa. Mandela will lead an 11-member ANC delegation in groundbreaking talks next week with the white-led government. The ANC wants an end to South Africa's system of racial separation and a one-person, one-vote system. Under apartheid, South Africa's 28 million black majority has no vote.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term Solutions Spell Long-Term Trouble For New President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th pvs, `Mrs. Chamorro...' with one graf to ADD dropped word ``not.'' Pickup 5th pvs, `The Sandinistas...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA3,4
An AP Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro may have stalled a Sandinista revolt by letting Gen. Humberto Ortega stay on as army chief, but the short-term solution to her problems spells long-term trouble for her new government. Two would-be Cabinet ministers have refused their posts and Contra rebels are reneging on a demobilization accord. The Contras last week signed an accord with Gen. Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition (UNO) to demobilize. But not a few laughed at the idea after Mrs. Chamorro received the presidential sash from Daniel Ortega on Wednesday. Mrs. Chamorro took over as defense minister, but that did not ease the anger over Gen. Ortega staying on. What the Contras want, says rebel chief Israel Galeano, is for the Sandinistas to relinquish all control of the military. The Sandinistas have warned of a renewed civil war if any attempts are made to alter the armed forces in any profound way. How Mrs. Chamorro and her government solve this deadlock will show whether they can deal with Nicaragua's complicated problems. Mrs. Chamorro's decision to stick to an agreement last month that effectively allows the Sandinistas to keep control of the armed forces has heightened the political split in the country. Mrs. Chamorro has been trying to close that chasm with calls for reconciliation. But for either the Contras or the Sandinistas to give up their weapons would be tantamount to surrender, and both sides claim military victory in the 9-year-old civil war. Observers were surprised last week when the Contras, who had said they would only negotiate demobilization with Mrs. Chamorro once she was in power, signed an accord less than 24 hours later to lay down their weapons. What was more surprising was that they did so without imposing any conditions. That led to speculation that there had to be some sort of secret pact between UNO and the Contras. Many of the estimated 9,000 rebel fighters inside Nicaragua have begun streaming into five security zones staffed by a 700-member U.N. peacekeeping force. The rebels are to give up their weapons voluntarily. Once they do that, they can begin receiving food and medical supplies from a mission of the Organization of American States. Many Contras interviewed in the countryside have said they are indeed tired of fighting and want to go home. Others reportedly have staged a rash of highway robberies, and the new government may find its hinterland controlled by small bands of rebels-turned-bandits. The thieving probably will increase if the rebels have to continue living off ever more skeptical peasants. ``Ortega! Ortega! The weapons will not be handed over!'' was one of the chants that greeted Daniel Ortega as he walked into a baseball stadium for his last act as president _ turning over power to Mrs. Chamorro. The chant by an unruly Sandinista crowd was a telling sign: Weapons mean power for the Sandinista Front, which brooked little opposition during its decade of rule after forging itself on the premise of armed revolution. And as long as the Sandinista armed forces remain intact, Nicaraguans _ long inured to dictatorships propped up by control of the army _ understand that they retain the real power. That power is constitutionally vested in the executive office but can rise against the president at any time. It is a lesson deeply ingrained in Latin American politics. It also is something the Contras have warned about and brandished as one more reason for their reluctance to disarm. UNO members also are angry over Gen. Ortega staying on. ``We campaigned throughout the countryside during the elections without money, without anything,'' said Jaime Cuadra, explaining Tuesday night at an UNO Cabinet meeting why he rejected his appointment as agriculture minister. ``We told those peasants that once UNO won the elections, we would get rid of all the Sandinistas. Now, how am I going to look all those peasants if I take a post in the government and Humberto is still there?'' Cuadra is president of the Matagalpa Coffee Planters Association, a group of 260 private farmers in Nicaragua's heartland. He once was jailed by dictator Anastasio Somoza for smuggling guns for the Sandinistas. Now he refuses to have anything to do with them. Gilberto Cuadra, president of Nicaragua's most influential private business group, the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, also rejected his appointment as construction and transportation minister. The men _ who are not related _ are influential, both inside the country and among Nicaragua's exiles. While others were appointed in their place Wednesday night, their dissatisfaction is bound to find ready audiences. At a party celebrating the change of government, UNO revelers chanted ``Humberto Must Go!'' Vice President Virgilio Godoy, a strong Sandinista critic, was at the party at the lakeside Plaza of the Revolution. Asked about Mrs. Chamorro's decision on Gen. Ortega, Godoy said: ``Tonight we're celebrating. We'll get back to work tomorrow.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Doralisa Pilarte has been the AP correspondent in Managua since 1989, reporting on Nicaragua and Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Asked To Form Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for grafs 7-8 pvs, `Peres told...' to UPDATE with details, background. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Israeli newspapers...'
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog today invited right-wing leader Yitzhak Shamir to try to form a new government after Labor Party leader Shimon Peres failed to do so, officials said. The president's office said Peres informed Herzog he had been unable to break a deadlock in the Knesset, or parliament, and Herzog asked Shamir to come to his residence. ``I am unable to establish a government based on a majority, and I am therefore returning the mandate,'' Peres said in a letter to Herzog, according to a spokesman who demanded anonymity. It was the first time in Israel's 42-year history that a candidate selected by the president has failed to form a government. The 66-year-old Peres was assigned the task of putting together a new coalition five weeks ago after Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, lost a parliament vote of no confidence on March 15. The vote was triggered by Peres' demand that Shamir accept U.S. terms for convening Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo. Shamir declined, saying he needed more time. Peres spent 35 days trying to forge an alliance that included both ultra-Orthodox religious parties and small left-wing factions. He gave up the effort only hours before a midnight (6 p.m. EDT) deadline set by the president. Peres predicted Shamir also would fail to form a coalition in the deadlocked parliament. But he warned that if Shamir succeeded, he would create ``an extremist right-wing government the like of which Israel never had.'' In an earlier radio interview Thursday, Peres blamed the opposition of leading rabbis for the failure of his effort. He said two small religious parties ``changed direction'' after Rabbi Eliezer Shach, 96, condemned the secular groups that back Labor . Peres indicated he had no chances left after a prospective Likud defector, Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai, rejected Labor's offers. His decision to stay with Likud left Peres with only 60 supporters in the 120-seat parliament. Israeli newspapers said intensive efforts were under way in Likud to win back Avraham Sharir, a former tourism minister who defected to Labor.
