Shamir will have 21 days to form a coalition and a possible extension of an additional 21 days. Peres was given a 15-day extension on April 11 after his initial 21-day mandate expired. The Yediot Ahronot daily said Likud hoped to muster a majority of 65 within several days. That majority would include extreme right-wing factions and ultra-Orthodox religious parties.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Link Chemical Weapons Accord to Halt in U.S. Production
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Soviet negotiators today ended their latest round of talks on chemical weapons, and the Soviets said there would be no accord on destroying stockpiles unless the United States agrees to halt production. Both sides said, however, that they hoped a draft accord could be signed at the Washington summit between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The agreement, already reached in principle, would reduce superpower stockpiles to 5,000 tons each, following up on a proposal first submitted by Bush in a speech to the U.N. General Assembly last year. The United States says that by taking the lead in destruction, the superpowers would give new impetus to the multilateral talks on a chemical weapons ban in the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament. U.S. chief negotiator Stephen Ledogar told the Geneva Conference on Tuesday that such an accord would reduce the U.S. stockpile to roughly 20 percent of the current level. It would mean that the U.S. total, never officially disclosed up to now, would be about 25,000 to 30,000 tons. The Soviet Union has announced it has 50,000 tons, a figure U.S. experts have said was below the actual size. Speaking to reporters, Ledogar's Soviet counterpart, Serguei Batsanov, said it was ``vital'' for Moscow that the bilateral accord on destruction include a U.S. commitment to stop the chemical weapons modernization program approved by Congress in 1985 after production had been suspended for 16 years. The Soviet Union continued to build up its capability until 1987. Batsanov said continuation of U.S. production could force the Soviet Union to reconsider its 1987 decision. Inclusion of a U.S. commitment in the accord ``is a very important position for the Soviet side,'' he said. ``It is a vital position,'' he added. ``I cannot imagine that we would agree to any bilateral accord that would not include that commitment.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Eviction Of Settlers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld an eviction order against 150 Jewish settlers who occupied a complex owned by the Greek Orthodox Church in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. The settlers, who moved into St. John's Hospice on April 11, must leave the 72-room complex near the Church of the Holy Sepulchre by Tuesday, said Chief Justice Meir Shamgar, reading the ruling by a three-judge panel. The judges said the Panama-based company, SBC, that subleased St. John's Hospice to the settlers could keep up to 20 guards and maintenance employees there until the tenancy dispute was settled by a lower court. The Jewish settlement provoked deep anger among clerics and Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem.The State Department called the settlement, which came during Easter Week, ``an insensitive and provocative act.'' Adding to the anger was the admission by the government, after repeated denials, that it had provided $1.8 million of the money for the settlement. The admission brought protests from American pro-Israeli and Jewish groups. During arguments today, the Justice Ministry contended that the continued presence of the settlers would inflame Arabs and provoke violence. ``Every event in the area has influence on the fabric of relations, problematic these days, between members of different religions and faiths,'' argued the ministry's representative, Nili Arad. She told the three-justice panel that the settlement site ``is a very sensitive place...both sides recognize there has been a disturbance of the peace.'' Avraham Socholovsky, an attorney for the Greek Orthodox Church which owns the compound, accused the settlers of provocative behavior. The group had entered the building with weapons, he said. ``It was like an occupation. Is this what they call subletting?.'' The Old City, captured from Jordan during the 1967 Middle East war, is divided into Moslem, Christian, Jewish and Armenian quarters. Each group jealously guards its sector, which contains holy sites and shrines, and the slighest changes in the status quo have historically led to violence. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said the settlement brought ``horrible damage to Jerusalem'' by heightening tensions between the religious communities. In an unprecedented move, leaders of 10 major Christian sects said they would close all Christian shrines in the Holy Land on Friday in protest. City officials had said they hoped a Supreme Court decision upholding the eviction orders would ease the tensions and prompt Christian leaders to call off the demonstration. The eviction would be the first time that settlers have been forced out of homes in occupied areas since April 1982, when the army oversaw the evacuation of 300 settlers from Yamit in the Sinai Desert. The Sinai was returned to Egypt under the 1979 peace treaty. The Jerusalem settlers claimed they had subleased the four-building complex from an Armenian Christian tenant. The Greek Orthodox Church contends the lease is illegal. Two lower courts upheld the church's claim and ordered the Jews out. The settlers have argued they were upholding the rights of Jews to live anywhere in Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Venezuelan President
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with presidents' arrival statements; picks up 4th graf pvs, A senior...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave a warm welcome to Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez today, praising him for restoring his country's economic health and for his struggle on behalf of democracy in Nicaragua. ``This is a time to celebrate,'' said Bush noting that Perez had come here after attending the inaugural Wednesday of Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro. With the Venezuelan leader standing at his side during an arrival ceremony on the White House south lawn, Bush said the political evolution in Nicaragua came about in part because Perez's ``deep personal commitment to the advance of democracy never wavered.'' Discussing Perez's economic policies, Bush said they have brought some pain to the Venezuelan people but at the same time have laid the foundation for future growth. Perez, in turn, said that Latin American nations are determined to modernize their institutions but complained that they don't always get ``understanding and encouragement'' from the industrialized democracies. He added that Latin America is now in a position to help shape a world of ``peaceful neighborliness.'' Perez was to be guest of honor tonight at a White House dinner after his morning meeting with Bush and a luncheon hosted by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. A senior U.S. official who briefed reporters Tuesday on condition of anonymity said Perez has shown courage in sticking to an austerity program in the face of enormous domestic opposition. ``It's a model for how a democracy can change an economy,'' the official said, asserting that Perez virtually had to decree a recession in order to get ``over the hump of economic reform.'' Perez imposed his austerity program after riots erupted about three months after he took office at the end of 1988. The U.S. official said Perez is a far different president this time compared with his initial term in office between 1974 and 1979 when he was far more supportive of a dominant state role in the economy. His ``shock program,'' among other benefits, has improved export performance and reduced inflation, the U.S. official said. The official said the short-term consequences of austerity are serious in terms of unemployment but the medium- to long-term effects are worse if nothing is done. ``If you do it right, if you make your country competitive, then at one point ... you've got a country that's not only competitive, the industries begin to work more efficiently and the standard of living goes up,'' the official said. One example of creditor confidence in Perez's economic policies was demonstrated last month when Venezuela and the banks that have lent it money reached agreement in principle on reducing the country's $20 billion debt to those banks. Final agreement is expected in July. Venezuela has an overall foreign debt of $37 billion, the fourth largest in Latin America. It has fallen behind on interest and principal payments in recent years. Perez will host a luncheon Friday in honor of the members of the international banking community.

DOC.HEAD: Standoff Ends with Suspect Dead, FBI Agent Grazed, Cocaine Seized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with gunman found dead in house, cocaine seized from cars leaving house, four arrests. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Drug agents raided a suburban house after finding 400 pounds of cocaine in cars leaving the building, sparking a shootout that left one suspect dead and an FBI agent slightly wounded, police said today. After trying for more than five hours to negotiate with a man believed holed up inside the suburban home, Metro-Dade police and FBI agents moved inside this morning and found the man dead. Police initially said the Wednesday evening shootout involved an arms deal, but spokesman Don Blocker said today that was incorrect, that the incident involved drugs. The house had been under surveillance before the shooting. Early Wednesday evening, three men who left the home in one car were arrested when they started unloading 286 pounds of cocaine at another location. Later, a fourth man in another car was stopped and 100 pounds of cocaine was found. The agents then obtained a search warrant and tried to enter the house, said Metro-Dade spokeswoman Myriam Royle. Shots were fired and an FBI agent was grazed by a bullet on his right side, she said. The agent, whose name was not released, was treated and released at Jackson Memorial Hospital, said FBI spokesman Paul Miller. After the agent was shot, a Metro-Dade officer who was stationed at the back of the house shot at a man who tried to flee. The man, armed with an automatic weapon, fled back inside the house. Police cordoned off a 20-block area, made repeated attempts to talk to anyone inside the house and lobbed tear gas shells inside without response, police said. Five hours after the shooting, officers moved inside and found the man dead. His name was not immediately released. The four men arrested on cocaine trafficking charges were Rene Vasquez, 42, Luis Antonio Sastre, 69, Antonio Sastre, 28, and Bernardo Maria Ahumada, 21.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania to Impose Some Food Rationing
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian lawmakers decided today to impose food rationing on May 1 as the rebellious republic continued to struggle under an economic blockade that has reduced its supplies of fuel and medicine. Lithuania widened efforts to circumvent sanctions imposed last week by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who wants Lithuania to rescind laws designed to implement its March 11 declaration of independence. A Lithuanian delegation was due in the northern Russian city of Leningrad on Friday to talk with local officials about a direct exchange of goods either for hard currency or barter, a Leningrad journalist said. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene announced Wednesday that Lithuania had halted its usual supplies of meat, milk and other food products to the rest of the Soviet Union. She instead urged Lithuania to settle its accounts with the republics ``almost in marketplace conditions'' of bartering for other goods. Gorbachev, visiting the central Russian city of Sverdlovsk, was asked by citizens why he had refused to open negotiations with the Lithuanian leadership, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. He replied that the Kremlin only negotiates with foreign governments, not its own republics. Rita Dapkus, a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian parliament, or Supreme Council, said lawmakers decided to ration some food products beginning May 1, although no details were released. Unlike most Soviet republics, Lithuania produces all the meat and dairy goods it needs, so the rationing presumably would be of those foodstuffs it does not produce, or of meat and milk products earmarked for export. Gasoline already is being rationed in the republic of 3.8 million people, since Gorbachev cut off its oil and curtailed natural gas deliveries by more than 80 percent. Individuals are limited to 7.8 gallons of gasoline per month. The Supreme Council on Wednesday also endowed its Council of Ministers with broad control over the economy and local governments during the period of the embargo, Ms. Dapkus said. The powers include the ability to change supply plans, transfer workers to different jobs, and use natural and financial resources in a centralized manner, she said. Effects of the embargo mounted. Hospitals, running low on medicine, discouraged all but emergency surgery, Radio Vilnius reported. In addition, newspapers prepared to cut back the size of their editions by as much as half. Prunskiene said Lithuania wanted to start immediate trade negotiations with sympathetic groups in Moscow, Leningrad, the oil-rich Tyumen region of Siberia and the Ukrainian city of Lvov, according to Ms. Sinnig. Even if Lithuania struck such deals, however, transporting the goods would be difficult, because Moscow controls the train, truck routes and pipelines throughout the nation. The Kremlin began cutting off natural gas, oil and other supplies to Lithuania one week ago, stepping up pressure on the Baltic republic's leaders to reverse their drive for independence. Lithuania, forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia, declared independence on March 11. Lithuanian Deputy Prime Minister Algirdas Brazauskas estimated the republic's oil reserves would last until May 20. The Soviet Union is Lithuania's sole supplier of fuel. Other shortages of grain, sugar, salt and margarine have been noted, and Soviet supplies of wood products also have been reportedly cut off.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Beginning Aerial Spraying to Eradicate Medfly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with spraying beginning after delay caused by equipment problems. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The target...'. Subs 10th graf pvs, ``There are no,'' to delete redundant first reference to Habeck.
DOC.TEXT: Aerial pesticide spraying to attack an infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies in one southern Florida county began today after a three-hour delay caused by equipment problems. A helicopter loaded with syrupy insect bait spiked with the pesticide malathion took off at midmorning for up to seven hours of spraying over parts of Dade County, said Phyllis Habeck, spokeswoman for the eradication task force in Miami. The helicopter had been airborne shortly after sunrise but quickly returned after spray nozzles clogged, she said. Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner ordered the spraying in Dade County to protect Florida's $1.4 billion citrus industry. In Southern California, which is also waging a battle against the pest, a federal judge ruled Wednesday that malathion spraying to eradicate the Medfly does not violate environmental, aviation or pesticide laws. U.S. District Judge Alicemarie Stotler said the cities of Azusa and Alhambra, which sued to stop the spraying, should have sought action instead by the Federal Aviation Administration or the Environmental Protection Agency. Deputy Attorney General Charles Getz said the Medfly infestation was declared a state emergency, thus eliminating any need for approval from the cities. In Florida, the spraying that began this morning was to cover a 16-square-mile area near Miami International Airport. In about a month, millions of sterile Medflies will be released to foul up the pest's breeding cyle. The target area will be covered with pesticide in a concentration of 2.4 ounces, or about three tablespoons, of malathion per acre. That compares with 3.1 ounces of malathion per acre routinely sprayed throughout Florida to control mosquitoes. The female Medfly found Tuesday in a Port Everglades back yard trap brought to 10 the number of Medflies discovered in South Florida in as many days. Officials were hopeful that the Medfly in Broward County, just north of Dade, did not signal an outbreak but was ``a lone hitchhiker.'' The other Medflies were found in Dade County. There are no plans to spray Broward County, said Habeck of the eradication task force. A quarantine went into effect Wednesday for an estimated 100-square-mile area, including parts of Miami Springs, Hialeah and sections of unincorporated Miami. The quarantine means most produce won't be allowed out of the area until inspected. Medflies could strike a harsh blow to Florida's citrus industry, which was crippled by a Christmas freeze. Medfly larvae hatch inside more than 250 varieties of fruits and vegetables, turning them into mush. Environmentalists in California and here have objected to use of malathion, contending too little is known about the chemical's long-term health effects. In Southern California, where the Medfly has spread into orange and grapefruit groves in some of the region's richest farmland, aerial spraying of malathion in suburban neighborhoods has caused an uproar. Following the court ruling Wednesday, attorneys for Azusa and Alhambra said they would seek a court order forcing the FAA to prohibit the helicopter sprayings, which have occurred on almost a nightly basis over more than 400 square miles in Southern California since July.

DOC.HEAD: Heated Talk About Monetary Union in Forefront
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany called on his countrymen today to stop complaining that a proposed monetary union with West Germany treats them unfairly. De Maiziere's comments in Parliament followed agreement on a basic 1-1 exchange rate of the strong West German mark for the faltering East German currency for wages, pensions and savings up to $2,300. East Germans across the country have rushed to their banks to withdraw savings above that level, which would be exchanged at two East marks for one West mark under the proposal. De Maiziere's government is trying to raise the 1-1 exchange level above the $2,300 limit, and he said his countrymen should keep their money in the bank until the issue has been resolved. ``We have already made achievements in that area, considering there is now a willingness to exchange wages at 1-1 in a country where until now there was a rate of 1-4.65 _ not to mention the black market rates,'' he said. Black market exchange rates shortly before the country's first free elections March 18 were as high as eight East marks for one West German mark. Commenting on charges that the monetary proposal makes East Germans second-class citizens, de Maiziere said: ``Until now we have been third or fourth class.'' De Maiziere refused to discuss monetary union in detail, saying it could disturb negotiations between the two Germanys that began Wednesday. About 1,000 farmers and foresters gathered outside the Parliament building to demand protective measures after unification, fearful of how they will fare in a market economy when some state subsidies are scrapped. A delegation of protesters met briefly with Agricultural Minister Peter Pollack. In Bonn, the leader of West Germany's central bank today said he could not rule out a tax increase to finance unification with East Germany. ``We cannot simply discount a tax increase out of hand,'' Bundesbank President Karl Otto Pohl told a banking conference in Bonn, but he added that all other options for financing the union would be tried first. A target date of July 2 has been set for monetary, economic and social union between the two Germanys. Political union is to take place after all-German elections, which West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl would like to see by the end of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook To Produce Electricity This Week
DOC.TEXT: Nuclear-generated electricity produced by the long-delayed, $6.5 billion Seabrook nuclear power plant will flow to consumers briefly this weekend for the first time, plant officials said. Workers are expected to open valves directing steam to the plant's huge turbine-generator when the plant reaches about 10 percent of its operating capacity, said Edward Brown, president of New Hampshire Yankee. The plant has generated electricity briefly before, but with steam generated by the friction of water rushing through a piping system, not from nuclear power. The plant has been conducting tests and operating at low power since receiving its federal operating license last month after a years-long battle with critics who questioned its safety. The reactor previously was taken to 10 percent power without generating electricity. Plant spokesman Ron Sher said today that the electricity will flow into the New England power network. He said the generation would last for a few minutes, and then longer periods would follow, perhaps also during the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: New York Court Awards America's Cup To San Diego
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with Fay saying he accepted decision, add detail, recast. ADDS byline. Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: New York's top court today awarded the America's Cup to the San Diego Yacht Club, ruling that the club legally won yacht racing's most coveted prize and that sportsmanship was none of the court's business to decide. Possession of the trophy, which was fought for as hard in the courts as on the water, is worth millions of dollars to the host community during cup defenses. The 5-2 ruling by New York's Court of Appeals ends a legal battle for the 139-year-old silver trophy that began even before the San Diego Yacht Club's speedy catamaran trounced the huge single-hulled yacht from New Zealand's Mercury Bay Club in September 1988. ``The question of whether particular conduct is `sporting' or `fair' ... is wholly distinct from the question of whether it is legal,'' said Judge Fritz Alexander, writing for the court majority. According to the America's Cup Deed of Trust, a 19th century document, the New York Court of Appeals is the final arbiter of cup disputes. Challenger Michael Fay, in a statement this morning from Auckland, New Zealand, said ``the ruling is final and we accept it.'' He said he looked forward to another race in 1992. The catamaran Stars and Stripes, with Dennis Conner captain, easily defeated Mercury Bay's yacht New Zealand in two match races in the Pacific Ocean just off San Diego in 1988. The legal battle had begun the previous year. In February 1987, Conner's San Diego club had won the cup back from Australia, avenging a loss four years earlier when the Aussies became the first racers from outside the United States to take possession of the cup. Then, five months later, Fay issued an unwelcome challenge to the San Diegans, calling for a radical departure from the traditional America's Cup format. He wanted the race held in 1988 instead of waiting four years until 1991, and he wanted to use a boat roughly twice the size as the 12-meter yachts that had been in use in recent years. San Diego rejected the challenge but lost in the first round of court battles. The club then made a countermove, deciding to use a twin-hulled catameran, which is far faster and more manueverable that a large single-hulled yacht. That led to the one-sided victory in the race in 1988 that was upheld today. Fay had complained that by using the catamaran, San Diego made a farce of the race and broke rules of sportsmanship. In fact, the disparity between the two crafts was so large that Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, during court arguments in February, said racing a monohull against a catamaran was ``like putting a New York City bus against a Ferrari.'' While there have been disputes over the America's Cup in the past, this was the first to reach New York's highest court. Lower state courts had split on the question of who deserved the cup. In March 1989, state Supreme Court Justice Carmen Ciparick disqualified Conner and awarded the trophy to Mercury Bay. But a midlevel New York appeals court reversed that decision in September and returned the trophy to San Diego. In a 31-page dissent to today's opionion, Judge Stewart Hancock Jr. said that San Diego had a higher obligation to attempt to make the race a fair match because the yacht club was the defender of the cup and therefore its trustee.

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Preschool Building Sold
DOC.TEXT: The building that housed the McMartin preschool, scene of child abuse charges leading to the longest criminal trial in U.S. history, has been purchased by a developer who wants to tear it down. ``Who needs that monument anymore?'' said Arnold Goldstein, a real estate broker who bought the property from Danny Davis, the lawyer for McMartin defendant Raymond Buckey. Goldstein said Wednesday he wants to build a three-story office building. He paid Davis $320,000 for the school on Feb. 6, Los Angeles County records show. Davis said he acquired the property in lieu of a legal fee. The McMartin case began in 1983 when a parent told police that her child had been molested at the preschool. Other parents echoed the allegations. In January, after court proceedings that lasted more than five years, a jury acquitted Peggy McMartin Buckey. Her son was acquitted of all but 13 counts. He is being retried on some counts. Manhattan Beach is a seaside suburb about 20 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Steele, Ala., Plant Kills One, Injures Eight
DOC.TEXT: One of nine people injured in an explosion at an aluminum recycling plant died today, and the plant manager suggested that a foreign material in the scrap metal caused the explosion. The explosion Wednesday at the Culp Smelting and Refining Co. occurred just after workers put a compressed bundle of aluminum into the main furnace, said plant manager Bob Pine. The bales of industrial aluminum sheets are melted into ingots to be used in manufacturing automobiles and other products. ``There appeared to be some foreign item of material that was in with scrap aluminum,'' he said, but he added that he could only speculate about the possible cause of the blast. Pine said Wednesday's blast followed a smaller explosion Tuesday night in the same smelting area that injured one worker and other, less serious blasts. He said an investigation was under way to determine the supplier of the aluminum bundle. John Hall of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which has begun an investigation, said that such a blast could occur if scrap material containing water was lowered into the furnace. ``Anything could get into the metal,'' he said. He said it is too early to tell exactly what caused the blast and that that it might take OSHA several weeks to make a determination. The explosion, which was felt 10 miles away in Rainbow City, blew apart the furnace and part of the building. One of those injured, Jeffrey Howell, 23, of Gadsden, died today at University Hospital at Birmingham. Hospital spokesman Hank Black said Howell was burned over 90 percent of his body. Two other workers remained in intensive care but their condition was upgraded from critical to serious, Black said. Six other employees were treated and released for minor injuries. Culp Smelting employs 100 people and handles 6 million pounds of scrap aluminum a month.

DOC.HEAD: Etonians (Finally) Can Wear Jeans Outside School
DOC.TEXT: Eton College, the breeding ground of the British establishment, has bowed to modern times by allowing the youths to go into town wearing jeans and open-necked shirts. But if they look scruffy the concession may be withdrawn, headmaster Eric Anderson ruled. Until now, the exclusive 550-year-old prep school west of London required boys crossing the single bridge into the neighboring town of Windsor to wear dress trousers, jackets and ties. The change was recommended by a committee of teachers and senior pupils, said a statement issued Thursday. ``We try to keep a balance between comfort and looking respectable. If the more informal rules for Windsor result in scruffiness, we shall review them again,'' Anderson said. ``But I suppose you could say that we want to retain our traditional uniform at work but to be in tune with the times when relaxing.'' Eton has 1,260 pupils, all boys. The statement said there was no change in the rule requiring boys to wear tail coats and striped trousers in the classroom.

DOC.HEAD: 34 Killed in Stampede to Get Free Clothes
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of poor women and children stampeded to reach a building where free clothes were being distributed Thursday, and police said at least 34 people were killed and 20 injured in the crush. About 8,000 people had gathered at a factory in the southern port city of Chittagong for the giveaway, said police officials reached by telephone from Dhaka. It was organized to mark the end of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan. People broke open the steel gate of the factory and began running down a narrow passageway to reach the building where the clothes were being given out, police said. Many people were trampled after they tripped and fell, police said. A senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, blamed the stampede on ``mismanagement'' and said the incident would be investigated. Bangladesh, a predominantly Moslem nation, is one of the world's poorest. The average income among its 110 million people is $160 per year.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sailor Jailed in What Officials Call Unprecedented Case
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. sailor began serving a 60-day sentence Thursday for injuring and insulting two Filipino reporters in what officials said was the first case of an American serviceman being jailed here. Prosecutor Dorentino Floresta said Michael Carpaneto, a crewman on the USS Midway, was taken to the Olongapo city jail three weeks after a court convicted him of the charges. No hometown was given for the 27-year-old sailor. Olongapo is the home of the U.S. Navy's Subic Bay base. Floresta said that since 1980, 95 percent of the complaints lodged against U.S. military personnel in Olongapo were dismissed before reaching trial. Of those cases that went to trial, only 1 percent ended in conviction. In those cases, Americans opted to serve sentences in the U.S. Navy brig or were sent out of the country, the prosecutor said. ``This is unprecedented,'' Floresta said of Carpaneto's case. Subic Bay is among six U.S. military installations in the Philippines on a lease that expires in September 1991. Manila and Washington are to begin talks in May on whether to extend the agreement. Opponents of the bases have complained that U.S. personnel involved in crimes against Filipinos escape prosecution or arrest because American authorities intercede on their behalf. Carpaneto was accused of punching and shouting profanities at two Filipino reporters during an altercation last year. The two Filipinos refused a $50 out-of-court settlement and hired a lawyer to pursue the case. After nearly a year's delay, Carpaneto was convicted April 4. He was sentenced to 60 days in jail and ordered to pay damages of more than $1,700 to the plaintiffs.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Proposes Prosecuting Officials For Not Warning About Chernobyl
With AM-Chernobyl, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A hospital has suggested that top Communist Party and government officials be prosecuted for failing to take measures to reduce the impact of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, a newspaper said Thursday. The daily Mlada Fronta said the proposal was made by the staff of a hospital in Novy Jicin, 156 miles southeast of Prague. The newspaper also published an open letter by the daily's editor in chief, Libor Sevcik, to prosecutors. He accused authorities of official silence and inaction in the wake of the Chernobyl accident, which occurred one year ago Thursday. ``Unknown offenders have exposed several million inhabitants of this country to danger by not fulfilling their duties ... and by doing nothing ... to protect the lives and health of the inhabitants,'' the letter said. Official reports say 31 people were killed when one of the four reactors at the Chernobyl plant in the Soviet Ukraine caught fire and exploded April 26, 1986. Unofficial reports say 250 people died as a result of the accident. The blast spewed cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. After the catastrophe, Czechoslovak authorities failed to warn people about possible dangers. ``While all top representatives of the ruling Communist Party were informed and were eating clean food imported from abroad for hard currency, the uninformed mothers were exposing their infants to the danger of the radioactive fallout, feeding them contaminated food,'' the letter said. Meanwhile, at Temelin in south Bohemia, activists of the Greenpeace environmentalist movement scaled a cooling tower at a nuclear power station under construction and pinned up a banner saying ``Stop CSFRnobyl _Greenpeace.'' CSFR is the abbreviation of Czechoslovakia's official name _ the Czech and Slovak Federative Republic. A Greenpeace press release made available in Vienna said 13 Greenpeace climbers left the cooling tower ``exhausted but satisfied.'' It said police took the protesters' ID cards but did not otherwise intervene.

DOC.HEAD: French Couturiers Fighting Anti-Fur Movement
DOC.TEXT: The French fur industry is fighting back against slumping sales, a series of warm winters and an international animal rights campaign waged by conservation groups, celebrities and others. Two top fashion houses, Yves Saint Laurent and Christian Dior, staged shows Wednesday and Thursday to present their new fur styles for the 1990s. The shows featured younger, sportier styles _ putting old-fashioned minks into the closet and bringing out swirly, light looks, blousons and fur-lined luxury cashmere, taffeta or poplin styles. The shows came amid a growing movement against furs in the United States and Europe. The industry's most visible setback was the closing in February of the fur salon at London's giant Harrods department store. It said sales had dropped more than 40 percent in the past four years. Some of the new styles seemed to anticipate the hostility that has been directed at fur wearers. Dior designer Gianfranco Ferre ``hid'' some of the furs in his garments, making furs reversible, dying them or disguising them to look like fabric. His new angle on astrakhan came out in blazers patterned to look like chevron tweed. But the ``disguised'' fur outfits don't come cheaply. Even though featured in the boutique rather than the haute couture line, a blazer will sell for nearly $4,000. Dior's show was grouped under either boutique (luxury ready-to-wear) or haute couture categories. Both were designed by Ferre, who said: ``It's wonderful to work with such fabulous furs.'' These included minks and sables, de-colored and dyed in shades of gold or caramel. The boutique collection had a younger look, featuring trendy duffels, lamb-lined moire trench coats or blouson jackets with big collars _ one model dyed red, tied by a moire taffeta bow at the waist. Ferre had fun using his favorite organzas and chiffons as bows at waists and necks underneath or topping the furs. One of Ferre's favorite shapes was a terrific short, full pyramid, also appearing in shortie jackets. Saint Laurent's fur collection was designed by Robert Merloz, who has been at the house since graduating four years ago from the Paris Chambre Syndicale couture school. Merloz presented garments that included soft trapeze or shortie trench coats in moire, poplin or taffeta, lined in lamb or mink. He used plenty of curly Persian lamb touches, putting wavy piping on ``nappa'' leather coats with bold heart-shaped buttons, or contrasting dark gray lapels and cuffs on swirly little white beaver short coats. Merloz also draped chinchilla, sable or mink coats with ribbons over lace and satin dresses. Taking a bow after the show, the Parisian-born Merloz, 25, wiped away tears of relief and happiness. ``I was trying to give furs a lighter, more supple and yet full look,'' he said. Will Merloz be the successor to Yves Saint Laurent? At 53, Saint Laurent is often ailing and rumors are flying about his possible retirement. Following a nervous collapse just before his last ready-to-wear collection, Saint Laurent was hospitalized and missed the show. According to associates, he is resting outside of Paris and plans to begin work again in June. Pierre Berge, chairman of the Saint Laurent empire, declined to discuss a possible successor. But when asked if Saint Laurent would be designing the winter couture collection to come out in July, he exclaimed: ``I certainly hope so!''

DOC.HEAD: The End of the Line for Broadway's Longest Running Show
LaserPhotos NY17,20
DOC.TEXT: This time, it really is the end of the line. ``A Chorus Line,'' Broadway's longest running show, plays its 6,137th _ and final _ performance Saturday night. The evening, a benefit for the New York Shakespeare Festival, has a top ticket price of $500, and the 1,483-seat Shubert Theater has been sold out for weeks. The last performance promises to be an event, especially with most of the original cast in the audience, and possibly on stage at the finale. And it will be a celebration and remembrance of Michael Bennett, the man behind the musical, who died of AIDS in 1987 at age 44. ``In a funny way, we all felt the show wasn't going to close,'' said Tom Porter, who probably has seen the Broadway production more than anybody. ``But now, we're beginning to realize it certainly is going to happen, and I'll miss it. When the show closes, there won't be a Michael Bennett musical on Broadway.'' Porter, the musical's production stage manager, has been with ``A Chorus Line'' for more than 12 years, first with the Chicago company for eight months and then in New York. From a spot in the back of the house or by watching a television monitor in his backstage office, he keeps an eye on each performance. ``A Chorus Line'' tells the stories of 17 dancers who compete for eight roles in a big Broadway musical. It was Bennett's baby, born out of more than 40 hours of taped conversations by Broadway dancers who talked about their lives, loves, hopes and fears. During an extended series of workshops at the New York Shakespeare Festival, Bennett conceived the show, hiring Nicholas Dante and James Kirkwood to fashion the book from the tapes, Marvin Hamlisch to write the music and Ed Kleban the lyrics. The show, which arrived at the Shubert on July 25, 1975, after performances at the Shakespeare Festival off-Broadway, was an immediate hit. More than 6.5 million people have paid $150 million to see the musical on Broadway. The show, which also has been performed in more than 20 countries, has made $38 million in net profit for the festival. But grosses have been dwindling, and the show incurred heavy losses last January. Joseph Papp, head of the Shakespeare Festival, announced Feb. 21 that the show would end its 15-year run the following month. It set off a box-office stampede, with grosses doubling to nearly $400,000 a week. The original closing date, March 31, was extended by four weeks. The extension enabled the show to do a special benefit on April 8, Bennett's birthday, which raised more than $50,000 for ``Equity Fights AIDS.'' ``It was an emotional night,'' Porter recalled. ``The dancers went back to their dressing rooms, changed their clothes and the audience was still on its feet, applauding.'' In the weeks since Papp announced the closing, the news media have descended on the Shubert. ``I think we started outdoing the Statue of Liberty in terms of visitors,'' said Porter. Television crews, some from as far away as Sweden and Japan, were nightly visitors. Original cast members sang and cried on Phil Donahue's and Geraldo Rivera's TV talk shows. Current performers in the show were profiled on ``Nightline'' with Ted Koppel. The musical spawned four books in the last year, including a biography of Bennett by Boston Globe theater critic Kevin Kelly and ``On the Line,'' remembrances by members of the original cast. According to Ken Mandelbaum, author of ```A Chorus Line' and the Musicals of Michael Bennett,'' the musical's main legacy is the way it was put together through the workshops. ``From then on, almost every musical that got to Broadway went through some form of workshop,'' Mandelbaum said. ``When the workshop of `A Chorus Line' started, there was no script really and no songs. They went into rehearsal to create the show.'' Today, he added, most directors and producers of musicals don't use workshops as effectively as Bennett did. They use them mostly as additional auditions or as extra rehearsals. ```A Chorus Line' also represents Broadway in a way that probably no other show did,'' Mandelbaum added. ``No other musical was so about Broadway. And as it traveled around the country, people really got that feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian President to Visit China
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's president will visit China next month and formally end decades of strained relations between the Asian neighbors, the Foreign Ministry announced Thursday. President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat will tour China from May 4-9. He will be the first Mongolian head of government to visit China since 1962, the ministry said. Ochirbat became chairman of the Grand People's Hural, or parliament, last month in changes that resulted from weeks of protests for democratic reforms. The reforms promised by Mongolia's new leaders reportedly worry the conservative Beijing government, and Mongolian sources say China has stepped up surveillance of its Mongol minority in Inner Mongolia. In China, Ochirbat will be seeking greater economic exchanges, a relaxation of border tensions and access to a Chinese port as a transit point for Mongolian trade. China and Mongolia have often been opponents in war, with Genghis Khan's successors ruling China for a century and China later occupying Mongolia. The Mongolians were allied with the Soviet Union in gaining independence and establishing the world's second Communist state in 1921. Inner Mongolia, with a heavy Chinese presence, stayed under Beijing's rule. China did not recognize Mongolian independence until the Chinese communists came to power in 1949. China and Mongolia maintained good relations in the 1950s, but Mongolia joined its patron state, the Soviet Union, in splitting with China in the early 1960s. Relations began to thaw as the Soviet Union and China patched up their differences in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Government Vows Crackdown on Labor; Riot Police Surround Shipyard
DOC.TEXT: The government vowed Thursday to crack down on a growing wave of labor unrest, and thousands of riot police surrounded the country's largest shipyard, where striking workers have put up barricades. The government's action came a day after thousands of workers at the shipyard of Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. went on strike. Labor protests also continued at the state-run KBS television and radio network. The government issued a statement Thursday vowing to act firmly against illegal labor protests. It warned that, if unchecked, the protests would increase social unrest and hurt South Korea's sluggish economy. ``The government has decided to take strong countermeasures against spreading, unlawful labor strikes,'' the statement said. The warning came after an emergency meeting of economic and law enforcement Cabinet ministers presided over by Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon to discuss the labor unrest, which mainly involves political issues. The warning did not specify what measures the government would take, but there were strong indications of possible police action. Police were on increased alert after militant unions in other major industrial centers threatened protest actions in support of the striking shipyard workers. In the southern industrial city of Changwon, thousands of workers rallied at a dozen companies, threatening to begin a general strike if police moved into the Hyundai shipyard. Militant unions affiliated with the dissident National Labor Federation said they would stage a nationwide support strike on May Day. Radical leaders urged students to support striking workers. Police reinforcements were rushed to the Hyundai shipyard in the coastal city of Ulsan, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, government officials said. No official figures were given, but newspaper reports said up to 12,000 riot police gathered near the shipyard. Police brought in bulldozers, helicopters and fire trucks, newspapers said. Witnesses said shipyard workers had pitched 200 tents and put up iron barricades at the main gate and other strategic points. They also said workers had stacked steel bits, stones and firebombs in anticipation of a police attack. In March 1989, riot police launched an air, sea and land attack on the shipyard that ended a violent three-month labor protest. The dispute began when workers broke away from a company-sanctioned union and set up a separate union to demand better pay and working conditions. The latest strike broke out just days before wage negotiations were to begin. But union leaders said the dispute was not over wages. They said the shipyard workers were demanding the release of four union leaders who were jailed earlier this year for labor protests, and the dropping of criminal charges against three fugitive union activists involved in last year's strike. Government officials said the shipyard strike is illegal because workers did not go through the required legal steps, including a cooling-off period. Union leaders say the complexity of labor laws make it virtually impossible to stage a legal strike. About 20,000 of the shipyard's 24,000 employees are members of the union, but union leaders said the number of workers participating in the strike had dropped to 12,000 since police surrounded the shipyard. In another development, more than 1,500 KBS workers staged a sit-down protest in the lobby of the network's Seoul headquarters to press their demands that their new president resign. Theey contend the new network head, Suh Ki-Won, is pro-government and anti-reform. KBS workers have staged daily protests involving up to 4,000 people for the past two weeks. The network's three television channels and five radio stations have been crippled by the dispute, broadcasting old movies, shortened news casts, documentaries and music. At Hyundai Motor Co. in Ulsan, the nation's largest car maker, union leaders said Thursday they would go on strike May 10 to press their demand for an 18.9 percent wage hike.

DOC.HEAD: Government Files Rebellion Raps Against Marcos Lawyer, Two Others
DOC.TEXT: The government filed rebellion with murder charges Thursday against a lawyer of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, a former press officer and a journalist in connection with the December coup attempt. Aurelio Trampe, senior state prosecutor of the Department of Justice, said charges were filed against attorney Rafael Recto; former presidential broadcast bureau chief Lito Gorospe; and free-lance journalist Cecillo Arillo. Trampe said the three were charged with joining mutineers Dec. 1 in taking over the government television station in suburban Quezon City. He quoted witnesses as saying Recto, who represents Marcos and his family in civil cases here, was seen entering the station's building with rebel soldiers to inquire where a press conference would be held. Gorospe and Arillo were seen trying to reactivate the station's television transmitter in an apparent attempt to broadcast rebel propaganda, Trampe said. ``We think there is probable cause, that's why we filed the charges,'' Trampe said in a telephone interview. ``The government television station was clearly in rebel hands at the start of the coup, and yet they were there.'' ``They should explain their presence (at the station) ,'' Trampe added. Judge Tirso Velasco, who is hearing the case, immediately ordered the arrest of the three. No bail was recommended. The December coup, the sixth and most serious attempt to oust President Corazon Aquino, left at least 113 people dead and more than 600 injured.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Rivers Asks Phil Donahue: Can We Talk Again?
DOC.TEXT: Phil Donahue, who earlier this year had talk show host Joan Rivers as a guest on his show, will be her guest Monday on the first live version of ``The Joan Rivers Show,'' a Rivers spokeswoman said Thursday. Since its September debut, Rivers' syndicated series, carried by 146 stations, has been taped for broadcast two weeks after taping. Starting Monday, it will be sent live to stations at 9 a.m. EDT each weekday, said spokeswoman Linda Lipman. The stations have the option of broadcasting each show live, or taping it for broadcast on a same-day or next-day basis, Lipman said. The appearances of Donahue and Rivers on each other's shows continues a trend of recent months in which talk show hosts and news anchors interview each other. The most recent example was Barbara Walters' interview last month of NBC ``Today'' co-host Bryant Gumbel on ABC's ``20-20.''

DOC.HEAD: NATO May Declare End to Lance Missile Project
DOC.TEXT: In the new atmosphere of reduced East-West tensions, the NATO alliance may end controversial plans to add a new short-range missile to its nuclear arsenal, sources said Thursday. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization also could decide in the coming months to make cuts in its stockpile of nuclear artillery, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There's a possibility that there could be an announcement of unilateral reductions of (those arms),'' said one source. A diplomat said ``it's a near certainty'' that the allies will agree to end the nuclear missile project and to trim their battlefield nuclear artillery. ``All these things are being discussed right now,'' said another diplomat. ``Short-range nuclear forces is very much a hot subject.'' The sources emphasized that no final decisions have been made. U.S. officials said in Washington last week that the Bush administration was postponing indefinitely the development of new short-range nuclear missiles that were to be based in West Germany. NATO's defense ministers meet May 9-10 in Canada to discuss the West's future nuclear posture at a time of tremendous change in East European countries, once considered adversaries. Aides to the defense ministers meet Friday in Brussels to discuss nuclear issues in advance of the Canada meeting. In recent months, NATO diplomats have said there was dwindling support for the U.S. plan to develop a new, more powerful generation of short-range nuclear missiles. It would replace the aging Lance surface-to-surface missile. One source said there was ``a possibility'' the defense ministers at their Canada meeting would declare the project dead. Another said it was unlikely. A third said he had not seen any draft statements making such a reference. There is strong opposition to the new weapon in West Germany. That is where most of the missiles would be based. The Lance was introduced in 1972, and military analysts say it will become obsolete in 1995. Its maximum range is about 75 miles. Its replacement would be designed to hit a target more than 250 miles away, just under the limits of the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces treaty. At a summit last May, President Bush and other NATO leaders agreed to delay until 1992 the decision on deploying the new weapon. The decision was part of a summit compomise that linked reductions in conventional, or non-nuclear, weapons to the start of negotiations on clipping short-range nuclear forces. Germany had demanded immediate negotiations with the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact on slashing nuclear weapons. U.S. and British officials wanted attention focused first on negotiations in Vienna to reduce conventional arms. Negotiators want to wrap up a conventional arms accord by the end of this year. Once a treaty is signed, officials say the two sides could quickly enter into bargaining on reducing battlefield nuclear weapons. In Vienna, U.S. and Soviet negotiators said petty bargaining was slowing the talks on troop reductions. The talks began in March 1989 with the goal of reaching an accord before the end of 1990. The superpowers have agreed to a ceiling of 195,000 troops each in Central Europe, with the United States able to keep up to 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe. However, the negotiations have been bogged down in definitions of weapons categories. The two sides also disagree on the number of combat aircraft each side should have. NATO has proposed a ceiling of 4,700 aircraft for each side, with an additional 500 air defense interceptors, but the East would like a higher ceiling.

DOC.HEAD: Attractive Faces Are Really Just Average, Study Suggests
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: Alluring eyes and a sunny smile are not enough. If you want to find an attractive face, a new high-tech study suggests, look for one that is basically average. ``Averageness is probably a necessary condition for attractiveness,'' said researcher Judith Langlois of the University of Texas at Austin. The bad news for ordinary Joes and Janes is that, as Langlois put it, there are ``probably not that many faces that are exactly average'' in the way she studied. Langlois and a colleague used a computer to construct faces that blended facial features of up to 32 people, averaging out such features as nose length and chin prominence. In this way, the more faces that went into a composite, the more it represented an average face for the population of college-age students from which it was drawn. When other students judged the attractiveness of the composites and of individual faces, without being told which was which, they found the composites made from 16 or 32 faces to be more attractive than the real faces that went into them. And the more faces went into a composite, the more attractive it became. Although other factors probably make movie stars unusually handsome or beautiful, ``I'll bet their faces have the fundamental attribute of averageness,'' Langlois said Wednesday. ``And without that they would not be very attractive.'' ``We don't know yet about all the other components of attractiveness, but I would say this is a major one, and it's a required one.'' Langlois presents the study in the March issue of the journal Psychological Science with Lori Roggman, who is now at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville. ``I think the research is absolutely fascinating,'' commented University of Minnesota psychologist Ellen Berscheid. ``I would say this is about the first time anyone has even begun to unravel what the standards of beauty are,'' she said. But she cautioned that the experiment involved faces of white college-age students, and said similar work must be tried with faces from other racial and age groups to see if the results still apply. If the principle does apply generally, Langlois said, it might help dentists and surgeons in reconstructing faces shattered by accidents or disfigured by abnormalities. The average face for a person of the patient's age and race could be used as a guide for the reconstruction, she said. Langlois said the appeal of an average face might be explained by evolution. Individuals best exhibiting the central tendencies of a population might be preferred for mating because their genes might be less likely to contain harmful mutations, she suggested. Another possible explanation is that, in a sense, average faces might be the most face-like. If humans evolved to respond to faces to get social information, they may respond most strongly to the most face-like faces they see, the researchers wrote. Previous studies show that even infants prefer faces that adults consider more attractive, Langlois said. The new study used faces of 192 undergraduate psychology students at the Texas university, plus the composites. For each sex, a computer built composite photos that blended two, four, eight, 16 or 32 faces. Attractiveness was judged by a different group of 300 students using a scale of one to five, with five being the most attractive. Male individual faces averaged a rating of 2.51, compared with 3.27 for composites of 32 male faces. For females, individual faces averaged 2.43, compared with 3.25 for 32-face composites.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Stronger in Early 1990 but Will it Last?
DOC.TEXT: Unexpected strength in the U.S. economy has led many analysts to double their estimates of growth for the first part of the year, some pegging it as high as 3 percent rather than the puny 1 percent they thought earlier. But some economists, noting continued high interest rates as well as the warm weather and other special factors pushing growth so far this year, say the pace cannot be sustained. And inflation, running hotter than expected, is also a worry. The gross national product _ the nation's output of goods and services _ grew 3 percent in 1989 but had slowed to a rate of 1.1 percent in the final quarter of the year. The figures for the first three months of 1990 will be released Friday. Where many private economists had predicted growth of between 1 percent and 1.5 percent for the January-March period, they now foresee an increase between 2 percent and 2.5 percent. Some believe it could be as high as 3 percent. While opinions differ on the growth rate during the rest of this year, there is virtual unanimity that the Federal Reserve has achieved its ``soft landing'' _ slowing the economy without tipping it into a recession. But the central bank so far has not been able to achieve the goal that made it want to slow things down in the first place: Holding back price increases. Inflation rose from 4.6 percent in 1989 to an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the first quarter of 1990 as measured by the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index. The weather that helped propel business growth also pushed up prices, especially for food and energy, although they have since moderated. At the same time, the stronger economy created about 726,000 jobs during the first three months of 1990, driving unemployment down to 5.2 percent, its lowest rate in a year. Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser at the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said his forecasting service has changed its first-quarter growth prediction from between 1 percent and 1.5 percent in late December to 2.5 percent now. ``And it actually wouldn't surprise me if it is higher than that,'' he told a reporter. Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, also said in an interview that first-quarter GNP will show a 2.5 percent gain, up from his 1 percent forecast in January. ``If it's outside the 2-2.5 percent range, it most likely will be on the up side rather than the down side,'' he added. Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics, a Washington forecasting service, also predicted a 2.5 percent growth rate and is ``looking for a pretty solid growth rate, probably 3 percent or a little higher, for the remaining three quarters of the year.'' Chimerine, on the other hand, says he is reluctant to conclude that the economy is picking up steam for the long run. ``Some of what we're getting in the first quarter is temporary,'' he contended, saying that growth will advance only 1.8 percent or 1.9 percent for the year. ``A lot of people are ignoring the fact that over the last four months, long-term interest rates have moved up almost a percentage point,'' he said. ``So we're clearly going to see construction and interest-rate sensitive sectors of the economy remain very weak and may weaken more as we move through the year.'' Chimerine's projection mirrors the 1.9 percent consensus forecast in the latest survey of 51 top economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz. Economic strength in the first-quarter included building construction, particularly housing, which was much stronger than expected. But analysts point to unusually warm weather in January and February which caused builders to ``borrow'' activity from subsequent months. The trade deficit also narrowed but a stronger dollar may make further improvement difficult since U.S. goods exported overseas will be more expensive while imported products will be cheaper and thus more attractive to American buyers. Other pluses were strong expansion of business investment and moderate consumer spending increases.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Whip Up Tornadoes, Flash Flooding, Wind Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Guard also sent to Weatherford, more detail on Proctor evacuations, picking up at the 7th graf, `Among those..'.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms carrying heavy rain, high wind and at least six tornadoes hopscotched across Texas and Oklahoma, forcing hundreds of people to evacuate today, flooding towns and closing roads. At least three people were killed in Texas and two others were missing. The Texas National Guard was called out today to help evacuate businesses and hotels in Brownwood, southeast of Abilene, and Weatherford, just west of Fort Worth. Police in Brownwood reported all major traffic routes under water, some waist deep. Two of the three deaths were reported in that town. ``I have never seen it rain this hard. It's raining so hard that you can hardly see out,'' said Laura Goehl, a resident of Stephenville, between Brownwood and Fort Worth. In Carter County, Okla., about 30 families were evacuated in the town of Healdton late Wednesday after authorities broke into cable television programming to ``warn them to head for higher ground,'' Healdton civil defense director Bill Dixon said. Emergency workers had to rescue a few elderly residents from their homes, he said. At least 130 people were evacuated in the area of Proctor, Texas, and nearby Proctor Lake, about 20 miles northeast of Brownwood, as the lake rose and the rain continued today. Comanche County officials warned people not to go outside except in emergencies. Many of those evacuees had to be rescued by boat early today after their cars and campers were flooded at a park near Proctor Lake. ``We were pulling these people off the top of their campers and trailer homes,'' said Sam Marshall, civil defense coordinator for the area. ``A lot of the motor home under water are $100,000 jobs,'' he said. ``And 28 to 30 have lost new Blazers or new automobiles.'' Among those evacuees were elderly campers from northern states, many of whom had to flee the lakeshore without vital medication, said police Sgt. Ron Moe. ``A lot of them have heart problems or are diabetics,'' Moe said. About 100 people were evacuated this morning from a flooded subdivision in Parker County, just west of Fort Worth, said Sheriff's Department dispatcher Ken Galbreaith. ``It's a madhouse right now,'' Galbreaith said. Extensive damage was reported at Laughlin Air Force Base in the Big Bend section of Texas. A base spokesman said wind up to 100 mph damaged buildings and three T-37 trainer aircraft. More than a foot of water flooded the emergency room and first floor of DeLeon Community Hospital in Comanche County, Texas. ``It's just a mess,'' a hospital spokeswoman who did not give her name, said. ``It's still raining outside. It just keeps coming in. We're trying to mop it up.'' Some areas southwest of Fort Worth received as much as 10 to 15 inches of rain, the National Weather Service said. More than 13 inches of rain was reported at Comanche during the night. Most of north-central, central and southwestern Texas remained under either flood, severe thunderstorm or tornado watches and warnings early today. Eastern and central Oklahoma remained under a day-long flash flood watch. Several highways were closed by high water in southeastern and south-central Oklahoma, with water up to 8 feet deep in places, said highway patrol dispatcher Robert Morales. High water in Carter County, Okla., prompted the closure today of several schools. Numerous roads and highways in Texas were closed at dawn today. Some bridges were washed out and others were damaged by flooding, highway department officials said. In southeastern Oklahoma, emergency workers sandbagged a nursing home in Calera against rising water to avoid having to move its residents to higher ground, the Bryan County sheriff's office in McAlester reported. A tornado touched down today in Corsicana, Texas, south of Dallas. There were no immediate reports of injury. Two possible tornadoes were reported in the San Antonio area early today. One damaged a mobile home, some cars and trees at Concan. Hail as big as golf balls was reported in northwest San Antonio. The series of storms began during the late afternoon Wednesday. The weather service confirmed at least five tornados touched down in Texas' Parker and Wise counties. ``It's on the ground. It's on us right now. It's real wide rotation. I'm shutting the door. Here it comes,'' a National Weather Service weather spotter near Weatherford, Texas, reported by radio as a tornado neared her home. ``Metal is flying. Everything is flying around the air. It's going to miss our house. It's over our neighbor's house. It's kind of sitting on their house.'' That twister damaged four homes in Parker County, about 40 miles west of Fort Worth, officials said. A 77-year-old man died Wednesday in Brownwood when he was swept away while trying to clear a drain near his home. A second elderly Brownwood man died today when he was swept away while trying to get in his car. In the Texas Panhandle, a 27-year-old woman drowned Wednesday when a car was swept into 13 feet of water in Moore County and two companions were missing, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Impeached Federal Judge Arrested On Hunting Violations
DOC.TEXT: A former federal judge who was impeached by Congress and removed from office in November has been arrested along with a state wildlife officer on hunting violations, officials said Thursday. Former U.S. District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. was released on $100 signature bond early Thursday after being booked at the Jackson County Sheriff's Department, according to Capt. Mike Diamond. Nixon, of Ocean Springs, was charged with hunting game birds by using bait, a misdemeanor, Diamond said. Austin Shattles, a supervisor with the state Red Creek Game Management Area in Jackson County, was charged with conspiracy to bait turkey, the officer said. He also posted $100 bond. The arrests were the result of an undercover investigation by the state Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks. The Senate convicted Nixon, 61, on two counts of making a false or misleading statement regarding a drug case to a grand jury in 1984. It removed Nixon from his federal judgeship Nov. 3 and stripped him of his $89,500 salary. He was convicted in Hattiesburg in 1986 of lying to a grand jury by denying he had discussed a pending case with a former prosecutor. On March 23, 1986, Nixon began serving two simultaneous five-year prison terms and was paroled in November from a New Orleans halfway house.

Here, at a glance, is a look at how aircraft systems would fare under the cuts proposed Thursday by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. The information was provided by the Pentagon in a ``memorandum to correspondents.''
DOC.HEAD: A-12
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has reduced from 858 to 620 the number of A-12s that it wants to purchase. Production of the plane, a long-range, carrier-based, all-weather attack aircraft, is scheduled to begin during the current fiscal year.
DOC.HEAD: Advanced Tactical Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: Cheney wants to defer production of the ATAs beyond the six-year defense program that ends in fiscal 1997. The department had planned to purchase 400 of the long-range, land-based, all-weather aircraft for the Air Force.
DOC.HEAD: Advanced Tactical Fighter
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon still wants to purchase 750 of the land-based fighter aircraft for the Air Force, but has proposed delaying the start of production from fiscal 1994 to fiscal 1996. Peak production was to have reached 72 planes per year by fiscal 1999; the Pentagon now says peak annual production will be 48 planes by fiscal 2001.
DOC.HEAD: Navy Advanced Tactical Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: The carrier-based aircraft is designed for air-to-air combat. The department has reduced from 618 to 546 the number of planes it hopes to purchase. Production would begin in fiscal 2000, delayed from fiscal 1998.
DOC.HEAD: B-2
DOC.TEXT: The department had planned to buy 132 of the long-range, strategic bombers for the Air Force, but has reduced that to 75. The department said production of the aircraft, which began in fiscal 1988, would reach a peak of 12 planes per year by fiscal 1994. This is down from 24 planes per year.
DOC.HEAD: C-17
DOC.TEXT: The C-17 is the strategic and tactical passenger and cargo airlift aircraft. The department has reduced from 210 to 120 the number of C-17s it plans to buy. Production of the aircraft began in fiscal 1988, and now is expected to peak at 24 planes per year by fiscal 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Transport, Schools Disrupted By Nationwide Strike
DOC.TEXT: Government workers across France staged a one-day strike for more pay Thursday, disrupting public transport, blocking bridges and forcing some schools and museums to close. Air France and Air Inter canceled many of their flights because air traffic controllers joined the strike. Only 25 percent of regional trains operated. In the southeastern city of Bordeaux, striking workers blocked three bridges leading into the city center, causing rush-hour traffic to back up more than seven miles. In Paris, several thousand strikers joined a protest march to the office of Premier Michel Rocard. The Orsay Museum in Paris, which houses a major collection of 19th century art, was closed because of the strike. So were many schools across the country, although no figures were available immediately. The strike was called by unions representing the nation's 5 million public workers, but neither the unions nor the government gave estimates of many employees stopped work. Union leaders contend that the government did not keep promises regarding the 1988-89 wage package and have been demanding an across-the-board 1 percent supplementary payment. The government denies claims that public employees are losing purchasing power. It says workers received increases averaging 7.2 percent last year, compared to an inflation rate of 3.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Leader Warns of Jewish Influx in Holiday Message
DOC.TEXT: PLO leader Yasser Arafat said Thursday the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel is more ominous for the Arabs than the creation of the state of Israel. He made the statement in a speech to a crowd gathered for dawn prayers marking the Moslem feast of Eid al-Fitr. The feast ends the holy month of Ramadan, during which Moslems fast from dawn to dusk. Arafat urged Arab and Islamic nations to confront the issue of increased Soviet Jewish emigration ``with effective measures and not with mere resolutions.'' ``The Jewish immigration is a more dangerous conspiracy than those of 1947 and 1948,'' he said. The immigration has been spurred by growing anxiety over the Soviet Union's future and the spread of anti-Semitism there, as well as by U.S. visa restrictions. It is expected to total 100,000 this year. About 24,200 Soviet Jews have gone to Israel so far this year, according to figures released by the Israeli government. The Arab world has complained that Israel plans to settle Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, lands seized from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel denies it steers immigrants to the occupied lands.

DOC.HEAD: Radiation Still High Four Years After Chernobyl
With AM-Chernobyl, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sweden and Norway, which were in the path of the radioactive cloud from the Chernobyl explosion four years ago, said Thursday many of their lakes and rivers are still dangerously contaminated. Finland, wedged between its Scandinavian neighbors and the Soviet Union, escaped with less contamination because it had no rainfall for several weeks after the accident April 26, 1986. Winds carried radiation from the nuclear reactor in the Soviet Ukraine to the wilderness of central Sweden and Norway, 1,200 miles to the northwest. Radioactive cesium soaked into the ground, contaminating lichen and other plants eaten by wildlife. Finnish scientists said they were continuing studies to determine if fallout had increased the incidence of cancer. First results should be available next year. Swedish researchers said 14,000 lakes, or about 15 percent, still contained fish too contaminated to eat. It may be 30 years before the lakes will be considered safe. Fish have been found containing radiation levels 66 times higher than the permitted level, according to researchers who examined 644 lakes. In Norway, newspapers reported that the level of cancer-causing substances in the most effected regions was 10 times normal levels in plants and up 20 times above normal in topsoil. Experts said parts of Norway will live with effects of fallout well into the next century.

DOC.HEAD: Open Letter Asks Congress to Assure Endowment's Future
DOC.TEXT: More than 30 prominent figures urged Congress on Thursday to assure the survival of the National Endowment for the Arts in the face of attacks from conservative lawmakers over federal support for controversial art. In a full-page open letter to Congress published in The New York Times and The Washington Post, the signers strongly supported the grant-making endowment as the primary catalyst for extending the arts to millions of Americans in the last 25 years. ``It is unfortunate that, recently, the NEA has become a subject of political controversy,'' the letter said. ``Misrepresentation and misunderstanding threaten its integrity, perhaps even its survival.'' The 31 signers urged Congress ``to safeguard what has evolved from a national resource to a national treasure,'' as the House and Senate consider legislation authorizing a five-year extension of the endowment, an independent, $171 million federal agency. The letter, published in the name of the bipartisan ``Emergency Committee for the Arts,'' was initiated by New York publisher Arthur Levitt Jr.; Andrew Heiskell, former chairman of Time Inc.; David Rockefeller, former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, and former Postmaster General Winton Blount. The other signers included Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times; S. Dillon Ripley, former secretary of the Smithsonian Institution; Chicago business executive Marshall Field; Derek Bok, president of Harvard University; former Treasury Secretary C. Douglas Dillon; former Democratic National Chairman Robert S. Strauss; Vernon E. Jordan, former president of the National Urban League, and philanthropist Paul Mellon. The NEA's political troubles began last summer, when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., protested the agency's previous financial support for traveling exhibitions of controversial works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. The Mapplethorpe show, the object of an anti-obscenity court battle in Cincinnati, includes several homoerotic images and pictures of nude children. Serrano was criticized for depicting a crucifix submerged in urine. At Helms' urging, Congress voted last fall to prohibit the NEA from financing works that ``may be considered obscene'' and lack serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., and conservative religious groups are demanding that Congress eliminate all funds for arts endowment. Attacks on the NEA have continued despite repeated declarations by endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer that the agency will refuse to finance obscene art. ``This agency is not a pornographer. This agency is not a blasphemer,'' he said during a recent interview with television evangelist Pat Robertson. Levitt said the letter to Congrss published Thursday was prompted by its sponsors' fears of an ``imminent threat'' to the arts endowment's reauthorization because of the controversy. Levitt said the issues raised by Helms and his conservative allies were ``dangerous issues, in that they are the kind of issues it is very easy to mislead the public about.'' He said the letter's signers, many of them influential in local arts institutions around the country, believed it was time to remind Congress of the endowment's achievements in sparking private, community-based support for the arts through matching federal grants.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44, CX5
DOC.TEXT: Actor Corey Feldman pleaded innocent to two felony counts of possession of drugs for sale, then announced he will enter a rehabilitation program. ``I would like to seek help for myself, and I would like to help others,'' Feldman, 18, told reporters Wednesday outside court. ``He realizes he has a problem and he wants to do something about it,'' said Feldman's attorney, Richard Hirsch. Prosecutors say police found about 25 balloons, each containing about a tenth of a gram of cocaine or heroin, in Feldman's car during a March 9 traffic stop. Each count carries a possible four-year prison term upon conviction. The actor who appeared in ``Stand By Me,'' ``Goonies'' and ``The 'Burbs'' remains free on $5,000 bail. A preliminary hearing was set for May 17.

Paraguayan author Augusto Roa Bastos on Thursday picked up the world's most prestigious Spanish-language literary prize. He said he would use the $93,000 award to make books available cheaply in his homeland. King Juan Carlos presented the Cervantes Prize to Roa Bastos in a ceremony in Alcala de Henares, Cervante's birthplace east of Madrid. In presenting the prize, the Spanish monarch called Roa Bastos ``a man of letters and ideas, of words and conscience.'' ``I see the prize as a double honor,'' Roa Bastos said, ``for my work and for the culture of my country.'' The 72-year-old author, who spent several decades in exile during the dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, is best known for his 1974 historical novel ``I, The Chief'' about the life and times of 19th-century Paraguayan dictator Jose Gaspar Rodriguez de Francia. The prize is named for 16th-century Spanish writer Miguel de Cervantes, the author of ``Don Quixote'' and considered by many to be the father of the novel. The award jury, assembled by the Ministry of Culture, selected Roa Bastos from among 32 candidates in November.

Former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop says promoting old-fashioned morality is the key to preventing deadly diseases. ``At the base of each one of these painful, tragic, destructive and, of course, preventable health problems is an equally tragic and destructive human behavior,'' Koop told 500 people Wednesday at a fund-raiser at Butterworth Hospital. The donations will go toward research, education and patient care at the hospital, which marked its 100th anniversary Tuesday. Koop, who retired as surgeon general last year, said the biggest lesson he learned was the link between people's behavior and disease, including smoking, alcohol abuse, unwanted pregnancies, child abuse, domestic violence and AIDS. ``Stern warnings about behavior can eventually lose their effectiveness if they are used too often,'' Koop said. ``Instead, we must affirm in the next generation a new sense of respect for each human life. ``Perhaps a return to good, old-fashioned morality will do the trick.''
