Stewart Copeland, former drummer for The Police, is revising his opera, ``Holy Blood and Crescent Moon,'' which opened last fall in Cleveland to lukewarm reviews. ``There's a lot more that the opera has to offer that we didn't achieve,'' said Copeland, who is being assisted by the Texas Christian University orchestra. The new version is expected to make its premiere on Nov. 16 at the Tarrant County Convention Center. Copeland also said getting back together with his former Police bandmates for more music making is a possibility. ``One day we'll probably give it a go,'' he said.

A 21-year-old woman who achieved her goal of being a Playboy Playmate of the Month last fall, became the first black Playmate of the Year, the men's magazine announced Thursday. ``I don't think of myself as black or white,'' said Renee Tenison, who has a black father and a white mother. She will be featured in the June issue, on newsstands Wednesday. She was chosen by the Playboy staff, and Playboy founder Hugh Hefner gave the final nod. As Playboy's Miss November, the Boise woman was introduced to readers as ``the best thing to come out of Idaho since the spud.'' Ms. Tenison, employed by a Boise electronics company, has done local modeling, including TV commercials and catalog photos, besides posing for Playboy. Why a black woman now? Magazine spokesman Bill Farley said: ``The bottom line is, there's no reason not to.''

The night at the Academy of Country Music Awards belonged to Clint Black, an ironworker with a hot first record. He came away with the most trophies during Wednesday's 25th anniversary awards show, which was broadcast by NBC-TV. ``It feels very emotional. It feels great. It's wonderful. It's just a big thrill. It's hard to describe,'' said Black, whose first single, ``A Better Man,'' earned him single record of the year honors. Black also took home top male vocalist, top new male vocalist and album of the year trophies. Black, 28, has performed in Houston nightclubs with his brother since he was 15. ``A Better Man,'' describing the end of an affair that left him a better man, was his first single, debuting last spring. ``It's very special to me because it's a tribute to someone very special to me _ a girlfriend of many years,'' Black said backstage.

DOC.HEAD: Booby Trap Suspect Charged With Reckless Manslaughter, Faces No Jail Time
DOC.TEXT: A handyman who set a shotgun booby trap that killed an intruder at his warehouse will be charged with reckless manslaughter and given a deferred sentence under a plea bargain announced today. As part of a plea bargain, 46-year-old Philip Connaghan will plead guilty to the manslaughter charge and to a misdemeanor charge of violating the state's booby trap law, District Attorney Norm Early told a news conference. In return, Early will recommend that Connaghan be given a deferred sentence, meaning that he can have the conviction removed from his record if he goes through a court-set time period without breaking the law. Connaghan also will be required to perform community service. The case aroused sympathy for Connaghan, who had $7,000 worth of tools stolen from the same warehouse in July. He also reportedly had been burglarized on other occasions. ``Philip Connaghan had no criminal record and had a positive history of being a hard-working, law-abiding citizen,'' Early said. ``He recognizes that his conduct is illegal and ... he feels booby trap devices are a danger to society and should be illegal.'' Early said Connaghan was forthright about his actions and admitted setting the booby trap in the warehouse that he leases in downtown Denver's warehouse district. Michael McComb, 19, was killed by a blast from a 12-gauge shotgun after he broke into the warehouse about 10:30 p.m. April 14 with three juveniles. The three youths, who have been released into the custody of their parents, face possible burglary charges. Connaghan, who was in Kansas on vacation when McComb was killed, surrendered to authorities on April 20 and was released on $5,000 bond Monday. Connaghan's friends helped rally support for the handyman, taking up a collection to pay for a new set of tools and for his legal defense. More than 100 other people have expressed support for Connaghan through newspaper letters and calls to radio talk shows. Early acknowledged that past burglaries played a role in Connaghan's decision to set the trap. He said he decided the facts did not support charges of first- or second-degree murder. The plea bargain is subject to approval by a judge, who must either accept or reject it as written. The judge does not the option of accepting the guilty plea alone and imposing a sentence where none is recommended, Early said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. House Vote on Jerusalem To Delay Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: A radical Iranian newspaper said Thursday that a congressional resolution endorsing a united Jerusalem as the capital of Israel will delay the release of Western hostages in Lebanon. Syria also denounced the resolution by the U.S. House of Representatives, saying it emphasized an American desire to ``defy Arabs and Moslems by stealing their rights without any lawful or historical justification.'' Iran's daily Islamic Republic said the congressional move ``made things more complicated by blocking the way for solving problems.'' Calling the resolution a deliberate snub to world Moslems, it suggested Washington does not want to save the seven Americans and 10 other Western hostages in captivity in Lebanon. The hostage takers will ``delay their release in a natural reaction,'' it said. Excerpts of the paper's commentary were carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency, which is monitored in Nicosia. The non-binding resolution approved by the House on Tuesday goes against longstanding U.S. policy of refusing to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The eastern half of Jerusalem was occupied by Israel during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. It contains the third-holiest site in Islam, after the mosques in Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia. The resolution was passed two days after U.S. educator Robert Polhill was released by pro-Iranian Lebanese captors after 1,182 days in captivity. Both Iran and Polhill's kidnappers, the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, had called on the United States and the West for a goodwill gesture to facilitate the release of the other hostages. Along with Syria, Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani is believed to have played a major role in gaining Polhill's release. In Damascus, the Syrian capital, a government statement said Arab countries should work to overturn the House's ``unfair decision'' before it becomes official U.S. policy. A similar resolution was passed last month by the U.S. Senate, provoking an outcry in the Arab world. The Syrian state newspaper Al-Thawra said the Senate resolution was a test balloon and that Arab inaction had allowed the House of Representatives to act. ``It is not enough for the Arabs to cry, they must find a way to support a powerful struggle,'' the editorial said. The Iranian newspaper, which is aligned with Rafsanjani's radical rivals, said ``the timing of the resolution is not coincidental, and it shows that the U.S. does not want the hostage issue to be ended once and for all.'' ``The U.S. representatives either lack political insight and have launched on this foolish move or have signed the resolution deliberately to stop the process of the release of hostages,'' the paper said. Most of the Western hostages in Lebanon are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. In Sidon, Lebanon, meanwhile, four officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross arrived to explore chances for the release of two kidnapped Red Cross workers. Their arrival followed appeals by Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and Lebanese and Palestinian groups for the quick release of orthopedic technicians Emanuel Christen, 33, and Elio Erriquez, 24. The pair were abducted from the Red Cross orthopedic center for artificial limbs in Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, on Oct. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: What will those rogue historians at Lipman, Richmond, Greene claim next _ that Columbus arrived in America in 1493? In promoting Yonkers Raceway's 40th anniversary Friday, the agency produced two radio spots featuring three wrong dates. ``The year is 1950 and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is president,'' according to an ad broadcast Monday on New York radio stations. ``The Army-McCarthy hearings are going full blast.'' Wrong. Wrong. Harry S. Truman was president in 1950. The Army-McCarthy hearings began in 1954. The ad was redone, with Truman replacing Eisenhower and Bobby Thomson's famous home run for the New York Giants substituting the hearings. Wrong again. Thomson's ``shot heard 'round the world'' resounded in 1951. ``So, we were off by a year or two here and there,'' said a beleaguered Richard Lipman, head of the agency. The first two mistakes were made by an agency employee, Lipman said. The Thomson date was provided by the raceway. In the end, a third version of the commercial dropped the reference to Thomson and did not replace it. ``We finally gave up on trying to be factual,'' Lipman said.

About 2,000 people tried to smooch their way into the Guinness Book of World Records, aiming to set a record for the greatest number of people kissing at the same time and place. Participants at Wednesday night's kiss-off at Oregon State University signed ticket stubs to be tabulated and submitted to the record book. The current Guinness book does not contain a record for this event, said Cassandra Wozniak, an organizer. She said efforts to contact the Guinness record keepers earlier this week failed. At 7:03 p.m. Wednesday, organizers began a five-second countdown. At the end, amid many giggles, hundreds of pairs of lips smacked. Techniques varied. Some settled for modest pecks; others were more dramatic. One couple was still kissing when the crowd broke up and had to be separated by friends. Bryan Cook, 9, who did not participate, rolled his eyes when asked what he thought. ``It's not gross, because I don't have to do it. If I did, it would be.'' At the other end of the age scale, Allen Scott, 74, and Janey Wertz, 68, said the event was great. Scott, a retired professor, had one small complaint. ``They started the event late. So we started a little bit early,'' he said with a wink. The two plan to marry in July.

The woman who brings pizzas to the door may look familiar to her customers. She's their former state senator. Shirley Marsh, who spent 16 years in the Legislature before retiring in 1988, is now a delivery person for a pizza chain. The wife of state Treasurer Frank Marsh said she took the job on a bet. ``I had been saying I'd like to have a part-time job, but a friend said I could never find the time with all the volunteer work I'm involved in,'' she said. Mrs. Marsh won the bet and is saving her earnings for a trip to Europe. But she's done some fancy schedule juggling _ squeezing her first two days of the job between trips to New York City for the finance committee of the National Council of Churches, and to Scottsbluff for Business and Professional Women, of which she was district director. Next week, she's going to Kansas City for a meeting of the United Methodist Women. ``That's why people didn't think I could get a job,'' Mrs. Marsh said. She said she hoped her adventure into food service wouldn't reflect badly on her husband's re-election campaign. She didn't tell him about the job until she completed the training. ``On my first night out, I delivered a pizza to an 11-year-old boy who said, `You must be having fun, delivering the best pizza in the world.' And he had a dollar tip for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan May Avoid Trade `Hit List'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES with new 4th graf, bgng, White House... with White House comment
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is resisting heavy pressure to place Japan on a trade ``hit list,'' but members of Congress are threatening to block approval of other trade agreements unless there is a change of heart. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills gave strong indications Wednesday that Japan will not be targeted a second time as a country deemed to have erected the most onerous barriers against sales of American products. The issue was to be reviewed today by President Bush's Cabinet, with a final decision expected before the end of the week. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the matter is being considered by the Domestic Policy Council and President Bush has not made a decision. He said he did not know when the decision would be made. The deadline is Monday, and a decision then is ``a possibility,'' he said. The administration a year ago targeted Japan, Brazil and India under a tough section of the 1988 trade law that provides for economic retaliation against countries that fail to remove objectionable trade barriers. The provision of the law, known as Super 301, was written with Japan in mind. Several members of the Senate Finance Committee let Hills know Wednesday that they believe Japan should be targeted again. However, Hills objected that the Super 301 designation was not appropriate in current circumstances and called on Congress to give her more negotiating flexibility. She lavished praise on Japan and the government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, saying the Japanese had made significant strides in the past month to reduce trade tensions between the two countries. ``We have witnessed a remarkable transformation in Japanese public attitudes about its protectionist trade policy,'' Hills said, praising Kaifu's government as ``responsive and decisive.'' She announced to the committee a last-minute agreement in which Japan met American demands to remove barriers blocking sales of U.S. forest products. She said the pact, which lowers tariffs and revises Japanese building code standards, should boost sales of U.S. wood products by more than $1 billion in the next year. The forest products issue was one of three raised in last year's Super 301 case against Japan. The other issues _ expanding sales of U.S. supercomputers and satellites _ were resolved in recent weeks as Japanese officials rushed to make concessions in hopes of heading off designation again as a country with unfair trade barriers. Despite the concessions, many U.S. industry groups and members of Congress are calling on the administration to target Japan again to keep pressure on a country that accounts for nearly half of America's overall trade deficit. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said the administration would be making a serious mistake if it failed to cite Japan. He contended that the country has a poor record in honoring its market-opening commitments. Bentsen and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., held out the threat that Congress would block legislation needed to implement pending trade agreements with Eastern European countries, the Soviet Union and China and new rules being negotiated as part of a global round of trade liberalization talks. ``If the administration ignores a trade law that Congress has constitutionally enacted, I am concerned it may poison the well for the consideration of those agreements,'' Bentsen told Hills. Some in the administration have argued that no country should be cited this year for fear that it would be wrong to antagonize other nations when the United States is seeking their help to conclude trade liberalization talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which regulates world trade. But Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said failure to cite Japan and other countries would send a ``dangerous and inaccurate'' message that the administration is not serious about protecting the interests of U.S. businesses. Danforth complained that the administration was confusing ``achieving agreements with obtaining results.'' Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., told Hills that he would push for legislation to extend the requirement for the administration to target countries, which was to expire this year. However, Sens. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., both said Japan should be rewarded for its newfound willingness to negotiate.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Think Bell Destined for Well is Swell
DOC.TEXT: Ask not for whom the bell tolls, but who stole it. Rita Reichel last saw the 200-pound brass school bell in her basement around Christmas. Now it's gone and she has no idea who could have carted it up the steep stone steps. ``I know it would take at least two strong men,'' said Reichel, who recently discovered the bell missing and reported it to police. Reichel, 40, said her father gave her the bell on her 16th birthday so she could someday build an old-fashioned wishing well like her grandmother had. ``It's so valuable, just to me,'' she said. The bell was estimated to be worth about $1,500. Reichel remembers that even getting the bell down to the basement was an experience. ``We used ropes. I just can't figure out how it would get out of that house.''

DOC.HEAD: After Mother's Long Campaign, Grand Jury Begins Probe Into Girl's Kidnapping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Ms. Cutshall...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with grand jury selected. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Jill Cutshall...'.
DOC.TEXT: Awaiting the start of the grand jury investigation she had fought for, Joyce Cutshall strolled in the woods where her kidnapped daughter's clothing was found. It is in the Wood Duck wildlife refuge, Ms. Cutshall said, that she feels close to her missing child. ``She gave the best hugs,'' Ms. Cutshall recalled, her voice cracking. Ms. Cutshall, who spent weekends in shopping malls collecting more than a thousand signatures to force the grand jury probe, saw her long campaign bear results today when the grand jury was chosen. Madison County District Judge Richard Garden selected 16 grand jury members and three alternates from a pool of 40 people and instructed them to report Friday for a meeting with a prosecutor. Testimony is expected to begin Monday. Jill Cutshall was 9 when she was abducted on Aug. 13, 1987, from the steps of a baby sitter's home in this city of 20,000 about 110 miles northwest of Omaha. Her father, Roger, had dropped her off in the morning, and she was waiting alone for the baby sitter to arrive when she disappeared. Four months later, a hunter found some of Jill's clothing at the wildlife refuge, but an extensive search yielded no other trace of the girl. No one has been arrested. Authorities said the kidnapping may have been a random sexual assault. Thousands of fliers with Jill's picture have been distributed throughout North America, and the case was the subject of a ``60 Minutes'' report. The CBS show identified two former Norfolk residents who were questioned by local police but were not charged, including one who said in an interview with an Omaha TV station he was involved in the abduction. But the man told Norfolk police he made the statements because he was threatened. Roy Stephens, a private investigator who worked on the Cutshall case, has acknowledged firing a gun into the air before the man made his videotaped statements. Frustrated by what she considered lax police work, Ms. Cutshall launched a petition drive to force a grand jury investigation. Under state law, a court is required to convene a grand jury if presented with petitions from at least 10 percent of the county's voters who took part in the last governor's election. Ms. Cutshall needed 1,024 signatures and collected 1,471. ``It won't be over for me until I can bring Jill home,'' Ms. Cutshall said Tuesday. ``The answer I want is where is Jill and when can we get her back here. Once we get her back, we will have all of the other answers.'' She said she believes police overlooked or did not follow up on information and failed to put pieces of the puzzle together. Ms. Cutshall said she is confident the grand jury will ``have no other choice than to hand down indictments.'' But Police Chief Bill Mizner said he is proud of the work done on the case. ``I think the police division has done an excellent job, and it's not only the police division but all other law enforcement agencies involved,'' he said. A special prosecutor assigned to the case, James D. Smith, said that a grand jury probe will only duplicate investigators' efforts and that it holds the danger of a premature indictment. Ms. Cutshall, who was living in Kansas and divorced from Jill's father at the time of the kidnapping, moved back to Norfolk to pursue her quest for answers into the girl's disappearance. She finds herself coming back to the refuge. There, she said, she feels close to her daughter, who enjoyed music and writing poetry. Sitting among the trees and dense underbrush, she lightly patted the ground where her daughter's clothes were found in a neat, leaf-covered pile _ shoes first, then jeans and her purple shirt on top. ``Intellectually, I know she's not going to come home,'' the mother said. ``There's probably 2 percent of me (that believes she is alive), and that's because you always have to have some kind of hope.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says it Will Execute Alleged U.S. Spies
DOC.TEXT: Iran said Thursday that a number of people convicted of spying for the United States will be executed in the next few days. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency did not say how many alleged spies would be executed, and it did not identify any of them. IRNA, in a dispatch monitored in Cyprus, quoted Ibrahim Raisi, the Tehran Revolutionary Court's prosecutor, as saying: ``In a bid to deal a blow on the Islamic revolution, the U.S. intellignce service used to regularly receive information from these people on the country's social and economic situation.'' It said the people ``will be hanged within the next few days.'' Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said in April 1989 that a network of spies who provided the CIA with details and documents about Iranian military planning had been broken. The New York Times reported in August that U.S. officials confirmed the Iranian report. Four alleged U.S. spies were hanged in November in Iran. Revolutionary courts in Iran are usually run by radicals. The report of expected executions appeared designed to fan anti-American sentiment _ an issue that might complicate President Hashemi Rafsanjani's efforts to end Iran's decade-long isolation. Thursday's announcement followed the release in Beirut of American educator Robert Polhill, who was held 39 months by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem zealots. Tehran was reported to have played a major role in securing his release. Rafsanjani is believed to favor an end to the hostage issue to normalize ties with the West and attract investment and technology for his country's flagging economy. Rafsanjani's opponents want the hostages to remain as the major hurdle blocking good ties with the West, especially the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Minister Says Soviets Trapped by `Halfway Reforms'
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's transition from a communist to private enterprise economy will be swift and thorough in order to avoid the ``halfway'' reforms that are causing economic chaos in the Soviet Union, the Czech finance minister said Thursday. ``Partial reform of a distorted economy ... is much worse than a non-reform,'' and delays to prepare a comprehensive blueprint mean ``postponing it to eternity,'' Minister Vaclav Klaus said. Such a cautious approach ``leads very soon to chaotic disintegration of the economy, as we see in the Soviet economy just now,'' Klaus added in a speech to the World Bank's second annual conferening the problem to see what was wrong. ``Either we are getting the wrong information to make our calculations or we are making a mistake somewhere procedurally,'' he said. ``We are just going to have to slowly and systematically work through that before we decide what is wrong.'' Originally, officials had said the second outage also lasted about 45 minutes. But four hours later, the center still had not communicated with the high gain antennas, which are the primary communications links to relay science data to the ground during normal operations, Elliott said. There was contact with the telescope's low gain antennas which can be used in emergencies. The telescope, embarking on a 15-year search for new worlds, was released from the shuttle's cargo bay Wednesday after a last-minute snag that almost sent two astronauts on an emergency spacewalk. Mission Control awakened the crew early today with a loud rendition of the song ``Shout,'' a fraternity house favorite. ``Good morning, Discovery. I guess you're awake after that song,'' said Kathy Thornton, shuttle communicator. ``There are a lot of happy people down here. We saw a great deploy yesterday and Hubble had a good night while you were asleep.'' ``We appreciate the good words from everybody,'' replied Discovery Commander Loren Shriver. After Wednesday's deployment, Shriver gently backed Discovery away from the telescope and put the shuttle through a series of maneuvers, the last one completed this morning, to ``park'' Discovery in orbit 46 miles behind Hubble. ``The telescope really looked great as we flew away from it, and we sure hope it does good work,'' Shriver said Wednesday. ``Well, it sure is now, Loren, and thanks for all the great work you've done,'' replied Mission Control. ``Galileo is real proud of you.'' Scientists have hailed the Hubble _ NASA's most expensive unmanned spacecraft _ as the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo raised a small telescope to his eyes nearly 400 years ago. Discovery and its five astronauts will follow the telescope while controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., make sure Hubble is operating properly, such as responding to directional commands. The next milestone is Friday, when the telescope's 10-foot aperture door is to be opened, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Then on Tuesday, NASA expects to release the first image from the telescope: an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Data will follow in a month or two. If the aperture door doesn't open properly, Discovery could return to the telescope so two astronauts could perform a spacewalk to fix it. Hubble project manager Fred Wojtalik said the telescope would be tested today for its ability to maneuver before the aperture door is opened. ``We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the Hubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight,'' he said. Too much light could damage the telescope's sensitive instruments. On Wednesday, mission specialist Steve Hawley used the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm to gently grasp the 12{-ton telescope and hoist it from the cargo bay. One of the telescope's solar arrays unreeled from its mast as expected and started providing power to the telescope's batteries, which otherwise had only eight hours of charge. But there was trouble with the second panel. It wouldn't budge when the latches were released, and then moved about a fifth of its 39-foot length and stopped again. The panel rolled all the way out on the third attempt. By the final attempt, astronauts Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were in their space suits in the airlock, 30 minutes away from taking tools in hand and going on an outer-space maintenance call. Wojtalik said the cause of the problem is unknown. The 8{-hour procedure was performed 380 miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any shuttle has ever flown. The orbit was dictated by the need to put Hubble above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. Astronomers hope to use the telescope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, studying stars and galaxies so distant their light has taken 14 billions years to reach Earth. They hope to determine how and when the universe was formed, currently estimated at 15 billion years ago. The telescope originally was scheduled for launch in 1983 but was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident. Discovery, which blasted into orbit Tuesday, is scheduled to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee, Defying Bush, Votes to Halve Salvador Military Aid
DOC.TEXT: The House Foreign Affairs Committee defied President Bush on Thursday, voting to cut U.S. military aid to El Salvador in half and to impose strict new conditions on the money. On a voice vote, the Democratic-dominated panel moved to cut the $85 million a year that the United States provides to help El Salvador's military. The action amended a bill that would authorize spending of emergency aid Bush wants this year for Nicaragua and Panama. Congressmen expressing the Bush administration's opposition to the move called it partisan and unwise, giving legitimacy to leftist rebels. But supporters of the changes said the new conditions would encourage both the government and rebels to negotiate a peace agreement. It would be up to the president to decide whether the conditions have been met. If the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front continue to receive weapons shipments from outside the country, thwart peace talks or mount a military offensive, the government's military aid would be restored. If the government fails to negotiate in good faith or adequately investigate last year's murders of six Jesuits, it would lose the other half of its military aid. Any military aid that is cut would not be lost entirely by the government, but would be funneled instead into humanitarian programs for the country. ``There are real consequences for either side in the event they misbehave,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., who sponsored the amendment. It remained unclear whether the restrictions on aid would ever be finally enacted into law. House Democratic leaders planned to meet next week with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in an effort to begin drafting a new bipartisan U.S. policy toward El Salvador which could head off the restrictions. The administration, which voiced strong disapproval of Thursday's move by the House committee, saw it largely as an attempt to improve Democrats' negotiating position as they enter discussions with Baker. The FMLN has waged a decade-long civil war in the countryside of El Salvador, and right-wing military elements have responded with death-squad killings. The war has claimed an estimated 70,000 lives. ``We've already waited too long,'' Studds said. ``We've been far too patient, far too timid, and we've watched far too many people die.'' The two sides recently agreed to negotiate under the auspices of the United Nations. That, coupled with a change in governments in neighboring Nicaragua, which is expected to shut down the weapons flow to the rebels, has created the most hopeful climate for peace in years. Republicans on the House panel argued that any tampering with El Salvador's aid would damage that climate. ``This is an effort to score partisan political points,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich. Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., said the move would grant credibility to the FMLN which it does not deserve. ``This assumes there is only one set of thugs in El Salvador,'' he said. ``Why do we want to legitimize the other thugs, the FMLN?''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
United States, Soviets Reach Agreement on Trade Accord
DOC.TEXT: U.S. negotiators announced today that they have reached basic agreement on a new trade accord with the Soviet Union that would normalize trade relations between the two countries for the first time in nearly a half century. U.S. Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz, the leader of the U.S. negotiating team, said ``fundamentally, we have reached agreement on the text'' of the new pact. He said that the exact language still needed to be worked out on four minor issues but he did not believe they would pose an obstacle to signing a final document when President Bush meets Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington from May 30 to June 3. ``As far as I am concerned, we have substantial agreement and I do not see an obstacle to its signature at the time of the summit,'' Katz said in a telephone conference call. He spoke to reporters in Washington after the end of Thursday's negotiating session in Paris. The discussions were allowed to continue this week after Bush decided against imposing economic sanctions on the Soviet Union because of its crackdown in Lithuania. Bush on Tuesday announced that he was not imposing any sanctions, ending days of debate inside the administration over whether the economic talks with the Soviets should be cancelled in an effort to bring pressure to bear on Gorbachev to seek a negotiated settlement of the Lithuanian situation. Even after all the minor issues have been cleared up, the new economic agreement cannot be signed by Bush until he certifies that the Soviet Union is allowing free emigration of Soviet Jews and other dissidents from the country. Bush has said he will sign such a waiver once the Soviet Union's more liberalized emigration policy is written into law by the Soviet Parliament. At the summit with Gorbachev in Malta, Bush expressed the hope that normalizing trade relations would give a boost to the Soviet economy. The trade agreement is needed to grant the Soviet Union the trade status of ``Most Favored Nation,'' qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to any other country. Currently, Soviet exports into the United States bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other nations. U.S. officials have predicted that trade between the two countries could double or even triple over the next three years with a new trade agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Diamond Worn by Marilyn Monroe Brings $297,000
DOC.TEXT: The Moon of Baroda, a 24-carat diamond that Marilyn Monroe wore to promote the film ``Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' eclipsed its presale price by fetching $297,000 at Christie's auction house. ``Bidding was strong, and the room was crowded,'' Christie's spokeswoman Doris Athineos said Wednesday. The buyer bid by telephone, said Athineos, who did not identify the person. The price far surpassed presale estimates of $120,000 for the pear-shaped yellow diamond. The Moon of Baroda's history dates from the late 15th century. It became the property of the Gaekwars of Baroda, a powerful family in India. It kicked around in royal circles for the next five centuries, finally getting confiscated from the Gaekwars by the Indian government after World War II. Meyer Rosenbaum, president of Detroit's Meyer Jewelry Co., acquired the stone in the 1950s. He suggested Monroe use the diamond to promote the film, which starred Monroe singing, ``Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Mexican President Still Angry Over Drug Arrest
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 18 grafs from Quayle news conference; picks up 5th graf pvs, Today's trip...
DOC.TEXT: Mexican President Carlos Salinas expressed ``strong displeasure'' to Vice President Dan Quayle today over the U.S. handling of a drug arrest and called for new ground rules for U.S.-Mexican cooperation in the war on drugs. Quayle and Salinas met for nearly three hours at the president's residence in what the U.S. vice president conceded was a contentious session. Mexico has accused the United States of a role in the abduction of a Mexican doctor, Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who now is awaiting trial in Los Angeles in the 1985 torture and murder of a U.S. drug enforcement agent. ``President Salinas expressed to me his strong displeasure with the Dr. Alvarez incident,'' Quayle told a news conference after his meeting. The session was Quayle's final stop on a fence-mending mission assigned to him last January by President Bush to soothe Latin American hard feelings over the U.S. invasion of Panama. Mexico claims U.S. DEA agents violated its sovereignty in seizing Alvarez. Quayle again reiterated U.S. insistence that it had not sent DEA agents into Mexico to seize Alvarez Machain. However, Quayle appeared to indicate that his reassurances to Salinas fell short of calming the situation. Quayle said that Salinas told him that Mexico wants new rules and agreements to govern future U.S.-Mexican cooperation on drug investigations and arrests. However, while claiming that Bush was ``always open to new ideas,'' Quayle gave no indication that the administration was ready to progress toward a new drug agreement. A Bush administration official who attended part of the Quayle-Salinas session told reporters that among the ``new rules'' that Salinas wants are provisions for better advance notice by the United States of its drug operations that involve Mexico. The official, who spoke under conditions of anonymity, also said that Salinas wants a better system for sharing information with the United States. The official said Quayle told the Mexican president, ``He thought we already were sharing information.'' Quayle said U.S. agents did not go into Mexico in the Alvarez Machain matter and said the administration was not ready to consider recalling the DEA agents that are now working on Mexican soil. Quayle said these agents are ``a constructive force for conducting a cooperative effort in the war on drugs.'' Quayle insisted that the flap did not undermine long friendly U.S.-Mexican ties. ``Mexico is a friend. Mexico is a neighbor,'' Quayle said. And the vice president said, ``There should be no doubt whatsoever that we respect the sovereignty of Mexico.'' Today's trip to the United States' closest ally in Latin America wraps up a fence-mending assignment that Bush gave Quayle after the December 1989 U.S. invasion of Panama that toppled the government of Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``The purpose of my visit is to once again emphasize on behalf of President Bush the importance that we place on this relationship,'' Quayle said in arrival remarks at the Mexico city airport. Quayle on Thursday attended the inauguration of Nicaragua President Violeta Chamorro, bringing her the first installment of a $24 million U.S. food aid package and promising additional U.S. support in the future. This was Quayle's third Latin American swing in the aftermath of the Panama action and ``this trip completes the mission,'' said the vice president's press secretary, David Beckwith. The Justice Department said last week there were no plans to return Alvarez Machain to Mexico, saying he would be held to face charges in Los Angeles for alleged participation in the murder of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena. The Mexican government claims U.S. agents violated Mexican sovereignty in the arrest of Alvarez Machain _ suggesting he was kidnapped to the United States. He was arrested at the El Paso, Texas, airport on April 3. The DEA has denied published reports that it paid bounty hunters to capture the Mexican doctor and bring him to the United States. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said last week that DEA agents were not involved in Alvarez Machain's capture in Mexico. The arrest sparked a diplomatic protest from the Mexican government. And the Mexican attorney general, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, has said it could end U.S.-Mexican cooperation on drugs. Quayle represented Bush on Wednesday at Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration in Managua, Nicaragua. Her election in February ended the 11-year rein of Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega. Quayle praised Mrs. Chamorro as ``a symbol of unity'' in Nicaragua. But he also said she faces ``Herculean economic problems'' in taking over from Ortega. He voiced U.S. support for her decision _ unpopular even among many of her own backers _ to retain Gen. Humberto Ortega, Daniel Ortega's brother, as chief-of-staff of the armed forces. Quayle called it a ``very delicate decision'' she had to make, but suggested retention of Humberto Ortega could help heal divisions in the country. And, in naming herself defense minister, Mrs. Chamorro made it clear the military ``will be civilian-controlled and civilian-ruled,'' Quayle said.

DOC.HEAD: House GOP Leader Orchestrates `Opportunities Workshops'
DOC.TEXT: House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich will host a satellite broadcast ``American Opportunities Workshop'' that he says is a non-partisan outreach program designed to attract disaffected voters. Yet the May 19 broadcast from five locations around the country, estimated to cost at least $250,000, is being bankrolled by GOPAC, a fund-raising committee that helps Republican candidates. ``There are references to ideas, but there are no references in the entire show to either political party,'' Gingrich said in an interview before Wednesday's announcement of the program. Gingrich said he is trying to convince Americans of all political stripes that ``the bureaucratic welfare state and permissive attitudes'' are responsible for many of today's problems. They must be replaced with ``a new model'' for government, he said, in which Americans solve problems by helping themselves rather than relying on the government. Gingrich said some Democrats, such as former Carter administration Attorney General Griffin Bell and Polly Williams, a member of the Wisconsin legislature who once was on welfare, will join in the effort. The program will originate from Gingrich's home district in Georgia and will contain appearances by participants in four other cites. Some 500 workshops have been set up around the country, he said, where people will watch the program by satellite hookup and debate the issues. Gingrich long has worked to increase the ranks of Republicans in the House, where they are outnumbered by Democrats 258 to 176. But he insisted the telecast, which may set the stage for a series of such workshops, is not a party-building effort per se. Gingrich said that if a Democrat such as Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey or Sen. Charles Robb of Virginia ``someday ends up as president on a platform made up of these kind of ideas ... that's fine.'' ``Our goal is not the shape of the parties. It's the shape of the country,'' he said. Gingrich acknowledged that while he will avoid preaching GOP gospel as such, the self-help appeal is designed to attract disaffected Democrats and others from the nearly 50 percent of the voting population that did not participate in the last presidential election. ``It is true that a lot of Democrats, for ideological reasons don't feel comfortable being involved,'' Gingrich said. ``Because in their party it wouldn't be positive to be involved in something like this. But it seems to me that's a commentary on the Democratic Party, not a commentary on what we're trying to do.'' Asked whether it was an effort to build the Republican Party, the ``nonpartisan'' label notwithstanding, he replied, ``Oh, sure.'' ``It is fair to say that it is part of a continuing effort ... to expand the Republican base,'' he said. ``But it is also fair to say that, in the tradition of Franklin Roosevelt, that you become less partisan and more interested in serving.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill Three Palestinians, Wound More Than 120
With AM-Israel-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers fired into a crowd of 4,000 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip on Thursday, killing three and wounding more than 120 in the worst clash in nearly a year, hospital officials and Arab witnesses said. In the West Bank, soldiers killed a Palestinian youth when a procession of Moslem worshipers pelted an army compound with stones as they marched to a cemetery to honor the dead, the military said. The Gaza confrontation began as thousands of chanting believers left two mosques after morning prayer services for the Eid al-Fitr, which celebrates the end of the holy month of Ramadan. It was one of the worst incidents of the 2-year-old Arab rebellion and the bloodiest since three Palestinians were killed and about 50 wounded during the same holiday last May 6. The upsurge of violence came in marked contrast to the subdued level of conflict in recent months. The army confirmed that two Palestinians were killed and 117 wounded in the Jabaliya refugee camp, a shantytown of 53,000 where the revolt against Israeli occupation began more than 28 months ago. It said 12 soldiers were slightly injured by stones in the clash and that it was checking a hospital report of the third death. Ahmad, a street vendor who was wounded in the arm, told a reporter from his hospital bed that soldiers panicked when crowds chanting ``Allahu Akbar!'' (God is Great) approached a fenced-off army encampment on their way to a traditional cemetery visit. About 20 soldiers inside the camp then fired tear gas, he and other witnesses said. ``We were heading to visit our dead people and then they started shooting tear gas at us,'' he said, refusing to give his last name because he feared arrest. ``I think the army thought we wanted to attack them after they saw such huge crowds.'' Witnesses said scores of Arabs responded with a barrage of stones until a dozen border police jeeps, several armored personnel carriers and a helicopter came to the soldiers' assistance. They said troops and border police clashed with the worshipers as the helicopter dropped dozens of tear gas canisters. Gaza commander Brig. Gen. Shmuel Zucker told army radio soldiers had been given special orders to restrain from opening fire. He said soldiers avoided shooting ``until the stones began to endanger their lives. ... The event is completely out of the ordinary. Jabaliya has been quiet for a long time.'' The army put the camp under curfew and declared the Gaza Strip a closed military zone, barring journalists from entering. Jorgen Rosendal, the administrator of Ahli Arab hospital, said nearly 140 Palestinians were treated for wounds in the city's two major hospitals. ``It's the highest number of casualties we have had since last May,'' he said in a telephone interview. Arab reports identified those Killed as three camp residents: Awadallah Ibrahim Awadallah, 25, a laborer shot in the chest; Khaled Musa Al Aswad, 35, a mosque prayer caller who was hit in the stomach; and Muhammed Ali Muhammed Abu Sammam, 30. In Qabatiya in the West Bank, troops fatally shot 20-year-old Naher Shelaby and wounded five other Palestinians during a similar religious procession, the army command said. The army imposed a curfew on Nablus and surrounding camps, home to 120,000 Palestinians. In Bethlehem, reinforcements were posted near cemeteries to prevent violence. Cemetery visits also came in response to a call issued by the pro-PLO underground leadership of the uprising for honoring the graves and families of ``martyrs'' killed in the revolt. Thursday's deaths brought to 680 the number of Arabs killed by Israeli gunfire in the rebellion. In addition, 209 Palestinians have been slain by other Arabs as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vt. Governor Launches Comeback Gubernatorial Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Richard Snelling launched his 1990 campaign Thursday to regain the office, saying the state ``faces a dramatic blend of great opportunities and sobering risks.'' The 63-year-old Republican, whose previous term in office was 1977-1985, called for a renewed effort to balance Vermont's environmental desires and its needs in view of a faltering economy. ``We have held on to much of the spectacular beauty which was bequeathed to us by our forefathers,'' he said. ``But we all know that we have been losing some of these wonderful elements of our inheritance and that without determination, hard work, sound planning and prudent investment, we will not be able to give to children that which was given to us. ``But we cannot neglect an equal responsibility to assure a standard of living that enables Vermonters to stay in Vermont.'' The political landscape in the gubernatorial race was turned upside down this month with the decision by Gov. Madeleine Kunin, a Democrat, not to seek re-election. Former state Sen. Peter Welch jumped onto the Democratic ticket. A group of Republicans already had been pushing for a Snelling candidacy.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Former Hostage Returning to U.S. With Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: A smiling Robert Polhill returned to American soil today after 39 months as a hostage in Lebanon. Polhill flashed a thumbs up sign and waved as he walked off the U.S. military plane that flew him to Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. He quickly shook hands with a small welcoming delegation, then walked with his wife, Feryal, to a nearby car for a drive to Walter Reed Army Hospital. The 55-year-old business professor declined to talk to reporters, pointing to his throat as if to say he was not yet ready to speak. Polhill's release left seven Americans among 17 Western hostages still held in Lebanon. The longest-held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. AFN, the U.S. military's radio network, reported that a special U.S. debriefing team that met with Polhill in West Germand earlier in the week had left Europe. The report gave rise to speculation that another hostage release was not immediately expected. Polhill was released by his captors in the Middle East on Sunday and underwent medical tests and intense debriefings at a U.S. Air Force Hospital in Wiesbaden. He was to undergo additional tests at Walter Reed. His release left seven Americans among 17 Western hostages still held in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. One U.S. source said the debriefing team was impressed with the vivid details that Polhill provided about the conditions and surroundings in which he was held for 39 months in Lebanon. On Wednesday, Hussein Musawi, the reputed spiritual mentor of Polhill's captors, Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, urged the kidnappers not to release another hostage because of a U.S. House of Representatives resolution declaring Jerusalem Israel's capital. Syria today also sharply condemned the House resolution, saying it was intended to emphasize the American desire to ``defy Arabs and Moslems by stealing their rights without any lawful or historical justification.'' In Iran, a radical newspaper said today that the resolution would delay the release of other Western hostages in Lebanon. The Farsi-language Jomhuri Islami, or Islamic Republic, said it ``made things more complicated by blocking the way for solving problems.'' On Wednesday, he visited with a kindergarten class of children of U.S. servicemen who had sent him a welcome-back card they designed featuring a teddy bear. In his first public appearance since arriving on Monday, he posed for pictures on a hospital balcony with the 14 children. Accompanied by his wife and his two sons, Polhill waved to reporters and kissed and hugged his wife. The balcony was lined with American flags and draped with a banner saying: ``Welcome Home! Pray For The Others.'' About 75 servicemen, nurses, doctors and fellow patients cheered Polhill, who clasped his hands over his head and held his fingers high to form a victory sign. Polhill, who quickly has become known for his good sense of humor _ something doctors say helped him endure captivity _ bantered with his sons Stephen, 26, and Brian, 23. ``I'm funnier than he is,'' Brian shouted. Laughing, Polhill pointed to himself and gave a thumbs-up sign and a thumbs-down sign to his sons, then spoke to them. ``He says you're making him feel really wonderful _ thanks,'' Brian shouted to the crowd of onlookers and reporters. Kindergarten teacher Kim Miller said that during the five-minute visit, Polhill gave each of the children a yellow flower, and they gave him pictures they had drawn. ``He gave everybody a little hug and he thanked us for coming,'' Mrs. Miller, of Upland, Calif., told reporters. Polhill, a diabetic, lost 25 pounds during his captivity and was very tired when he was released Sunday. Mrs. Miller said he still appeared weak on Wednesday and spoke very softly. ``I told him that it was nice to have him back,'' said 6-year-old Ricky Houser III from Youngstown, Ohio. Wiesbaden City Manager Reinhold Edel visited Polhill earlier and formally welcomed him to the city with a case of local wine. Polhill said he hoped the case contained a reorder blank, military officials said. Polhill was abducted on Jan. 24, 1987, from the Beirut University College campus along with two other U.S. academics, Alann Steen and Jesse Turner. U.S. officials said Tuesday that Polhill shared a room with Turner and Steen and was probably in the same building as some of the other Western hostages held by the Moslem Shiite fundamentalist group Hezbollah, or Party of God.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Presidential Candidate Killed in Attack Aboard 727
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 9th pvs, `Pizarro and...' to UPDATE with two gunmen arrested at airport where plane was to have landed, three buses torched in protest of the assassination. Pickup 10th, `Pizarro was...'
DOC.TEXT: A former guerrilla leader who joined the presidential race last month was killed today by an assailant who opened fire with a machine gun aboard an airliner reportedly carrying more than 100 people. The assailant was immediately killed by the candidate's bodyguards, police said. The plane returned to Bogota, where the leftist politician died one hour after being admitted to a hospital, officials at the hospital said. Radio reports said about 120 people were aboard the Avianca Boeing 727 but that no passengers or crew members were injured in the shootout, which occurred shortly after the plane left Bogota on a domestic flight. An anonymous caller to the Caracol radio network said drug traffickers killed the politician, Carlos Pizarro, and that he was targeted in a lottery with the names of other candidates. The caller claimed to be a spokesman for the Extraditables, the name given to drug traffickers wanted for trial in the United States, and he threatened another such attack. Pizarro, 38, was the third presidential contender killed since August 1989 in Colombia, which is engaged in brutal battles with drug cartels, leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads. Caracol radio said in a report from the hospital where the candidate was taken that he was hit by 15 bullets, including three in the head. The unidentified assailant opened fire 10 minutes into the flight, which was heading to the Caribbean city of Barranquilla, a spokesman for the national police told The Associated Press. The assailant emerged from a bathroom aboard the plane, drew a machine gun from a black leather jacket, and opened fire on Pizarro, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Pizarro and his bodyguards were seated near the rear of the plane. The bodyguards opened fire, killing the assailant, the spokesman said. Officials in Pizarro's political party said at least six bodyguards were aboard the flight. Two men with machine guns were arrested at the Barranquilla airport, a police spokesman in the city said in a telephone interview. The two apparently were waiting to kill Pizarro in case the assassin aboard the plane did not get a chance to do so, the policeman said on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, violent demonstrations to protest Pizarro's slaying occurred in the port city, and three buses were set afire, the policeman said. It was not known if the protests resulted in injuries. Pizarro was commander of the leftist M-19 guerrilla movement, which disbanded on March 8 and surrendered its weapons. The group became a political party, with Pizarro as its candidate for the May 27 presidential election. M-19 takes its name from the date of a presidential election on April 19, 1970, that the group claimed was fraudulent. As a guerrilla leader, Pizarro commanded 900 fighters, who opposed capitalism and what they viewed as U.S. imperialism. In its most daring operation, the guerrilla group captured the Palace of Justice in a 1985 assault that left 115 people dead, including 11 Supreme Court justices. On March 22, another leftist presidential candidate, Bernardo Jaramillo, was killed in a hail of machine gun fire from an assassin at Bogota's airport. Jaramillo represented the leftist Patriotic Union Party. The government blamed drug traffickers for the killing, but party members blamed right-wing death squads. More than 1,000 members of the Patriotic Union have been assassinated in the last six years. On August 18, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, an anti-drug crusader and a governing Liberal Party presidential candidate, was assassinated by drug traffickers at a rally outside Bogota. Within hours, the government declared war on the traffickers and announced plans to extradite drug lords to the United States for prosecution. The Medellin and Cali drug cartels once imported more than 80 percent of all the cocaine smuggled into the United States, U.S. officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Legislature Sends Congress Message: Curtail Campaign Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, ``We will ...'' to CORRECT to Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party sted Democratic Farm Labor Party.
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature has overwhelmingly approved a campaign-reform package that its supporters hope will be a model for similar legislation in Congress. The Elections and Ethics Reform Act of 1990, which sets voluntary spending limits and provides public financing for congressional races, cleared the House on Wednesday by 128-0. The Senate sent the bill to Gov. Rudy Perpich for his signature on a vote of 61-1. Perpich said he's inclined to sign the bill. The bill also prohibits state lawmakers from soliciting campaign contributions from lobbyists during legislative sessions, expands lobbyist disclosure requirements, requires the Legislature to conduct its business in public and establishes a new screening process for judicial appointments. Supporters say Minnesota is the first state to enact such legislation. ``People everywhere are frustrated with the excessive influence that money plays in politics today, especially when it comes to the United States Congress,'' said state House Speaker Robert Vanasek. ``We will be sending the strongest possible message to Congress that the time has come for Congress to mend its ways and enact campaign finance reform on its own,'' said Vanasek, of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party, which controls the House and Senate. ``The way to get the federal government moving again is to end the money monopoly that has weakened our elections and made the voters cynical and turned off when election time comes,'' he said. Many Independent-Republicans said they saw the reform package as a step in the right direction and voted for it despite reservations that it may be found unconstitutional. Ben Ginsburg, chief legal counsel for the National Republican Committee, has said if the campaign finance provisions become law they will be challenged. The bill sets voluntary spending limits of $425,000 for U.S. House candidates and $3.4 million for U.S. Senate hopefuls, effective Jan. 1. If both major party candidates for an office agreed to abide by the limits, neither would receive taxpayer subsidies. If one candidate agreed and the other did not, the candidate who limits expenditures would receive public financing of up to 25 percent of the limit established for the office they seek. Under a 1974 state law, candidates for the Legislature and state constitutional offices, including governor, receive a partial public subsidy if they agree to accept spending limits. The bill also reinstates a state income tax credit for contributions to political parties and to state and federal candidates who agree to abide by spending limits. Under the bill, individuals can claim a credit equal to contributions of $50 or less and couples can claim a credit equal to contributions of $100 or less.

DOC.HEAD: Secretary of State Will Hold Talks In Warsaw
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to CORRECT date of talks from Saturday to May 6
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker will hold talks in Warsaw on May 6 with Polish leaders about the pace of German unification. His visit, announced Thursday by the State Department, will follow a meeting of the World War II Big Four _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ on military aspects of the impending merger of East Germany with West Germany. Poland was overrun by German forces in World War II. Millions of Poles were killed in battles and concentration camps. As a result, Poles have been seeking reassurances that the Germany that will emerge from unification will not threaten its neighbors. West German officials, meanwhile, have informed Warsaw that Germany would not try to recover territory that was taken from it and made part of Poland at the end of the war. Baker will go to Warsaw from, Bonn where he will meet with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, Britain and France on German questions.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand, Kohl Call on Lithuania To Suspend Independence Drive
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged Lithuania on Thursday to meet Moscow's demands for a suspension of its independence drive. In a letter, Mitterrand and Kohl said Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis should rescind pro-independence laws to clear the way for talks with the Kremlin, ``so that the current crisis ends in a solution acceptable to all parties.'' ``Without doubt, it would facilitate the start of such talks to suspend temporarily the effects of decisions taken by your Parliament,'' the letter said. Lithuanian lawmakers declared the republic independent March 11. The letter said temporarily rescinding pro-indpendence laws ``would take nothing away from their validity since they were taken under a universally accepted principle _ the principle of the self-determination of peoples.'' The letter was drafted during a two-day summit in which Kohl and Mitterrand discussed a wide range of issues. It came two days after President Bush refused to impose economic sanctions against the Soviet Union for its military and economic campaign against Lithuania. Kohl and Mitterrand said a copy of their letter was sent to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two Western leaders said at a news conference that they wanted to avoid ``complicating'' Gorbachev's problems. The Soviet Union said Monday it might negotiate with Lithuania if the Baltic republic froze its March 11 declaration of independence for two years and agreed to adhere to the Soviet constitution for achieving independence. Lithuanian leaders repeatedly have refused to do that, saying their country was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 and was never legally incorporated into the Soviet Union. They also contend Soviet laws would make actual secession extremely difficult. Landsbergis has denied reports Lithuania would consider suspending its declaration. However, an aide has said a Lithuanian delegation, waiting in Moscow for a chance to negotiate with Soviet leaders, would consider such a proposal if it were formally made. In an article published Thursday in the conservative French newspaper Le Figaro, Landsbergis wrote that Moscow was becoming ``its own worst enemy'' by persisting with a hard line against Lithuania's bid for independence. ``If the Soviet Union continues to use force to crush Lithuanian independence ... we will all lose. It will prove that perestroika is a collection of political failures and not an authentic transition toward democracy,'' Landsbergis wrote. Landsbergis said his people ``were under no illusion about our economic dependence on Moscow.'' ``But we don't understand why, today, this master-slave relationship must be prolonged, and why _ to our great surprise _ it is considered by certain of our Western friends to be the solution to the problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Communications Outages Mar Hubble's First Day, But Problem Finally Solved
With PM-Hubble-Amateurs, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with problem solved. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `The telescope, embarking...'. SUBS 21st graf, `Discovery and...', to delete now-redundant reference to Greenbelt, Md.
DOC.TEXT: Ground controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center finally made contact today with the two main antennas on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope after trying for more than six hours to lock on. Applause erupted in the Hubble control center in Greenbelt, Md., as the glitch that marred Hubble's first full day in space was solved. ``We have confirmation that we have achieved communication with the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite through the high-gain antenna system,'' said NASA's Dave Drachlis. Engineers had said all along they believed the antennas were working all right and that the problem was in incorrectly pointing either the satellite or the TDRS, an orbiting communications satellite that acts as a switchboard. In the successful attempt, they nearly doubled the width of the antennas' beams to take in more territory, from a sweep of 6.2 degrees to 10.8 degrees. The telescope's low-gain antennas, which receive and transmit information at a much slower rate and can be used in emergencies, were working well. Space shuttle Discovery was 46 miles away, available to remedy certain problems. The outage was not a problem for which space walkers would have been summoned. The five astronauts were otherwise busy making pictures of storms over Texas from their 380-mile-high perch, and doing experiments. Steve Terry, director of a team calibrating various aspects of the telescope, said the first outage was caused by human error and was not a serious problem. It began between 1 and 1:30 a.m. EDT and lasted 45 minutes to an hour, he said. The second failure occurred at 6:44 a.m. when controllers attempted to send a signal to the telescope's two high-gain antennas through the TDRS. ``This time it was a pointing problem,'' said Jim Elliott, a Goddard spokesman. ``It's a new spacecraft and we think inexperience dealing with it was the cause.'' The telescope, embarking on a 15-year search for new worlds, was released from the shuttle's cargo bay Wednesday after a last-minute snag that almost sent two astronauts on an emergency spacewalk. Mission Control awakened the crew early today with a loud rendition of the song ``Shout,'' a fraternity house favorite. ``Good morning, Discovery. I guess you're awake after that song,'' said Kathy Thornton, shuttle communicator. ``There are a lot of happy people down here. We saw a great deploy yesterday and Hubble had a good night while you were asleep.'' ``We appreciate the good words from everybody,'' replied Discovery Commander Loren Shriver. After Wednesday's deployment, Shriver gently backed Discovery away from the telescope and put the shuttle through a series of maneuvers, the last one completed this morning, to ``park'' Discovery in orbit 46 miles behind Hubble. ``The telescope really looked great as we flew away from it, and we sure hope it does good work,'' Shriver said Wednesday. ``Well, it sure is now, Loren, and thanks for all the great work you've done,'' replied Mission Control. ``Galileo is real proud of you.'' Scientists have hailed the Hubble _ NASA's most expensive unmanned spacecraft _ as the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo raised a small telescope to his eyes nearly 400 years ago. Discovery and its five astronauts will follow the telescope while controllers at the Goddard center make sure Hubble is operating properly, such as responding to directional commands. The next milestone is Friday, when the telescope's 10-foot aperture door is to be opened, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Then on Tuesday, NASA expects to release the first image from the telescope: an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Data will follow in a month or two. If the aperture door doesn't open properly, Discovery could return to the telescope so two astronauts could perform a spacewalk to fix it. Hubble project manager Fred Wojtalik said the telescope would be tested today for its ability to maneuver before the aperture door is opened. ``We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the Hubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight,'' he said. Too much light could damage the telescope's sensitive instruments. On Wednesday, mission specialist Steve Hawley used the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm to gently grasp the 12{-ton telescope and hoist it from the cargo bay. One of the telescope's solar arrays unreeled from its mast as expected and started providing power to the telescope's batteries, which otherwise had only eight hours of charge. But there was trouble with the second panel. It wouldn't budge when the latches were released, and then moved about a fifth of its 39-foot length and stopped again. The panel rolled all the way out on the third attempt. By the final attempt, astronauts Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan were in their space suits in the airlock, 30 minutes away from taking tools in hand and going on an outer-space maintenance call. Wojtalik said the cause of the problem is unknown. The 8{-hour procedure was performed 380 miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any shuttle has ever flown. The orbit was dictated by the need to put Hubble above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. Astronomers hope to use the telescope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, studying stars and galaxies so distant their light has taken 14 billions years to reach Earth. They hope to determine how and when the universe was formed, currently estimated at 15 billion years ago. The telescope originally was scheduled for launch in 1983 but was delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident. Discovery, which blasted into orbit Tuesday, is scheduled to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Man Injured In Immolation Attempt
With AM-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: A Lithuanian man was hospitalized after he set himself on fire Thursday in central Moscow, Soviet authorities said. The man, identified by the official Tass news agency as Stanislavas Jamaitis, was in the intensive care unit at Sklifasovski Hospital with second- and third-degree burns. Interfax, a branch of state-run Moscow Radio, said his last name was Janaitis. He made no political statements, displayed no signs, and gave no written account of his motives, Tass said. However, relations between Lithuania and the Kremlin have been tense since Moscow imposed an economic embargo on Lithuania in response to the republic's declaration of independence. The man poured flammable liquid on his trouser leg and ignited it outside the Bolshoi Theater a few blocks from Red Square, said the duty officer at Moscow police headquarters. The officer, who refused to give his name, said passers-by rushed to the man shortly after he set himself afire and extinguished the flames. Jamaitis was born in 1938, is married with two children, and had not maintained constant employment in recent months, Tass said. Vilnius radio said he lived in western Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Lifts Exclusion Order on Irish-American Activist
DOC.TEXT: The government has revoked an order barring Irish-American activist Martin Galvin from entering the country, the Home Office said Thursday. Galvin is publicity director for the New York-based Irish Northern Aid Committee. It has been accused of supporting the outlawed Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to end British rule over the province of Northern Ireland. He was deported in August as an illegal alien after being arrested in Northern Ireland for defying a 1984 order banning him from Britain. Galvin appealed the expulsion. Home Secretary David Waddington notified Galvin on Monday that he had overruled an appeals officer and was lifting the exclusion order, said a Home Office spokeswoman. ``During the appeal hearing, Mr. Galvin's solicitors produced a certificate of his registration as an Irish citizen,'' said the spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The adjudicator accepted that Mr. Galvin was a dual citizen of the United States and of Ireland. This means that he is a (European Community) national, subject to community law, and therefore benefiting from rights of free movement under the Treaty of Rome,'' the spokeswoman said. Galvin, a lawyer and resident of New York City, has been banned from entering British territory since July 1984 when he gave a speech endorsing violence one day after a soldier was killed in Londonderry, Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage Back in U.S., in Army Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Robert Polhill returned to American soil Thursday, offering a broad smile and a thumbs-up salute but no word on his 39 months in captivity. Polhill, 55, stepped off a military jet minutes after landing at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. He smiled broadly and offered intermittent waves and thumbs-up signs but would not respond to questions shouted by reporters. He pointed to his throat at one point when pressed to speak and mouthed the words, ``I can't.'' His reception was low-key, with a State Department protocol official and Army and Air Force officers on hand to welcome the New Yorker and his Lebanese wife, Feryal. Polhill walked from the plane to a government car and was whisked away under sunny skies to Walter Reed Army Medical Center for a physical and other medical tests. He gave a final salute as the car passed by reporters and about 30 other people, most of them uniformed Air Force personnel, gathered on the edge of the tarmac. Polhill was flown here from Wiesbaden, West Germany, where he spent three days in an Air Force hospital after his weekend release. Army doctors on hand for the arrival said the length of Polhill's stay at Walter Reed depends on his condition. Polhill, a diabetic, lost 25 pounds during his captivity. He was reported to have had a voracious appetite in Wiesbaden. ``Rather than speculate what his problems will be, we would like to take some time to evaluate and allow him to rest,'' said one of the doctors, Russ Zajtchuk. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that President Bush planned to have Polhill in for a visit soon but that a date had not been set. Also leaving Wiesbaden on Thursday was the U.S. team that debriefed Polhill, a development that further dampened hopes another American hostage might soon be freed. Immediately after Polhill's release, there was some hope that at least one of the seven Americans still held in Lebanon would be released. In the last few days, however, a number of developments have suggested otherwise, among them demands from Shiite militants that Arab prisoners held by Israel and Kuwait be freed before they release another hostage. House passage earlier this week of a resolution recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel also angered Arab leaders. ``We have no indication that there is going to be a release'' in the near future, Fitzwater told reporters. Polhill, a business professor, was abducted with two other American educators on Jan. 24, 1987. The others, Jesse Turner of Idaho and Alann Steen of Boston, remain captives. All taught at the American University in Beirut. During his stay in Wiesbaden, Polhill reportedly gave the debriefing team a detailed account of his captivity and kidnappers. U.S. officials said Polhill likely was kept in the same Beirut building as other Western hostages. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held American hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Secretary Proposes Major Cuts in Aircraft Programs
Desk: CORRECTS 20th graf, On the, changing figure from $12.6 billion to $11.9 billion, a correction issued by the Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed today to sharply reduce the Pentagon plan to purchase 132 B-2 Stealth bombers to 75 planes as he unveiled a package of aircraft cutbacks designed to save $34.8 billion through 1997. Testifying before the House Armed Services Committee, Cheney said the changes were warranted because NATO faces ``fewer enemy aircraft and a reduced ground threat'' as a result of the dramatic changes sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., told reporters after the morning session that Cheney's reductions may not placate the budget cutting ardor on Capitol Hill. He faulted Cheney's program, contending it was ``still based on an unrealistically pessimistic view of the Soviet threat.'' Cheney's blueprint follows a detailed Pentagon study of military needs, and came one day after an Army official said troop levels would probably be cut by 250,000 over the next five or six years. He was scheduled to testify later in the afternoon before the Senate Armed Services Committee. The proposed reductions in aircraft would also affect the size of the Navy. In answer to a question from Aspin, Cheney said reducing the number of A-12 attack planes could mean elimination of two of the Navy's 14 aircraft carrier battle groups. The defense secretary testified that his plans would trim $2.41 billion from earlier estimates of Pentagon spending plans for 1991, and $34.8 billion through 1997. Cheney offered his plan at the same time the Democratic-controlled House and Senate are drafting spending blueprints for 1991 expected to call for sharp cuts in Pentagon spending. The proposal drew mixed reactions from members of the Armed Services committee. ``Let me tell you where I think this proposal is in trouble,'' said Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, and an opponent of the B-2 bomber. ``We're cutting a little bit and we're stretching a lot ... and when you cut and stretch you drive up the cost.'' But Rep. Robert Davis, R-Mich., said Cheney's cut in the number of B-2 purchases gives the Republicans ``a very dependable position, something we can sell to the House and the American people.'' In his statement, Cheney said the reduced purchases and delays ``will save $16.8 billion in 1991 through 1994, the department's current five-year spending plan, and another $18 billion during 1995 through 1997.'' He said the Stealth cutback would lower the projected cost of the plane from $75.4 billion to $61.1 billion, a saving of $14.3 billion over the life of the program. Cheney also said he intends to cut planned purchases of the C-17 long-range transport plane and the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft, and delay purchases of the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Aircraft and the Advanced Tactical Fighter. Congressional pressure has intensified to reduce the Pentagon's budget following the lessened Soviet threat and the budget crunch. Supporters of the $530 million radar-evading bomber have warned that the per-plane cost could double if fewer aircraft are ordered. Cheney's statement said some of the widespread changes were necessary because NATO forces will face ``fewer enemy aircraft and a reduced ground threat'' once announced Soviet withdrawals from Warsaw Pact nations are completed. But the secretary insisted that despite such developments, the nation's current bomber force must be updated with the B-2 by the turn of the century. The primary contractor for the bat-winged plane is Northrop Corp. ``Soviet air defenses, both missiles and fighter aircraft, will pose an increasing challenge to our current standoff and penetrating bombers,'' Cheney said in the statement.
