Cheney said he intends to cut the number of B-2 aircraft to be purchased in the next fiscal year to two planes, from the five currently proposed at a cost in the fiscal 1991 budget of $5.5 billion. And the maximum number of planes to be built during peak years of production would be reduced to 12 instead of 24, Cheney suggested. On the other aircraft programs, the secretary proposed to buy 120 of the C-17 long-range transport planes instead of the 210 originally planned at a proposed savings of $11.9 billion over the life of the program. The plane is designed to replace the aging C-141 transport plane. Cheney noted the new transport plane's ability to land on the ``shorter runways typical of the Third World.'' The statement was a plug for its use by the armed forces of the future, designed to fight in conflicts such as the Panama invasion as the threat of a major land war in Europe recedes. The secretary also proposed that the Pentagon buy a smaller number of Navy's A-12 all-weather medium attack planes, cutting the original request of 858 to a minimum of 620. The A-12 is designed to replace the Navy's A-6E Intruder, which is now reaching the end of its service life as a aircraft-carrier based long-range strike jet. Cheney said the Air Force's version of the plane, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft, which is supposed to be used for deep attack missions now handled by the F-111 and F-15, ``can safely be delayed given the current nature of the threat and capabilities of aircraft in inventory.'' Production of the ATA would be delayed beyond 1997, the end of the Pentagon's long-term five-year budget cycle, Cheney said. Cheney also suggested that purchases of the Advance Tactical Fighter be delayed from 1994 to 1996. The aircraft is intended to replace the Air Force's F-15. The number to be purchased should remain at 750, Cheney said. The delay in that fighter will also delay the procurement of the Navy's version by two years, and reduce the number of aircraft to 546 from the original 618 planned, the Pentagon statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Plans to Go Ahead With Holy Sites Protest Strike
LaserPhoto JRL5
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 4th graf to give exact date settlers moved in. Insert graf after 12th, `The Panama-based...' to add statement from settlers. Pickup 13th pvs, `The church...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Thursday ordered the eviction of Jewish settlers who stirred an international protest by moving into a building in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's old city. Officials of the Greek Orthodox Church, which owns the building, were dissatisfied because the ruling allows maintenance workers and 20 guards hired by the settlers to remain until a lower court resolves the tenancy dispute. The church argues the settlers are in the building under an illegal sublease. It said it would close all Christian shrines in the Holy Land on Friday to protest the presence of the 150 armed settlers. The Jewish settlers moved into the 72-room St. John's Hospice on April 11. The action brought protests from Christian clerics, Palestinian Christians and Moslems, the U.S. State Department, pro-Israeli lobby groups and the government of Greece. The Neot David settlement in Jerusalem was seen as part of a new settlement drive by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the hawkish leader of the right-wing Likud Bloc who was chosen Thursday to form a new government. The State Department called the Neot David settlement ``an insensitive and provocative act.'' The U.S. government opposes all settlements on land Israel captured in the 1967 war, saying it is an obstacle to peacemaking with the Arabs. The walled Old City is divided into Moslem, Christian, Jewish and Armenian quarters. Each sector contains holy sites and shrines, and the slighest changes in the status quo have historically led to violence. In its ruling, the three-judge panel said the settlers who are affiliated with the Ateret Cohanim seminary must leave by Tuesday. Settler representatives said they would comply. Church attorney Avraham Sochovolsky claimed victory. ``Twenty people is not a settlement. The main point was (to have their) children and women. Now they have watchmen and maintenance.'' But church spokesman Bishop Timothy Margaritis said the court did not go far enough. ``We were expecting that the building would be evacuated completely and that somebody else would undertake to guard the place,'' he said. ``Now, it's like recognizing the rights of the Panamanian company.'' The Panama-based SBC says it subleased St. John's from Martyros Matossian, an Armenian Christian, for $3.5 million, and that the settlers were its guests. The government admitted this week that it contributed $1.8 million to the settlement. A spokesman for the settlers said in a statement: ``We are pleased that the court has recognized SBC as having legal possession of the property and hope the courts will decide to let the company continue to operate the guest house.'' The church says Matossian had no right to sublet. It has filed separate eviction orders against Matossian and SBC, and the Supreme Court urged the lower court to act quickly in the tenancy dispute. Dan Avi-Yitzhak, an attorney for SBC, said the case was a test of Jewish sovereignty over Jerusalem. ``If we give up the right to settle in the capital of Israel, where do we have the right to settle?'' Avi-Yitzhak asked the court during the seven-hour hearing. Israel captured Arab east Jerusalem, including the old city, from Jordan during the 1967 Middle East war. It annexed the sector but Israel's claim to sovereignty over the entire city is not recognized by most countries. Church officials said they opposed Jewish presence in St. John's because it was so close to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, which marks the sites where many Christians believe Jesus was crucified and buried. ``We don't want people with machine guns walking near our church and frightening the pilgrims,'' said Archbishop Cornelius of Sebastian, who attended the court session. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, who argued the settlement provoked strife among religious groups, welcomed the court ruling and said he hoped it would help restore calm in the city. ``To my great sorrow, the damage that has been caused will nonetheless take years to repair,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Explosion Prompts New OSHA Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department on Thursday promised quick new safety rules for the petrochemical industry in an effort to prevent disasters such as last year's Phillips explosion that killed 23 workers in Texas. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration plans to establish the new safety guidelines by the end of the summer, the agency said in a report to President Bush outlining causes of the Oct. 23 blast at the plant in Pasadena, a Houston suburb. Another 130 workers were injured. The probe showed the explosion could have been prevented through better safety procedures and that it demonstrated the need for mandatory safety rules at plants that use and store highly flammable liquids and chemicals, the report said. ``The investigation of the Phillips catastrophe has caused OSHA to take stock and consider a strong course of action to prevent such disasters,'' the report said. Phillips Petroleum Co. has said its own investigation showed company safety procedures were not followed. It plans to appeal at least part of the $5.7 million in fines OSHA proposed last week for alleged ``willful'' safety violations. ``Phillips is eager to review any recommendations OSHA can offer that will further improve the safety of our operations,'' the Bartlesville, Okla.,-based company said in a statement Thursday. Most of OSHA's new requirements will be fundamental safety procedures that many firms already are following, said Gerard Scannell, assistant labor secretary in charge of OSHA. The mandatory safety guidelines, which would affect about 2,300 petrochemical plants nationwide, would include requiring companies to analyze hazards in the workplace, ensure equipment works properly, train and inform employees on hazards, and develop emergency response procedures, Scannell said. The agency is required to review public comment on the proposed rules, so it could be up to a year before they take effect. C.T. Roberts, a Phillips employee at the Texas plant who was off duty when the blast occurred, said the new OSHA guidelines are long overdue. ``The only way these companies are going to take safety seriously is to be pushed into it,'' said Roberts, who was in Washington for an AFL-CIO event to spotlight attention on workplace injuries and deaths. OSHA also will consider revising the way it sets priorities for inspections and devoting more attention to the petrochemical industry, Scannell said. Right now, OSHA allocates resources according to a priority system based primarily on industry injury rates. The report to Bush said OSHA may start considering other factors as well, such as the potential risk to workers. Historically, the petrochemical industry has had a lower injury rate than other industries, the report said. But it noted that major disasters have occurred recently in the industry, including the 1984 disaster in Bhopal, India, where a deadly chemical release killed more than 2,000 people, and in Mexico City, where an explosion of liquified petroleum killed about 650. Sectors of the petrochemical industry with a high potential for fire, explosion or catastrophic release include those involving plastics, synthetic rubber and petroleum refining, the report said. OSHA's investigation into the Texas blast showed that four highly flammable gases escaped from an open valve, forming a huge vapor cloud that traveled through the plant within seconds under high pressure. A series of explosions occurred after the cloud came in contact with an unidentified ignition source. Contrary to Phillips' own procedures, as well as standard industry practice, there was no backup protection such as a double valve to protect against valve failure or protect against an untimely valve opening, Scannell said.

DOC.HEAD: That Cosmo Girl Is 25, Still Looking for Right Man, Right Job, Right Lipstick
LaserPhotos NY23,24
DOC.TEXT: She's That Cosmo Girl! It's her 25th birthday and she still wants it all _ a man who loves her, good sex, a great bod', and a job that makes her happy. What does she read? Cosmopolitan, of course _ Helen Gurley Brown's magazine for women who are ``ambitious, achieving, man loving.'' ``The magazine was for and still is for a woman who loves men, loves children, is very female, loves sex. But she doesn't want to live through other people,'' said the 68-year-old editor in chief. The May issue, Mrs. Brown's 300th, was published Tuesday. It features a brunette Madonna, red lips just parted, in a white dress with the plunging neckline that has become a trademark of the sultry Cosmo covergirls. ``I think people like to look at bosoms. I do,'' Mrs. Brown said in an interview Wednesday in her office. ``I think if you have a terrific bosom, you're wondering how you compare. If you don't have a wonderful bosom, you still enjoy looking.'' The magazine's topics have stayed as constant through the years as the cover cleavage: Sex, male-female relationships, Mrs. Brown's ``deadly sins'' (anger, greed, hate, fear and jealousy), and careers and health. ``The format is so sound and solid that there is really no reason to change it,'' she said. In 1965, when Mrs. Brown revamped the format of what was then an ailing, 79-year-old magazine, its circulation was 783,000. Today, it is bought monthly by 2.7 million Americans, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulation. There are 24 foreign editions in 10 languages. In line with the Cosmo format, the silver anniversary issue includes articles on how to improve your self-esteem (invest in your looks, be well-informed, choose supportive men) and how to boost your sexual confidence (learn to satisfy yourself, don't hide erotic skills, forgive your flaws). There's also a centerfold of TV celebrity David Hasselhoff with two well-placed Shar-Pei puppies. Mrs. Brown was a 38-year-old disgruntled copywriter at a Los Angeles advertising agency when she wrote the titillating 1962 best seller, ``Sex and the Single Girl,'' a how-to book on having an affair. She and her husband, David Brown, the film producer, then parlayed the book into a magazine proposal that they pitched to Hearst Magazines. Hearst was unwilling to risk starting a new magazine but was interested in a makeover of the fading, literary Cosmopolitan, which had published John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway and W. Somerset Maugham. In March 1965, Mrs. Brown recalled, she walked into the office of Cosmopolitan as editor in chief, after ``weeping up a storm'' the night before because she knew nothing about publishing and editing. Thus a new Cosmo was born, along with That Cosmopolitan Girl, the personification of the magazine's readership in advertisements. The magazine preached that single girls could have their own jobs and apartments, fall in love and enjoy sex _ shocking concepts in days before America's sexual revolution. Although the rising feminist movement would soon reject the magazine as one that fostered reliance on men, contemporary feminists now recognize that Cosmopolitan played an important part in reshaping women's views of themselves. ``I think ... that Helen Gurley Brown, in her editorship, has been a rather spirited and gutsy example in the revolution of women,'' said Betty Friedan. Mrs. Brown says she has always been a devout feminist. ``I totally sympathize with what they did and had to do. But at the same time the Cosmo format was and still is along the lines of my philosophy, which is that life is better with somebody to love.'' The magazine that was so long a leader is now being criticized by some as outdated. ``Cosmo still has a peculiar 1972 singles orientation to it,'' said Danielle Crittenden, a writer and analyst of women's magazines. Where the magazine once popularized sexual freedom for women, she said, it now reflects ``a kind of desperation and loneliness that is very depressing _ that things didn't work out for whatever reasons.'' Circulation has dropped slightly from an all-time high of 3 million in 1985, according to the Audit Bureau. Its readership is slightly older than it was 10 years ago _ 30.7 years old, up from 30.1. Half the readers are married. Mrs. Brown still believes in a Cosmo girl who can have it all. ``I get absolutely incensed that women are told that we can't have it all, that it's not working out, it's too much work, that we've got to go home and behave ourselves, because it's never said to men.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Run Tests to Determine Why Game Show Host Bert Convy Collapsed
DOC.TEXT: Game show host Bert Convy was in fair condition and underwent tests Thursday to determine why he collapsed during a hospital visit with his mother. ``They are still running some tests to try to figure out why he passed out,'' said Ron Wise, spokesman at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. ``His condition is listed as fair and he's stable.'' On Sunday, the ``Win, Lose or Draw'' host was visiting his mother, Monica, who has been hospitalized for a stroke, and he passed out, Wise said. ``He took a very hard fall,'' Wise added. The nature of the tests wasn't disclosed. Convy, 50, also was host of the game show ``Tattletales'' and appeared in the movies ``The Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders,'' ``The Man in the Santa Claus Suit,'' ``Help Wanted: Male,'' ``Love Thy Neighbor'' and ``Hero at Large.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientist May Miss Shuttle Flight Due to Illness
With AM-Hubble-Gadgets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A scientist who was to have flown on the next space shuttle mission has contracted an unspecified illness and NASA said Thursday he may be dropped from the flight. The scientist, Samuel T. Durrance, didn't arrive at the Kennedy Space Center on Thursday with the six other astronauts who will fly aboard the Columbia, which is scheduled for launch May 16. NASA said only that Durrance ``has developed a medical condition which is being evaluated to determine if it will affect his assignment as a payload specialist on the upcoming STS-35 flight.'' He would be only the second American astronaut to be dropped from a flight. In 1970, Thomas K. Mattingly was exposed to measles shortly before the Apollo 13 mission to the moon. Mattingly was replaced and flew later in the Apollo and space shuttle programs. Durance, 46, holds a doctorate in physics and is a research scientist at John Hopkins University in Baltimore. He is assistant project scientist for the Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope, one of the instruments scheduled to fly as part of the Astro Observatory aboard the Columbia. Durrance would be replaced by Kenneth H. Nordsieck, another scientist, who has trained as a backup.

DOC.HEAD: Women's Groups Protest Bishop PR Plan Against Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Twelve Roman Catholic women's groups on Thursday termed as ``scandalous'' a plan by U.S. bishops to launch a multimillion-dollar public relations campaign against abortion. ``We were shocked by your decision,'' the groups said in an open letter urging the bishops to halt the project. ``More fetal life could be saved by $5 million spent on caring for pregnant women and their children than by developing slick slogans or by bullying politicians.'' The letter was addressed to Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, and Cardinal John O'Connor of New York, chairman of the bishops' anti-abortion committee. A spokesman for O'Connor declined to comment on the letter until it had been reviewed. O'Connor announced recently that a New York public relations firm, Hill & Knowlton, and the Wirthlin Group, a polling enterprise, had been retained for a broad-based national campaign against abortion. He said about $1 million a year was expected to be spent during the next three to five years in the campaign directed at Catholics and non-Catholics. The women's groups, in a letter released by Catholics for a Free Choice in Washington, D.C., said the ``resoundingly negative public reaction'' to the plan should have persuaded the bishops to abandon it. ``If not, we must add our voices to the growing chorus of the faithful who insist that these efforts, which are seriously damaging to the credibility of all Catholics who work in the public arena on justice issues, cease. ... Detailing other church financial needs, the letter said: ``Our church is in economic trouble. Many dioceses are running deficits. Elderly nuns are on welfare. Inner-city parishes are closing daily because the buildings cannot be maintained. ``Parents can barely manage to pay the rising tuition rates necessary to keep their children in parochial schools. Teachers are so poorly paid they need two and three jobs to care adequately for their own families. ``Social problems related to the church's mission abound: feeding the hungry, clothing the naked, sheltering the homeless, caring for the sick and elderly. Are these needs not more urgent than the politics of abortion? ... ``Spending $5 million on the politics of abortion when the church is unable to provide for the spiritual and social needs of Catholics is scandalous,'' the women's groups said. Among the organizations were several major groups, such as the National Coalition of American Nuns, the National Assembly of Religious Women and Chicago Catholic Women, all based in Chicago. Other groups included the Women's Ordination Conference, based in Fairfax, Va.; Quixote Center Women-Church of Mount Rainier, Md.; Institute of Women Today of Chicago, and Women's Alliance for Theology, Ethics and Ritual of Silver Spring, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Former Marine Sentenced to Psychiatric Treatment for Espionage
DOC.TEXT: A former Marine communications officer was sentenced Thursday to 10 years' imprisonment in a psychiatric facility for selling classified information to the Soviet Union. U.S. District Court Judge T.S. Ellis III issued the sentence after a court-ordered psychiatric exam found that Frank Nesbitt, 45, suffered from severe personality disorders, depression and apparent episodes of psychosis _ a disability that can impair one's touch with reality. Doctors, however, also had raised the possibility that Nesbitt was pretending to be ill. Nesbitt's attorney, David Hopkins, said the sentence was appropriate, as did Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Hulkower. Nesbitt served from 1963 to 1966 in the Air Force's Electronic Security Command in West Germany and from 1969 to 1979 in the Marine Corps, where he dealt with classified communication gathering. He also worked at the Los Alamos Naional Laboratories from 1983 to 1984. During all his jobs he maintained a top secret clearance. He pleaded guilty to espionage charges earlier this year after admitting he had agreed to cooperate with the Soviets. But he claimed he did not know the information was classified. ``It was my true and honest effort not to do that,'' Nesbitt told the court on Feb. 1. An FBI Special Agent testified Nesbitt abandoned his wife and two children at their Millington, Tenn., home last June, and left behind a note that said ``Don't look for me. I'm gone.'' Nesbitt will serve his time at a federal facility in Buttner, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Camp Rejects Disarmament, Threatens Prospects for Peace
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
LaserPhoto MGA6
DOC.TEXT: On a sun-baked slope, hundreds of Contras rebels listened to an aide of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro telling them to lay down their weapons. But the attitude among Contras outside this mountain hamlet recalled U.S. Gen. George McAuliffe's famous World War II response to a German general's invitation to surrender. ``Nuts,'' the rebels replied Wednesday _ in loosely translated Spanish invective _ to their earlier agreement to disarm when Mrs. Chamorro was inaugurated. Others met the appeal by the Chamorro aide, Roberto Ferrey, with silence and stares. The rebels laughed when Israel Galeano, one of 12 rebel chiefs standing at the bottom of the hill, asked ``anybody who wants to give up his rifle, come forward.'' He said would be the last handing over his gun. When one shouted, ``Nobody gives up his gun!'' all cheered and applauded. The rebels are angered and alienated by Mrs. Chamorro's concessions to the leftist Sandinistas, which allow them to keep command of the army. ``We're prepared to hand over our weapons only when not a trace of those elements is left,'' one rebel told Ferrey, calling the Sandinista officer corps ``insects.'' Members of the anti-Sandinista army, created by the United States in 1981 and sustained by Washington until early this year, were to begin handing over their weapons to U.N. peacekeepers Wednesday after Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. A pact signed last week by leaders of the Contras, the Sandinistas and the new government committed the rebels to demobilize by June 10. El Destino is about 85 miles north of Managua. It is one of five zones where about 9,000 Contras are to gather and voluntarily surrender their weapons to U.N. soldiers. About 3,000 came here during the past week and this week and 2,000 more are expected in coming days. They roamed the 180-square-mile zone at will, still armed with Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, grenade launchers and weapons. A few dozen U.N. peacekeeping soldiers _ mostly Venezuelan, with Spanish and Irish officers _ were on duty, but, under their mandate, they could do nothing other than receive weapons that were voluntarily handed over. The Contras were low on food and were supposed to receive rations and demobilization aid from the Organization of American States after surrender. But few, if any, apparently had received the aid. Immediately after she became president, Mrs. Chamorro canceled compulsory military service, become her own defense minister and temporarily retained Gen. Humberto Ortega, the brother of former president Daniel Ortega, as army chief. In an interview with The Associated Press, Galeano was asked what the Contras' specific conditions before demobilizing were. He replied: ``A state of law with guarantees that we don't have a politicized army.'' Galeano said it was up to Mrs. Chamorro's administration to find a formula for meeting those conditions, but hinted the rebels wanted the Sandinista army virtually abolished and suggested it be temporarily replaced by an international security force. ``The problem is not one man _ Humberto Ortega. The problem is the whole repressive structure of the army. If they remove Humberto Ortega, there are 10 or 20 other Humberto Ortegas to replace him,'' Galeano added. No. 2 rebel leader Oscar Sovalbarro, who signed last week's demobilization accord for the Contras, was asked if he believed the rebels will demobilized by June 10. ``If the climate of confidence necessary for these men to give up their arms is improved, it could be done,'' he replied. He talked of ``reforming'' the Sandinista-dominated army instead of abolishing it. Like Galeano, he insisted that demobilization is the voluntary decision of each fighter. But that now appears to be a more uncertain prospect than ever. Said one regional commander, who identified himself only as Jackson: ``I for one am not disposed to hand over my rifle. I'd rather take to the mountains, live in the jungle with my comrades until our conditions are met.''

DOC.HEAD: Arms Control Adviser Resigns Over Pace of Strategic Arms Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf pvs, White House, to clarify `the positions' to `two positions.'
DOC.TEXT: Edward L. Rowny quit Thursday as a senior arms control adviser to President Bush. Sources said Rowny resigned over what he felt was undue haste in completing a treaty with the Soviet Union to limit strategic nuclear missiles. Bush acccepted Rowny's resignation with ``deep regret'' and said he had always valued his adviser's candor and loyalty. ``You have served as one of the principal architects of the American policy of peace through strength,'' Bush said in a letter the 73-year-old, retired Army lieutenant general. Rowny, who will leave his post on June 30, said in a statement that he looked forward ``to contributing to his (Bush's) efforts for peace through strength.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Rowny had authorized him to say there was no disagreement or reason to leave other than a desire to take two positions outside government. But the sources, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said Rowny disagreed with Secretary of State James A. Baker III over Baker's pushing to complete the treaty at what Rowny felt was too fast a pace. ``He wanted to slow down START (the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty talks) before we give up too much,'' said a source outside the government and close to Rowny. ``He is saying, `What's the rush?''' The administration would like to conclude at least a framework agreement on the key START issues for initialing by Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their summit meeting that begins in Washington May 30. ``He is saying, by resigning, `Why sacrifice the national security in a rush to get a glad hand and a smile from Gorbachev?''' the source said. ``He will now make that point as a private individual.'' Rowny will become a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a private research group in Washington, and a visiting professor at George Washington University. The United States and the Soviet Union remain far apart on several key issues in the START talks. Among them are the procedures for verifying that missile reductions have been carried out, whether to impose ceilings on land-based and sea-launched cruise missiles with multiple nuclear warheads and what kind of limitations to place on cruise missiles carried aboard jet fighters. Rowny has also strongly advocated concluding a treaty between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact to reduce sharply U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. An administration official, also insisting on anonymity, said Rowny was resigning because he had limited influence within the administration in projecting his views. Rowny was an adviser to both Bush and Baker. He had also served as an arms control adviser to then-President Reagan and his secretary of state, George P. Shultz. In 1979, he quit as an arms control specialist for the Carter administration during negotiations to conclude the 1979 Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. That U.S.-Soviet accord, which imposed some limitations on long-range nuclear weapons, was denounced by Reagan as he sought the presidency. After Reagan's election, Rowny returned to the government to serve as chief START negotiator. In a recent speech, Rowny said the Soviets would have a completely modern, formidable nuclear force even after carrying out cutbacks under a START treaty with the United States. The cutbacks, now being negotiated in Geneva, would trim the size of the Soviet arsenal, Rowny told the Reserve Officers' Association. In the meantime, he said, Soviet strategic forces _ long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines _ are being upgraded to provide for a powerful arsenal after the treaty takes effect. ``The U.S.S.R. is intent on retaining its claim to the status of a superpower equal to the United States that only first-rate nuclear forces can provide,'' Rowny said. The Soviets are upgrading their strategic nuclear weapons far more aggressively than is the United States, he said. For instance, Rowny said, the Soviets are making their land-based SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles more accurate and more powerful while continuing to deploy SS-24s with 10 warheads both in silos and as mobile weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Figure In Barry Investigation Sentenced To Probation
DOC.TEXT: A figure in the criminal case against Mayor Marion Barry was sentenced to a year on probation and fined $1,000 Thursday after pleading guilty to aiding and abetting a possession of drugs. James McWilliams also was ordered to serve 50 hours of community service by U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson. He could have faced up to one year imprisonment and a $100,000 fine. McWilliams told the magistrate he accepts ``full responsibility'' for his actions, will ``try to make amends'' and that he had learned ``a bitter, costly lesson.'' Details of his case are under seal. McWilliams pleaded guilty Jan. 30 and agreed to cooperate with the U.S. attorney's office in the criminal investigation of Barry. McWilliams is an employee of the District of Columbia Department of Public Works. In December 1988, he went to a Ramada Inn in the district and loaned his car to Barry associate Charles Lewis so that Lewis could go purchase drugs, prosecutors in the McWilliams case have said. The mayor is accused of four counts of cocaine possession in connection with his visits to the Ramada. Lewis, the government's chief witness against Barry, said in court in November that he was paid $140 by Barry in December 1988 so that Lewis could buy crack cocaine for the mayor. Lewis pleaded guilty to conspiring to buy crack for the mayor and to distributing cocaine to others and agreed to testify on behalf of the government against Barry. Barry faces trial June 4 on five counts of cocaine possession and three counts of making false statements before a federal grand jury. In his testimony, Barry said he was not aware that Lewis was involved with drugs and denied that he and Lewis had given each other drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela to Visit Ireland This Summer
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela will visit Ireland in July, the Irish government said Thursday. The black nationalist leader was made a freeman of Dublin during his 27-year prison term in South Africa and it was expected he will formally receive the honor at a ceremony in the Irish capital. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Charles Haughey to visit Dublin July 1-3, the government said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has invited Mandela to meet with her. He has not formally accepted, but has indicated he intended to meet with her and other world leaders in coming months. Mandela, 71, was in London over the Easter weekend for a televised concert celebrating his Feb. 11 release from prison, but he did not meet with political leaders.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's `Today' Show Continues Ratings Droop
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Good Morning America'' garnered its 16th consecutive ratings victory Thursday and for the second time in a month, NBC's once-dominant ``Today'' had its lowest ratings in nearly three years. ABC's show averaged a 4.3 rating last week, the same as for the previous week. But second-place ``Today'' dropped by two-tenths of a ratings point to a 3.3 average last week, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates. ``Today'' had the same 3.3 average in the week ending April 2. An NBC official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that was the show's lowest rating since August 1983. The show's ratings decline and the rise of ``Good Morning America'' began in January, when Deborah Norville succeeded Jane Pauley as co-host of ``Today.'' ``CBS This Morning'' remained a distant third in last week's ratings, averaging a 2.4. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Says It Doesn't Want to Be Part of NATO
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks before the World War II allies meet to discuss Germany's military future, East Germany said Thursday it does not want a united Germany to be part of NATO. In a parliamentary session, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said his reluctance until now to set out an official East German stance toward NATO was no accident. ``We want to overcome the military blocs, not rearrange them,'' he said. The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Bonn on May 5 to resolve the international aspects of German unification, including the sticky issue of its military standing. Asked about East Germany's stance toward NATO, East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel said: ``Membership in NATO is not our goal.'' He spoke in favor of building up a new European security system. However, since unification will come about sooner than a new system, he said, a temporary solution may be necessary. If under those circumstances East Germany has to consider membership in NATO, then the Western alliance would have to substantially change its strategy, Meckel said. He did not say how NATO would have to change. President Bush and the entire NATO alliance have insisted the new Germany be a full member of NATO, including its military arm. The Soviet Union has dropped its insistence that Germany be neutralized but suggested overlapping NATO and Warsaw Pact membership. Also Thursday in parliament, a new oath of allegiance for soldiers was passed that strikes the word ``socialism'' and uses ``peace'' instead. The new oath says soldiers must do everything in their power to ``maintain peace and protect'' East Germany. That and similar wording replaces passages that for more than 40 years referred to ``fighting alongside the armies of the Soviet Union and our Socialist allies.'' As the two Germanys scramble to accomplish monetary, economic and social union by July 2, heated debates are taking place over how to bring the mighty West German mark into East Germany. West Germany's proposal of a 1-1 exchange rate for wages, pensions and savings up to 4,000 marks ($2,300) is at the heart of the discussion. The East German government has said it will push for a higher ceiling for the savings exchange. De Maiziere addressed the issue in parliament Thursday. ``We have already made some achievements, considering there is now a willingness to exchange wages at 1-1 in a country where until now there was a rate of 1 (West mark) to 4.65 (East marks),'' de Maiziere said, drawing a round of applause. Commenting on charges that under the current plan East Germans would become second-class citizens, de Maiziere quipped: ``Until now we have been third- or fourth-class.'' In West Germany, the central bank said it could not rule out a tax increase to finance unification with East Germany. ``We cannot simply discount a tax increase out of hand,'' Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said at a conference in Bonn. He added that all other options for financing the union would be tried first. The bank said the proposed exchange rate represents the limits of what West Germany's economy can take. The bank had suggested a 2-1 swap, saying a 1-1 exchange would dilute the value of the West German mark and possibly cause high inflation and rising interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: More Control Over Intelligence Agency Demanded
DOC.TEXT: Civil liberties groups on Thursday demanded tighter control of Britain's MI5 intelligence service after the 23-nation Council of Europe found it guilty of breaching human rights. In a ruling this week, the West European nations censured MI5 for spying on two former officers of the British National Council for Civil Liberties in the 1970s and classifying them and their organization as subversives. The council's court, the European Court of Human Rights based in Strasbourg, France, has found Britain guilty more often than any other country. The latest ruling sparked a new dispute over what critics see as a warping of civil liberties in Britain and resistance to reform by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Charter 88, a pressure group that includes retired judges, academics and politicians, said the ruling underlined the need for Britain to have a written constitution and Bill of Rights. One of the people classified as subversive and a Communist sympathizer, Harriet Harman, is now a senior legislator in the opposition Labor Party and likely to become a Cabinet minister if the socialists win the next election. The other, Patricia Hewitt, was press secretary to Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock in the 1980s. The two women demanded Thursday that MI5 destroy files it presumably has amassed on them through surveillance, including suspected phone taps. Ms. Harman said the surveillance ``casts a shadow over me which is totally unjustified and which I bitterly resent.'' ``I want my file destroyed,'' she said at a news conference at the House of Commons. She urged that MI5 and MI6, which gathers intelligence abroad, should be directly accountable to Parliament in the style of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. The demand was echoed by the civil liberties council and legislators from both parties, who consider current controls too lax. The government made no comment in accordance with its practice of refusing to discuss the security services. According to leaks to British newspapers, MI5 has removed the civil liberties council from its classified list. The government has also said it has rectified the human rights charge with a 1989 Security Service Act. This laid out a charter for MI5 for the first time, provided for a complaints tribunal for people who suspect they are under surveillance and it required agents to get a Cabinet minister's approval to bug or break into buildings. But MI5 continues to report only to the prime minister and another Cabinet minister, the home secretary, not Parliament. MI5 has been accused in recent years of infringing civil liberties by tapping telephones of labor union activists and anti-nuclear campaigners. According to the memoirs of a retired agent, Peter Wright, MI5 tried to destabilize the Labor government of Harold Wilson in the 60s and the 70s. Britain has been convicted of 22 violations of the European Human Rights Convention including several on issues related to Northern Ireland, such as no-jury trials and imprisonment of terrorists. Britain's frequent run-ins result partly from the fact that it is the only country in Western Europe that has no written bill of rights or constitution. Human rights issues are automatically transferred to the European Court instead of being filtered through domestic courts. The nearest thing in Britain to a constitution is a 1689 declaration accepted by William III that ensured the ascendancy of parliamentary power over royal power.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Foundation Honors 19 Heroes
DOC.TEXT: A college freshman who rescued a pilot from a burning seaplane that crashed along a Maine lakeshore was among 19 people recognized Thursday by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission. ``I didn't plan to be a hero. It just kind of happened,'' Jonah Rosenfield, 18, said in a telephone interview from Brunswick, Maine, where he attends Bowdoin College. ``I'm so glad I could help that man. I'd do it again in a second for anyone.'' Rosenfield, from South Euclid, Ohio, is among 7,443 Americans and Canadians honored by the commission since its founding by industrialist Andrew Carnegie in 1904. The award carries a $2,500 cash grant and a medal. More than $18.4 million has been awarded in one-time payments and pensions to the heroes or their survivors. Five of those honored Thursday died in performing their heroic acts. Rosenfield was relaxing on the shores of Lily Pond in Deer Isle, Maine, on Aug. 25 when the single-engine plane, which had just taken off, crashed into trees less than 30 feet from him and other college students. ``I remember seeing the plane burn and the guy trapped inside the cockpit engulfed in smoke,'' he said. ``I remember thinking, `There's no way you can let him stay in there.' '' Rosenfield said despite his friends' shouts to stay back, he ran to the plane, opened the door and pulled out the dazed pilot, John H. Reid, 64, of Cape Cod, Mass. ``I accidentally dropped him in the lake, which actually was a good thing. He was on fire, but I didn't realize it,'' Rosenfield said. Reid was hospitalized for almost a month for treatment of second- and third-degree burns. Rosenfield was not hurt. The commission identified the other heroes as: _David M. Nyman, 31, of Anchorage, Alaska, who dragged an injured climbing partner down a mountain in Denali National Park on April 21, 1989. The rescue effort, slowed by a snowstorm and avalanches, took five days. _Melody S. Killen, 29, of St. Helens, Ore., and Norman J. Thomas, 63, of Seattle, Wash., who tried to save four teen-age girls from drowning in the Pacific Ocean in Ocean Park, Wash., on July 30. Thomas, the grandfather of one of the girls, died two days later. _Gene G. Roberts, 29, of Angleton, Tex., who saved a man from drowning in a bayou following a highway accident in Angleton on Feb. 4, 1989. _David H. Thomas, 30, of High Point, N.C., who drowned trying to save a woman who was thrown into a lake when her boat capsized in Jamestown, N.C., on May 26. _Joey C. Barnett, 34, of Lafayette, La., who helped save a 10-year-old boy from drowning in the Atlantic Ocean in Fort Pierce, Fla., on May 21. _Karl B. Weiss, 19, of Orlando, Fla., who helped save a man from suffocating when smoke from a faulty heating unit filled his apartment in Winter Park, Fla., on Dec. 9, 1988. _Hampton Henton Jr., 40, of Versailles, Ky.; Edwin V. Crowther, 36, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; and Gordon S. Anderson, 30, of Edmonds, Wash., who helped save a woman and her two young sons from drowning in the Atlantic Ocean in Fort Lauderdale on Feb. 15, 1989. _Kurt A. Buffington, 18, of Petoskey, Mich., who died trying to save a man from drowning in a Lake Superior harbor in Marquette, Mich., on Oct. 4, 1988. _Derrick A.J. Wilson, 49, of Drumheller, Alberta, who rescued his uncle from a burning crop-dusting plane in Rosedale, Alberta, on July 19. _Donald I. Gordon, 51, of Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., who saved two toddlers from a burning apartment April 22 in Lauderdale Lakes. _Paul E. Kennedy, 32, of Anniston, Ala., who tried to save a woman from drowning in a flooded drainage ditch July 5 in Anniston. _Paul Tafalla, 43, of Garland, Tex., who pulled two children from a burning van on a Dallas highway on July 31, 1988. _Dennis L. Johnson, 26, of Bothell, Wash., who dove into an icy creek and pulled a 4-year-old boy from a car submerged 75 feet in Scenic, Wash., on Jan. 28, 1989. _Fraser M. Dean, 51, of Montrose, Mich., who died helping to save his cousin's 15-year-old daughter from drowning in the Gulf of Mexico in Orange Beach, Ala., on March 30, 1989. _Ronny C. Odom, 40, of Metter, Ga., who died trying to save a man from suffocating in a flooded underground pump station in St. Augustine, Fla., on May 31.

DOC.HEAD: Child Poverty Called `National Tragedy'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with White House comment, inserting 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, ``These are
DOC.TEXT: Poverty and despair facing many American children are not only personal tragedies but ``a staggering national tragedy'' that threatens America's future, a federal commission reported Thursday. The National Commission on Children said in an interim report that children have become the poorest age group in the United States, with one child in five living below the poverty level. It said the childhood poverty more than any other factor places young Americans at risk for a range of long-term problems, including poor health, failure in school, teen-age pregnancy, crime and drugs. As a result, it said, many of today's children will reach adulthood unhealthy, illiterate and unemployable. ``The health and vitality of our economy and our democracy are increasingly in danger,'' Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., chairman of the panel, said in releasing the report. ``These are personal tragedies,'' Rockefeller said. ``They are also a staggering national tragedy.'' At the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We have very deep concerns about the children of this country and the poverty level that they may be facing. ... We know this problem exists.'' He added, ``It's always constructive to get the best kind of analysis we can over how deep and how wide this problem is.'' The commission was established by Congress, and its members were appointed by the president and House and Senate leaders. It made no recommendations in its interim report, which was required by law, but its findings are expected to form the basis for suggestions for new spending next year. At a news conference with other members of the commission, Rockefeller acknowledged the recommendations likely will be expensive. But commission members said the recommendations will involve efforts by business and families as well as government, and are needed to head off future costs to society. ``We know these kids are going to cost us billions in the future,'' if not helped, said Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, professor of pediatrics at Harvard University. ``They're going to be the terrorists of the future.'' In the report, Rockefeller said it is a tragic irony that at a time of prosperity, the United States ``seems to be failing its children.'' ``The evidence of this failure is pervasive,'' he said. ``The seriousness of the problems afflicting many of the nation's children and their families is now largely beyond debate.'' The report cited an array of jarring statistics, all of them previously reported, about childhood poverty: _ Malnutrition affects nearly a half-million children, and 100,000 children are homeless. _ Among black and Hispanic children, poverty is even worse. The poverty rate in 1987, the year the report cited, was 15 percent for white children but 45 percent for black children and 39 percent for Hispanic children. _ One of every four rural child is poor, and rural families are less likely than urban ones to receive public assistance. U.S. children on average are economically better off now than they were in the 1960s, primarily due to rising family incomes through 1973 and the trend toward smaller families, it said. But those figures do not reflect the growing disparity among families, the report said. The 20 percent of children living in a poor family was up from 15 percent in 1970, it said. The problems of poor children are compounded by a patchwork health care system that omits many, with ``harsh and senseless consequences,'' the commission said. More than 10 million children have no health insurance coverage, including Medicaid, the report said. Every day 100 babies die before reaching their first birthday, many for lack of prenatal care, it said. The report lamented the rise in single-parent families, which are more likely to be below the poverty level, the pervasiveness of drugs, and the school dropout rate. About one in four 18- and 19-year olds have dropped out of school, it said, and among Hispanics the figure was 45 percent. The report said that at a time when the conditions of children call for more flexibility in the schools, many school systems are becoming more rigid in their operation and less accommodating to students' needs.

DOC.HEAD: Protest at Insurer that Denied Benefits
DOC.TEXT: About 30 people demonstrated at the headquarters of an insurance company that has withheld $1.1 million in payments from a Toledo center that uses recreational activities to treat Alzheimer's disease patients. The protesters presented Nationwide Insurance officials with petitions demanding a review of the dispute, prompted by the insurer's finding that the treatments aren't covered by Medicare. The treatment center, Intergenerational Services Inc., has challenged the insurance company's decision to reject its claims, and an internal review of the contested claims is expected to be finished by Monday, a company official told the demonstrators. But the official, William P. Ramsey, vice president of Nationwide's Medicare operations, told the demonstrators he agreed with the original decision to reject the claims. Columbus-based Nationwide Insurance administers Medicare Plan B in the area. Since October, the insurer has rejected 40,000 claims worth $1.1 million filed by Intergenerational Services for psychotherapeutic services to Alzheimer's patients. The claims involve some 2,000 families. Nationwide says the claims are for recreational and social services and so fail to qualify as psychotherapy under Medicare guidelines. The Rev. Al Baumann, president of the board of Intergenerational, said its program _ in which patients reminisce about the past, sing songs and examine objects that will spark their memories _ is psychotherapy. ``We're trying to get them to relate to an object and to people because their problem is mainly depression and not being in touch with reality,'' he said. ``Constant reinforcement is a form of behavior modification ... and that is psychotherapy.'' Alzheimer's is an irreversible disease characterized by the degeneration of brain cells and often leads to severe dementia. If the company review goes against Intergenerational, the program could appeal to an administrative law judge. But Baumann said after Monday, it will be too late. Eighty percent of the agency's budget is Medicare money, he said. ``At the end of April, we're out of money,'' Baumann said. ``Sure, we could get into a court thing, which would take a year, two years. It's not good because ultimately, we may win the battle, but lose the war.'' Among the protesters was Judith Messinger, chairman of the Advocates for Alzheimer's Victims who said that no matter what the fate of the agency, her organization would pursue the case. ``Quite clearly, we don't intend to give up on this. Other Alzheimer's patients not only in Ohio, but in other states are going through the same kind of problems. They'll be looking at us to see how this is settled,'' she said. The protesters also took their case to Gov. Richard Celeste, delivering petitions with 10,000 signatures. Spokesman Reuven Carlyle said the petitions had been received, but that there was little the state could do because Medicare is a federal program.

DOC.HEAD: Medfly Spraying Begins Around Miami
DOC.TEXT: Pesticide-laced insect bait rained upon neighborhoods west of Miami on Thursday as authorities sought to snuff out a Mediterreanean fruit fly infestation that could threaten Florida's $1.4 billion citrus industry. It was the first assault on Medflies in Dade County in three years. State biologists, meanwhile, examined fly traps about 25 miles north to check the scope of the infestation. ``Hopefully what we've done is the beginning of the end for the Medflies,'' said Maeve McConnell, a spokeswoman for the eradication task force in Miami. ``We're keep our fingers crossed.'' A helicopter loaded with syrupy insect bait spiked with malathion blanketed a 16-square-mile area near Miami International Airport, where the first flies were found last week. Ms. McConnell said experts from the Florida Department of Agriculture will be checking traps around Fort Lauderdale this week for any indication of more Medflies, whose larvae eat the core of fruit. A female Medfly found Tuesday near Port Everglades was found not to be pregnant, she said. Officials have speculated the fly could have been trapped inside a ship or plane. As of late Thursday, 10 Medflies had been discovered in South Florida. Scientists have determined that for every Medfly found in a trap, there are probably 500 to 1,000 fles nearby, according to the state agriculture department. Present plans call for three more aerial applications in the Miami area in May with a mixture of about 2.4 ounces of malathion per acre. That compares with 3.1 ounces of malathion _ or about four tablespoons _ per acre sprayed throughout Florida to control mosquitoes. The use of malathion to kill Medflies has caused controversy in southern California, but there were no organized protests reported in Miami on Thursday. A few school officials and parents complained that afternoon spraying coincided with release of students from class, and one environmentalist blasted the effort. ``There is no choice involved here. The malathion is sprayed directly on places where people live. I have a problem with that,'' said Joseph Podgor Jr., Dade County chairman of the Friends of the Everglades. ``At least if it's sprayed on fruits you can wash it off.'' Officials advised remaining indoors and keeping small pets under cover during spraying. Malathion, which can irritate eyes, also can damage paint on automobiles. Water-use restrictions were waived for the spray zone to allow residents to rinse their cars. Next month, millions of sterile Medflies will be released in a slightly larger area in an attempt to break the insect's one-month breeding cyle. A quarantine went into effect Wednesday for about a 100-square-mile area west of downtown Miami that requires inspection of all Medfly-host produce _ including some 250 varieties of fruits and vegetables _ leaving the area. The last Medfly spraying in Florida occurred in 1987 in Hialeah, a city neighboring Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Booby Trap Suspect Charged With Reckless Manslaughter, Faces No Jail Time
DOC.TEXT: A man who was beset by burglaries and rigged a shotgun booby trap that killed an intruder in his warehouse will get a deferred sentence for reckless manslaughter under a plea bargain announced Thursday. Philip Connaghan, 46, will spend no time in jail and his record will be cleared of the conviction if he has no further run-ins with the law, Denver District Attorney Norm Early said. The deal is subject to approval by a judge, who does not have the option of accepting the guilty plea alone and imposing a sentence where none is recommended, Early said. Early said he decided to file a felony charge of reckless manslaughter and a misdemeanor charge of violating the state's booby-trap law because the facts failed to support filing first- or second-degree murder charges. Connaghan will plead guilty to the charges under the agreement. ``Philip Connaghan, an otherwise law-abiding citizen ... knowingly stepped beyond the lawful means of protecting property because of the severe frustration created by repeated victimization,'' Early said. Michael McComb, 19, was killed by a blast from a 12-gauge shotgun on April 14 after he and three juveniles broke into the warehouse that Connaghan rented. The three youths, who have been released into their parents' custody, face possible burglary charges. Connaghan, who was in Kansas on vacation when McComb was killed, surrendered on April 20 and was released on $5,000 bond Monday. Under the plea bargain, Early will recommend that Connaghan be given a deferred sentence and be required to perform community service. If the judge rejects the agreement, Early said his office would have to consider new charges. Connaghan was pleased with Early's decision, said Connaghan's lawyer, Bob Ransome. Connaghan will not comment until it is resolved, Ransome said. Before the April 14 killing, the warehouse, which contained about $7,000 worth of Connaghan's tools, had been burglarized six times, Ransome said. ``It became a battle of wits,'' Ransome said. ``He couldn't get any satisfaction.'' Connaghan, a handyman, set two shotgun booby traps in the warehouse in January after it was burglarized a fourth time, Ransome said. During the fifth burglary, in March, one of the booby traps was triggered, but malfunctioned, and Connaghan ``felt terribly relieved that it didn't work,'' Ransome said. He dismantled one of the traps and spent about 200 hours repairing damage to the warehouse that was caused by the burglars. Then, he went on a short vacation to Kansas, but left the second booby trap rigged, Ransome said. ``I think when he got in his car he just drove away. He thought about turning around, and then thought, `Well, they're not going to hit me on Easter,''' Ransome said. After learning of McComb's death, Connaghan felt remorse. ``He realizes that even though the young man was burglarizing him ... in fact, he was a human being and someone's son,'' Ransome said. The booby-trap case aroused sympathy for Connaghan from people who have become frustrated with rising crime rates. Telephone calls to the residence of Tim and Rosalie McComb, parents of Michael McComb, went unanswered Thursday. But in a letter to the editor published Wednesday in The Denver Post, the McCombs defended their son, and criticized those who offered sympathy and support to Connaghan. ``Our son fell off life's path for a period of time. He was on the road back when he was robbed of the chance to justify his life,'' they wrote ``Everyone who knew Mike loved him. He was not scum, he was not a career criminal, nor, to our knowledge, was he convicted of anything other than being a teen-ager trying to make his way in a world gone mad. ``As Colorado business owners for 30 years, we have experienced the anger of being broken into many times. However, killing anyone has never crossed our minds. Alarms and insurance are certainly a less barbaric method of prevention. By the way, burglary has not been proven against Michael.''

DOC.HEAD: Dugan To Be Nominated As Air Force Chief Of Staff
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michael J. Dugan, commander in chief of U.S. Air Forces in Europe, will be nominated by President Bush to be Air Force chief of staff at the Pentagon, it was announced Thursday. If confirmed by the Senate, Dugan would succeed Gen. Larry D. Welch, whose term expires June 30. Dugan, 53, hold several posts in Europe simultaneously. He is commander of Allied Air Forces Central Europe; commander in chief of U.S. Air Forces in Europe; and Air Force component commander, United States European Command. A native of Albany, N.Y., he is married and has six children.

DOC.HEAD: Department Approves Eastern Route Transfer, Continental Houston-Tokyo Service
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday approved the sale of most Eastern Airlines foreign routes to American Airlines and awarded a new Texas-Tokyo route to Continental Airlines. President Bush has authority to reject either deal if he believes it will harm U.S. national security or foreign policy interests. The Transportation Department's decision, made tentatively 10 days ago, includes transfer to American of Eastern's Central and South American routes as well as its Miami-Madrid flights and a Miami-London route operated by Continental, eastern's sister corporation in the Texas Air group. The department refused to allow transfer of Eastern's Florida-Toronto route as part of the deal, saying it would examine the proposal further and consider selecting a carier other than American to operate the service. Three other carriers have indicated an interest, officials said. A bankruptcy judge last week turned over Eastern to a trustee, removing it from the control of Texas Air Corp. owner Frank Lorenzo. Eastern's previous management had said sale of the routes to American, approved by the bankruptcy court, was key to Eastern's financial plans. American had agreed to pay $349 million, but that sum included the Toronto route. The awarding of a Houston-Honolulu-Tokyo route to Continental ended competition among six carriers for a service formerly belonging to Federal Express. The cargo service, lost by Federal Express when it took over Flying Tiger Line which already had U.S.-Japan cargo authority, has been expanded to include both passenger and cargo service. Continental and three other carriers _ America West, Aloha and Delta _ proposed a Honolulu-Tokyo route to replace the Federal Express service. Hawaiian Airlines wanted to run the service between Honlulu and Nagoya and American proposed a service between San Jose, Calif., and Tokyo. The department said the Honolulu-Tokyo market provided the greater pbulic benefit and Continental was selected largely because it proposed to serve Houston with the same planes it flies to Japan. No single-plane service now exists between Houston and Tokyo, and Continental's cargo service should significantly increase Houston's exports to Japan, the department said. If Continental decides it does not want the route, America West will be allowed to operate its proposed route between Tokyo, Honolulu and Las Vegas, Nev. and Phoenix, Ariz., the department said.

DOC.HEAD: One Two, One Two; Fitness on the White House Lawn
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and bodybuilder-actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, along with a supporting cast of celebrities, will kick off National Fitness Month with a gymnastic workout at the White House on Tuesday. The event, billed as ``A Great American Workout,'' will take place on the South Lawn beginning at 7:10 a.m. _ available for the morning network television shows. ``Arnold has got a very aggressive program laid out. ... We're going to have gymnastic equipment out there, and baseball stuff and golf stuff _ this will be great,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Schwarzenegger is chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Also on hand will be a host of entertainers and amateur and professional athletes, including Randy Travis, Carl Weathers, John Travolta, Dorothy Hamill, Bruce Jenner, Mary Lou Retton, Pam Shriver, Arthur Ashe, Carl Lewis, Rafer Johnson, Brooks Robinson, Billy Williams and Jane Blaylock.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Sun Fails to Overcome Difficult Odds
Also moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Notebooks were tossed in the trash and job postings tacked on the bulletin board Thursday at the St. Louis Sun, the new metropolitan newspaper that abruptly stopped publishing after only seven months of business. The newspaper didn't publish a farewell edition. Its last edition, the 213th, appeared Wednesday morning. The sudden demise came as a shock to employees, readers, newspaper analysts and others, and it also underscored the nagging slowdown that has hit the newspaper industry. Local and national newspaper advertising around the country grew just 4 percent last year, its smallest increase in more than five years. Daily newspaper circulation has been stagnant at about 62 million for a decade and it's been declining the past two years. About the only thing going well for newspaper publishers is that the price of newsprint is about 23 percent lower than last year. ``The newspaper market is in turmoil,'' said Ralph Ingersoll II, chairman and chief executive officer of Ingersoll Publications Co. and editor-in-chief of the Sun. ``This is at least the third such crisis I have personally lived through.'' But Ingersoll, who personally directed the creation of the Sun, which debuted Sept. 25, 1989, said he didn't know what role the industrywide troubles played in determining the Sun's fate. ``I think it had a direct impact,'' said Kenneth Berents, a stock analyst in Baltimore with Alex Brown & Sons, Inc. ``It's tough enough to do a startup, but it's almost impossible to do in a bad climate like this.'' When he first set out to bring a second daily newspaper to St. Louis to compete with the 111-year-old St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Ingersoll said he hoped his effort would help invigorate the newspaper industry. And even though the Sun didn't make it, he hasn't ruled out the possibility of trying it again somewhere else. Certainly, no one else is going to try it, analysts say. ``First of all, Ingersoll was a maverick and there aren't many mavericks around. Second of all, this is a very unfriendly environment for newspapers right now,'' said Lisa Donneson, a stock analyst in New York for County NatWest USA. At a Wednesday news conference, Ingersoll said the reason the Sun didn't last longer was its failure to sell enough newspapers out of vending boxes and newspaper racks in stores. Ingersoll expected to sell most of the news newspapers on a single-copy basis, but soon after the paper started, home-delivery sales outnumbered single-copy sales by a two-to-one margin. That cost the Sun $5 million more than planned. Ingersoll said the newspaper had spent more than $25 million to start up, but he didn't know how much of that would be recoverable. On Thursday, in the Sun newsroom where windows overlook the Gateway Arch and clocks tell what time it is in Tokyo, some of the newspaper's 194 full-time employees cleaned out their desks and pondered the future. Some showed up in white shirts and ties and talked about job interviews they had just returned from. Some still peppered their sentences with words like ``shocked'' and ``stunned.'' And some talked about Thursday's softball game, the first of the season. ``We're going to play as far as I know,'' said the Sun's Business editor Dan Kadlec, who was in the office with his wife and five-month-old daughter. He left a job at USA Today and moved to St. Louis from New York to work for the Sun. ``I haven't even unpacked,'' he said. Some reporters said they were upset that Ingersoll didn't give the Sun more time to prove itself and more notice of the newspaper's collapse. They said the general consensus in the office was that they had two years to try to make it. ``I knew that this newspaper might not be around after two-and-a-half years, but it didn't think he would pull the plug so soon,'' said Ellen Whitford, a general assignment reporter who came to the Sun from Virginia. ``I'm going to start applying for jobs, but the market's pretty bad, so I guess you could say I feel pretty grim at the moment,'' she said. Ingersoll said all employees would be given at least 12 weeks severance pay and efforts would be made to find them jobs at other newspapers in the Ingersoll chain. Meetings were scheduled for Monday and Tuesday to discuss parting benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Transfers Oil Test Tank to Interior Department
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department will reopen, refurbish and manage a 2.5 million gallon oil spill test tank at a Navy site in Leonardo, N.J., according to an agreement signed Thursday. The tank, which fell into disrepair after closing in 1987, is the only one of its kind in North America that accommodates full-scale oil cleanup equipment. Research there has produced most of what experts know about oil spill response. Officials hope to reopen the Oil and Hazardous Materials Simulated Environmental Test Tank near the Earle Naval Weapons Station by 1991. ``This is a milestone event for oil spill containment and cleanup research operations,'' said Barry A. Williamson, director of the Interior Department's Minerals Management Service. He and Navy Rear Adm. Robert Ailes, deputy commander of the Naval Sea Systems Command, signed documents Thursday transferring control of the facility to the Minerals Management Service for five years. Following oil spills in Prince William Sound in Alaska and along the Delaware River, politicians began focusing attention on reactivating the wave-generating tank, which simulates open water conditions for testing prototypes of booms and small skimmers. Jim Nash, a former engineer at the facility, has estimated it will cost $500,000 to resume operations. at the tank, which is 667 feet long, 67 feet wide and 8 feet deep. According to Thursday's agreement, the cost of operating the tank will be shared by the Minerals Management Service, the Coast Guard and Environment Canada, which is Canada's environmental department. Angela Calos, a spokeswoman for Minerals Management, declined to disclose how much money is being set aside for the project, but said the American Petroleum Institute indicated willingness to underwrite some research at the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Piano Man to Play at House That Ruth Built
DOC.TEXT: Now playing center field at Yankee Stadium ... Billy Joel. The five-time Grammy winner, whose most recent album is the former No. 1 ``Storm Front,'' will become the first rocker to headline a show at the stadium, as far as New York Yankees officials can determine. Two popes and several heavyweight fights have sold out the stadium, but no musical acts. Joel will play a June 22 concert at the Bronx ballpark, the playground of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle, to name a few. His piano will be set up in left-center field. The show, for an expected 57,000 fans, will be a homecoming for the native New Yorker. ``It's the House that Ruth Built, man. It's a magic place,'' Joel said in a telephone interview from Chicago. ``The day we set up, I'm going to walk out to the mound and do a little pitching, maybe shag a few flies.'' The show will be part of Joel's second swing through the United States on a tour that began last year. On May 5, he begins a one-month European tour. Joel, who early in his career played under the nom-de-tune Billy Martin, said there's a possibility of a second show at the stadium if the first sells out. The show will be co-promoted by Yankees owner George Steinbrenner, whose biggest concern was the Yankees infield. Joel, who first visited the stadium for a late '50s World Series game, agreed. ``That's understandable. That grass is sacrosanct,'' he said. Joel's group will not be the first band to play at the stadium. The Beach Boys and the Charlie Daniels Band have performed following Yankee games in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms And Record Warm Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Another day of thunderstorms with heavy rain over the southern Plains caused severe flooding Thursday in Texas, and more high temperature records were toppled in the northeastern quarter of the nation. Snow fell along the northern Rockies. San Antonio, Texas, got 2.5 inches of rain in one hour near sunrise, the National Weather Service said. From Wednesday evening to Thursday afternoon, more than 5 inches of rain fell across Clay County, Texas. Severe flooding was reported in the counties to the west and southwest of Fort Worth, and hundreds of people were evacuated, especially in the city of Brownwood, where most major traffic routes were under water. Flooding also continued in south-central Oklahoma, where 6 or more inches of rain had fallen fell since Wednesday morning. Elsewhere during the afternoon, showers and thunderstorms extended from west-central Missouri across southeastern Kansas, Oklahoma, the lower Texas Gulf Coast and south-central Texas. Showers reached from central Colorado across north-central Wyoming, and over northern Montana. Showers turned to snow at higher elevations of Colorado and Wyoming. Three inches of snow fell overnight on the continental divide west of Denver and as much as 8 additional inches of snow was possible during the night in Colorado's higher elevations. Rain also fell over northwestern Minnesota, eastern North Dakota and northeastern South Dakota, and from northwestern Oregon into southwestern Washington state. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. CDT, all in Texas, included 3 inches at Beeville, 2.58 inches at Killeen, 2.23 inches at Austin, 1.94 inches at Waco, 1.74 inches at Dallas and 1.39 inches at Austin. In central Kansas, a tornado that swept through Ellis County on Wednesday evening destroyed six homes and several outbuildings, officials said Thursday. No injuries were reported. Record highs Thursday were 91 in downtown Baltimore; 85 at Flint, Mich.; 84 at Marquette, Mich.; 90 at Philadelphia; 85 at Syracuse, N.Y.; and 88 at Wilmington, Del. Alpena, Mich., tied its record of 79 and Williamsport, Pa., tied its record of 91. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 24 at Burns, Ore. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 32 at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 99 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Voices Opposition to Iraqi Sanctions Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New with Baker comments first 4 grafs; editing thruout
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday that the United States is reviewing loans granted to Iraq that allow it to buy American farm products. Baker, in comments to reporters after he met with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, said officials are ``reviewing the situation with respect to the relationship'' with Iraq, ``particularly ... the matter of CCC credits.'' Through the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation, the United States guaranteed loans for Iraq to buy $500 million in agricultural products last November. Baghdad has asked for another $500 million in credits. Baker said stronger sanctions, similar to those imposed against Libya and Iran, ``have never been under consideration.'' He spoke shortly after Assistant Secretary of State John H. Kelly reiterated to a House committee the Bush administration's objection to sanctions against Iraq that have been proposed in Congress. Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein, has reportedly used chemical weapons to kill thousands of Kurds living in his nation _ a charge the Iraqi government denies _ and has threatened to use the weapons against Israel. ``While we do not rule out appropriate responses to recent actions by the government of Iraq, we are not prepared to see economic and trade sanctions legislatively imposed at this point,'' Kelly told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Middle East. His comments were met with incredulity by several committee members. ``There is an Alice-in-Wonderland element in your testimony,'' Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., told Kelly. ``At what point will the United States recognize that (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein is not a nice guy?'' Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif. and the author of legislation that would bar giving Iraq the agricultural credits and disallow the sale of items, such as computers, that can be used for both military and peaceful purposes, asked what would trigger stronger administration action. Kelly acknowledged the Saddam's recent behavior had damaged relations between Washington and Baghdad. ``Recent developments, taken together, are serious,'' he said. ``They raise questions in our minds about the intentions of Iraq's leaders towards such international commitments as the non-proliferaton treaty and the Geneva protocol banning the use of chemical weapons.'' Still, Kelly said the administration doesn't think legislatively imposed sanctions would work to temper Saddam's actions. In fact, they would hurt the U.S. trade deficit by reducing U.S. exports. Kelly said the United States is interested in seeing Saddam change his ways. There is a ``possibility of improvement and we want to encourage that improvement,'' he said. In general, the United States is interested in having relations with Iraq because of the country importance in the Middle East. The country is second to Saudi Arabia in oil reserves.

DOC.HEAD: Verdi Requiem Honors Those Who Died in Nazi Death Camp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No leads planned
DOC.TEXT: In 1944, Jews imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp in Czechoslovakia performed Verdi's ``Requiem,'' the Catholic Mass for the dead, and in a few days were themselves deported to death camps. To commemorate those who participated in the ``Requiem'' at the Terezin camp near Prague, the Verdi work was being performed Thursday night at Carnegie Hall by the 150-member New York Choral Society, with Robert DeCormier conducting. The 1944 performance was organized as the Germans were losing ground in World War II and trying to cover up atrocities in the concentration camps. The Terezin camp's Nazi commandant wanted a program to show the Red Cross that Terezin was a ``model ghetto.'' The young conductor Rafael Schachter, held at Terezin, organized Jews in the camp to perform the work. Their lines, in Latin, included, ``Therefore, when the Judge shall be seated, nothing shall be held hidden any longer, no wrong shall remain unpunished.'' Despite the camp commandant's promise to Schachter, he and nearly all the 150 singers and musicians were deported to death camps a few days after the performance. The Carnegie Hall performance was being introduced by Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, as part of a week of Holocaust memorial observances. Janet Robb, Yanyu Guo, Gregory Hopkins and Richard Zeller were scheduled soloists.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda's Blood Pressure Soars; Recess Called
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th, ``She's improved ... '' to UPDATE with Mrs. Marcos reported resting comfortably at home
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' blood pressure soared Thursday, forcing a recess of her trial, after she heard testimony about the day she and her husband fled the Philippines with a ``tremendous amount of jewels'' and cash. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan adjourned the trial until Friday morning, provided the former Philippines first lady was able to return. Her lawyer, Gerald Spence, said he expected her back in court. ``I think it was the reliving of probably the saddest day of her life,'' Spence said. ``It brings back vividly her memories of that day.'' Spence said Mrs. Marcos, 60, wanted the testimony to continue, but her doctor would not permit it. Mrs. Marcos was sobbing during the testimony, and went to the nurse's station in Manhattan's federal court when the lunch recess was called. Her doctor examined her and found her blood pressure was extremely high, and the nurse confirmed his findings, Spence said. ``Her blood pressure is going up and down at this particular time,'' Spence said. Mrs. Marcos rested in the nurse's office, then left the courthouse on foot and with friends. ``She's very distressed about her memories,'' Spence told reporters. ``She has been the pillar of strength for our side up to this time.'' The nurse, Marian Leonard, refused to answer questions about Mrs. Marcos' physical symptoms, but said: ``She became very upset, kind of emotional. She's under a lot of stress, as you know. ... ``She's improved. She just needs a little rest.'' Another Marcos attorney, John Tigue, said later that Mrs. Marcos returned to her Manhattan apartment and was ``resting comfortably.'' He added, ``We expect her to be well enough to be in court tomorrow.'' Mrs. Marcos' husband died last September in Hawaii.
