The incident climaxed a morning of dramatic testimony and a surprise visit to the courtroom by film actress Bo Derek, accompanying members of the family of Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant. Mrs. Marcos became upset during the testimony of U.S. Customs agent Leslie E. Kinney. He supervised the arrival of Mrs. Marcos and her husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, in Honolulu on Feb. 26, 1986, the day after Marcos was ousted as president in a civil revolt. Kinney told of the official greeting party and red carpet that awaited the Marcoses and their entourage of 90 people at Hickam Air Force Base, Hawaii. He said some of the hundreds of suitcases and boxes that accompanied the entourage contained a ``tremendous amount of jewels and luxury items as well as money.'' Kinney said one of the most striking things he found was a case on which was embossed, ``Ferdinand Marcos, on our 24th wedding anniversary.'' Inside, Kinney said, were 24 gold bars each weighing about a kilogram. That would be worth about $286,000 at Thursday's gold prices. Mrs. Marcos has been on trial since March 20. She has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, obstruction of justice and mail fraud for allegedly stealing $220 million from the Philippines treasury to buy New York real estate and art. Her husband had been charged in the 1988 indictment. When Keenan excused jurors for the day, he told them not to speculate on why the trial was recessed, saying the reason was ``nothing unusual.'' As he does at the end of every day, the judge told jurors not to read, watch or listen to any media reports about the case. Mrs. Marcos' lawyers earlier asked Keenan to caution the jury against watching a mini-series, ``A Dangerous Life,'' which dramatized the fall of the Marcos regime. The three-part series was televised on a cable station this week.

DOC.HEAD: Political Crisis on President Chamorro's First Day in Office
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro encountered a political crisis in her first full day in office Thursday for allowing the Sandinistas to retain temporary control of the army and security forces. Her decision to be her own defense minister but to allow Gen. Humberto Ortega to stay on as army chief drew fire from rebel leaders and split her coalition in the national legislature. Ortega is the brother of former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. Two ministers Mrs. Chamorro had named to her Cabinet refused to serve as long as Gen. Ortega remained. Rebel leaders refused to surrender their weapons to United Nations peacekeepers and talked about taking to the hills and renewing their war against the Sandinistas. A news conference scheduled for 11 a.m. by Mrs. Chamorro was canceled without explanation and she remained out of sight for most of the day. Journalists' telephone calls to the presidential office went unanswered. Immediately after her inauguration Wednesday, Mrs. Chamorro abolished the unpopular compulsory military service that forced youths into the Sandinista army to fight a nine-year war against the U.S.-backed rebels, known as Contras. She also announced plans to depoliticize the army and reduced it in size. With an estimated 150,000 soldiers, it is the biggest in Central America. Her transition team explained that her decision to retain Humberto Ortega and other Sandinista security officials was a temporary one. But this did not mollify her United National Opposition. The coalition of 14 parties ranges from Communist to conservative. UNO representatives in the National Legislature are split between those willing to go along with Mrs. Chamorro, and those who demand Ortega's removal. An agreement signed last week by Mrs. Chamorro's transition team, the Contras and the Sandinistas called for the Contras to voluntarily surrender their weapons to U.N. military peacekeepers and disband by June 10. Up to her inauguration, Mrs. Chamorro remained vague about allowing Sandinista officers to keep command of the army. The Sandinistas warned all along of renewed war if she made any attempt to alter the armed forces in any profound way. When word leaked that the Sandinistas would remain in control, the Contras balked at disarming. Hours after Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration Wednesday, Israel Galeano and Oscar Sovalbarro, commanding about 3,000 out of 5,000 Contra fighters in Safety Zone 1 in the northern village of El Destino, refused to disarm. There are a total of 9,000 Contra rebels inside Nicaragua. Like Zone 1, reports from the other four internationally monitored enclaves showed that few if any Contras had actually surrendered their weapons. Mrs. Chamorro's UNO coalition handily won elections on Feb. 25, ending 11 years of Sandinista rule and confrontation with the United States. Washington accused the Sandinistas of endangering regional security with their close military ties to Cuba and the Soviet Union and imposed an economic embargo. The 60-year-old Mrs. Chamorro is the widow of publisher Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, whose assassination helped ignite the 1979 revolution that brought the Sandinistas to power. Nicaragua's confrontation with the United States ended when Mrs. Chamorro was sworn in for a six-year term. Vice President Dan Quayle attended the inauguration and the Bush administration lifted trade and other sanctions against Nicaragua and prepared to help revive its battered economy But the Sandinistas, who got 41 percent of the vote, remained Nicaragua's single biggest political party. This became evident after the inauguration. Manuel Espinosa, information minister while Daniel Ortega was president, called reporters Thursday to tip them that ``the defense ministry just told me to say the Contras are reconcentrating in San Rafael del Norte,'' a town near one of the security zones. No one knew for sure if he still had a government job. Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos was still Defense Ministry spokeswoman, but when journalists called to check out the report she was not immediately available, an aide said. A brawl _ after much drinking _ broke out at a ``popular fiesta'' in Managua late Wednesday to celebrate Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration and was put down by the Sandinista-controlled police. Three people were injured, and about a dozen revelers were arrested. A man, who had four front teeth knocked out by police, said the fray apparently started over an argument that the square where the fiesta was held should be renamed Plaza of the Republic, and not Plaza of the Revolution as the Sandinistas had it.

DOC.HEAD: Technician Charged With Inserting Religion Into Porn Broadcast
DOC.TEXT: A television technician was charged with federal criminal violations Thursday for allegedly interrupting the satellite transmission of a pornographic television show with religious messages. Thomas M. Haynie, a technician for the Christian Broadcast Network in Virginia Beach, Va., was accused of using his employer's satellite transmission equipment to break into transmissions of a program called ``American Ecstasy'' on the Playboy cable television channel, the Justice Department said. A department news release described the interrupted cable broadcast as ``a hard-core pornography show.'' The program was interrupted three times on Sept. 6, 1987, with the video message: ``Thus sayeth the Lord thy God. Remember the sabbath and keep it holy. Repent, the kingdom of God is at hand!'' according to the indictment. The indictment, returned by a federal grand jury in Norfolk, Va., charged Haynie with intentional interference with two communications satellites, including one used by the Playboy Channel to transmit the program to its cable outlets. The charge carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. According to the indictment, Haynie was in charge of maintaining the earth station at Christian Broadcast Network and knew how to send signals to communications satellites. The case was investigated by prosecutors in the criminal division of the Justice Department, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Courts Conservatives
DOC.TEXT: President Bush won applause from conservative leaders Thursday by voicing support for an array of causes ranging from a cut in capital gains taxes to a constitutional amendment allowing prayer in public schools. Bush previously has endorsed all of the proposals he cited before the conservatives, but the leaders were still appreciative, anyway. Bush spoke before nearly 200 people in the Old Executive Office Building in the latest in a series of meetings with conservative leaders, whom Bush credited with helping him win the presidency. Bush said the past two decades have demonstrated the conservatism is ``a philosophy to which most Americans subscribe. And I think that's still very true across the country.'' He joked that ``some reporters say I don't have a vision. Sorry, I don't see it.'' More seriously, he said his vision revolves around an America that is prosperous and at peace. Calling for a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, Bush said a cut would spur business investment and create new jobs. Along with his call for a constitutional amendment on school prayer, Bush also urged that presidents be given a power known as line-item veto, permitting them to delete individual items in large appropriation bills. He won loud applause by saying that in any federal program for child care, ``I will not see the option of relgious-based child care restricted or eliminated. We're going to fight against that.'' He made only a passing reference to Lithuania, which is struggling against Soviet pressure to break away from Moscow's control. ``In Lithuania _ as in Czechoslovakia and Nicaragua, Budapest, Berlin _ the words of Thomas Dewey ring true _ you can't beat down ideas with a club. Today, freedom is on the march and will not be denied.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration: Ban on `Saturday Night Specials' Would Harm Citizens
DOC.TEXT: A bill extending the ban on imported ``Saturday night specials'' to domestic arms manufacturers would deprive some Americans of the ability to defend themselves with handguns, the Bush administration said Thursday. Gun control opponents paint the attempt to outlaw small, cheaply made handguns as a class and racial issue because poor people, especially blacks, are more often the victims of crime and inadequate police protection. Assistant Attorney General S.G. Dennis Jr. told the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on crime Thursday that a total ban on the handguns commonly known as ``Saturday night specials'' would ``deprive citizens who do not already own a handgun of their ability to obtain one suitable for self-defense but not for sporting purposes.'' But the committee's chairman, William J. Hughes, D-N.J., and other Democrats said it was hypocritical to ban imports and not domestic versions of the weapons. ``I regret that you have to come up here and advance that argument,'' Hughes said. ``I just think if you can't take it in you ought not to be able to sell it here,'' said Rep. Romano L. Mazzoli, D-Ky. But Dennis said the administration was called to testify on the bill that is being proposed, not the law that has been on the books since the late 1960s. The administration has no proposal to repeal that law, he said. The proposed legislation, ``The Handgun Violence Prevention Act,'' would ban the manufacture, assembly, acquisition and future transfer of the Saturday night special-type pistols, said sponsor Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla. The Gun Control Act of 1968 banned the import of guns that lacked ``sporting purposes'' and required the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms to create a panel to screen weapons using a point system. The administration used that standard last year to ban the import of rapid-fire, multiround rifles that have been used by drug dealers and in mass killings. The subcommittee has approved legislation covering the U.S.-made versions of those so-called assault rifles. Among those testifying was former White House Press Secretary James Brady, who used the occasion to argue for another proposed bill bearing his name. The Brady bill would require a waiting period for anyone wanting to buy firearms to let authorities check the record of the would-be purchaser. The bill is so-named because Brady, the former press secretary to President Ronald Reagan, was seriously wounded and remains disabled as a result of the assassination attempt on Reagan in 1981. The attacker, John Hinckley, was able to buy a .22-caliber pistol easily despite a record of mental illness. Another James Brady _ James C. Brady _ allegedly used a higher-caliber pistol made by the same company to gun down five people at an Atlanta shopping mall on Tuesday. Brady had bought a pistol hours after being discharged from a mental hospital, where he had been treated for homicidal and suicidal tendencies.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President to Study French-German Proposal on Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said Thursday he will carefully study a proposal from France and West Germany that the Baltic republic temporarily suspend its independence drive. The letter from French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, delivered to Lithuanian representatives in Moscow, said such a suspension could lead to talks with the Kremlin ``so that the current crisis ends in a solution acceptable to all parties.'' Also Thursday, Vilnius Radio reported Lithuania will begin food rationing May 1. The republic of 3.8 million people is struggling under an economic embargo imposed last week by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to break its campaign for independence. Gorbachev himself was confronted Thursday by activists protesting his crackdown in Lithuania. During his visit in an industrial city in the Ural Mountains, demonstrators raised a banner that called him a ``political hypocrite.'' Landsbergis described the letter from Mitterrand and Kohl as ``a step forward toward the realization of Lithuanian independence,'' said parliamentary spokesman Ed Tuskenis, speaking by telephone. Lithuania wants an immediate dialogue, Landsbergis said, and ``a termination of the Soviet economic blockade against Lithuania would be beneficial to the atmosphere of this dialogue.'' ``The leadership of Lithuania, greatly appreciating this act of goodwill on the part of two noted leaders, will carefully study this letter's proposition,'' he added. Tuskenis said Landsbergis viewed ``as positive'' that the letter from Kohl and Mitterrand did not mention revoking Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. The letter discussed temporary suspension of some decisions by the Lithuanian parliament. The letter from the French and German leaders came two days after President Bush said he would put off sanctions against Moscow for bringing economic and military pressure against Lithuania. Kremlin authorities on Monday urged Lithuania to suspend for two years its declaration of independence. Lithuanian leaders have refused to revoke the declaration. But the Baltic republic's leadership has always been willing ``to discuss the timing and the form of independence, whether or not that's a year or two,'' Tuskenis said after talking to Landsbergis. Lithuania has increased its efforts to circumvent the sanctions imposed last week by Gorbachev. A Lithuanian delegation was due in Leningrad on Friday to talk with officials about a direct exchange of goods either for hard currency or barter, a Leningrad journalist said. Another group arrived in Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, and met with local lawmakers, according to the grassroots group Rukh. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene announced Wednesday that Lithuania had halted its usual shipments of meat, milk and other food to the rest of the Soviet Union. She instead urged Lithuania to settle its accounts with the republics ``almost in marketplace conditions'' of bartering for other goods. The emergency committee of Lithuania's leadership considering responses to Moscow's embargo has decided to start rationing some food products beginning May 1, according to Vilnius Radio. No details were released. Unlike most Soviet republics, Lithuania produces all the meat and dairy goods it needs, so the rationing presumably would be of those foodstuffs it does not produce, or of meat and milk products earmarked for export. Gasoline already is being rationed in the republic since Gorbachev cut off its oil and curtailed natural gas deliveries by more than 80 percent last week. Individuals are limited to 7.8 gallons of gasoline per month. Sugar and soap detergent also is being rationed, the radio said. Hospitals, running low on medicine, discouraged all but emergency surgery, Radio Vilnius reported. In addition, newspapers prepared to cut back the size of their editions by as much as half. Even if Lithuania were able to strike barter deals with other Soviet republics, transporting the goods would be difficult, because Moscow controls the train, truck routes and pipelines throughout the nation. Lithuania may be getting some help from neighboring Estonia. That republic's leadership is expected to order its railway workers to ignore directives from Moscow to stop sending goods to Lithuania, according to a spokesman for Estonia's Foreign Ministry. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Lithuania's top diplomat in the West said in Rome Thursday the Baltic state was prepared to make ``all possible concessions'' to Moscow except revoking its independence declaration. Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., who heads the Lithuanian diplomatic mission to Washington and the Vatican, also distanced himself from sharp criticism of the Bush administration by Landsbergis for not instituting sanctions. Lozoraitis, speaking at a luncheon of The American Club of Rome, called the United States a ``staunch friend'' of Lithuania and said it was probably too late to influence Moscow through economic pressure. ``It (Moscow) will not react to the sanctions,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Mark Accident With Biggest Commemoration Yet
LaserPhotos MOS23, VIE4
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 10th graf pvs `The Chernobyl' to UPDATE with fundraising figures; INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th pvs, `In the ... TV reported' with protest in small village and evening activity in Minsk. Picks up 14th pvs, `On the...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviets joined wdespread protests, a 24-hour telethon and a strike at a major factory Thursday to mark the fourth anniversary of the world's worst nuclear accident, the reactor explosion at Chernobyl. It was the Soviet Union's biggest national commemoration of the 1986 disaster, and it followed years of state-encouraged passivity on the topic. This year, the Ukrainian legislature designated Thursday as ``Chernobyl Tragedy Day'' and its Byelorussian counterpart passed a similar measure. Other government bodies in contaminated areas sanctioned demonstrations. Official reports say 31 people were killed when one of four reactors at the Chernobyl plant, in the Ukraine, caught fire and exploded April 26, 1986. Unofficial reports say 250 died. The blast spewed cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. For the first two days after the accident, the Soviet Union refused to report it to the outside world and withheld information from its own people on the scope of the contamination. Residents in the southwestern Soviet regions most affected by the partial meltdown organized demonstrations Thursday to demand better medical treatment, protection from radiation and punishment for officials who covered up the accident's effects, activists said. In Kiev, the Ukrainian capital 70 miles south of Chernobyl, 70,000 people gathered for Mass outside the 11th century Saint Sophia Cathedral, reported Rukh Press International, a branch of the Ukrainian people's front. In a subsequent protest, drivers stopped traffic for five minutes and honked their car horns, the report said. In the Byelorussian city of Gomel, most of the 35,000 employees of the GomSelMash industrial complex staged a daylong strike, said Alexander Korniev, a plant worker. Their demands included prompt closure of the Chernobyl plant and criminal charges against all officials involved in the cover-up. Three of Chernobyl's four reactors continue to operate. The Chernobyl Telethon, one of the Soviet Union's first experiences with televised fund-raising, collected the equivalent of about $115 million in rubles, as well $5 million in U.S. dollars, organizers said. The live broadcast from Moscow interspersed singing groups and interviews with gripping footage of Chernobyl rescuers and children from the contaminated zone suffering radiation-caused cancers. Along with money, telethon pledges included donations of radiation-free fruit and 1,100 pounds of honey for children in the contaminated area. In the Byelorussian cities of Minsk and Gomel and throughout the Ukraine, tens of thousands of residents gathered for church services and mourning protests, Soviet TV reported. Vetka, north of Gomel, was among the small villages staging demonstrations and strikes, according to local councilman Oleg Gromyko. After dusk, Minsk residents lighted thousands of candles and rang church bells, Tass reported. On the eve of the anniversary, the national parliament adopted a $26 billion program that would involve resettling an additional 200,000 people from irradiated areas. After the accident, about 116,000 people were evacuated, and some Soviet scientists and politicians have been campaigning for further resettlements. They say 4 million Soviets live on contaminated land. Many Chernobyl-area residents have complained of inadequate medical care. Cases of anemia, leukemia and cancers have been reported rising among people living on contaminated land. Many residents still eat irradiated food because alternatives are not available. Social and environmental fallout from the Chernobyl accident continue in neighboring countries as well. In Sweden, which was in the path of the radioactive cloud, authorities reported that fish from about 15 percent of its lakes still are too contaminated to be eaten. It may take 30 years before health authorities will clear the lakes. In Norway, newspapers reported that the level of cancer-causing substances in the most affected regions is 10 times the normal levels in plants and up to 20 times above normal in topsoil. In Czechoslovakia, Greenpeace environmentals scaled a cooling tower at a nuclear power station. To cheers from onlookers they hung a banner saying, ``Stop CSFRnobyl _ Greenpeace.'' CSFR is the initials for the name of the Czech and Slovak Federative Republic. A Czechoslovak hospital urged prosecution of its country's Communist Party and government officials, whom it charged with failing to take measures to protect citizens after the Chernobyl accident. Official Soviet willingness to play up the Chernobyl anniversary reflected the growing awareness of the catastrophe as well as the reformist views of many new local governing councils. The television news program ``Vremya'' focused its afternoon show on Chernobyl reports. ``We have been silent too long,'' a Vremya reporter said. The Soviet legislature's new program was adopted Wednesday even though many members criticized it as inadequate to deal with the health, agricultural, economic and environmental aftermath of the accident. The $26 billion earmarked Wednesday is twice the level spent in the four years since the accident but still far short of the $405 billion Ukrainian legislator Yuri Scherback has estimated is needed over the next 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Rejects Social Security Tax Cut
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 6 grafs new with committee update of vote tally and party breakdown; picks up 6th graf pvs: ``Earlier Thursday,''
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Budget Committee on Thursday refused to endorse a $36.5 billion Social Security tax cut for next year. The non-binding vote was Congress' first formal show of sentiment on the politically sensitive proposal. By 17-6, the panel rejected the offering by Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C. It was based on an almost identical measure advanced last December by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., as a way of forcing action on the federal deficit. ``This nonsense has got to stop,'' Hollings said before the vote. ``We are wrecking ourselves. We are wrecking our country.'' Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said he supported the idea of reducing the tax rate but feared the consequences it would have on the budget deficit. ``We've got to have a way to replace that revenue loss,'' he said. Nine Democrats and eight Republicans voted against the tax cut plan, while four Democrats and two Republicans supported it. Earlier Thursday, the committee rejected four 1991 deficit-reduction plans after the panel's majority Democrats failed to unite behind a single package. The votes on the deficit plans left the committee floundering in its search for a way to slash at least $37 billion from next year's budget shortfall, which the Gramm-Rudman law requires. The panel's work is expected to continue into next week. Across the Capitol, the House continued debating a $1.24 trillion budget for next year that provides less for defense and more for domestic programs than President Bush prefers. Final House approval of the Democratic-written plan is expected Tuesday. The House rejected two Republican-sponsored alternatives. A proposal by Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio., to freeze military and domestic spending at current levels lost 305-106. A plan by Rep. William Dannemeyer of California featuring the use of gold-backed bonds to reduce the government's debt costs was defeated 354-48. The Social Security vote was only symbolic in nature. Congress' budget committees set targets for revenue collection, but other committees decide which taxes will be raised and by how much. But the issue has been sensitive. The White House has accused supporters of the tax cut of ultimately wanting to reduce Social Security benefits. Some Democrats have supported the proposal because of the attractiveness of offering a tax cut, but others have opposed the plan, arguing that it would simply make the deficit even larger. The provision would have lowered the 6.2 percent payroll tax to 5.1 percent next Jan. 1. The tax is paid by both wage earners and employers. A family with a median income of $32,000 would save $400 a year. Over five years the reduction would have lowered payroll taxes by $267 billion. Moynihan and Hollings have complained that the Social Security trust fund is building up huge surpluses each year that make the government's overall deficit appear smaller. Cutting the Social Security tax, and thus reducing that surplus, would force lawmakers to address the shortfall problem, the two Senators say. In defeating the four deficit-reduction proposals, Republicans on the Senate panel did what they have been promising to do for weeks. They have said any budget written solely by Congress will be meaningless because Bush will veto elements he opposes, such as deep defense cuts and tax increases. ``It can't be carried out, it can't be implemented,'' the committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, said during a break. ``You just have to have both houses of Congress and the president involved to get anything meaningful.'' The committee's 13 Democrats divided their votes about evenly. As a result, the panel rejected four Democratic plans that called for savings ranging from $50 billion to $56.5 billion. All the Democratic plans relied more on defense cuts and tax collections than Bush wants. They also surpassed the $37 billion in deficit reduction the president proposed in January. But each one of them was turned down as Democrats skeptical that the savings could be enacted into law joined the bloc of Republicans. The only proposal that came close to approval was offered by Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., which lost on an 11-11 tie. Measures must receive a majority of votes to be approved. Wirth proposed imposing a $5 per barrel oil import fee, and spending the $6.4 billion raised for environment, education and deficit-cutting efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Lawmakers Declare Falklands Part of Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Argentina's Congress voted Thursday to claim the Falkland Islands, eight years after losing a war with Britain over the remote South Atlantic archipelago. Britain immediately objected to the measure, which appeared to be largely symbolic. The legislation, approved despite opposition by Argentina's foreign ministry, declares the Falklands _ known in Argentina as the Malvinas _ to be part of the new Argentine province of Tierra del Fuego. It also covers the Sandwich and South Georgia islands, also British possessions. In London, a spokesman for the British Foreign Office, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``We don't accept this or any other Argentinian claim to British territory.'' The Senate has already approved the legislation, and President Carlos Menem was expected to sign it. Menem said the measure ``does not signify that England recognize our sovereignty, but rather, simply, that we ratified the Malvinas are ours.'' He added he did not expect the move to ``cause obstacles'' in relations with Britain. Britain has held the Falklands since 1833. In 1982, Britain and Argentina fought a 74-day war over the windswept islands, causing the deaths of nearly 1,000 men. Argentina's ruling Peronist party had pushed for the inclusion of the Falklands in the legislation creating the new province. However, critics warned that the measure could backfire. They said the move could hamper Argentina's continuing claims of sovereignty by giving credence to British arguments that Argentina might try to impose its will on the 1,900 islanders. The islanders are British subjects and say they prefer to remain so. For seven years after the war, Argentina refused to formally declare a cessation of hostilities. Diplomatic ties were severed and relations handled through third countries. Commerce, trade, travel and investment declined. Improving ties was one of Menem's top foreign policy goals after he became president last July. Consulates were upgraded to embassies, direct air travel resumed, and a military exclusion zone around the islands lifted. Britain and Argentina restored full diplomatic relations Feb. 16, following two days of talks between the two countries in Madrid. Britain agreed to lift a 150-mile military protection zone enforced around the islands since Argentina invaded them in June 1982. The agreement said new arrangements to ensure the security of the islands would involve advance notice by both sides of military maneuvers in the area. By mutual assent, their agreement did not touch on the two countries' conflicting claims to the Falklands. The British Foreign Office spokesman in London said: ``The recent progress made on British-Argentine relations was only possible on the understanding that we were not willing to discuss sovereignty. And we will be repeating our views via diplomatic channels.'' The new province was created in response to demands by Argentine residents of the island of Tierra del Fuego for greater government representation. It had been Argentina's lone territory. Chile shares ownership of the island at the foot of South America. The dividing line between Chile and Argentina was extended years ago through Tierra del Fuego. Under the measure, residents of the new province would elect a governor, who is now appointed by the president. Representation in the national Chamber of Deputies would double to four, and two Senate seats were to be alloted. The provincial capital is to be Ushuaia, 2,260 miles south of Buenos Aires and the southernmost city in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Calls for Big Cuts in Plans for B-2, Other Aircraft
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 5 grafs after 5th graf pvs, bgng: Citing analysts, to UPDATE with comment from Nunn; INSERTS 1 graf after 21st graf pvs, The cuts, with Cheney disclosing cost figures on A-12
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday called for slashing Pentagon plans for the B-2 stealth bomber and other sophisticated aircraft, citing a diminishing Soviet threat. Cheney, pressed by congressional Democrats to cut military spending in response to rapid changes in Europe, testified his blueprint would trim $2.4 billion from President Bush's $307 billion defense budget for 1991 and would save $34.8 billion through 1997. In addition to cutting the proposed number of B-2 bombers from 132 to 75, Cheney said he intends to cut planned purchases of the C-17 long-range transport plane and the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft, and to delay purchases of the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Aircraft and the Advanced Tactical Fighter. The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., commended Cheney for ``coming to grips with some things he clearly needs to come to grips with'' but said he didn't go far enough. Citing analysts' testimony one day earlier on the internal problems in the Soviet military as well as U.S. intelligence reports predicting instability of the broader Soviet economy, Aspin said Cheney's plan ``is based on an unrealistically pessimistic view of the Soviet threat.'' Cheney later presented his plan to the Senate Armed Services Committee, where the panel's chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., gave the secretary high marks for his efforts but declined to adopt the program totals. Nunn was puzzled, however, by Cheney's ability to reduce aircraft programs without final figures on the armed forces. ``How can you make the decision on the numbers without having a firm force structure in mind?'' Nunn asked. Cheney said the present situation dictates cuts in the B-2 and C-17, and possible reductions in aircraft carriers and Air Force wings will decide the other programs. ``I can tell you with some conviction that both the Navy and the Air Force are going to be a lot smaller in the future than they are today,'' Cheney said. The Democratic-controlled House is already debating a fiscal 1991 budget that would make significant cuts in proposed Pentagon spending. The Senate is working on its own version. Cheney told the House committee, ``Soviet military capability will continue to be robust but we can in fact afford to slow down the pace of developing and fielding the next generation of aircraft. He said NATO faces ``fewer enemy aircraft and a reduced ground threat'' as a result of the dramatic changes sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The defense secretary said that although the Soviet Union has consistently found a way to upgrade its military despite economic woes, ``we expect the overall performance of their economy to have an impact on what they're able to build and deploy by the way of sophisticated new weapons systems.'' He predicted a slip in the years in which the new systems will be deployed. Cheney said his proposed cutback would lower the projected cost of the B-2 program from $75.4 billion to $61.1 billion. But he said building fewer planes would drive up the cost of a single plane from about $530 million to more than $800 million. ``We are in fact looking at targeting requirements,'' Cheney said, noting the obvious change in what would be deemed targets in Eastern Europe since the collapse of the Warsaw Pact. Cheney said he intends to cut the number of B-2 aircraft to be purchased in the next fiscal year to two planes, from the five currently proposed at a cost in the fiscal 1991 budget of $5.5 billion. And the maximum number of planes to be built during peak years of production would be reduced to 12 instead of 24, Cheney indicated. Conservatives on the House panel suggested that Cheney's plan for the B-2 will help the program survive on Capitol Hill. ``It could make it more palatable to members on defense,'' Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., said following the hearing. Rep. Robert Davis, R-Mich., said Cheney has given Republicans ``a very dependable position, something we can sell to the House and the American people.'' But Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., said lawmakers still will alk at the ``imponderable, tremendous amounts of money either for the overall program or the unit cost.'' In other specifics, Cheney proposed: _ Buying 120 of the C-17 long-range transport planes instead of the 210 originally planned at a proposed savings of $11.9 billion over the life of the program. The plane is designed to replace the aging C-141 transport plane. _Purchasing a smaller number of the Navy's A-12 all-weather medium attack planes, cutting the original request of 858 to minimum of 620. The A-12 is designed to replace the Navy's A-6E Intruder, which is now reaching the end of its service life as an aircraft-carrier based long-range strike jet. The cuts could mean elimination of two of the Navy's 14 aircraft carrier battle groups, he said. Cheney said the total cost of the A-12 program is $52 billion and the Pentagon has spent $5.1 billion on the aircraft. The total cost amounts to about $84 million per plane. _ The Air Force's version of the plane, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft, is supposed to be used for deep attack missions now handled by the F-111 and F-15. Production of the ATA would be delayed beyond 1997, the end of the Pentagon's long-term five-year budget cycle, Cheney said. Cheney also suggested that purchases of the Advanced Tactical Fighter be delayed from 1994 to 1996. The aircraft is intended to replace the Air Force's F-15. The number to be purchased should remain at 750, Cheney said. The delay in that fighter will also delay the procurement of the Navy's version by two years, and reduce the number of aircraft to 546 from the original 618 planned, Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Volcano Claims 101st Hawaii Island Home
DOC.TEXT: The relentless lava flow from Kilauea Volcano destroyed three Hawaii Island homes Thursday, bringing to 101 the number of dwellings lost during the seven-year eruption. The homes caught fire over a three-hour period as the molten rock advanced through Kalapana Gardens subdivision, said Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. At 8:50 a.m. HST, the lava was menacing another home 80 feet from the last to go up in flames. Kilauea has wiped out 25 Kalapana-area homes this month. Lava halted overnight and built up mass, then began advancing rapidly at 4 a.m., Butts said. The flow was a quarter mile from Kalapana town, which has the area's only store and a historic painted church. The coastal community may soon be history, said Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim, who has stopped referring to the ``evacuation'' of residents. Kim doesn't believe people forced from their homes will be able to return and now says they have ``relocated.'' ``Most of them are not going back. Ever.'' he said. The lava-ravaged area is in the midst of a ``massive disaster'' and should qualify for federal and state aid, he said. Hawaii County Mayor Larry Tanimoto met with Gov. John Waihee on Wednesday to make a formal appeal for disaster aid. In a letter to Waihee, Tanimoto said: ``If an overnight tragedy claimed as many homes and had displaced as many residents, we would anticipate an enthusiastic, generous and immediate response to the needs of those involved.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Presidential Candidate Urges No Western Aid Before Election
DOC.TEXT: A major presidential candidate on Thursday urged the West to withold aid to Romania until all vestiges of communist rule are removed, as anti-government protests went on here for a fifth straight day. Ion Ratiu, considered interim President Ion Iliescu's chief rival in the the May 20 election, said he opposed a recent European Economic Community decision to allocate immediate aid to Romania because he feared it might strengthen the position of Iliescu's National Salvation Front. The Front dominates the interim government running Romania until the elections, and Ratiu said it seized power ``illegitimately.'' He told reporters he was against ``any gestures at this moment .. . that could reinforce the power of the Front in any way.'' Demonstrators, numbering 2,000-3,000 during daytime but down to a few hundred in early morning hours, have lashed out at what they say is communist infiltration of the interim government. Protesters at the anti-government rally at University Square accused Iliescu of being a ``closet communist,'' despite his repeated promises to break with the country's communist past. Iliescu was a senior Communist official until he fell afoul of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed during a revolution in December. Many Western countries, including the United States, have already sent limited aid to Romania, including food and medicine. Ratiu apparently was referring to pooled economic assistance from the 12 EEC countries, but he did not elaborate and EEC officials were not immediately available for comment. Ratiu, 72, candidate of the 600,000-member National Peasant Party, accused Iliescu and his Front of being unrepentant communists guilty of manipulating the media in the electoral campaign. Ratiu also said his life was threatened by a mob organized by the Front in Buzau, about 200 miles northeast of Bucharest. The state Rompres news agency reported on Thursday the official formation of a new intelligence service to replace Securitate, the old state police agency which Ceausescu used to terrorize his foes and ordinary Romanians. The new service will gather data solely on espionage services or terrorists planning subversive actions to undermine Romania's national economy, Rompres said.

DOC.HEAD: Link Between Disease, Diet Supplement Maker Now Found in Four States
DOC.TEXT: Researchers in four states have now linked a single manufacturer of the dietary supplement L-tryptophan to a potentially deadly blood disorder which has struck 1,500 people. Federal epidemiologists from South Carolina and New York reported Thursday that many of their states' cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, a painful blood disorder linked late last year to L-tryptophan, occurred after patients took the product from just one Japanese manufacturer. Researchers from Oregon and Minnesota reported similar findings Wednesday at a national epidemiology conference at the Centers for Disease Control. ``The L-tryptophan use that's causing people to get ill is virtually universally from one particular company,'' said Dr. Ed Kilbourne, a CDC specialist in eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS. ``Significantly fewer users were unaffected if they were using that company's products.'' L-tryptophan has been widely taken in this country by dieters, insomniacs and people fighting depression. Before its recall by the Food and Drug Administration earlier this year, it was widely sold in health food stores. Several Japanese manufacturers make L-tryptophan and their products are sold under a host of different brand names. The CDC has refused to specify the company whose product has been implicated because ``there are still a number of ongoing investigations which are not yet complete,'' Kilbourne said. But The Washington Post on Thursday quoted a spokesman for the Showa Denko Co., one of Japan's largest chemical manufacturers, as saying the studies ``showed a strong statistical association between our product and EMS.'' Showa Denko has already been named in at least one lawsuit from an EMS patient, a $20 million claim from a Oregon woman. ``But it is important to note that the studies do not independently identify the precise cause of EMS,'' said the Showa Denko spokesman, Bob Schwadron. The fact that one specific manufacturer has been implicated means the likely cause of the illness is some sort of product contamination _ and not simply L-tryptophan itself, Kilbourne said. But researchers still don't know what sort of contaminant might be responsible in that manufacturer's product, or how it got there. ``This is still a very complicated investigation,'' Kilbourne said. Nationwide, nearly 1,500 cases of EMS have been reported to the Atlanta-based CDC. Twenty-one patients have died. A Minnesota telephone survey reported Wednesday found that 3 percent of households contacted had someone taking L-tryptophan between August and November 1989. South Carolina researchers found a number of EMS cases in one psychiatric clinic that prescribed L-tryptophan for more than three-quarters of its 654 patients in 1989. Forty-seven confirmed EMS cases were found, and 45 were in patients taking one particular brand from the implicated Japanese manufacturer, said Mary Kamb, a federal epidemiologist in South Carolina. In New York, which has reported 145 EMS cases, the majority of a study group of cases were linked to the same manufacturer, said epidemiologist Ephraim Back, and most patients took the product between December 1988 and May 1989. ``The epidemic rise of EMS supports the role of a contaminant as the source of this disease,'' he said. EMS is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash, fatigue, cough and sometimes fever. In some cases, victims show signs of congestive heart failure and develop a condition that causes progressive weakness and sometimes leads to paralysis.

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Rejects Seabrook Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist rejected a final appeal Thursday to delay start-up of the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant in a decision that clears the way for the reactor to begin routine operations. Rehnquist, without comment, rejected a bid by opponents of the plant to hold up operation until a lower-level federal appeal can be heard next September. ``We and the other (opponents) continue to have very serious concerns about the operation of that plant and that's why we could not in good conscience go ahead without exhausting every legal remedy available,'' said Mary Breslauer, a spokesman for Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, who is leading the anti-Seabrook forces. Shannon, along with the Seacoast Anti-Pollution League and the New England Coalition on Nuclear Pollution, will present the case against Seabrook to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Sept. 18. The chief argument against the plant all along has been that its location could trap thousands of coastal residents and tourists in a nuclear emergency. Plant spokesman Ron Sher said the Seabrook reactor is currently being operated at 8 percent power and the power plant is on the verge of producing its first commercial electricity, more than two decades after it was first conceived. ``That will be the most significant milestone in Seabrook station's history,'' Sher said. ``That will mark the first time that Seabrook's electricity will be traveling through the power lines of New England to homes and businesses and industries.'' Now that Seabrook opponents have exhausted their last bid to delay the plant, Sher said plant officials hoped ``Massachusetts would stop its opposition and work with us constructively to continue to update the emergency response plans for the communities near Seabrook.''

DOC.HEAD: State Says Nevada Cricket Infestation Under Control as Feds Attack Insects
DOC.TEXT: The worst Mormon cricket infestation in Nevada since the 1930s appears under control, a state agricultural official said Thursday as the federal government launched a second aerial attack on the voracious insects. The infestation covers some 700,000 acres in five counties of north-central Nevada with crickets counted at up to 100 per square foot in some areas near Winnemucca, 160 miles northeast of Reno. ``I think we've made real progress in killing the insects, although there's a lot of them out there,'' said Dick Rowe, coordinator of the Nevada Department of Agriculture's Plant Industry program. ``At the present time I think we've got things under control. ``I might change my mind 30 days down the road, but for now it looks like we're doing OK and the insects haven't done any real damage yet.'' Rowe said the crickets, which are related to grasshoppers, are about three quarters of an inch long now but will grow up to two inches long within the next month _ the size of a small mouse. If the juice-spitting insects aren't killed at the mouths of canyons where they hatched, they'll merge together in a hungry march across rural Nevada at a rate of one-half mile to one mile a day, eating everything organic in sight such as crops, gardens and grasses. Migrating bands can be one-half to one mile across and one to 10 miles long and usually aren't stopped except by cold weather or poison. The barbed-legged insects have few natural predators, authorities said. The insects, which can bite humans if disturbed, got their name from a similar infestation reported in Utah in the 1800s. Sea gulls from Salt Lake City reportedly flew over the infested land, eating the crickets to save the area from total destruction, according to Mormon legend. During the past few weeks, state agriculture officials on the ground have been spreading bran bait laced with the pesticide carbaryl-a to kill the crickets in the canyons. On Wednesday, the federal government began aerial spraying of the pesticide in the Battle Mountain area where there aren't any nearby waterways that could get contaminated. Silvia Holman, a spokeswoman for the Plant Protection and Quarantine division of the U.S. Agriculture Department, said more than 5,000 acres were sprayed Wednesday. Officials planned to spray an additional 6,000 acres in the area during Thursday's second flight. ``The crickets are really coming out of the woodwork,'' she said. ``But we're fighting them every day.'' Ranchers such as Eldon Crawford of Golconda have their own crews killing crickets. ``I've had them for the past three years, but this is the worst,'' Crawford said this week. ``I don't know how strong they're going to get. My gut feeling is that we're going to stop them ... But it's anybody guess.'' Several dry winters in a row and a lack of predators created perfect conditions for the record infestation, experts said.

DOC.HEAD: Former California Senator Gets 6{ Years In Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former state senator convicted of accepting payment to push a bill through the Legislature was sentenced to 6{ years in prison Thursday. In sentencing state Sen. Joseph Montoya, U.S. District Judge Milton Schwartz called Montoya's vote-selling ``the most serious type of white-collar crime.'' ``It attacks every single person and it attacks the process of being able to continue a representative form of government,'' Schwartz said. Montoya, chairman of the Senate Business and Professions Committee, was the first California legislator in 35 years to be convicted of a felony while in office. He was the first person to stand trial on charges stemming from an FBI sting of statehouse corruption. He resigned from the Senate on Feb. 9, a week after he was convicted of one count of racketeering, one count of money laundering and five counts of extortion. The case stemmed from a lengthy FBI investigation. He was convicted of demanding campaign contributions and honorariums in exchange for votes and other legislative favors. Montoya, who turns 51 on Monday, showed no emotion during the hearing. But two of his daughters, who sat behind their father, had tears in their eyes. ``I believe in this system,'' Montoya told Schwartz. ``The system found me guilty ... I will live with those consequences and so will my family.'' Schwartz also ordered Montoya to spend three years' probation after serving his sentence, fined him $32,000, and ordered him to pay $8,000 in restitution to cover money he collected in connection with the case. The judge ordered the former lawmaker to surrender by June 29 to begin serving his sentence. Defense attorneys said they would file a motion to allow Montoya to remain free pending an appeal. The prosecution's case focused on a videotape of a breakfast meeting the lawmaker had in 1988 with an FBI undercover agent who posed as a southern businessman seeking legislation to help a dummy company. During the meeting at a downtown Sacramento restaurant, the undercover agent gave Montoya an envelope containing a $3,000 check. Prosecutors contended the check was a payoff requested by Montoya for his help in getting a bill through the Senate. The defense denied that Montoya had done anything special for the bill and argued that the money was a legal honorarium.

DOC.HEAD: Puyallup Indians Begin Receiving Land-Claim Payments
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Puyallup Indians received $20,000 checks Thursday under the largest Indian land-claims settlement outside Alaska, and a state official said tribal leaders feared the cash would draw con artists. ``This money is the candy, the frosting, but hardly the most important element'' of the settlement, said Michelle Aguilar, executive director of the Washington State Office of Indian Affairs. Puyallup leaders refused to speak with reporters and barred them from headquarters where checks were being distributed to more than 800 adults through Monday. Another 700 members are entitled to the checks when they turn 21. ``There has been some concern that when you hand out this much money to any large group of people _ Puyallup tribal members or anybody else _ some people will be conned,'' Aguilar said. ``I know the tribe has done what it can,'' she said. ``It has offered financial planning classes, but whether people availed themselves of those classes was up to them.'' The payments were made under a $162 million land-claims settlement that took six years to negotiate. The tribe relinquished its century-old claim to thousands of acres in the industrial heart of Tacoma and other parts of Pierce County in exchange for cash, programs and real estate from federal, state and local governments, as well as private land owners. ``Everybody is focusing on the money, but that's the least of this settlement,'' Ms. Aguilar said. ``The settlement will give the tribe and its members an opportunity to participate in their own destiny'' through development of valuable real estate and other financial avenues provided by the settlement, she said. The settlement is second in size only to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act of 1971, in which Congress gave $960 million and 44 million acres to Eskimos, Aleuts and Alaska Indians in exchange for their giving up land claims. Earlier, tribe officials told The Morning News Tribune of Tacoma they were carefully guarding the membership list to try to keep con artists at bay. Lena Landry, head of the tribe's trust fund board which is overseeing the cash payments, said she and other leaders were confident most recipients would spend the money wisely. The tribe took measures to spot problems, including forming an alcohol crisis-intervention team and monitoring schoolchildren for signs of family problems. Some Puyallups were less optimistic, recalling the alcoholism and domestic abuse that plagued the Klamath tribe in Oregon after members received cash payments more than 20 years ago. Ara Satiacum told the paper that drug dealers had come around her home the last few days. She sold crack cocaine before undergoing treatment earlier this year, and the dealers hoped to front her a large quantity of crack to peddle in smaller amounts, she said. Others have said they wouldn't bank the money for fear of taxes, even though just the interest would be taxable. ``There's going to be a lot of people carrying their money around because they don't want to put it in a bank account,'' said Shirley Satiacum, Ara's mother. ``I'm worried people will be hit over the head and robbed.'' Tribe members told the paper some have already bought cars from dealers who offered deferred payment plans. Tribe member Dennis LaPointe, a 36-year-old father of three, made an offer on a small green house this week. LaPointe said most in the tribe were using their money to buy necessities that have long been out of reach to many. ``We have a lot of hard-working Puyallup people who are just waiting for a chance to show people what they can do,'' LaPointe said.

DOC.HEAD: Telescope's Main Antennas Work on Second Try
With AM-Hubble-Gadgets, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `There had been...,' to UPDATE with minor problem with stabilizing gyros. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `Now we have...
DOC.TEXT: Ground controllers cheered after re-establishing contact Thursday with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope through its main antennas. An attempt six hours earlier had failed. ``I'm pretty relieved, I must say,'' said Al Boggess, Hubble project scientist at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Applause erupted at Goddard's Space Telescope Operations Control Center when the high-speed contact was made Thursday afternoon. Controllers sent information to the telescope about its location, and ``this basically improved the telescope's knowledge where it was, what its position was,'' said Goddard's Dave Drachlis. They also widened the radio beam to cover a larger area around the two high-speed dish antennas. ``We have confirmation that we have achieved communication with the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite through the high-gain antenna system,'' Drachlis reported. The antennas are the primary communications links for relaying scientific information to the ground. Controllers' lack of experience with the new satellite was part of the problem, Boggess said. ``This probably won't be the last time we have a problem,'' he said. ``We'll keep working at it until we have all these things that need to be done, done. We'll get them right.'' The problem began Thursday morning when engineers tried pointing the two high-speed antennas toward two widely-separated TDRS satellites without success. Two low-speed antennas were working fine, but Boggess said they would be ``excruciatingly slow'' for sending data. There had been a communications outage with the telescope earlier. It lasted only 45 minutes and was due to human error. In addition, one of four ``rate gyros,'' wheels whose spin maintains the telescope in a stable position, was disconnected by an automatic system for a reason engineers were unable to explain immediately. But it was restored later and the stability of the satellite was unaffected. The problems won't delay the schedule for putting the telescope into use, said Jean Oliver, Hubble deputy project manager at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. ``Now we have to do an analysis to make sure ourselves just what part of it worked and whether there are things we have to do differently in the future to make it continue to work,'' Boggess said. ``Having done it once, we've got confidence we can do it and that means the mission can proceed.'' Space shuttle Discovery trailed 57 miles behind the telescope and was to stay nearby until the Hubble's aperture door was opened, set for Friday morning. Its five astronauts spent the day doing experiments and taking pictures of storms over Texas and other views of Earth from 380 miles up, the highest a shuttle has ever flown. When the door covering the telescope aperture is opened, starlight will strike the telescope's finely polished 94.5-inch mirror for the first time. If signals fail to activate the 10-foot-wide aluminum aperture door, mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan will go into open space and crank it open Saturday. The shuttle is scheduled to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The mission would be extended a day if the space walk became necessary. On Tuesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration releases its first image from the telescope, an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. The 12{-ton, 43-foot-long telescope, about the size of a bus, is named for astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who died in 1953. The Missouri-born Hubble discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding, a finding that gave rise to the theory the universe was created about 15 billion years ago by a tremendous explosion. Astronomers expect to look back 14 billion years with the space telescope.

DOC.HEAD: Father Knows Best _ Gotti Missed Son's Wedding, Priest Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS throughout to CLARIFY that Gotti wanted to avoid having media discover location of wedding, according to priest.
DOC.TEXT: Criminal charges may slide off the ``Teflon Don,'' but the sticky news media kept John Gotti from attending his son's wedding, said the priest who conducted Saturday's ceremony. The Rev. Alfred F. Sepe said the reputed boss of the Gambino crime family was absentbecause he feared his constant ``tails,'' the media hordes searching for signs of the service's location, would have followed him and found the church, New York Newsday reported Thursday. The son, John A. Gotti, married Kim Albanese at the Church of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Brooklyn. About 30 people attended the 22-minute service in the 137-year-old church. ``It was religious and done well,'' Sepe said. The elder Gotti _ attended by the media _ later made a grand entrance at the reception through the grand foyer of the Helmsley Palace, surrounded by friends, associates and the hotel security staff.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Chosen To Form Israeli Government After Labor Fails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs, UPDATING with defector's return boosts Shamir. Picks up 6th graf, Shamir, 74 ... with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TLV1
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, was chosen to form a new government Thursday after Labor Party chief Shimon Peres gave up trying to forge what he called a peace coalition. A Shamir-led government could spell trouble for U.S. efforts to arrange a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. At a Likud meeting Thursday, defector Avraham Sharir announced his return to Shamir ranks, giving the prime minister the edge over Labor, 61-59, with the support of non-Likud deputies in Israel's 120-seat Knesset, or parliament. Sharir earlier switched over to Labor when it seemed that Peres had a chance to form a government. Peres predicted earlier that Shamir would also fail to form a coalition, but added that if Shamir did succeed, he would create ``an extremist right-wing government the like of which Israel never had.'' On Thursday, Peres called President Chaim Herzog and announced he was unable to break a standoff in parliament. Herzog's office said the president would give the job to Shamir, head of the caretaker government that took over after parliament voted March 15 to end the Labor-Likud coalition. Peres, as he left the president's residence Thursday evening, said Shamir should count his 61 votes carefully, Israeli Radio said. Shamir, 74, will get the mandate in a ceremony Friday morning at the president's residence. A spokesman said he would accept. The Polish-born Shamir, who lost his parents and two sisters in the Nazi Holocaust, was a prestate radical underground leader who later served as a senior official in Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. Shamir has rejected any dealings with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization and has forged ahead with settlement building in Israeli-occupied lands, despite increasing signs of strain with Washington. In recent weeks, for example, Shamir's government approved settlements in the occupied Gaza Strip and the West Bank. It was also revealed that it secretly gave $1.8 million to a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem. The new settlement activity sparked sharp protests from the U.S. State Department, which considers settlements in the occupied territories an obstacle to peace. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States was dismayed by reports of new settlements at Dugit in the Gaza Strip and Alon in the West Bank. ``It is disturbing that the caretaker government is taking steps that the National Unity government was unwilling to take on settlements,'' Boucher said. ``It is our longstanding position that settlement activity in the occupied territories is an obstacle to the achievement of a just and lasting peace.'' Peres spent 35 days trying to forge an improbable alliance of ultra-Orthodox religious parties and small left-wing factions. He abandoned the effort only hours before a midnight deadline. Peres, 66, triggered the crisis by demanding that Shamir accept Secretary of State James A. Baker III's terms for convening Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo. Shamir refused, and Peres won a vote of no-confidence in parliament. Roni Milo, the communications minister, said Shamir would not respond positively to Baker's peace proposals and opposed sharing power with Labor. Peres, who has headed the Labor Party since 1977, is likely to face a major challenge to his leadership, especially from the supporters of Yitzhak Rabin, who served as prime minister from 1974 to 1977. At a party meeting Thursday night, Rabin said Labor should consider entering a unity government with Likud if Shamir agreed to electoral reform within six months.

DOC.HEAD: 6.9 Earthquake Kills More than 100 in Central China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 109 dead, 1,000 homes damaged, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake on Thursday killed more than 100 people and damaged hundreds of homes in a remote region of central China populated mainly by Tibetan herders, officials said. The quake Thursday evening measured 6.9 on the Richter scale, striking Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture in Qinghai province, about 900 miles southwest of Beijing, a State Seismology Bureau said Friday. A bureau official, who did not give his name, said 109 people were killed and 120 were hospitalized. More than 1,000 homes in the sparsely populated, rugged area collapsed from the initial quake and more than 500 aftershocks, he said. Aftershocks as strong as 5 on the Richter scale were felt in the provincial capital of Xining, about 70 miles northeast of Hainan Prefecture, and in Lanzhou, a city 180 miles the east. The official Xinhua News Agency said homes in Heka Township of Xinghai County were damaged and a landslide occurred at the Longyangxia Reservoir on the Yellow River. A hydroelectric power station at the reservoir was not damaged, it said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by a quake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 6 can cause severe damage in a populated area, and one measuring 7 is 10 times stronger and can cause widespread, heavy damage. Qinghai is a mountainous region inhabited by miners and herders, where quakes occur fairly frequently with few casualties. A quake measuring 6.7 struck the region in January, damaging some buildings but causing no casualties. The far western Chinese province of Xinjiang was hit by a quake measuring 6.4 on April 19. About 1,300 homes were damaged but only two people were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Conservative Government Wins Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis won a vote of confidence early Friday, gaining the mandate he sought to take drastic measures to cure Greece's ailing economy. Members of Mitsotakis' party cried out ``Axios!'' (worthy) and lined up to congratulate him. ``We need to get to work now and put into effect the policy which we have proposed,'' Mitsotakis told reporters. Besides economic reforms, he has promised to improve relations with Greece's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community. Greece was often at odds with its Western allies during eight years of Socialist rule under Andreas Papandreou. The confidence vote began at Thursday midnight and the government won 152 votes in the 300-member Parliament, with 146 deputies voting against, one abstaining and one absent. ``The government enjoys the confidence of Parliament,'' announced Athanassios Tsaldaris, president of the chamber. Mitsotakis' New Democracy party won 150 seats in April 8 elections after failing to win a majority in elections last June which removed the Socialists from office. Another inconclusive poll was held in November. Coalition governments ruled from June to April. Mitsotakis formed a government after the Democratic Renewal party pledged to support it in Parliament. He has said he intends to govern for a full 4-year term. Mitsotakis has promised to renew negotiations with the United States on an expired defense agreement and to recognize the state of Israel. He has blamed Socialist policies for the economic troubles and stressed that sacrifices will be required for a recovery. ``The government has the honor to present a policy that is painful and unpleasant,'' he said. ``It saddens us, but we have to carry it out because there is no other choice, and it can lead the country to revival.'' Mitsotakis announced increases in public utility rates, cuts in government spending and widespread privatization. Papandreou predicted Mitsotakis' steps would ``cause the immediate shriveling of people's wages.'' The measures also drew fire from some of Greece's powerful trade unions. The General Confederation of Greek Workers raised the possibility of protest strikes.

DOC.HEAD: California's `Big Green' Initiative Seen as Voter Puller
DOC.TEXT: Environmental advocates announced Thursday they had collected 800,000 signatures favoring the state's ``Big Green'' initiative, which would curtail pesticide use, offshore drilling and timber cutting. The all-Democratic leadership of the ``Big Green'' environmental initiative intended for the November ballot predicted that it would bring out voters like never before. ``Earth Day gave us just a hint of how deeply Californians care about our environment. On election day we'll deliver the whole message. Nothing can stop us from passing Big Green,'' John Van de Kamp, the state attorney general and a Democratic candidate for governor, told a Capitol news conference. The news conference and ones in Los Angeles and San Francisco were called to announce that 800,000 signatures had been collected in favor of placing the initiative on the ballot. The measure needs 372,178 valid signatures; the signatures will be checked by the secretary of state's office. If ``Big Green'' wins approval it would go on the books as the Environmental Protection Act of 1990. The act proposes stringent controls on pesticide use, preservation of ancient redwood stands, bans on clear cutting timber, blocks on offshore drilling and the creation of an environmental czar to oversee enforcement and implementation. It would appropriate $20 million to seek alternatives to pesticides. Al Meyerhoff of the Natural Resources Defense Council called it ``the most sweeping measure ever put before the voters by environmentalists anywhere in the country.'' He said it would serve as a litmus test for political candidates, and ``send a message to Congress.'' Two opposing ballot issues are being readied to challenge some of the provisions of Big Green. Under the aegis of Californians for Responsible Food Laws, or CAREFUL, agribusiness interests are trying to get a less restrictive pesticide measure on the ballot. And the timber industry is backing a measure to cancel out the initiative's provisions to save trees. Van de Kamp, whose staff wrote the measure with the help of environmental groups, has touted it as evidence of his commitment to environmental issues. Big Green also has the support of Van de Kamp's rival in the June Democratic primary for governor, former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, who endorsed it on Earth Day. The GOP candidate for governor, Pete Wilson, hasn't taken a stand. In addition, Big Green is sponsored by environmental groups including the Sierra Club, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the National Toxic Campaign. The proponents said they expect to spend $1 million to $3 million campaigning. Van de Kamp, in explaining support for the measure, said, ``Some 800,000 Californians have signed up to ban cancer-causing pesticides from our food, to protect our coast from oil drilling and tanker spills, to stop the dumping of sewage and industrial waste in the ocean, to save our virgin redwood forests and to lead the fight against global warming.''

DOC.HEAD: NATO May Scrap New Short-Range Missile Deployment Plan
DOC.TEXT: With East-West tensions subsiding, the NATO alliance may abandon a controversial plan to deploy a new short-range missile in Europe, sources said Thursday. The alliance may also cut its stockpile of battlefield nuclear artillery, the sources said. North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials will begin a series of meetings next week that could result in dramatic policy changes as they seek to shape the alliance from a military organization to a more political one. An announcement of moves to end the nuclear missile project and trim battlefield nuclear artillery could come at an expected summit, possibly in the summer, of the leaders of the 16 NATO nations, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The sources emphasized that no final decisions have been made. However, a diplomat said ``it's a near certainty'' that NATO will agree to the measures. ``All these things are being discussed right now,'' said another diplomat. ``Short-range nuclear forces is very much a hot subject.'' The moves are being considered in light of the pro-democracy revolutions that have swept through Eastern Europe and the resulting changes in military strategy. The alliance's defense ministers meet May 9-10 in Canada to take a look at the West's future nuclear posture. Aides to the defense ministers will gather Friday in Brussels to discuss nuclear issues in advance of the Canada meeting. In recent months, NATO diplomats have said there was dwindling support for an American plan to develop a new, more powerful generation of short-range nuclear missiles. The new weapon would replace the aging Lance surface-to-surface missile. One source said there was ``a possibility'' the defense ministers at their Canada meeting would declare the project dead. But another said it was unlikely. A third said he had not seen any draft statements about the project. The Bush administration said last week that it was postponing development of the weapon. It said the Army had put on hold plans to issue a formal request for contractors' proposals to build the new missile. The new Lance weapon is strongly opposed in West Germany, where most of the missiles would be based. The Lance, introduced in 1972, has a range of about 75 miles. Its replacement would be designed to hit a target more than 250 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Reviewers Find Cancer-Fluoride Evidence Inconclusive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The study...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comment from from Health and Human Services official.
DOC.TEXT: A study linking cancer in rats to fluoride was inconclusive, a government scientific panel said Thursday after reviewing research on the cavity-fighting chemical. The review by scientists of the National Toxicology Program was intended as a guide to government policy makers on the safety of the chemical, which is consumed by 53 percent of Americans in their drinking water and is a standard ingredient in toothpaste. The government study, released in February, was seized on by opponents of fluoridation, who have waged an emotional, decades-long battle against adding the chemical to the water supply to prevent tooth decay. Many previous studies had found fluoridation safe. The panel, the National Toxicology Program's Board of Scientific Counselors voted after debate and public comment to label the new evidence ``equivocal.'' ``It is like a little flashing yellow light on the instrument panel, saying you need to look at this more closely,'' said Dr. David Rall, a government scientist. ``At this moment, I don't think it implies any change in policy.'' Rall is director of the National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences and the National Toxicology Program, whose scientists carried out the study. ``What we're trying to say is we really don't know,'' said panel member Robert Garman. Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services, issued a statement Thursday saying no information existed that would call for a change in Public Health Service policy supporting the use of fluorides for the prevention of tooth decay. Mason said the panel's action was ``one step in a continuing evaluation of health risks and health benefits of fluoridation underway by the Public Health Service.'' The findings will be incorporated into a broader review with other animal and human studies involving fluoride ``to ensure that every possible avenue of research has been re-examined in light of the NTP findings,'' he said. The Public Health Service scientists reviewing the research are expected to report their conclusions in July. The study released Thursday found bone cancer in five of 130 male rats given high doses of fluoride. No tumors were found in female rats or either sex of mice. The panel's report said the study found a marginal increase of tumors that may be related to the chemical. In the emotionally charged atmosphere surrounding the fluoridation debate, panel members labored long just to reach that seemingly mild conclusion. The panel labored for nearly an hour to choose words that wouldn't become weapons for either side in the fluoride fight. Before arriving at the final version of its report, the panel voted down a motion to say there was absolutely no evidence of a cancer link in the study. ``The more we do this, the more I recommend that we don't do this,'' said Ellen Silbergeld, who said the panel might be ``lending ammunition inadvertenly or whatever to one side or another.'' Before the vote, Dr. John Stamm, dean of the School of Dentistry at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, argued that the results were too weak even to be called ``equivocal.'' Stamm also is a spokesman for the American Dental Association. ``The potential misunderstandings created could lead to immediate turmoil in the U.S. public health arena,'' he said in prepared comments. Dr. James Bawden, representing the American Association for Dental Research and the American Association of Dental Schools, said the study gives ``no indication that fluoridation of municipal water supplies is unsafe.'' On the other side, Dr. John Yiamouyiannis of the Safewater Federation in Delaware, Ohio, said the study and others ``provide clear evidence that fluoride is carcinogenic.'' The Safewater Federation campaigns against fluoridating the water supply. An estimated 132 million Americans drink water that has fluoride added to reach the level of one part per million, according to the Academy of General Dentistry. An additional 10 million people drink water from naturally fluoridated water supplies that have levels as high as eight parts per million. The study found one rat in a group of 50 developed osteosarcoma _ a form of bone cancer _ after drinking water with 45 parts per million of fluoride over two years. Four rats in another group of 80 developed cancer _ three osteosarcomas _ after drinking fluoride at 79 parts per million during the period. The scientists who conducted the study labeled as insignificant the difference in cancer incidence between rats given fluoride and those without. The study's author, J.R.
