Bucher, noted that in one earlier study, three bone cancers occurred among a group of rats who weren't exposed to excess fluoride. During the public comment period, Bob d'Amato of Procter & Gamble Co. said a recently completed study at his company found just one case of osteosarcoma among 70 rats _ that in a female that received little fluoride.

DOC.HEAD: White House Tweaks Congress For Resolution On Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs, Rep. Berman replies to White House
DOC.TEXT: The White House chided Congress Thursday for its resolution declaring Jerusalem to be Israel's capital, saying the lawmakers need to give more serious consideration to unintended consequences of such resolutions. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater made the comment when asked about criticism of the resolution in the Arab world and suggestions that it might hinder the possible release of additional U.S. hostages. ``Our only comment would be that Congress needs to consider these resolutions more seriously than they have in the past. And that sometimes they can have unintended consequences,'' Fitzwater said. On Wednesday, Hussein Musawi, the reputed spiritual mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, urged the terrorist group not to release another hostage because of the resolution passed by the House. Syria sharply condemned the resolution Thursday, saying it was intended to emphasize the American desire to ``defy Arabs and Moslems by stealing their rights without any lawful or historical justification.'' In Iran, a radical newspaper said the resolution would delay the release of Western hostages in Lebanon. The Farsi-language Jomhuri Islami, or Islamic Republic, said it ``made things more complicated by blocking the way for solving problems.'' The nonbiding resolution was approved by the House 378-34 on Tuesday. It conflicts with official U.S. policy, which does not recongize Jerusalem as Israel's capital and calls for negotiations to determine the final status of the city. Israel declared Jerusalem its capital in 1967 after capturing the city's east side from Jordan in the Six-Day war. Jerusalem contains sites considered sacred by Christians, Moslems and Jews. The House resolution is identical to one passed March 22 by the Senate. Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., has said that this measure was a mistake and has damaged the Bush's administrations efforts to foster Middle East peace negotiations. Rep. Howard L. Berman, D-Calif., one of the supporters of the resolution, brushed off Fitzwater's criticism Thursday, saying, ``I think the White House has little standing to criticize Congress since this entire resolution developed as a response to President Bush's reckless comments about Jerusalem.'' Berman referred to Bush's unexpected remark last month linking East Jerusalem with the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza by saying Israel should not settle Soviet Jews coming to Israel in any of those three territories. Previous U.S. administrations had always treated East Jerusalem separately, arguing the status of the entire city should be settled in peace negotiations. As for comments in Iranian newspapers, Berman said: ``For 10 years now Iranians have found one thing or another to justfiy falling short of the fundamental standards of civilized nations. This is just another excuse.''

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan President Visits With Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs before last graf with toasts
DOC.TEXT: Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez told President Bush on Thursday that Latin America wants to take part ``in shaping a world of peace, of peaceful neighborliness and respect of human rights.'' Perez visited with Bush a day after the Venezuelan president attended the inauguration in Managua of Violeta Chamorro as president of Nicaragua. Bush said Chamorro's inauguration was ``a great day for democracy'' and ``a time to celebrate.'' Bush gave the Venezuelan leader a warm welcome during an arrival ceremony on the south lawn of the White House. Bush said Perez's ``deep personal commitment to the advance of democracy never wavered.'' He also said Perez's free-market economic policy ``has meant some pain for the people of Venezuela, but ... is the kind of new beginning that will lay the foundations for future growth.'' Perez, responding, said, ``The Latin American continent is determined to modernize its structures, institutions and relations, even in spite of the fact that our efforts do not always meet with proper understanding, cooperation and encouragement.'' Perez imposed an austerity program after riots erupted about three months after he took office at the end of 1988. Bush, toasting Perez at a state dinner Thursday night, promised he would visit Venezuela later this year during a trip to several South American states, probably in late September. Praising Perez as ``one of Latin America's great statesmen,'' Bush said ``our two nations share a vision of totally democratic hemisphere and a common love of freedom. And we agree that no system is better than democracy at securing the peace and prosperity that all nations seek.'' Perez hailed Bush as a good friend and said it was important ``to cooperate as much as possible'' and to strengthen ties. Meanwhile, informed sources who asked not to be identified said Bush is expected to name career diplomat Michael Skol as ambassador to Venezuela. Skol, 47, has spent the past several years as a deputy assistant secretary of state for South American affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman on Jet Kills Presidential Candidate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, Pizarro was ... to INCLUDE name of guerrilla group higher in story. Picks up 5th graf, As an ... SUBBING 27th graf, The son ... to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG2
DOC.TEXT: A man on a suicide mission pulled out a submachine gun on a crowded Colombian jetliner Thursday and assassinated a presidential candidate before being killed in a blaze of pistol fire from bodyguards. A drug trafficking group called the Extraditables claimed responsibility for shooting former leftist guerrilla chief Carlos Pizarro and said his name was picked in a drawing, the radio network Caracol said. The group, mainly from the Medellin cocaine cartel, said other candidates will be killed until traffickers are pardoned. Pizarro, until last month commander of the notorious April 19 Movement, a rebel outfit known as the M-19. was the fourth Colombian presidential candidate to be assassinated in the past 31 months. Drug traffickers were blamed in all four deaths. As an apparent precaution against any violent reaction to Pizarro's assassination, Mayor Andres Pastrana ordered all public and private schools closed Friday in Bogota, the capital. In a communique, Pastrana also ordered a ban on alcohol sales for the metropolitan area of 6 million people until further notice. An anonymous telephone caller said the names of three other presidential candidates were in the death lottery and that another candidate will die. Passengers screamed and ducked down in their seats as shooting broke out eight minutes after the Avianca Airlines Boeing 727 left Bogota's El Dorado international airport, the pilot, Capt. Fabio Munevar, said. The plane, en route to the Caribbean coastal city of Barranquilla, where Pizarro was to campaign, returned immediately to Bogota. No one else on the plane was hurt. The killer, 25-year-old Alvaro Rodriguez, apparently retrieved the submachine gun from an airplane bathroom, Munevar said. He told Caracol Rodriguez went to the restroom at the back of the jet shortly after takeoff, then returned and took his seat two seats behind Pizarro. Minutes later he stood up and whipped out the weapon from his black leather jacket. Leaning over a passenger in the row in front of him, Rodriguez pointed the gun at Pizarro's head, about a foot away, and opened fire. Police said only Pizarro was hit. Eight bodyguards accompanied Pizarro on the flight, Caracol quoted an unidentified campaign worker accompanying Pizarro as saying. Two men with submachine guns were arrested at Barranquilla airport, a police spokesman there told The Associated Press. They apparently were part of an assassination squad with orders to kill Pizarro if he survived the flight. Disturbances broke out in Barranquilla to protest Pizarro's death, and three buses were burned, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. It was not immediately clear how the submachine gun was smuggled onto the plane. Air passengers boarding at Bogota are frisked and their belongings are searched. However, it is normal for presidential bodyguards to carry weapons, even on passenger flights. Caracol said in an unconfirmed report that five bullets smashed into the window near Pizarro, but none penetrated the thick, laminated plastic. The plane carried 91 passengers and a crew of six, an Avianca spokeswoman told the AP. The man calling Caracol said two gunmen were part of the plot to kill Pizarro, but did not say if both were on the plane. Police mentioned only one gunman. The caller said the other three candidates in the drawing were Alvaro Gomez Hurtado and Rodrigo Lloreda, both of the Conservative Party, and Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party. ``The next drawing will be between Gaviria and Lloreda,'' he said. The traffickers are no longer fighting extradition, the caller said. Now, he said, presidential candidates will be killed until the government gives traffickers pardons as if they were part of a ``political-military organization.'' Months ago, the traffickers said they should get the same treatment as leftist guerrillas who are pardoned. Last month the government pardoned hundreds of guerrillas of Pizarro's M-19 movement. Pizarro died 45 minutes after arriving at a government hospital about three miles from the airport, the hospital said in a communique. The Bogota morgue said Pizarro was hit by 13 bullets. The son of a Colombian navy admiral, Pizarro spent most of his adult life as a member of the the April 19 Movement, which took its name from the date of a presidential election Pizarro and other university students said was rigged. He commanded M-19 when it disbanded last month as part of a peace agreement with the government. M-19 then became a political party, and Pizarro was its candidate for the May 27 presidential elections. The assassination of Sen. Carlos Louis Galan last August led to the government's crackdown on Colombia's drug cartels. At the time of his death, Galan, of the Liberal Party, was the leading presidential contender and had urged a hard line against drug traffickers. Since the crackdown began, the government has extradited at least 15 drug suspects to the United States to face charges. The drug lords have waged a campaign of terror in an effort to halt the feared extraditions. The government also blamed drug traffickers for the killings of Jaime Pardo Leal, of the Communist Party, and Bernardo Jaramillo, of the leftist Patriotic Union Party. Pardo was killed Oct. 11, 1987, in an ambush on a dirt road near Bogota. Jaramillo was killed when a man walked up to him at Bogota's airport and opened fire with a submachine gun hidden inside a folded newspaper. The government said drug traffickers killed Pardo and Jaramillo because of the traffickers' hatred for leftists. Traffickers own vast amounts of land in Colombia, much of it cattle country where leftist guerrillas have long extorted ranchers for money to support their war against the government. Pizarro opposed extradition of traffickers to the United States. His aides said that was because he believed Colombia should solve its own problems. Since the crackdown began, drugrunners have killed more than 230 people, including judges, politicians, policemen, soldiers and newspaper employees. The bloodiest act occurred Nov. 26, when a bomb exploded aboard an Avianca jet shortly after it left Bogota. All 106 people aboard were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Preserves $420 Million in Panama Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-5: ``The Senate,'' to reflect Senate working late; veto threat from President Bush. Should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: The Senate late Thursday rejected an effort to cut the aid President Bush is seeking for Panama and use it instead for a variety of domestic programs. Senators left the $420 million Panama aid intact when, on a 51-48 vote, they defeated an amendment by Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. The Senate then labored late into the night as it tried to deal with dozens of proposed amendments, but prospects appeared remote for quick approval of the overall aid bill, which included $300 million for the government of new Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro. ``Mrs. Chamorro's term may expire before we get the aid down there'' cracked Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. The bill still faces a veto threat from President Bush, who opposes a provision that would allow the District of Columbia government to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. Such payments have been banned for the past two years. Byrd had proposed to slash Panama aid to $300 million and use the largest chunk of the savings for cleaning up Department of Energy nuclear plants. Other money would have gone for sanitation in Indian housing, agricultural disasters and a nutrition program for women and children. Capitalizing on the general unpopularity of foreign aid in Congress, Byrd cast his amendment as an effort to make charity begin at home. ``If we do not take a long, hard look at the way we parcel out our scarce dollars, the day will come when the American people are going to say `Enough!''' Byrd said. ``The support for foreign aid programs is dwindling and it will continue if those programs are not well justified and well crafted.'' But Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., said the United States has an obligation to Panama stemming from the U.S. economic embargo and the damage inflicted by December's invasion, which ousted dictator Manuel Noriega. ``We owe them,'' Hatfield said. ``This is a bill that's due.'' Byrd's move came as the Senate began consideration of a $3.4 billion spending bill that included the Panama money as well as $300 million for the new democratic government of Nicaragua and funds for a laundry list of congressional add-ons. Among the additions were flood relief, food stamps and veterans' benefits, as well as items included for individual lawmakers. Byrd, for example, won inclusion of $185 million for an FBI fingerprint lab planned for Clarksburg, W.Va. Supplemental spending bills are sent to Congress late in each fiscal year to cover shortages in government programs that have been underfunded or to meet unforeseen needs that have arisen during the year. Bush asked Congress for $500 million for Panama, $300 million for Nicaragua and $70 million for refugee programs. When the House passed the bill April 3, it cut the amount for Panama to $420 million and added domestic spending items that pushed the measure's overall cost to $2.4 billion. The Senate panel added still more, pushing it to $3.4 billion. Most of the new spending in both versions of the bill is covered by cuts in the Pentagon budget, including personnel, weapons systems and research and development. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., a sponsor of Byrd's amendment, said many purposes of the Panama aid, such as restoring tourism and providing student scholarships, were not emergency needs and could wait. ``Should this $120 million be used for non-priority needs in Panama, or should it be used for emergency needs here in the United States? It's that simple,'' he said. Referring to environmental problems at Energy Department facilities such as Rocky Flats, Colo.; Savannah River, S.C.; Fernald, Ohio; Hanford, Wash.; and Oak Ridge, Tenn., Johnston said, ``If there's an emergency in the United States, this is it.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Seizes Soviet Fishing Trawler Off Alaska
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard description of chase, U.S. Attorney's plan to file charges, amount of fine in earlier case. Picks up penultimate graf pvs, ``The `doughnut...
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard seized a Soviet trawler Thursday for allegedly fishing in U.S. waters off Alaska and was escorting the vessel to port, officials said. The Soviet factory trawler Ilya Ilyin was being escorted by the Coast Guard cutter Yocona to Kodiak, about 250 miles southwest of Anchorage, the Coast Guard said. Operators of the 3,147-ton vessel will be charged with violating the Magnuson Act, a 1976 law that established the nation's 200-mile Exclusive Economic Zone, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Tim Burgess in Anchorage. The ship, expected to reach port by Sunday, will be subject to possible forfeiture, he said. Coast Guard surveillance aircraft spotted the Soviet trawler allegedly fishing inside U.S. waters northwest of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea, the Coast Guard said. The Yocona was dispatched to intercept the trawler, and Thursday morning ordered the Soviet ship to halt, but the vessel attempted to elude the cutter and return to international waters. ``The cutter pursued the vessel at high speed for the next hour and a half, crossing into international waters before the vessel stopped and was boarded,'' the Coast Guard statement said. Inspectors told aides to Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, that they had found records that provided evidence of illegal fishing. ``This one is pretty clear-cut,'' said Bill Woolf, a fisheries expert on Murkowski's staff. The Soviet trawler _ believed to be fishing for pollock _ was observed by the Coast Guard cutter and several electronic ``fixes'' confirmed the ship was fishing inside the exclusive zone, Woolf said. The ship was observed with its fishing gear in the water, he said. The last time the Coast Guard seized a Soviet fishing vessel in the North Pacific was in May 1989, when the trawler Novoelnya was captured with 940 metric tons of pollock aboard. That case was recently settled when the Soviets agreed to pay $275,000 in fines, Burgess said. Both seizures were in an area of the Bering Sea known as the ``doughnut hole.'' The ``doughnut hole'' is a circular area surrounded by Soviet and U.S. exclusive fishing zones where Coast Guard and American fisheries officials suspect foreign ships await the cover of night or bad weather to sneak into the fish-rich U.S. zone. The United States and several other nations with high-seas fishing fleets have clashed for years over the rich North Pacific fisheries.

DOC.HEAD: National Guard Called to Evacuate Two Texas Towns From Fatal Floods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with number of people evacuated in Brownwood, UPDATE rainfall to 16 inches sted 15 and number of tornados to nine sted five; pickup 7th graf pvs, `I can tell...' SUBS 4 grafs for 21st graf pvs, `Minor damage...,' to UPDATE with details of tornados, flooding on Galveston. Pick up 22nd graf pvs, `A 77-year-old...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ARD1, ABI1
DOC.TEXT: Floodwaters gushed through Texas on Thursday after more than 24 hours of thunderstorms, forcing the evacuation of two towns and campers to the roofs of their cars. Authorities mobilized the National Guard and high wind damaged an Air Force base. At least three people drowned in Texas and two were missing from the storms, which were photographed by space shuttle Discovery's astronauts orbiting 380 miles above Earth. One family was rescued from a tree. Flooding in nearby south-central Oklahoma also forced evacuations and closed highways. The National Weather Service reported up to 16 inches of rain overnight in some areas of Texas as storms carrying at least nine tornadoes hop-scotched across the state. ``I have never seen it rain this hard. It's raining so hard that you can hardly see out,'' said Laura Goehl of Stephenville, southwest of Fort Worth, where more than 150 people waited out the storm in shelters overnight and into Thursday morning. The Texas National Guard sent 35 people and 20 trucks to help evacuate 200 people from Brownwood, southeast of Abilene, and from a small rural community on the Brazos River near Weatherford, just west of Fort Worth. ``I can tell you that in Horseshoe Bend everyone has been moved out. There is no one left,'' said Juanette Kaddatz, a spokeswoman for Parker County emergency spokeswoman. Officials had no estimates of its population. Ms. Kaddatz said 70 percent of the Parker County community was under water by mid-afternoon Thursday and the water was rising. Police in Brownwood reported all major traffic routes flooded, some several feet deep. Two of the three deaths were reported in that town. ``The big flood in 1957 was somewhat worse than this, but the water is still rising,'' said Brownwood police Lt. B.G. Watson. About 20 miles northeast of Brownwood, at least 130 people were evacuated early Thursday in the area of Proctor as Proctor Lake rose and the rain continued. Many had to be rescued by boat after their cars and campers were flooded at a park near Proctor Lake, which stood 23 feet above its normal level, its highest on record. ``We were pulling these people off the top of their campers and trailer homes,'' said Sam Marshall, civil defense coordinator. ``A lot of the motor homes under water are $100,000 jobs,'' he said. ``And 28 to 30 have lost new Blazers or new automobiles.'' Among the evacuees were elderly campers from northern states, many of whom had to flee without their medication, said police Sgt. Ron Moe. ``A lot of them have heart problems or are diabetics.'' In Graham, northwest of Fort Worth, a man and his four children had to be rescued from trees to which they were clinging by authorities who used a boat and a human chain to reach them. Officials said the children were 10 years old and younger. Elsewhere in Comanche County, more than a foot of water flooded the emergency room and first floor of DeLeon Community Hospital. A hospital spokeswoman said the 23 patients were not in danger. Many rural Texas roads and highways were reported closed with some bridges washed out and others damaged by flash floods, highway department officials said. Other storms early Thursday caused damage at Laughlin Air Force Base near Del Rio, close to the Mexico border. Wind in excess of 110 mph damaged nine Air Force jets and two buildings, officials said. The jets _ all twin-engine T-37 trainers _ had minor damage, although one aircraft suffered damage to a wing when it was hit by a windblown portable lighting cart. The second floor of an office building collapsed and another building lost its roof. Minor damage was reported in Corsicana, where a tornado touched down and a couple others were spotted at midmorning. Residents of Highland, near Houston, reported a tornado tore the roofs off two mobile homes. A twister flipped a tractor-trailer rig on Interstate 10 east of Houston, but the driver was uninjured, said Missy Taylor, a sheriff's dispatcher. A four-lane bridge on U.S. Highway 377 about 45 miles northwest of Dallas was closed because of water damage to its supports, said James Keller, a Denton County sheriff's deputy. Flooding also hit Galveston Island in the Gulf of Mexico, but no evacuations had been ordered by Thursday night, a sheriff's dispatcher said. A 77-year-old man died Wednesday in Brownwood, when he was swept away while trying to clear a drain near his home. A second elderly Brownwood man died Thursday when he was swept away while trying to get into his car. In the Texas Panhandle, a 27-year-old woman drowned Wednesday when a car was swept into 13 feet of water in Moore County and her two companions were missing, authorities said. To the north, high water forced the closing of sections of several state highways in south-central and eastern Oklahoma. Billy Frank Lance, a Carter County commissioner, said several houses in the small town of Dougherty were flooded Wednesday night. In Healdton, also in Carter County, authorities interrupted a cable television broadcast Wednesday night to warn viewers to head for high ground, officials said.

The Bush administration is resisting heavy pressure to place Japan on a trade ``hit list,'' but members of Congress are threatening to block approval of other trade agreements unless there is a change of heart. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills gave strong indications Wednesday that Japan will not be targeted a second time as a country deemed to have erected the most onerous barriers against sales of American products. The issue was to be reviewed today by President Bush's Cabinet, with a final decision expected before the end of the week. The administration a year ago targeted Japan, Brazil and India under a tough section of the 1988 trade law that provides for economic retaliation against countries that fail to remove objectionable trade barriers.

Some members of Congress are expressing growing discontent over President Bush's go-slow reaction to the Soviet Union's crackdown on Lithuania. ``I sense that more in Congress are beginning to share our concern about the administration's policy of inaction,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., whose state includes a large number of Lithuanian-Americans. If the Soviets continue their economic blockade against the breakaway Baltic republic, Simon said, ``My guess is that Congress will lead if the president does not.'' Lithuanians heaped criticism on Bush after the president postponed any economic sanctions against Moscow for fear of boxing Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev into a corner, and thus slowing the pace of Soviet reform.

Vice President Dan Quayle is embroiled in a simmering diplomatic dispute between U.S. drug agents and Mexican officials as he makes the last stop of a goodwill tour of Latin American countries begun after last winter's invasion of Panama. Panama wasn't even likely to be brought up at Quayle's meeting today with Mexican President Carlos Salinas. Instead, Quayle was preparing to defend the decision to keep in U.S. custody a Mexican doctor accused of participating in the 1985 murder of an American drug agent. Mexico claims the doctor's capture by U.S. agents violated Mexican sovereignty. ``I'm sure it will come up'' in today's session with Salinas, Quayle told reporters on the flight to Mexico on Wednesday.

Leading opposition politician Oskar Lafontaine was said by doctors to be out of danger today after being stabbed in the neck by a woman who offered him flowers and asked for his autograph at a rally. The 46-year-old Social Democrat who hopes to become West Germany's next chancellor lost a lot of blood in Wednesday's attack but awoke at 5 a.m. and was able to talk, said Dr. Heinz Pichlmaier, head of the team of doctors treating him. ``Considering the circumstances, his condition is satisfactory,'' Pichlmaier said. Lafontaine _ Chancellor Helmut Kohl's challenger in Dec. 2 elections and governor of Saarland state _ is one of West Germany's most colorful, acid-tongued and popular politicians.

DOC.HEAD: East German History Museum Takes New Look at Past
DOC.TEXT: Since the revolution, the Museum for German History in East Berlin is putting more truth and less distortion into its exhibits covering events of the last 1,500 years. Huge chunks of the Berlin Wall stand in the courtyard as part of a new display about the peaceful uprising that reversed four decades of Stalinist rule. Less than six months ago, an exhibit glorified the wall's construction in 1961. Museum officials have closed the section covering East Germany's history from its founding in 1949, which was redone just before the dramatic political events of autumn 1989. They seem embarrassed by their collection of everything from the office furnishings of the former communist rulers to clothing and dishes produced at the first state-run enterprises. In the section on the period from the end of World War II to the nation's founding is a new panel acknowledging the museum's ``guilt and responsibility'' for a display that, ``as we know today permitted no active, living relation to history and the present.'' Dr. Kurt Paetzold, a history professor at Humboldt University in East Berlin, is offering a course this spring called ``Historical Thinking and History Teaching in the Crises of Our Time.'' ``There is a need for a course like that,'' he said in an interview. ``You can't teach as if nothing happened.'' A new West German guidebook claims the exhibit beginning in 1949 was closed because it offered an ``all too euphoric'' view of East German history. The display on the revolution, opened April 12, has a collection of banners and posters carried by protesters in pro-democracy marches. Visitors have snapped up sets of postcards with the most famous slogans. Already sold out is a picture featuring the wide grin and large teeth of Egon Krenz, the first successor to Erich Honecker, the leader ousted in October.. Poor sellers include a book titled ``Lenin in Berlin,'' and postcards of the Soviet army supplying East Germany with food from the Soviet Union. Despite the tacit apology in the 1945-49 section, the communist state's creation still is called a ``wonder in the history of the German people and Europe.'' The Communist Party, which now has changed its name, is portrayed as incorporating the best traditions of German history. ``This is unbelievable,'' said Klaus Geberts, a retired factory worker from West Berlin on his first visit to the museum. ``One can even laugh; it's not forbidden anymore,'' he said, inspecting a collection of hand tools that belonged to Wilhelm Pieck, first president of East Germany. ``This museum won't be here much longer,'' Geberts predicted. Entries in the guest book indicate, however, that many visitors believe the exhibits should remain as they are. ``Leave everything as it is and build a new one with whole truth,'' wrote Andreas Kiest, who identified himself as a schoolboy from West Germany. Werner Fuehrer wrote: ``This museum is also part document. Leave it as is.'' A Swedish history teacher wrote in imperfect English: ``Please save this exhibition for the future. It is itself a monument of to lie with the help of history.'' The Marxist viewpoint permeates exhibits from the Middle Ages to 1949. Medieval conflicts between peasants and rich craftsmen are portrayed as an example of ``class warfare.'' The defeat of imperial Germany in World War I was made possible, the exhibit says, by the efforts of the ``working class.'' No mention is made of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact of 1939, secret provisions of which divided the independent Baltic states and much of Poland between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Population Growth Threatens Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The population is growing so fast it threatens to overwhelm the economy, but the Philippine government, demographers and Roman Catholic Church can't agree on what to do about it. An official survey conducted in 1988 found the Philippines to be the 14th most populous country in the world and the eighth in Asia. Its population grew from 7.64 million in 1903 to 19 million in 1948, then more than doubled in two decades to 48.1 million in 1980, when the last census was taken, the government report said. A new census is to be taken this month. Official projections put the number of Filipinos at 75 milllion to 80 million in the year 2000, or 10 times the number a century ago. President Corazon Aquino has called for a program to make sure the population increase, now about 2.4 percent a year, will not ``outstrip our other resources and annul what gains we make every year.'' Government population-control programs have stalled since the late President Ferdinand E. Marcos fled and Mrs. Aquino gained power in 1986, with strong support from the Catholic hierarchy. Critics say there is little evidence of an effective program or the political will to forge one. Local governments also have been lax because large populations mean more economic aid from Manila. Virtually all birth control programs, such as distribution of condoms, are financed by foreign governments or the United Nations. Population growth has declined from a peak of more than 3 percent annually in the 1950s, but Filipinos still multiply faster than the people of more prosperous nations of Southeast Asia. The rate is a full percentage point above Thailand and about 0.1 percent ahead of Malaysia. Nearly four of 10 Filipinos are under age 15, which strains educational, health and other public services. Officials and demographers say most Filipinos in the rural areas, where nearly 48 percent of the people live, prefer large families to provide cheap farm labor. High infant mortality also encourages having more children. Awareness of birth control methods is more widespread, but the number of couples using them dropped from 45 percent in 1986 to 36 in 1988, according to a survey by the Population Institute at the University of the Philippines. Lack of complete information and the strong male dominance in Philippine society are major reasons women avoid contraceptives, officials say. Despite growing awareness of the risks of overpopulation, critics say there is no consensus of the government, church and demographers on how to avoid it. Mamita Pardo de Tavera, secretary of social welfare and head of the Population Commission, disputes the idea that a large population must be a national burden. She takes a dual approach: educating the public about contraception and encouraging ``population development,'' or integration of government aid projects for the poor. Those who disagree say the central task is to reduce the number of births. ``You cannot have development unless you have a more manageable population, in terms of size, growth and composition,'' said Corazon Raymundo, director of the university Population Institute. A major factor in the population debate has been the Roman Catholic hierarchy, including Cardinal Jaime Sin, archbishop of Manila, who has great influence in the Aquino administration. ``We believe government should create job opportunities, develop natural resources, harness all these things for the sake of the people who are living now, not take measures to cut down population,'' said Monsignor Cesar Pagulayan, spokesman of the Family Life Apostolate of the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines. Mercedes Concepcion, former dean of the Population Institute, said the clergy had become aggressive in discouraging use of contraceptives. She said some members of Congress recognize the population problem, but ``have been silenced by the fact that the cardinal has been very active in threatening them with hell fire and brimstone . .. if they do something, particularly in terms of legislation.'' ``Since there is no signal from the top,'' meaning Mrs. Aquino, ``they know they will be by themselves only, unprotected,'' Mrs. Concepcion told an interviewer. The change in government in February 1986 created a new set of policy makers ``who have to be conditioned to the situation,'' she said. ``It's a massive training again.'' Mrs. Pardo de Tavera said the government program had been misunderstood. ``We are a pluralistic society and we have to give people choices, not only in the method but in the approaches,'' she said. ``We have to go beyond methods. We have to go to the values, education, other factors besides fertility.''

DOC.HEAD: Efforts to Save Everglades Threaten Agriculture
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The heightening drama over saving Florida's dying Everglades has cast new villains, the farmers and dairymen who work the land around giant Lake Okeechobee. Environmentalists say agriculture causes too much pollution in the precious Okeechobee, which provides water for the vast wetlands of the Everglades and the cities of the crowded coast. Some argue it's time to return the land to the wilderness it was before the ranchers and farmers came about a century ago. ``The first thing we have to do is get rid of the sugar cane south of Lake Okeechobee, then we have to get rid of the dairy cattle on the north side,'' said Marjory Stoneman Douglas, an environmental activist who has fought for much of her 100 years to preserve the Everglades system. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, who's filed suit seeking to force the state to increase protection of the Everglades, has said that if farmers can't reduce pollution, ``It's an easy choice. Save the 'Glades and let agriculture move to Wisconsin.'' Farmers feel they're politically expedient scapegoats. They say they're threatened by environmental experimentation that has only one sure result _ a big bill for state-ordered programs to cut pollution. ``I don't think it's fair,'' said David Beardsley, a fourth-generation farmer near Clewiston. ``It's our land. We're interested in our home as much as anybody else. But I think we're an easy target.'' The nutrient-laden pollutants that run off the farms and dairies feed unnatural growth of some plants in the Everglades, choking waterways and disrupting the system's food chain. At the same time, the heavy development of south Florida has disrupted rain patterns and the flow of water into the Everglades, drying up parts of the system. Residents of the region feel the environmental damage. Most are under some form of water rationing and may soon face stricter limits. Smoke from wildfires in the Everglades last year closed highways and caused respiratory problems. Gov. Bob Martinez says the environment ranks with crime and drugs as Florida's top issues. The environmental concerns of Floridians coalesced in the adoption of a ``Save Our Everglades'' plan in 1983. Its aim is making the Everglades look and function more as it did at the beginning of the century. In 1900, there were no big farms, which disrupt natural water flow, use water, then discharge pollutants back into the Everglades system. Nor did 4.5 million people live on the condominium-dotted ``Gold Coast'' from Palm Beach to Miami, sucking huge quantities of water from the system. Sugar growers fare worse than the dairies in their public image _ of government-subsidized millionaires who exploit foreign cane cutters and the environment. Two-thirds of the sugar cane land belongs to U.S. Sugar Corp. or companies owned by the Cuban-born Fanjul family, invariably described as ``sugar barons.'' More than 100 other farmers work land in the 700,000-acre Everglades Agricultural Area south of the lake, however. Some 413,000 acres are in sugar cane, the rest in winter vegetables like lettuce, celery, cabbage and carrots. Beardsley's family started farming when his great-grandfather came to Okeechobee before World War I and saw the newly drained land rich in decomposed vegetation. ``They just went wild when they saw the dark, rich muck,'' he said. Land was cleared by hand and boats were the only means of transport for years. Fires and floods from hurricanes made Okeechobee farming highly risky until the Army Corps of Engineers began building an extensive drainage and canal system five decades ago. About 1960, decreased sugar production in other U.S. growing areas resulted in higher domestic quotas; Florida farmers planted more cane. The U.S. economic embargo against Cuba cut sugar imports, and soon Florida was the nation's No. 1 cane producer. Moving north along the lake, the sweet smoke of the sugar mills and fields of tall cane give way to stretches of flat pasture dotted with grazing cattle. At McArthur Farms, manager Kent Bowen shows off the farm's ``$4 million experiment'' to cut pollution from 9,000 head of cattle: waste-collecting barns with concrete floors. Beef cattle have been in the area since the 19th century _ Frederic Remington sketched its cattle ranges in the 1890s _ but dairy operations didn't arrive until the 1960s, when land prices skyrocketed along the coast. Dairy cattle are fed extra phosphorous to enrich their milk for humans, but too much of it reaches their waste and taints waterways that feed Okeechobee. Reducing the waste flow has proved too costly for some small operations. At least 14 of the area's 47 dairy operations are accepting a state offer to move to less-sensitive land _ $602 a head to get out of town. That will cost the water district and state more than $5 million to move 9,500 cattle, a 20 percent cut in the Okeechobee dairy population that has produced about a fourth of Florida's milk. McArthur Farms plans to stay. ``We've looked at north Florida and Georgia, but this is a pretty good place to dairy. It's near the best milk market in Florida,'' Bowen said. Bob Butler, whose dairy has 2,200 adult cattle, said pollution control will cost his farm about $564,000 for fencing and catchment systems mandated by the state. ``We're realizing that we have a problem, and we're trying to come in and take care of our problems on our own,'' he said. Environmentalists give the dairy farmers good marks for effort, but say the sugar growers are flunking. The Everglades Coalition, an umbrella organization of conservation groups, plans to lobby for an end to federal import quotas and other indirect subsidies that keep the sugar growers profitable. George Wedgworth, president of the Sugar Cane Growers Cooperative for three decades, says the environmental goals for Okeechobee are unrealistic because of the vast artificial system built to support agriculture and protect residents from flooding. ``It's not a natural system anymore,'' he said, pointing to a map of the dikes and canals. ``You can't turn the clock back.'' Sugar growers levied their own environmental tax last year, assessing $5 an acre to finance environmental studies. Conservationists contend it's just a delaying action. ``Many of us have been out here a lifetime,'' Wedgworth said. ``We're going to be sure we have the right technical answers to the problems. We're not going to be distracted by the hysterics of the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Weapons Lab Finds Ways to Help Clean Up Environment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: for side-by-side or subsequent use with PM-Weapons to Industry, b0226.
With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: A new attitude toward the Soviet Union has already prompted retooling at America's national laboratories, the three top-secret centers of nuclear weaponry and ``Star Wars'' research and development. As scientists search for new ways to use their know-how, researchers at Sandia National Laboratories are finding ways to help clean up the environment.

The silver trough, as long as a football field, was developed to harness the sun and help wean the nation off imported oil. For years, it stood abandoned in the desert, an obsolete relic of the 1970s. Now, in another time and another growing national crisis, researchers at Sandia National Laboratories have dusted off their sophisticated solar panels and put them back to work. This time, the panels are helping the environment. Sandia scientists believe they've found an efficient way to use solar power to break down toxic waste, help clean up polluted dumps and cleanse contaminated water tables. ``We're just helping nature, that's all. There's nothing artificial about this,'' said Virgil Dugan, Sandia's director of Advanced Energy Technology. Solar research is just one area where scientists at Sandia, one of the nation's three nuclear weapons laboratories, are finding ways to help with growing environmental problems. As the need for ever improved nuclear weapons lessens, the laboratories are directing their technological might to greater peacetime use. With expertise developed for weapons programs and Army machinery, ``smart'' robots are hurriedly being assembled to clean out highly radioactive and toxic chemical waste at Department of Energy weapons plants across the country. ``It's the same technology (that goes into weapons programs), even though it seems there are two different applications,'' said Pat Eicker, manager of Robotic Science and Technology at Sandia. In the case of the abandoned solar collector, scientists realized they might be able to run contaminated water, such as polluted ground water, through the sunlight-focusing machine and use its power to help break down organic toxic waste. The contaminated water is mixed with a catalyst _ titanium dioxide _ and pumped through a clear tube in the center of the long, parabolic solar trough. The tube glows like Darth Vader's sword as sunlight activates the titanium dioxide, which frees an electron. The electron grabs onto organic material, in this case, the contaminates, and breaks them down into water, carbon dioxide and a mild, harmless acid. Until a full-scale experiment last June, scientists weren't sure if the solar machine would cause complete destruction of the pollutants. It did. ``You can drink the water that comes out at the end,'' said Mike Prairie, a senior technical staff member on the solar project. ``We never did this before because nobody thought of it before,'' Dugan said. ``Some might say it's a breakthrough. I think of it as an engineering advancement.'' Companies are lining up to learn more about Sandia's gadget, Dugan said. The laboratory plans to have a trial system out in a year, and Dugan thinks the system is about four years away from commercial use. Sandia has been testing the system with water contaminated by trichloroethylene, a common degreasing substance that contaminates ground water. Scientists believe the system will also work on PCBs, dioxins, pesticides, dyes, solvents and other organic, or carbon-based, materials. The solar panels won't help with the problem of nuclear waste, however, because that is inorganic. Companies must now package their toxic waste and ship it to dump sites or incinerators. The solar system might be economical enough to allow even small firms to have on-site waste systems and also may be portable, Dugan said. It will likely be more efficient, and cheaper, than current ground water purification systems, he said. Sandia's robotics researchers began eight years ago to find ways to use machines for the sometimes dangerous work of building nuclear weapons and handling plutonium and other hazardous parts. Already the lab has created a ``smart'' manufacturing system that will help automate some production in weapons plants. It has also designed wheeled robotic vehicles for the Army. Now work is under way to create a system that can clean up toxic areas too dangerous for humans to venture into at Department of Energy weapons plants, such as Hanford, Wash.; Savannah River, Ga.; Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Fernald, Ohio, and Pantex, Texas. Scientists say a robotic backhoe will be used at highly radioactive and toxic pits, along with a 40-foot robotic arm with sight and radar capabilities that can scan a dump, map pipes and other obstacles, vacuum sand and dirt, lift and remove drums, and clean leaking underground storage tanks. ``You've got to have some way to get in there and recover this stuff,'' Eicker said. ``And it's so dangerous, people can't do it.'' In one shed at Sandia, researchers hastily built a one-tenth-scale model of a waste dump, along with a robotic arm, because of a DOE rush to begin the cleanups. ``The use of models to simulate situations and the use of sensors to facilitate work on nuclear weapons production is what motivated this research,'' Eicker said. ``But this has far-reaching applications.''

DOC.HEAD: Repent, NBC's Jim & Tammy Show Is At Hand
DOC.TEXT: Early in the NBC drama ``Fall From Grace,'' TV preacher Jim Bakker, anguished and seeking comfort from an old minister friend, confesses a moment of adultery with Jessica Hahn. He then says this: ``Trying to build PTL into a worldwide ministry, the government attacking me about taxes, the newspapers writing stories about me, my marriage falling apart, a live television show six days a week _ the pressures never let up. ``I ... I just wasn't thinking straight.'' Later in the show, he snaps at an aide: ``Why does everyone want to nail Jim Bakker to the cross?'' It may be that those to whom the TV preacher refers had no advance knowledge his sad story would become a bad TV movie. This has come to pass, so they can stop singing ``If I Had a Hammer.'' NBC bought the TV rights from the Bakkers for an undisclosed sum and got their help in making what has emerged as ``Fall From Grace.'' It stars Kevin Spacey and Bernadette Peters, who play the Bakkers and lose. Airing Sunday, the movie dramatizes their descent from fiscal and evangelical heaven after the devil in the form of the Justice Department halts Bakker's works and his multimillion-dollar PTL empire. It'll probably get sky-high ratings, even though it's opposite ABC's ``The Story of the Beach Boys,'' a dramatization of the private woes of the lads who became a Major Cultural Force just by singing ``Surfin' U.S.A.'' But NBC's two-hour Bakkerarama sure gives awful a bad name. Directed by Karen Arthur with a 10-ton touch, it's written by Ken Trevey as if he sought divine guidance and got a busy signal. Although it tries to show the pain and frailty of the Bakkers, the show at times seems to be unconscious or semiconscious satire. Consider its opening moments, a vague version of the Hahn-Bakker coupling in Florida. Bare-chested and abed, he clutches her hand and advises, ``I've been through hell.'' Whooo. As they start to commune, her hand knocks over a glass of wine, spilling the grog onto a Bible on a nightstand. Make that two whoos. (Alas, she's not heard from again, save for furtive letters demanding alms. She's given what the vulgar call hush money.) Things end with the sex scandal out, Bakker awaiting federal indictments and the couple in Palm Springs, Calif., bravely facing disgrace, reporters and, although this is not mentioned, ``Nightline.'' In between? Well, you've got Peters busy chewing the scenery as her character's emotional stability steadily is shredded and her Tammy-brand mascara grows heavier with each crisis. The crises, such as buying sprees, an over-the-counter drug problem and pneumonia that almost kills her, are depicted as stemming from her frustration as her husband increasingly shuns her for work, work, work. Spacey's Bakker seems terminally vague, a Nowhere Man of no fixed philosophical address, an avaricious innocent harried by the Internal Revenue Service and snoopy reporters from the Charlotte Observer. At least he seems to notice that his wife's increasily erratic behavior may involve drugs of some sort. He even asks, ``Tammy, you been taking that medicine again?'' He twice curls up on the floor in tears, and shouts at his wife and aides as life gets worse. But he shows real emotion only on two occasions, the first when his wife is at death's door. The second occasion is when the rival Rev. Jerry Falwell, to whom he has been forced to turn over control of PTL, castigates him, alludes to ``homosexual problems,'' and does it all ... on TV! Bakker goes plumb bozo watching Falwell (Richard Paul plays him as a victim of extreme unction). A sympathetic Tammy says nobody will believe Falwell's charges. ``Yes, they will,'' Bakker roars tearfully. ``People will believe anything they see'' _ he slaps at the TV screen _ ``on that!'' Unkind things also are said in ``Grace'' about rival TV evangelist Jimmy Swaggart, who also scathingly denounced Bakker but later tearfully confessed he, too, had sinned (he didn't say if the sin was of the flesh or what). Although it is written, ``Let he who is without sin cast the first TV movie,'' NBC's rehash of the Bakkers' woes does seem a little soon. The real story ended only last October when Bakker, still protesting his innocence, was sentenced to 45 years in prison and fined $500,000 for using his TV show to defraud his flock. Oh, well. Consider that a famous person's life sometimes can be measured in whether it's made into a real movie or a TV movie. George S. Patton got a real movie, Ollie North a TV movie. Glenn Miller got a real movie, Liberace two TV movies. Moses got a real movie. But Jim and Tammy Bakker have gotten NBC's version of eternity.

Elsewhere in television... ECO-FILMMAKERS GET ROCKY MOUNTAIN ``HI!'': The first annual U.S. Environmental Film Festival will be held today through Sunday in Colorado Springs, Colo. Among the works on display: Ted Turner's ``Captain Planet'' save-the-planet cartoon series, and ``The Elite,'' a CBS pilot about a team that fights those who would pollute the planet.

DOC.HEAD: What Are You Paying For Services?
DOC.TEXT: If you are one of those people whose own inflation rate is rising faster than the official consumer price index, perhaps you might find the answer in the cost of services. For reasons not entirely clear, many people have a tendency to measure the prices they pay for tangible items _ for food, cars, houses and household goods and the like _ but are less aware of rises elsewhere. ``Elsewhere'' is the service as opposed to the goods sector, and it makes up by far the larger category, including health care, food vending, hair styling, banking, government, education, law and more. Not only is the service sector bigger, but prices there are rising much faster than in the goods sector. Price rises in health care, for example, have exceeded the general inflation rate for many years, including this one. Officially, the consumer price index rose at an annual rate of 0.5 percent in March. But within that rate was a significant split: Goods inflation was but 0.2 percent; service inflation, 0.7 percent. While the dichotomy could be temporary, it also might be fundamental and difficult to contain. How, for example, do you restrain health-care prices when lives are at stake? How do you offset mandated minimum wage increases in retailing? Do you really want to lower education costs while your children are in school? Some of those increases tend to sneak up on you. While you might buy food each day, you might avail yourself of a doctor's services only a couple of times a year, and a lawyer's services even less, and so lose a sense of price. A report by the Coalition of Service Industries gives a portrait of the service sector that might surprise many people. To illustrate, nine out of 10 workers added to the labor force since 1982 have been employed in services. Last year, nearly all the 2.5 million workers who entered the labor force found jobs in services. Goods producers added only 30,000 workers. The service society also is growing relentlessly. Two decades ago it occupied two-thirds of the labor force; today, there are three workers in services for every one in goods production. Meanwhile, service productivity has been lagging, and for an obvious reason: whereas goods production can be automated, the production of services is labor-intensive. Consider your landlord, barber, teacher, doctor, waiter. Some of those trends will continue. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects the formation of another 18 million jobs by the year 2000, an average of about 1.5 million a year, and most of the jobs will be in services. Total employment is expected to rise from 118 million in 1988 to 136 million by the turn of the century. Employment in services is projected to rise to 79 percent of all non-farm wage and salary jobs from 75.9 percent in 1988. It means, obviously, that jobs in the goods sector as a percentage of the whole will continue to decline. And remember, productivity increases, which tend to restrain price increases, are hardest to achieve in the service sector. While these generalities are based on the workings of the economy in general, the chances are high that your own personal economy is subject to the same pressures.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Trip Highlights Church's Decade of Change in Latin America
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II is making another trip to Latin America, where the Roman Catholic church has changed dramatically in the 11 years since he first outlined his vision of its role. The nine-day visit to Mexico, starting Sunday, will underline the changes since 1979, when John Paul set the tone of his papacy toward church activism in the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic region. Maintain your commitment to the poor, the pope told his bishops in Puebla, Mexico, but do not become partisan politicians. In the ensuing years, the church has assumed a greater role in social and economic affairs and gained broader prestige in Latin America, but divisions have emerged between liberal and conservative clergy. From without, the church is increasingly threatened by the aggressive proselytizing of evangelical Protestant churches. It is challenged by the dramatic growth of poverty in a region of vital concern to the Vatican. This is John Paul's 10th trip to Latin America and he also plans to visit Cuba, perhaps in December. Latin Americans make up nearly half the world's 850 million Catholics. The Latin church has influenced Catholicism worldwide with its bold efforts to adapt the gospel to Third World societies. Liberation theology, which links spiritual freedom to liberation from economic and social oppression, was born in Latin Ameria. John Paul has sought to blunt the philosophy's effect. ``Certainly, what I feel in the last few years is what we feel a little in the universal church; it is a moment of what some call conservatism,'' said the Rev. Irineu Wilges, a Brazilian who is the Franciscan order's counselor for Latin America. Despite that conservatism, the Latin American church leadership has transformed itself. Cardinals and bishops, once close to the ruling minority, began condemning political repression in the 1970s, when brutal dictatorships were common. Frequently, the church was the only institution strong enough to stand up to the government. Catholic officials who specialize in Latin America say the church leadership has extended its political role in three ways: _Encouraging the establishment of democracy, particularly in Brazil and Chile. _Serving as a mediator between the government and guerrillas, as in Nicaragua and El Salvador. _Speaking out on problems facing new, fragile democracies, such as land reform, foreign debt and the rights of native Indians. Those actions reflect the church's widespread credibility in Latin America and its effort to grow closer to the poor. ``The people have much more faith in the church than they did 10 years ago,'' said the Rev. Jose Luis Castaneda, a Peruvian who is the Jesuit order's regional assistant for South America. ``I don't know if it's the merit of the church or the disasters of the politicians.'' John Paul has supported the Latin church's ``option for the poor,'' declared at a 1968 conference of bishops in Medellin, Colombia. On trips to the region, the pope has assailed dictatorship, highlighted the foreign debt problem and defended labor unions. He also has condemned liberation theology that uses Marxist analysis and warned clerics to stay out of politics. Action has accompanied his words, particuarly in Brazil, whose bishops have encouraged liberation theology. Brazil has about 100,000 ``ecclesiastical base communities,'' church-sponsored groups that press for political and social change. The Vatican promoted conservatives in Brazil, which has moved the bishops conference to a more centrist position. In 1985 it ordered the Rev. Leonardo Boff, Brazil's most prominent progressive theologian, to maintain ``obedient silence'' for a year. Last year, the Vatican divided the Paolo archdiocese of another progressive, Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns, into five smaller dioceses, seriously diminishing his influence. ``It isn't that some people are for helping the poor and some are against,'' Wilges said. ``The church is divided over how to do it.'' Divisions between liberals and progressives have deepened because of the actions in Brazil and similar ones in other countries. Last year, the Vatican ignored the choice of the organization's own leadership in choosing a new secretary-general of the Latin American Confederation of Religious, prompting an outcry from priests and nuns. Religious orders account for about 80 percent of the priests and nuns in Latin America. Their members tend to be more liberal than diocesan clergy and bishops. The Vatican acted after the confederation introduced a Bible-study program for members that the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith condemned as too ``ideological.'' Whatever the internal problems, many church officials say Latin American Catholicism's greatest challenge is from conservative evangelical churches on the outside. Non-Catholics in the region now number more than 30 million, the Latin American bishops conference says. In Mexico, the number of Protestants grew more than 500 percent in 1950-1980, to 2.2 million, according to church figures. In some Mexican states, up to 20 percent of the people are believed to be non-Catholic. Some Catholic officials contend the church's approach to faith has been too political or intellectual. Others claim the evangelical churches receive money from the U.S. government or businesses hoping to hinder church efforts for social change. Officials say greater poverty and ever-growing urban slums create serious problems for the church in spreading its message. Activism on behalf of the poor continues to exact a price, as shown by the murder of six Jesuits by Salvadoran soldiers in November. ``The standard of living is ... lamentably regressive,'' Bishop Dario Castrillon Hoyos, president of the bishops conference, said in a recent report. ``We must therefore ask ourselves what have been the results of the church's effort to raise people's consciences, and of the political commitment of Catholics.''

DOC.HEAD: Rationing Miracles: Health Care in Era of Infinite Demand, Limited Resources
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Life-and-death questions once left to God and the family doctor may soon be answered in Oregon by legislators poring over a computerized, prioritized, cost-analyzed printout of ailments and treatments. The printout, ranking the relative benefits of 3,000 medical procedures, is due out this week after researchers spent months determining how Oregonians get sick and injured. The next step is for legislators to take the list, search their souls, and draw a line. Above the line will be illnesses covered under the state's Medicaid program for the poor. Below it will be ailments the poor must live with _ and sometimes die with. Welcome to medical rationing, Oregon style. Proponents say it's a necessary evil in an age of limited budgets and $200,000 liver transplants. And Oregon's high-tech approach is being watched closely by other states facing the same high-tech question: Can we afford the miracles of modern medicine? ``We can transplant hearts and lungs and livers and parts of the pancreas. We can do far more with trauma victims than ever before,'' said Connie Thomas of the Intergovernmental Health Policy Project, a research group in Washington, D.C. ``But deciding how to use those technologies in a fair and cost-effective way has eluded us all.'' The glowing success of organ transplants, for instance, is tarnished by the fact that nearly all patients first undergo ``wallet biopsies'' to see if they can afford the costly surgery. Every wonder drug or surgical breakthrough raises uneasy questions of who will be excluded. Should society pay to transplant a chronic alcoholic's damaged liver, even though he'll go through the new one in a couple years? Should a bedridden 90-year-old get triple-bypass heart surgery, even though other ailments will likely kill her within a year? What if she's 60? Once only the poor had to worry about being locked out of health care. But as medical costs rise, many middle-class Americans are feeling poor when it's time to pay the doctor: _ U.S. health-care spending this year is expected to exceed $600 billion, or about 12 percent of the gross national product, up from 7 percent in 1970, federal health officials say. _ Some 31.5 million people, or 13 percent of all Americans, have neither health insurance nor Medicaid coverage, the Census Bureau says. _ Even Americans with company health plans are being asked to pay more. And those plans may decrease in value, as insurance companies ponder dropping costly procedures from standard coverage. Medical rationing looms as a dominant health care issue of the 1990s, as Americans realize after decades of revolutionary medical advances that there are no miracles, just hard choices. ``Health care is a world of limited resources and infinite demand,'' said Dr. Arthur Feinberg, regent of the American College of Physicians. ``It comes down to a question of who lives, who dies _ and who decides.'' Indeed, who should decide? Doctors avoid the debate, saying their allegiance is to the individual patient, regardless of society's cost. Congress may seem a logical place to tackle the issue, but don't expect miracles there, either. National health care has long been batted around Washington, but the estimated annual price tag of $65 billion dampens enthusiasm. For now, the issue of health care sits with the states, nowhere more heavily than in Oregon. The story here began in 1987, when a cash-strapped Legislature halted Medicaid funding for most organ transplants, saving the money for other health needs such as prenatal care. Only two other states, Virginia and Arizona, exclude transplants. Oregon's decision drew little notice at first. Then Coby Howard, a 7-year-old leukemia victim, died as his family tried to raise contributions for a bone marrow transplant. Suddenly health-care allocation was an issue, kept alive by a stream of publicized hardship cases. Advocates for transplant patients and the poor demanded a new way of distributing state Medicaid dollars. Last June the Legislature gave them one. It was less _ and more _ than they expected. Legislators tackled a basic inequity of the state-federal Medicaid program. Congress designed Medicaid to provide health care to the poor, but millions of poor Americans don't qualify. That's because states adjust eligibility standards each year to match their budgets. The lowest standards are in Alabama, where a family of two qualifies only if it earns less than $88 a month, or 13 percent of the federal poverty level of $700 a month for one parent and child. The national eligibility average is 50 percent of the poverty level. Oregon decided to expand its 60 percent coverage to 100 percent of the poverty level, adding as many as 120,000 people to Medicaid rolls. The Legislature also passed a bill requiring employers to provide basic health insurance. The idea was to stop rationing people out of health care and start rationing services instead. The problem was finding a fair way to decide which services to cut. The newly created Oregon Health Services Commission held 61 public meetings. More than 50 committees of medical specialists compiled thick reports, listing ailments along with the cost and effectiveness of treatments. A telephone survey asked Oregonians to rate illnesses in terms of how they would impair their lives, from death at 0 to perfect health at 100. This mountain of data was crunched into a complex formula, and an all-night computer run produced a list of costs and benefits for treating 3,000 illnesses, from appendicitis to herpes zoster. The preliminary list will be released May 2 at a commission meeting in Portland. But the real test comes in January, when the Legislature must decide how far down the list funding will go. A treatment such as polio vaccine will no doubt rank high on the list; it's cheap and extremely effective. High-cost bone marrow transplants may be near the bottom. ``We don't have enough money to do everything,'' said state Senate President John Kitzhaber, an emergency room physician who masterminded the plan. A child dying for want of a liver transplant is sad, Kitzhaber acknowledged, but no sadder than a woman nine months pregnant seeing her first doctor in the emergency room, or patients staggered by pneumonia because they couldn't afford a doctor's care for flu. ``Most people don't have a need for the things that get most of the publicity,'' he said. ``The services most people are losing access to are things like treatment of minor trauma and respiratory infections _ common things that occur commonly.'' Oregon needs a congressional waiver of Medicaid rules to implement its plan, and that is not guaranteed. Critics in Congress and elsewhere say Oregon legislators are using technical hocus-pocus to justify unneeded rationing. ``Asking the poor to fight among themselves over the crumbs of the Medicaid program is not my idea of a courageous policy,'' said Arthur Caplan, director of the University of Minnesota's Center for Biomedical Ethics. ``We have lots of reasons to believe that the health-care system is bloated and inefficient. Before we ration anybody out of the health-care lifeboat, I think we ought to trim that bureaucracy.'' Even those who differ agree that Oregon's plan has raised awareness about setting priorities. And that, said researcher Thomas, is progress for a society once too proud to talk about it. ``We were the country without limits,'' she said. ``Now people are talking about rationing, about death and dying. That never would have happened a few years ago.''

DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: The Flip Side of Rationing _ When Government Picks Up the Tab
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Same name Rettig in grafs 22 and 25 is cq; officials are not related.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Medical Rationing, b0376
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen years ago, Congress took a small step toward national health insurance when it decided to take on the costs of life-saving treatment for nearly all Americans whose kidneys had failed. It was supposed to cost about $200 million a year. Today, the cost is more than $3.3 billion. ``If the kidney program were to come up today, it would be completely dead in the water ... because of the obsession to bring costs down,'' said Arthur Caplan, head of the University of Minnesota's Center for Biomedical Ethics. ``The reason we don't have national health insurance is the kidney program,'' he said. ``The costs associated with it scared legislators out of their gourds.'' In the early 1970s, government money was flowing more freely and only dollars stood in the way of life-saving treatment for the many thousands of people whose kidneys failed. The success rate of kidney transplants was up, but this option was expensive and limited by the supply of donated organs. The other effective option, the artificial kidney machine that cleans the blood of toxins in a process called dialysis, was also expensive. However, the number of patients who needed the relatively new procedure was far greater than the supply of machines could handle. Life-saving treatment was being rationed by hospital committees that were deciding, essentially, who would live and who would die. The technology to save lives was there. As Sen. Vance Hartke, D-Ind., posed the question on the Senate floor in 1972: ``How do we explain that the difference between life and death is a matter of dollars?'' That year, Congress extended Medicare coverage to nearly all patients in the advanced stages of kidney disease, regardless of age. With this coverage, patients pay about 20 percent of the cost of treatment _ whether transplant or dialysis _ and the federal government pays 80 percent. The medical industry responded by building dialysis treatment centers across the country. There are now about 1,800 centers, with 80 to 90 added each year. More than 80 percent of dialysis patients go to one of these centers three times a week for treatments that last four to six hours each, at a cost of about $25,000 to $30,000 annually. The remainder are treated in their homes, at around $20,000 a year. Caplan asserts that the kidney program has been a ``bonanza for for-profit medicine'' and says the program's price tag could be cut considerably if the government encouraged more home treatment. In Britain, he said, 66 percent of dialysis patients are treated in their homes. But that issue aside, even in the early years of the program, it was apparent that Congress had vastly underestimated the cost of dialysis and transplants, which now run about $25,000 per patient plus several thousand dollars a year for anti-rejection drugs. And as the costs rose steadily, the profile of kidney patients getting the life-saving treatment changed. Before the program, three of four dialysis patients were men, most were well-educated, almost 42 percent had jobs, 91 percent were white, and only 7 percent were over 55. By 1981, more than 45 percent were over 55, half were women, 35 percent were black and only 18 percent were working, researchers reported at the time. Now, the elderly are the fastest growing group on dialysis, with about 30 percent of patients over 65. Physicians ``are under a great deal of pressure from family and patients (to use dialysis) even when the prognosis is poor,'' said Daniel Callahan, director of The Hastings Center in Briarciff Manor, N.Y., an independent nonprofit research organization that examines ethical issues in medicine. The latest government figures available put the cost of the program in 1987 at $3.3 billion and rising by about $300 million a year. Some 147,000 patients had coverage under the program at some time in that year. ``We have chosen not to make difficult choices with this disease,'' said Paul Rettig, executive director of the American Hospital Association. ``The money is in the Medicare program ... and we made a financial choice to pay for it.'' But government money does not flow so freely now, and lawmakers are looking around every corner for places to cut the budget. Few suggest turning back the clock with repeal of the kidney program, but some question use of transplants and dialysis in ``marginal'' patients, those who have other medical problems and are not likely to live long in any event. The fundamental question is how scarce resources should be spread among all who need them, said Richard A. Rettig, who is directing an Institute of Medicine study on the kidney program. ``This is one of those things we recognize as a source of anxiety. We walk up to it and walk away from it and walk around it, because we have no way to decently confront it directly,'' he said. ``The renal world did confront it in the 1960s, they were relieved from doing so in the '70s and '80s,'' he said, ``but the question doesn't go away.''

DOC.HEAD: Voters Growing More Tolerant on Mental Health Issue
DOC.TEXT: Lawton Chiles compared himself to Abraham Lincoln when he told Floridians he was being treated for depression. But he may be more like Tom Eagleton _ and that bodes well for his gubernatorial prospects. Eagleton was forced off the Democrats' 1972 presidential ticket after disclosures that he'd had shock treatment for depression. But two years later, Missouri voters re-elected him to the Senate by a landslide. Like Eagleton, Chiles is well-known and well-liked in his state. And that familiarity, analysts say, is key to how voters treat candidates who have acknowledged problems such as mental illness, drug abuse and alcoholism. Tom Kiley, an adviser to Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis in 1988 and to Eagleton in his 1974 Senate race, said such troubles are a legitimate campaign issue because they bear on questions of judgment. But they can be blown out of proportion when voters don't know a candidate well, he said. When people are familiar with a politician, ``it's a lot easier for them to weigh the information, put it in context and come to a conclusion about the role it should play in an election,'' Kiley said. Rumors of depression swirled briefly around Dukakis shortly after he became the Democratic presidential nominee. He suffered considerable damage by failing to squelch them promptly, largely because he was new on the national scene. ``People had no long-term familiarity and personal information to fall back on,'' Kiley said. That is not the case with Chiles, who served three Senate terms before quitting in 1988. He blamed burnout and frustration. But leaving the capital didn't cure his blue moods, insomnia and lack of appetite. Only when Chiles started taking Prozac, a common medication for depression, did his spirits rise and his political drive return. Chiles entered the Florida governor's race this month and became the instant favorite over both Rep. Bill Nelson, his chief rival in the Democratic primary, and incumbent GOP Gov. Bob Martinez. Polls showed him the clear leader even after people were told he was taking medication for depression. Other candidates have been raising questions about Chiles' mental state, both indirectly and head-on. ``If Lawton is depressed sitting 18 years in committee meetings in Washington, if he spends about 13 minutes in the governor's chair he may blow his brains out,'' said former Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., who is challenging Martinez in the GOP primary. Eagleton's Missouri constituents apparently were unperturbed that he had received shock treatment. They sent him back to the Senate with 60 percent of the vote only two years after he was forced off the national ticket headed by George McGovern. His stability was not an issue in the campaign. ``It was obvious that voters didn't have any lingering concerns that needed to be addressed,'' Kiley said. ``He was held in high regard.'' Rep. Jim McDermott, D-Wash., the only psychiatrist in Congress, said any candidate who raises mental health questions about an opponent must be grasping for issues. Candidates should be judged by how well they perform under stress, not by the medication they're taking, he said. ``Abraham Lincoln probably would not have been qualified for the presidency if this were a disqualifying problem,'' McDermott said, referring to Lincoln's well-known bouts of melancholia. Frank Mankiewicz, who was McGovern's campaign manager in 1972, said voters find mental illness ``a lot less frightening and therefore less of a stigma'' now that it typically is treated with medication rather than shock therapy. He and others say voters generally have become more sympathetic to candidates fighting alcoholism, depression and other illnesses as the problems have become more widely acknowledged in society. Most families have had first-hand experience with such troubles, Kiley said. And increasingly, candidates are opening up to voters and counting on their understanding. Kiley cited Texas Treasurer Ann Richards, a recovering alcoholic who won a hard-fought Democratic gubernatorial primary, as a case in point. Voters seem to accept her explanation of her illness and treatment, Kiley said. ``Chiles is in a similar position,'' he said. ``He has great credibility, he's widely respected. He can talk with great candor about this aspect of his background and expect to get the fairest possible hearing from voters.'' Mankiewicz said voters might be less touchy about Chiles' mental health because he is running for state rather than national office. ``After all,'' he said, ``the governor of Florida doesn't have his finger on the button.''
