DOC.HEAD: Tiny Particles Suspected of Carrying Pollutants
DOC.TEXT: Particles called colloids apparently can attach themselves to, or encase, bits of toxic elements and allow them to flow for long distances in water, researchers said. A Los Alamos National Laboratory study suggests colloids could confound conventional means of predicting how far pollutants travel through ground water. That, in turn, means some hazards might have been underestimated. ``Colloids probably play a more important role than people expected in the past,'' said Wilfred Polzer of the lab's earth and environmental science division, one of the study's co-authors. The colloids, which might be composed of silica or various minerals, are so small that a powerful microscope is needed to see them and so light that they do not settle out of water. The study, published in the journal Environmental Science and Technology, concerned two radioactive elements _ plutonium and americium. But William Penrose, the study's lead author, said the phenomenon potentially could affect an array of hazardous and radioactive pollutants, pesticides and heavy metals. No one knows how widespread colloids are because nobody has routinely looked for them, said Penrose. Their existence in ground water was unknown until a few years ago, and there still is little data, Penrose said. The study underscores the importance of determining whether colloids are present at waste sites throughout the country, Penrose and Polzer said.
DOC.HEAD: Inventors Honored
DOC.TEXT: Chuck Henager came up with a way to make buildings more resistant to earthquakes. Ray Moore invented a fluid that removes impurities from industrial smokestack gases. Doug Elliott and Eddie Baker found a way to get more usable material from low-grade crude oil, which could help reduce the nation's reliance on foreign sources. They were among 344 people honored April 19 at an ``Invention Convention'' that was part of Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratory's 25th anniversary celebration. The scientists, engineers and technicians are responsible for 369 inventions from the laboratory that have received patents in the 25 years Battelle has provided research for the U.S. Department of Energy's Hanford nuclear reservation. ``The whole basis is good people coming up with good ideas,'' said Don Williams, director of technology transfer for Battelle. ``We're trying to honor some of those people.'' Henager created a concrete building joint that he said might have prevented the fatal highway collapse during last fall's earthquake if it had been used on San Francisco Bay area highways. But the joints are still being tested by the American Concrete Institute, he said. Moore, who is retired, has 20 patents. He said he is proudest of a molten salt system that is the fluid used in smokestack scrubbers to remove impurities before gases are released to the environment. The Invention Convention includes a booklet with four pages of small-type descriptions of patents. There is not a better mousetrap among them. But there are inventions to control the start-up of nuclear reactors, for more energy-efficient methods of melting glass, and for a method to detect plastic explosives in airline baggage.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for April 30

DOC.TEXT: An international investment group will pay about $1.5 billion for Saks Fifth Avenue, a respected name in American retailing since the 1920s. The high-fashion department store chain was put up for sale last September by its British parent company, BAT Industries PLC, and became one of the most sought-after retailers on the market. Investcorp, a well-capitalized group that acts on behalf of wealthy Middle Eastern, American, British and other European investors, won the bidding Wednesday with an offer retail analysts regarded as attractive.

The St. Louis Sun, which hoped to be the first major metropolitan newspaper to make a successful launch in this country since World War II, unexpectedly folded after only seven months. Ralph Ingersoll II, editor in chief of the newspaper, said Wednesday the Sun had published its last edition Tuesday night. The Sun had struggled to overcome higher-than-expected costs, revolving-door circulation, limited advertising and a murky image. It also had troubles developing everyday readers.

After weeks of fighting off hostile advances from a British conglomerate, Norton Co. agreed to a $1.8 billion merger with a French firm. The offer by Compagnie Saint-Gobain on Wednesday topped the $1.6 billion, $75-a-share offer from BTR PLC, the British company that had been pursuing Norton, a leading manufacturer of abrasives and engineering materials.

The corporate parent of American Airlines said it will spend $11 billion to expand passenger services and amenities in a bid to become the nation's premiere international airline. AMR Corp. said Wednesday it was embarking on the five-year plan that will include such luxuries as lobster and chocolate mousse served on special china, and possibly even airborne fax machines, despite a $19.3 million first-quarter loss reported last week. The program will include a previously announced $7.7 billion investment in aircraft, AMR said.

Exxon Corp., widely criticized for the Valdez oil spill, won a vote of confidence from shareholders who overwhelmingly rejected six resolutions asking the company to do more to protect the environment. Exxon's environmental record dominated the meeting Wednesday, with most speakers supporting the resolutions. But when the votes were counted, no proposal received as much as 10 percent of the vote. The resolutions sought pledges by Exxon to reduce emissions of pollutants and toxic waste, create a special environmental affairs committee on its board of directors and follow the so-called Valdez Principles for corporate environmental conduct.

East Germans rushed to their banks to withdraw their savings, hoping to get the best possible exchange rate with the mighty West German mark. While official delegations from both Germanys met behind closed doors in East Berlin to forge a plan for monetary union, worried people stood in long lines outside their banks Wednesday, eager to rescue some of their savings. Negotiations now taking place are based on a Bonn prosposal for a basic 1-1 exchange rate for wages and pensions. Amounts above 4,000 marks held in savings accounts would be swapped at a less favorable 2-1 rate, though.

Existing home sales in March remained below 1989 levels for the second straight month as mortgage interest rates stayed in the double-digits, a real estate trade group reported. The National Association of Realtors said Wednesday that resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.40 million units, unchanged from the number of sales in February but down from the 3.52 million rate in January.

Carl Icahn said that if USX Corp. shareholders approve his proposal to spin off its steel business, he would increase his USX stock holdings by $800 million and pledge not to seek control of the company. Icahn, USX's largest stockholder with a 13.3 percent stake, on Wednesday apparently was trying to counter suggestions that he has proposed the spinoff solely as a way to drive up the price of USX stock and then profit by selling his holdings.

Trustees of the Gannett Foundation, the largest shareholder in Gannett Co. Inc., voted unanimously to put its 10 percent block of stock up for sale. The foundation said Wednesday at annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association that it would prefer to place the stock in the hands of the Gannett Co. or an employee-stock ownership plan if possible.

The stock market pulled out of a week-long slide with a mild rally in light trading Wednesday. The Dow Jones insdustrial average, down 111.27 points over the last five sessions, rose 11.94 to 2,666.44. Bond prices finished lower. The dollar fell against most major currencies in light trading. Precious metal futures prices plunged; copper futures surged to an eight-month high; oil futures were sharply lower; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Pricetag on Saks $1.5 Billion; New Owner is Hands-off Operator
DOC.TEXT: The international investment company buying Saks Fifth Avenue plans to stick with the managers and the strategy that have made the high-fashion retailer successful, officials said. Investcorp, a Middle East-based company, is paying $1.5 billion to add the Saks name to a rack of upscale retailing investments that include Tiffany jewelers and Gucci. As the rich price indicated, Saks had been one of the most sought-after retailers on the market after its British parent, BAT Industries PLC, put it up for sale last September. ``It does show that a profitable and prestigious U.S. retailer can command top dollar despite all the retail properties on the market'' and a sluggish retail environment, said Janet Mangano, an analyst at Josephthal & Co. The transaction announced Wednesday by Investcorp and BAT should be completed within 10 weeks. Investcorp will assume certain of Saks' liabilities under the agreement. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy said Investcorp's proposal was financially sound and contained a substantial amount of equity to maintain Saks' reputation and support planned expansion of the 45-store chain. ``Saks will gain a new owner with a proven track record in building luxury businesses, solid financial backing, and a commitment to continuing the highly successful strategy established by BAT for the company,'' Sheehy said. Arthur Martinez, senior vice president of BATUS Inc., BAT's U.S. arm, said the acquisition will have nothing in common with the heavily debt-dependent deals that caused problems for others, such as Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retailers. ``This is not a traditional LBO (leveraged buyout) structure,'' Martinez said in an interview. ``Adequate capital is being put into the business to manage it the way that is has been managed.'' Store openings and renovations will be continued by the new owners, Martinez said. Excluding a store in Texas that is being closed, Saks has 45 stores in 20 states. The flagship store of the New York-based chain is located in Manhattan on Fifth Avenue. Investcorp is widely believed to have immense financial clout. It normally takes a laissez-faire approach to the companies in which it holds stakes. For that reason, it is anticipated that Saks' existing management, including Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Melvin Jacobs, will be retained. Jacobs has been credited with steering Saks on a successful course. The retailer rang up sales of $1.3 billion last year and earned $111 million before taxes and interest expenses. Paul Leblang, Saks senior vice president and director of marketing, said Jacobs was unavailable to comment. Jacobs, in partnership with a Japanese retailer, was one in a handful of losing bidders. Investcorp was established in 1982 and operates from bases in New York and London as well as well as cities in Switzerland and Bahrain. It is incorporated in Bahrain and publicly traded there. A controlling interest is owned by Investcorp's management committee and it has about 11,000 shareholders in total, including wealthy Middle Eastern, American, British and other European investors. Investcorp previously has bought into a wide range of retailers. It acquired the jewelry chain Tiffany & Co. from Avon Products Inc. and took it public in 1987; it owns 50 percent of the Italian luxury leather goods and fashion company Gucci; and has an interest in Chaumet, France's largest retailer of prestige jewelry. It also has stakes in ice cream chain Carvel Corp. plus some retailing and non-retailing companies. Paul Soldatos, a member of Investcorp's management committee that led the effort to buy Saks, said the company intends to meet with Saks management as soon as possible. He said in an interview that no discussions had taken place to date because the Jacobs group was a competing bidder. ``It is our intent to maintain the continuity of management,'' Soldatos said. ``We rely on professional managment to guide the business.'' The acquisition of Saks will make Investcorp a powerful behind-the-scenes force in a lucrative segment of the U.S. retailing industry. ``They really have an eye on retailers that have a name,'' said Janet Mangano, an analyst at Josephthal & Co. ``What's very significant about this is Investcorp automatically becomes a major participant in U.S. specialty retailing.'' BAT is selling its U.S. retailing businesses as part of a restructuring to focus on its core tobacco and financial services operations. The British conglomerate undertook the move to fend off a hostile $22 billion takeover bid by a group led by Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. The Goldsmith group dropped its bid earlier this week but BAT promised to carry out its restructuring to enhance the company's value to shareholders. On April 19, BAT announced the sale of Marshall Field & Co., the Chicago-based retailer, for $1.04 billion to Dayton Hudson Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Shareholders Overwhelmingly Reject Environmental Proposals
LaserPhoto HT2 of April 25
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. claimed a welcome victory after shareholders rejected measures urging it to do more to protect the environment, but at elast one of the company's big investors was dismayed by the vote. Shareholders at Wednesday's 3-hour, 40-minute annual meeting turned down six resolutions asking Exxon to improve its environmental performance in the wake of last year's Valdez oil spill. Although the resolutions received more support than is usual for shareholders' proposals, none got as much as 10 percent of the vote. Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl said the results indicated ``support of the management by large shareholders.'' That support didn't include New York City's pension fund, which own 6 million Exxon shares or less than 1 percent of the total outstanding. The fund voted in favor of five of the six environmental proposals and abstained from voting for the company's nominees to the board of directors. The fund's trustee, Elizabeth Holtzman, ``is still not persuaded that Exxon understands that its image and potential liability as a polluter could seriously affect the value of its stock,'' said Ms. Holtzman's spokeswoman, Nancy Young. Management had urged shareholders to vote against resolutions seeking pledges by Exxon to reduce emissions of pollutants and toxic waste, create a special environmental affairs committee on its board of directors and follow the so-called Valdez Principles for corporate environmental conduct. ``Liz is dismayed that a company in good conscience can oppose reducing air pollution and toxic emissions,'' Ms. Young said. Brion Blackwelder, vice president of Friends of the Earth who said he represented holders of 250,000 shares, also criticized management's opposition to the proposals. ``You've chosen to take a hard line and miss each pitch totally,'' Blackwelder told Rawl. ``You are out of touch with reality. You're running a ship that you're not able to control. I see no reason for you not to step down.'' Rawl did not respond, but later said Exxon's support of American Petroleum Institute environmental guidelines showed the company's commitment. ``In addition to reaffirming our own commitment to safety and environmental protection, Exxon has been an active participant in the development of guiding principles for the petroleum and chemical industries,' Rawl said. ``We're not taking a lackadaisical approach,'' he said. ``It's damn important to us what happens'' to the environment. Rawl and President Lee R. Raymond presented an upbeat report on Exxon's efforts to clean up Prince William Sound, where the Exxon Valdez ran aground on March 24, 1989, spewing 11 million gallons of crude in the nation's worst oil spill. ``The important point to make about the oil spill cleanup _ important to Exxon and you as shareholders and important to Alaskans _ is that very substantial progress has already been made,'' Raymond said. ``First by the massive effort that we mounted last year, and later by the continued impact of bioremediation applications which we made last year.'' Under bioremediation, a oil-eating chemical is sprayed along the ground. Raymond told reporters only about 60 miles of Alaskan shoreline will be cleaned this year when full-scale efforts get under way in a couple of weeks, compared to 1,100 last year. ``We really think that we'll be in very good shape by the end of the summer,'' Rawl said. Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, interrupted management's review of 1989 to criticize an upbeat, six-minute video showing Exxon's clean up efforts. He was booed when he suggested the spill had harmed more than Alaska's environment and even caused increases in child abuse and alcoholism. ``Listen to the people of Alaska whose lives have been destroyed and you're putting the profits in your pockets,'' Hair said. Although the environmental proposals fell far short of adoption, Federation spokeswoman Lisa Sylvester said the votes ``should be a clear signal to Exxon that it's not going to get away with trying to cover up the truth and it's going to have to change its policies in order to survive in a changing world.'' About 1,850 people attended Wednesday's meeting, with only about 20 protesters standing outside. Last year's meeting, held about a month after the Valdez ran aground, drew about 1,700 shareholders with about 250 raucous demonstrators outside.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Helped Companies, Boesky Gave Bags of Cash, But Both Are Felons
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken appeared to have it all: the brains, the power, the money, the achievements. Ivan Boesky was made to seem he would have had nothing were it not for cheating. Both wound up in federal court admitting they were felons. ``I regard both as criminals, both as having engaged in conduct which cannot be described as anything but arrogant disregard of the law,'' former SEC Chairman David Ruder said. ``I wouldn't be sorry for either of them.'' Some saw a difference, though. ``The fact is, you can distinguish Milken from Boesky,'' securities lawyer Ira Lee Sorkin said. ``Milken did not (hand over) paper bags stuffed with cash at 4 a.m. under the Brooklyn Bridge.'' Milken the financier and Boesky the stock speculator have been lumped together for more than three years. A 1987 Forbes magazine drawing showed them with ear-to-ear grins after fattening up on a pie of money. But while Boesky's wide legacy is that of swindler, Milken is regarded by many as a brilliant innovator who created a new form of financing that changed the way Wall Street and corporate America operate, for better or worse. During his tearful guilty plea in U.S. District Court on Tuesday, Milken sought to distance himself from his longtime customer at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He said he and Boesky ``had little in common.'' Afterward, Milken's lawyer, Arthur Liman, said Milken hoped history would recount not just the lawbreaking in several stock and bond transactions but his junk bond innovations that helped dozens of small companies. ``He's a genius but he broke the law,'' said former stockbroker Boyd Jefferies, who admitted to illegal dealings with Boesky, cooperated with investigators and was placed on probation. ``He has to suffer the consequences just like myself,'' Jefferies said Wednesday from his Aspen, Colo., home. ``I contributed a lot to the securities industry, but I stepped over the line and I had to pay.'' Tales abounded of Boesky's shady business dealings, such as swapping satchels of money with investment banker Martin Siegel for illegal inside information about takeover stocks he was trading. Boesky, now 53, rode in limousines, wore expensive black suits, beat his own drum in newspaper interviews, dined at the Harvard Club _ he never finished college but got a degree from Detroit Law School _ and was obsessed with money. Boesky once asked an interviewer to imagine a Jacob's ladder made of $500 million in silver dollars. ``Imagine,'' he was quoted as saying, ``wouldn't that be an aphrodisiac experience, climbing to the top of such a ladder?'' Milken, 43, wears a sharply different public face. He dresses in conservatively tailored blue suits and simple ties. By the standards of a billionaire, the Encino, Calif., home where he lives with his wife, Lori, and three children is modest. When Milken talks to reporters _ always under carefully controlled conditions _ it is about helping others. He focuses on the high-yield bond market's capital-raising attributes and on his favorite charities. Asked about money, he often says that ``wealth is a byproduct.'' It was a byproduct he enjoyed far more than Boesky. Milken earned $550 million in 1987 alone. And his reputation as a sometimes ruthless controller who worked 18-hour days is hardly flattering. Milken's detractors say junk bonds created a debt binge that has left many companies on the brink of failure. They also say junk-bond-financed hostile takeovers realigned the corporate power structure against managers in favor of noveau riche raiders. Four of the six criminal counts to which Milken pleaded guilty this week involved dealings with Boesky. The government's original 98-count indictment and the SEC's complaints against both men included allegations of more extensive illegal behavior. As head of Drexel's powerful high-yield bond department, Milken did business with Boesky beginning in 1983, raising $100 million for a Boesky-controlled hotel group. Drexel raised about $750 million for Boesky's arbitrage partnerships in the next three years. ``In many ways the Boeskys of this world are (Milken's) creation,'' said playwright Jerry Sterner, a one-time businessman who wrote the off-Broadway hit ``Other People's Money'' about a hostile takeover. ``It seemed to me he was the master puppeteer. Boesky was one of many puppets he had on his string.'' Until pleading guilty to six criminal counts and agreeing to pay $600 million, Milken asserted his innocence. In court, he broke down in tears while reading a statement about his ordeal. His family and dozens of friends watched in shocked disbelief. Boesky made no such statement when he pleaded guilty three years ago to one felony and agreed to pay $100 million in penalties. There was no horde of supporters, no business associates ready to extol his virtues. All of Wall Street's convicted professionals, Jefferies said, ``come in somewhere above that low point on a scale of one to 100. Ivan was minus 100 on the scale.'' ``Michael definitely had many, many pluses,'' he said, ``and he had some minuses.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress May Seek To Hear From Milken, Boesky
With PM-Milken-Boesky, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It started out as a hearing on penny stock reform legislation, changed into a report on the Michael Milken settlement and then into a dressing down of the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. When it was over Wednesday, officials said the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee may call the fallen financier Milken and ex-speculator Ivan Boesky to testify before Congress. Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies on Tuesday, ``might have things we'd be interested in hearing,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., whose committee oversees the SEC. A senior congressional aide who asked not to be identified said Dingell also may seek testimony from Boesky, who led prosecutors to Milken and was linked to the former junk bond king in a number of illegal deals. The disclosures came after a hearing of the committee's finance subcommittee, which is considering legislation to give the SEC more clout in fighting fraud in the low-cost, high-risk penny stock market. But SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden spent much of his time touting the settlement the SEC and Justice Department reached with Milken. The former high-yield wizard of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ended a three-year struggle with the government by pleading guilty to six securities and tax violations and agreeing to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces up to 28 years in prison at sentencing Oct. 1. Boesky settled criminal and civil charges by pleading guilty to one felony count and paying $100 million. He was freed earlier this month after completing two years of a three-year prison term. Dingell said he may call Milken to testify about purported violations involving junk bond offerings handled by Drexel. ``We think there may have been as many as 2,500 (violations) and that may be on the low side by an order of 10,'' Dingell told reporters after peppering Breeden with questions about the Milken settlement during a hearing on penny-stock reform legislation. At issue is the legality of trading accounts owned by limited partnerships _ controlled largely by Drexel employees _ that bought significant percentages of hot junk bond issues before they were made available to the general public. Critics say the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers, but the transactions' legality has never been resolved. Drexel halted the practice after it came to light. The existence of the limited partnerships was disclosed two years ago in documents and testimony presented to the oversight subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee. Milken was called to testify at that time, but invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. The documents and testimony were sent to the SEC and Justice Department but ``there has regrettably been no satisfactory response,'' Dingell said. Dingell complained about SEC inaction on the matter to Breeden, although he conceded the events occurred before Breeden took office last October. ``It is ... over a year since those matters were referred to the commission. Nothing was done,'' Dingell said. ``Can you tell us why nothing was done? Was it because of budgetary matters or indifference or what?'' ``I can't even tell if nothing was done,'' Breeden said, adding that he would look into it.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief Criticizes Many Aspects of Penny Stock Reform Bill
DOC.TEXT: Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard Breeden told a House panel he supports efforts to curb penny stock fraud but fears legislation being considered may cause as many problems as it solves. Penny stocks are low-cost securities, usually trading for less than $3 a share, that are typically used to raise capital for new or small companies. They are not listed on stock exchanges and thus reliable, up-to-the-minute information about them is hard to obtain. That makes penny stocks prone to fraud by unscrupulous traders and promoters. The Penny Stock Reform Act of 1990, introduced earlier this month by Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., would implement several reforms. They include beefing up the SEC's power to bar crooked promoters and consultants from pushing highly speculative stocks on unsophisticated investors and requiring that all penny stocks trade through an automated stock quote system. The Energy and Commerce Committee's finance subcommittee, which Markey chairs, heard testimony on the bill Wednesday. Supporters of all or most of the bill's provisions included U.S. Attorney Dee Benson of Utah and Susan E. Bryant, administrator of the Oklahoma Securities Department and president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, a state-level regulators group. But Breeden said that while the SEC supports the proposed legislation's goals, ``there are a number of specific areas where the bill as presently drafted create some problems we think it would be better to avoid.'' Unscrupulous penny stock brokers can evade SEC banishment from the securities business by calling themselves promoters or consultants, which the SEC has no authority to regulate. To close that loophole, the bill would redefine who is a person ``associated with a broker or dealer.'' Breeden said the legislative language was too broad, however, and would force broker-dealers to register all their officers and other employees _ and maybe even their accountants and lawyers. That point was supported by another witness, John F. Guion, president of the Associated of Publicly Traded Companies, a group of 800 concerns whose stock is traded over-the-counter. Breeden also criticized a provision to bar so-called ``blank check'' stock issues, which seek investors' money without a specific business plan or purpose, and ``blind pool'' penny stocks, which seek mergers and acquisitions in a specific industry or line of business. ``What appears to be a simple solution could have costly and undesirable side effects,'' Breeden said, noting that the provision could impose added responsibilities on the SEC without additional resources. He also said the provision could inhibit legitimate venture capital efforts in the real estate, oil and gas exploration and equipment leasing industries. Rep. Matthew J. Rinaldo, R-N.J., the subcommittee's ranking Republican and a co-sponsor of the bill, expressed concerns about weakening the legislation. ``We want a strong bill. We want this practice to a halt,'' said Rinaldo, adding, ``and I don't think we're going to be able to do it with a weakened piece of legislation.'' Breeden spent much of his testimony lobbying for passage of the Securities Law Enforcement Remedies Act, a market reform bill pending before the full House. It would give the SEC powers it never had before including the authority to impose civil fines of up to $500,000 and halt alleged illegal activity without first obtaining a court order. That bill ``would enhance the commission's enforcement power in all types of cases, and they would prove especially valuable in combating penny stock fraud,'' said Breeden.

DOC.HEAD: Company Agrees to French Merger in Takeover Fight With British
DOC.TEXT: In the spirit of 1776, a Massachusetts company threatened with invasion by a British conglomerate has turned to the French for help. Norton Co. announced Wednesday it had agreed to be bought by Compagnie Saint-Gobain, one of the world's leading glass makers, for $1.8 billion or $90 a share. The move averted a potentially debilitating siege by Britain's BTR PLC, which earlier made a hostile takeover bid of $1.6 billion or $75 a share. ``Everybody's happy,'' said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst with the brokerage PaineWebber Group Inc. ``An ongoing fight would be detrimental. They've put together an excellent deal.'' Norton had fought bitterly since BTR launched its bid last month but in the end conceded it couldn't stand alone. ``Given the increasing risk of the worst alternative for all constituencies _ fighting a war of attrition only to be bought in the end by BTR for an inadequate price with no protection for employees and the Worcester community _ we have concluded that a negotiated merger ... is the best alternative,'' Chairman John S. Nelson said in a statement. News of the agreement sent Norton's stock sharply higher on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock rose $13.37{ a share to $88.62{ Wednesday and was the most active issue on the exchange with more than 4.5 million shares traded. Under the deal, Norton will continue to operate under its name and keep its headquarters and principal manufacturing operations in Worcester. The companies said employee policies and benefits would continue at present levels and Norton would retain a separate board of directors. Those were key factors for Norton. The company had claimed a BTR takeover could have led to its dismemberment despite BTR's denials. Saint-Gobain Chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said he agreed to the deal to expand his company's U.S. interests and because ``we did not want to see it (Norton) dismembered or subjected to debt that would interfere with its strategic plans.'' BTR said it would withdraw its attempt to put three people on Norton's board of directors but is extending its offer to May 3. The extension is in case the deal with Saint-Gobain merger goes sour, said a BTR spokesman in New York City, who refused to give his name. ``Essentially, we're pleased by it,'' the spokesman said of the higher bid. ``We're 4.9 percent shareholders of Norton.'' Norton employees staged an impromptu rally in the company parking lot to celebrate their apparent escape from BTR, which they were convinced would have decimated the company. ``The mood is great,'' said Tom Morrison, organizer of a group formed by employees to fight BTR's bid. Employees had held rallies, published a daily newsletter and lobbied for legislation to make a BTR takeover more difficult. ``We're really proud of what we did. Things are really good. Hopefully, BTR's going away and this company we're setting up with seems to be a very good move,'' he said. Norton spokeswoman Andrea Priest said the merger appeared to be the best way out of the takeover battle. ``Saint-Gobain is a real strategic partner for Norton. Aside from the fact that it's offered a premium price for the company, it understands Norton's businesses, it believes in research and development,'' she said. Norton is a leading manufacturer of abrasives and engineering materials, including advanced ceramics, performance plastics and chemical process products. It had 1989 sales of about $1.5 billion, employs 16,000 people and operates 113 plants in the U.S. and 25 other countries. Saint-Gobain produces a variety of flat glass, fiber glass, piping, paper and wood products. It has annual sales of more than $11 billion, employs 88,000 people and operates 350 plants. ``I think that it's an ideal situation for Norton and Saint-Gobain,'' said Alvin Donius, an analyst with New York-based Altman, Brenner Wasserman. ``There is great synergy _ technology, research and development, manufacturing _ the whole nine yards.'' The merger requires the tender of at least two-thirds of Norton's common shares before April 30. The announcement came a day after a federal judge ordered Norton to reveal the amount of an offer the company said it received last week. Norton told the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday that a third party was interested in buying Norton for more money than BTR.

DOC.HEAD: The St. Louis Sun Sets Abruptly
DOC.TEXT: Few people could have been more shocked than John O'Connor when the St. Louis Sun, the morning tabloid that made its debut just seven months ago, went out of business. O'Connor joined the Sun's staff a little over a week ago _ just long enough to rent an apartment and learn his way to work _ and was out on assignment when the newspaper's editor-in-chief, Ralph Ingersoll II, announced the paper's closure in the newsroom Wednesday. ``I walked into a bar and I saw Ralph Ingersoll on TV,'' O'Connor said, standing outside his newspaper's downtown offices. ``I said, `That looks like my boss, I'm from the Sun.' They said, `That is your boss, you're out of a job.''' O'Connor, who came to the Sun from the Bloomington (Ill.) Pantagraph, was one of 194 full-time employees who were trying to recover from the shock that the Sun is no more. Ingersoll, who is chairman and chief executive officer of Ingersoll Publications Co. and has an interest in four other newspaper holding companies, said his new tabloid couldn't generate enough single-copy sales. ``It had nothing to do with money. It had to do, and you'll have to take me at my word for it, with single-copy sales '' said Ingersoll, who had moved to St. Louis to personally direct the rise of the new paper. Ingersoll said the Sun had to sell most of its 100,000 newspapers via vending boxes or from racks in convenience stores and on street corners in order to survive. Instead, it ended up with home-delivery sales outnumbering single-copy sales two-to-one. That cost the paper, which spent in excess of $25 million to start up, an unexpected $5 million. Home delivery costs are higher because of the expenses of billing customers and hiring delivery people. Ingersoll decided Sunday night to stop the presses and make Wednesday's newspaper, with the large, front-page headline ``Deathly Quiet,'' the Sun's final edition. After seven months and 213 editions, the newspaper's sudden death surprised everyone. ``They read the handwriting on the wall .... The weather was good, the Cardinals were playing, the Blues were playing and people still weren't buying the paper. You don't have to be a brain surgeon to figure it out,'' said Kevin Horrigan, a popular columnist who jumped ship from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch to join the Sun. In Horrigan's old newsroom, Post-Dispatch Editor William Woo said he was sorry about the demise of the Sun. ``The Sun undertook a difficult mission and made a valiant effort, which fell short,'' Woo said. With a circulation of about 100,000, the Sun never threatened the Post-Dispatch's huge circulation of 375,000 daily and 565,000 on Sunday. But it did manage to generate a fair share of controversy in this conservative Midwestern city. The Sun was criticized by some as sensationalizing stories for its coverage of a politician involved in a sexual assault and of the five-year anniversary of an accident in which a man was nearly sawed in two. The newspaper also was chided for running photos of new women's swimsuits and lingerie. But the Sun was praised for its coverage of the effort to build a new domed stadium downtown and of the troubles facing St. Louis' major air carrier, Trans World Airlines. Ingersoll said he didn't know how much money he had lost on the Sun. He said the decision to close had nothing to do with long-term debt problems at another of his newspaper companies. ``They have nothing to do with each other. They are different companies,'' he said. On Friday, an offer by Ingersoll to buy back much of the $240 million of junk bonds issued by his Community Newspapers, Inc. failed to attract a single bondholder. If he can't arrange a buyback, the interest rate on some of the bonds might have to be reset at an exorbitant level of more than 26 percent in June. Ingersoll extended the offer until May 4 and Wednesday said he was considering raising his offer. The St. Louis Sun was owned by Ingersoll Newspapers, Inc., which also owns 77 other newspapers in seven states. Ingersoll also has a stake in New Haven Newspapers, Inc., which owns the New Haven Register; Ingersoll Publications Ltd., which owns 29 newspapers in Great Britain; and Ingersoll Publications Co., which is a newspaper management group.

DOC.HEAD: Camaro, Firebird Production Moving to Canada from California
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s announcement that it will move production of two sports cars to Canada from California is antagonizing labor relations as contract negotiations draw near, a union official says. GM of Canada announced Wednesday that production of the new generation of the Chevrolet Camaro and the Pontiac Firebird, or F-cars, would begin in Ste. Therese, Quebec, in 1992 for the 1993 model year. The cars now are made at GM's Van Nuys, Calif., plant. ``Since General Motors clearly has sufficient capacity to build the F-car replacement in the United States we see no reason why it should not be built here,'' said Stephen Yokich, vice president of the United Auto Workers in charge of the union's GM Department. ``These annoncements are doing nothing to create a favorable environment for the difficult negotiating task we face later this year,'' he said. The UAW and the nation's Big Three automakers begin bargaining in July on contracts to succeed agreements that expire Sept. 14. Workers at the Ste. Therese plant are represented by the Canadian Auto Workers union. CAW President Bob White said the announcement ``was hopefully a measure of security for the future.'' The Ste. Therese plant now makes the Chevrolet Celebrity station wagon and the Oldsmobile Ciera, both A-cars. GM of Canada spokesan D. Stewart Low said Wednesday the new Camaro and Firebird would be the only cars produced at the plant. ``There's no question that the A-car will leave Ste. Therese,'' he said. In addition to Ste. Therese, GM now makes Celebrity wagons and Cieras at its plant in Oklahoma City. Sales of Camaros and Firebirds, first introduced in 1967, have been suffering this year like those of other GM cars. Through April 20, Camaro sales were down 35 percent compared with last year, and Firebird sales were off 39.6 percent. The precise timing of the production move hasn't been set, Low said, but, ``It looks like we're on target for a '93 (model year) launch.'' He also said it was too early to tell if the change would alter the work force at the plant outside Montreal. There are about 3,500 workers at the Ste. Therese plant and about 3,800 at the Van Nuys factory. GM plans to change the Van Nuys plant to a ``flex plant,'' or one that can make a variety of vehicles on the same assembly line. Such plants are used by Japanese automakers, but the move would be a significant break from GM's past manufacturing practices. ``It would be a facility capable of assembling a number of various models that would allow us to respond more quickly to the Western market,'' GM spokeswoman Kathy Tanner said in Detroit. She declined to say what kind of vehicles may be built there or how long it would take to convert the plant. ``It would be flexible from the standpoint of being able to build a new van they are bringing out as well as some cars,'' Henry Gonzalez, United Auto Workers union Region 6 assistant director, said from Southern California. It wasn't known what kind of cars would be made at the flex plant. Sports cars and convertibles are extremely popular in the West, along with sport-utility vehicles and vans. Tanner said final approval for the flex plant hasn't been granted, but said backers of the proposal were encouraged.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Car Sales Lagging
DOC.TEXT: The absence of a subcompact in Chrysler Corp.'s lineup and a retreat from large-scale fleet business are damaging the company's car sales, and relief won't arrive before 1992, analysts say. Sales at the nation's No. 3 automaker have fallen more than those for General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., the top two makers. Chairman Lee Iacocca acknowledged Wednesday that Chrysler's absence in the subcompact market is hurting. Chrysler stopped making its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompacts Feb. 2 when it closed a plant in Detroit. It said sales of the so-called L-cars were too slow. They will be replaced by stripped-down versions of the Plymouth Sundance and Dodge Shadow, code-named P-cars. ``We're taking a beating,'' Iacocca said in Chicago, the fifth stop of a six-city road show to promote the company's vehicles. ``We dropped the L-car. We don't have the lower-priced P-car ready for mass production for lots of reasons. We got out of the rental car business. There wasn't any money in it.'' Auto analyst David Healy of Barclays-BZW in New York agreed the absence of a subcompact is hurting sales, but suggested less of an impact on the bottom line. ``Part of it is they've discontinued Omni-Horizon so that takes units out but doesn't take profits out,'' he said. Inexpensive cars carry a smaller profit margin than expensive vehicles. Auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. in New York said sales are depressed even without subcompacts. ``There are two things operating in Chrysler car sales,'' she said. ``They dropped the Omni-Horizon. The other is that Iacocca has said that with the fleet business having gotten so ferocious, that Chrysler has pulled back from that.'' Healy estimated that 15 percent to 20 percent of the industry's sales volume so far this year has been in fleet sales to rental car companies, police agencies, taxi companies and large corporations. All of that has dented the company's car sales figures. But sales of light trucks, which comprise about 55 percent of Chrysler's U.S. sales, remain at fairly strong levels given the current general sales slump. Through April 20 of this year, Chrysler's North American-made trucks were selling at a rate 5 percent slower than during the same time last year. Sales of trucks made by Ford were down 4.5 percent while GM's truck sales were up 2.9 percent. Sales of Chrysler's North American-made cars were down 16.7 percent, while sale of Ford cars were off 11.4 percent and GM cars were down 5.7 percent. Sales of U.S.-made cars carrying Japanese companies' nameplates were up 20.2 percent. In his road show and on television advertisements, Iacocca has said Chrysler deserves a break. He contends Chrysler's quality is at least as good as that of the Japanese cars, and that Americans should head to dealerships to find out. But dealers aren't seeing big increases in customers in their showrooms. ``We had a good month last month, but it's a little slow now,'' John Johnson, sales manager and co-owner of Dodge of Kingfisher in Kingfisher, Okla., said Wednesday. ``For four or five years, it's been hard to put two good months together.'' There doesn't appear to be anything on the near horizon to reverse the car sales trend, analysts say. Chrysler plans to introduce a new line of cars in late 1992 for the 1993 model year developed from a project code named LH-LX. ``They need something really distinctive and I think LH will really do it for them,'' Sudol said. ``I don't think there is a whole lot coming between now and then,'' Healy said. ``They do have the restyled minivans coming this fall, but that's the main thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Foundation to Sell Its 10 Percent Share of Gannett Co. Stock
DOC.TEXT: Trustees of the Gannett Foundation, the largest shareholder in Gannett Co. Inc., said tax considerations will cause it to sell its 10 percent stake in the company. Foundation Chairman Allen H. Neuharth and President and CEO Charles L. Overby announced the plan to sell the stock holding in a joint statement at the American Newspaper Publisher Association meeting Wednesday. ``IRS regulations, which require foundations to pay out an amount equal to 5 percent of their assets annually, force us to seek higher income than common stock dividends pay,'' the statement said. ``With increased income, we will expand the work of the USA's largest information-based foundation, especially broadening programs in education, literacy and first amendment freedoms.'' The release said the foundation would prefer to place the stock in the hands of the Gannett Co. or an employee-stock owner plan if possible. ``But our financial advisers will explore all alternatives,'' it said. Gannett Co. issued a statement saying its board previously announced a stock repurchase program to acquire up to 7,500,000 shares of Gannett common stock. ``From time to time, the company has expressed its continuing interest in buying back its stock, subject to market price,'' the statement said. ``Gannett has not yet decided whether it will be in a position to be a purchaser of the stock that may be sold by the foundation.'' To date, Gannett said it has repurchased 2,957,000 shares of stock. The Arlington, Va.-based foundation held its annual meeting in connection with the ANPA convention.

DOC.HEAD: Cheers, Anger As Union Marches Outside Eastern
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Police moved in after strikers clashed with Eastern Airlines workers during a boisterous union farewell to ousted boss Frank Lorenzo. One union member was injured. Scuffles broke out when Eastern workers crossed the Machinists picket lines during a 3 p.m. shift change Wednesday. Hundreds of union members were marching outside Eastern corporate headquarters, as they have for more than 13 months. Dozens of Metro-Dade County and Miami Springs police officers waded into the crowd. One union member, his head bleeding after apparently being hit by a nightstick, was taken away for treatment in a Metro rescue vehicle. ``All he did was call a scab what he is _ a scab,'' said Charles E. Bryan, president of Machinists District 100. He said two police officers on horseback clubbed the unidentified union member. ``That's unconscionable,'' Bryan said. Metro-Dade police spokeswoman Lizette Williams said two union members were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct. Of the wounded striker, she said there was ``some controversy about how he was injured, whether the gentleman fell or what happened.'' She estimated the crowd of demonstrators at 450 people. Martin Shugrue, former executive at Pan American and Continental Airlines, was appointed by a federal judge as a trustee to run Eastern, still owned by the Lorenzo-headed Texas Air Corp. Striking Eastern Machinists, who walked out March 4, 1989, were joined in their rally by some 200 members of the union's international who were meeting at Hollywood's Diplomat Hotel. ``It's kind of a bittersweet type of thing,'' said George Kourpias, the union's international president. ``It's bitter because it took 13 months but it's sweet because Lorenzo is out.'' Kourpias said Shugrue's pledge to bring better labor relations to Eastern was encouraging, and that Shugrue has a reputation for fairness. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell had no comment about the rally.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Asks, `Is There a Future for Newspapers?'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: How will newspapers survive in a world where fewer and fewer people read them? Will there be enough literate people to care? A fittingly upbeat Walt Disney Co. chairman Michael Eisner said everything was going to be just fine. Alvin Toffler, author of ``Future Shock,'' said the answers lie in fusing education with the media. But for those assembled Wednesday at the American Newspaper Publishers Association's 104th annual meeting, one of the most compelling statements during a panel discussion titled ``A Look at the Future'' came from Lew Allen, director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab: ``There is a very large segment of our country that is not influenced by the L.A. Times'' or television news ``because by anyone's definition, they are functionally illiterate.'' The panel discussion, with TV newswoman Diane Sawyer as moderator, also included John Malone, director of Denver-based Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable systems operator, and John Seely Brown, a vice president of the Xerox Research Center. The 90-minute discussion touched on myriad issues confronting the future of print journalism, from dwindling readership to the proliferation of giant-corporation mergers. ``Are we talking about a limited number of huge corporations controlling everything in this country and are you going to buy CBS or what?'' Sawyer asked Eisner. The Disney chairman did not answer the second part of the question despite widespread speculation that his studio was interested in purchasing the bottom-ranked TV network. ``It takes huge corporations to compete in a world market,'' Eisner replied. ``But do I think it was necessary for Time to buy Warner's to compete? No, I think that was a fabrication of the moment.'' Asked by Sawyer to give a headline for the upcoming decade, Malone joked, ``Murdoch Stripped of U.S. Citizenship'' and ``President Turner Cites First Amendment Abuses.'' Futurist Toffler was more political and slightly more ambitious, speculating that ``Japan and the U.S. form an integrated economic and political system.'' And on the subject of whether computer networks will someday provide news at the touch of a key and thereby replace newspapers, Allen said, ``The interest of people in reading in our society is declining. The great difficulty is how do we get people to be interested in information. Getting the technology there is easy.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Like New Lean Meat Label, USDA Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumers apparently have generally accepted a new federal label for lean beef since the Agriculture Department carved it out more than two years ago. The new labeling took effect in November 1987 after consumer and industry people petitioned USDA for a name change in official federal beef grading, said Jimmy Wise of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service. ``Consumers told us they wanted a more positive description of leaner meat available in grocery stores, and they got it,'' Wise said Wednesday. The change involved scrapping the 60-year-old ``USDA Good'' label and substituting a new ``lean'' label on supermarket cuts. Many nutrition-conscious consumers wanted the name change because they felt the ``Good'' label misled buyers into thinking the beef was mediocre. When the label was established in the 1920s, it described the amount of fat, or marbling, in a cut of beef. The consumer view was that less fat was more healthful and that the ``Good'' label wasn't descriptive. A consumer organization, Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, petitioned USDA in June 1986 to change the name from ``Good'' to ``Select.'' The change, also endorsed by a dozen other consumer and health groups, went into effect in November 1987. The push to a ``Select'' beef grade also was supported by the cattle and meat packing industries, including the American Meat Institute, National Cattlemen's Association and the American Farm Bureau Federation. Wise said the ``Select'' grade was adopted as the result of ``a welcome coalition between industry and consumers.'' Moreover, he said,``Select'' beef is selling well. ``That wouldn't be happening if people weren't happy with it,'' Wise said. ``Industry is responding by providing more leaner beef for grading, and more retailers are beginning to carry the product.'' In the three months prior to the official name change, only 49,714 pounds, or 1.7 percent of all graded beef, qualified as ``Good.'' By the fourth quarter of 1989, the ``Select'' label accounted for 433,413 pounds, or 14.3 percent of all graded beef, according to agency records. Since the 1920s, USDA has provided eight grades and standards to beef quality. Those are: Prime, Choice, Good (now Select), Standard, Commercial, Utility, Cutter and Canner. Federal grading by USDA is a voluntary service that is requested by packers and paid for by user fees. It is designed to help assure the industry and consumers of uniform standards for a variety of commodities other than beef and cattle, including cotton, dairy products, fruit, other livestock, mohair, poultry rabbits, shell eggs, tobacco, vegetables and wool.

A House Agriculture subcommittee has approved a foreign trade section of the 1990 farm bill that would allow food giveaways to needy countries. The legislation is similar to the Senate measure on foreign trade approved in committee earlier this month. The farm bill will set agriculture policy for the next five years. An aide to the House committee said the major difference between the two bills is the way the food aid programs would be managed within the government. Both bills would allow the president to give food to countries whose governments he wants to encourage, like those of Eastern Europe. Currently, such assistance must be in the form of a sale. The bills also allow the United States to forgive the debts of financially strapped countries trying to restructure their economic programs. Both the House and the Senate followed Bush administration recommendations in writing their bills. Ann Veneman, the Agriculture Department's deputy undersecretary for international affairs and commodity programs, said the chief difference the administration has with either bill is in the language dealing with the Export Enhancement Program. Under the program, exporters collect bonuses, or subsidies, for sales of certain products to designated countries. The program is used to reduce the prices of U.S. commodities in order to meet foreign competition. The Senate bill says USDA must spend at least $900 million in fiscal 1991 on the program. The House versions requires that $500 million be spent. But the administration does not want any specific dollar amount named. ``It's a trade policy tool,'' said Veneman. She said the amount spent should be the prerogative of the administration.

The Agriculture Department says a record 492,000 acres of national forest land were replanted to trees last year. Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson said Wednesday the acreage was the most since the national forest system was created in 1905. Robertson said last year's effort was due in part to rehabilitation work in areas burned by the major wildfires of 1987 in California, Oregon and Washington, and to high levels of reforestation in areas of 1986-88 timber harvests in the national forests. Of the total area reforested in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, about 307,000 acres were directly seeded or planted to trees. The remaining 185,000 acres were reforested through natural regeneration, by seed falling from nearby trees onto areas prepared by the Forest Service, or through sprouting. Robertson said the previous record was 434,000 acres reforested in 1980. An estimated 460,000 acres will be reforested this fiscal year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Slightly Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were slightly higher at midday Thursday, boosted by a steady British currency and scattered institutional buying. Traders said they expected the buoyancy to last through the day, particularly if Wall Street opened higher as expected. ``There's a buzz in the market which we haven't seen in quite a few days,'' said the head of trading at a major British brokerage firm. At about midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 1.2 points, or 0.06 percent, at 2,144.3. Volume came to 314.5 million shares, more active than most sessions over the last two months. At the same time Wednesday, volume totaled 242.5 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Publishing Giant Considering Selling Part of Business
DOC.TEXT: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. has confirmed that discussions are underway for the possible sale of part of its business. The announcement Wednesday followed months of denials from the giant publisher that its assets were for sale in an effort to reduce the company's $1.5 billion debt. But Peter Jovanovich, president and chief executive officer, said in a statement that the Orlando-based corporation ``is not for sale.'' Instead, he said, the company has begun preliminary talks involving the sale of some or all of its existing debt at a discount, or the purchase of ``certain assets of the company by a third party.'' ``It is simply premature to speculate as to whether a transaction will occur, and, if one does occur, as to its eventual form or terms,'' he said. The statement was released hours after a report that former U.S. Sen. Eugene McCarthy, who has served for a decade on HBJ's board, said the company had held talks for a month with Thomson Corp. of Canada. HBJ is saddled with debt, and its textbook business does not generate enough income to meet its future obligations. Within three years, the publisher is to start paying hundreds of millions of dollars annually in dividends and interest to bondholders. HBJ incurred the debts through a recapitalization that fought off a hostile takeover in 1987. Thomson, in turn, has been seeking publishing assets. Last year, the company had sales of $5.1 billion from operations involving educational, medical and scientific books as well as newspapers. McCarthy said he didn't know when a sale might occur. ``There's no conclusion in sight,'' he said. ``It's a question of what kind of pressure we're under.'' In the past week, HBJ stock has risen 25 percent on speculation that the company was discussing a sale to Thomson. HBJ common stock closed Wednesday at $4, unchanged from Tuesday. The stock was one of the most actively traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 3 million shares changing hands. Analysts were not surprised to hear that HBJ's debt might force the sale of additional assets. In the last three years, HBJ has sold its theme parks, its magazines and its book clubs. ``Sometimes the generator just can't generate,'' said Ivan Obolensky, who follows HBJ for the Josephthal & Co. brokerage in New York. ``It's a shame, but they have to make some adjustments.'' HBJ has said it wanted to refinance its debt, possibly extending it so interest payments on the bonds are less onerous. But the company may have found that it cannot refinance any debt until it presents creditors with cash. ``The company is under a lot of pressure. The stock and bonds are way down, and it has been blasted in the media recently,'' said Bert Boksen, who follows HBJ for the Raymond James & Associates brokerage in St. Petersburg, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists: Spill's Human Costs Surface in Hearings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Exxon Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The costs of the Exxon Valdez oil spill should be measured not only in dead otters and oiled birds but in neglected children, broken families and shaken communities, environmentalists said in a report. The report, timed for release on the day of the annual Exxon shareholder meeting in Houston, includes comments by more than 120 Alaskans from hearings held by a citizens commission in November at Cordova, Kodiak, Old Harbor, Homer and Anchorage. ``The human impacts of the oil spill have largely been ignored, but they're continuing,'' Doug Miller, director of the National Wildlife Federation's Alaska office, said Wednesday. The federation was one of the sponsors of the report, which criticizes Exxon for ignoring the human costs of the March 24, 1989, spill, and calls on it to help pay for social services. Exxon spokesman Jim Robertson in Anchorage said company officials had not had time to read the report to respond to it. Members of the citizens commission said residents around the sound reported increased alcoholism, domestic violence, child abuse and neglect. ``It certainly wasn't just a wildlife disaster,'' said conservationist Celia Hunter. ``People were totally torn out of their whole way of life. It's a catastrophe like a hurricane.'' Many in the affected communities made money from the cleanup ``boom,'' receiving high wages from Exxon to scrub beaches. But such ``spillionaires'' created envy and anger in the communities the commission visited, Hunter said. Native communities living off the land were hit particularly hard, the report said. Commission member Ralph Eluska, president of the Akhiok-Kaguyak Native Corporation, said Akhiok villagers still were afraid of catching and eating seafood, activities at the center of their communal life. And cleaning up beaches, he said, has been a frustrating substitute for fishing. The state reported Wednesday that 80 percent of the shoreline sites inspected by a team preparing this season's cleanup of the Exxon Valdez spill still have oil on them. Most of the 481 sites surveyed in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska were lightly or very lightly oiled, while 12 percent were moderately oiled and 6 percent heavily oiled, the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation reported. The survey was conducted this month by state and federal agencies, Exxon and Alaska Native landowners. The group's conclusions will be used to help determine what kind of treatment should be applied to the beaches this summer. ``There is still a lot of oil present, either on the surface or beneath it, and we need to choose the right tools and stick with them until the job is done,'' said department commissioner Dennis Kelso. Exxon is preparing its final cleanup plan, to be released Friday. But spokesman Fred Davis said Exxon was ``not terribly surprised'' by the state's figures ``because the sites that we went to are the ones that all parties agreed had the highest probability of having oil.'' The interagency group expects to survey a total 617 sites before its project is completed at the end of the month. The state has said it can't approve bioremediation _ the use of fertilizer to boost naturally occurring oil-eating bacteria at cleanup sites _ until it receives reports from the Environmental Protection Agency on the fertilizer's toxicity. Davis said bioremediation will be ``a major part of the company's work program.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan's NKK Increases Stake In National Intergroup
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. tentatively has agreed to sell most of its 50 percent stake in National Steel Corp. to NKK Corp., a Japanese company that already owns the other half of the steelmaker. Howard M. Love, chairman and chief executive officer of Pittsburgh-based National Intergroup, said Wednesday the deal realizes his company's goals of shedding its steel interest to focus on its growing pharmaceutical distribution division. National Intergroup also wants to allow NKK to have more influence in National Steel, Love said. NKK will pay $147 million cash for 20 percent of National Steel, then in a second stage will pay preferred stock with a face value of $147 million for another 20 percent. After the transaction is completed, National Intergroup will own 10 percent of National Steel, and NKK will own the remaining 90 percent. NKK is Japan's second-largest steelmaker and the world's sixth largest. ``I am convinced that NKK is committed to building a stronger NSC for its employees and continuing NSC's reputation as a dependable supplier to its customers,'' Love said. ``NKK has the resources and technological expertise that will be fundamental to NSC's future success.'' ``Our company is strongly committed to the steel business and we are prepared to provide the support required to bring National Steel to its full potential as a high quality supplier,'' said Yoshinari Yamashiro, president and chief executive officer of NKK. Kokichi Hagiwara, president and chief operating officer of National Steel, said the company expects to continue its ongoing $1.8 billion capital improvement and modernization plan. ``NSC has a strong team in place,'' he said. ``Management and employee policies and labor and customer contracts will not change.'' The deal is contingent on a definitive agreement being reached by the directors of National Intergroup and NKK, officials said. National Intergroup reported sales of $3.1 billion in fiscal 1989. NKK's sales for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1989 were $9.6 billion. National Steel, the nation's sixth-largest steel maker, had sales of $2.6 billion in the year that ended Dec. 31, 1989. National Intergroup began leaving the steel business in 1983 when it sold the Weirton Steel division. It sold 50 percent of its remaining basic steel business to NKK in 1984 for $292 million.

DOC.HEAD: Field's New Owner May Terminate up to 1,700 Jobs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: 3rd graf new to include attempt to reach companies; SUBS penultimate graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with executives announcing they will leave Field's.
DOC.TEXT: Most of 1,700 corporate jobs at Marshall Field & Co.'s central headquarters may be eliminated as part of a consolidation effort by Dayton Hudson Corp., the company acquiring Field's. Dayton Hudson told Marshall Field & Co. employees in a letter Wednesday that the Chicago retailer's central functions will be merged with Dayton Hudson's once the acquisition is completed. A skeleton staff of Field's current 1,700 corporate employees will remain in Chicago. Telephone calls by The Associated Press to both Dayton Hudson and Marshall Field offices went unanswered this morning. Last Thursday, Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson announced it would acquire Marshall Field's for $1.04 billion, beating out several suitors including a group of Field's managers. Dayton Hudson expects to complete the deal within two months. BAT Industries PLC of Britain put the 24-store chain up for sale last year. In the letter, Dayton Hudson said it will offer jobs in Chicago and Minneapolis to certain Marshall Field's central office employees to fill openings in a new organization. A Marshall Field's regional organization, focused on customer service and community involvement, will be based in Chicago, the letter said. Of the 1,700 corporate employees, 350 to 400 are in the merchandise group, including buyers and managers. Remaining jobs are largely administrative and operational. Employees will be notified as soon as possible if their positions will be eliminated, the letter said. They will be offered severance packages and placement services. ``It's our goal that when the transition is complete, you'll feel that you've been treated with sensitivity and professionalism,'' said the letter signed by Dayton Hudson President Stephen E. Watson and Chairman Marvin W. Goldstein. Still unclear is whether Field's Chairman Philip B. Miller, who led the management buyout bid, will stay on. Miller would say only that there are ``ongoing discussions with senior management members ... regarding continued employment with Dayton Hudson.'' Meanwhile today, Field's Chairman Philip B. Miller, who led an employee buyout bid, and president Burnett Donoho, announced they will be leaving Field's shortly after Dayton Hudson's acquisition is completed. ``We will be working ... to insure a smooth transition of ownership for our associates and customers,'' Miller said in a news statement. Neither announced future plans. Dayton Hudson's department store division operates 37 stores known as either Dayton's or Hudson's in seven Midwestern states.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Reports $254 Million First-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss of $254 million, or $2.93 per share, stemming from its interest in a struggling Chicago-based real estate investment firm. Otherwise, the company reported ``good growth'' in its document processing business and a slump in earnings from its financial services division that it attributed to the weak market for property and casualty insurance. The Stamford-based business products and financial services company announced earlier this year that it had taken a $400 million pre-tax writeoff due to its investment in VMS Realty Partners, a Chicago real estate investment firm. After taxes, the writeoff totaled $375 million, Xerox said. Even without the writeoff, Xerox earnings from continuing operations in the first three months of the year slumped to $121 million, or $1.06 per share, from $158 million, or $1.47 a share, in the same period of 1989. The company said its document processing division, which includes its copier business, earned $110 million on revenue of $3.1 billion, up from $91 million on $2.8 billion in revenue in the same period in 1989. Earnings from continuing operations in the company's financial services division slumped to $11 million on revenue of $1.2 billion, down from $67 on revenue of $1.3 billion in the same period a year ago. David T. Kearns, Xerox's chairman and chief executive officer, said the growth in document processing earnings and revenues were particularly encouraging in light of the soft market for business products. But he said those gains ``were more than offset within our continuing operations by substantial weakness in the property and casualty insurance business and lower capital gains.''
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 419.86 down .70 from the previous day's close.
