DOC.HEAD: Wolf Speaks Out at UAL Shareholders Meeting
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen M. Wolf pledged today to manage United Airlines' parent company as aggressively as he can while its employees try to accomplish their $4.38 billion buyout. Wolf, the company's chairman since late 1987, is likely to be replaced by United's three labor unions if they succeed in getting the financing for their $201-per-share bid, which UAL's board has accepted. Separately, UAL reported a first quarter loss of $36.4 million on revenue of $2.19 billion, compared with a profit of $65.44 million on sales of $2.04 billion in the year-ago period. ``I want you to know that I will continue to manage the company in as aggressive a fashion as possible,'' Wolf said in remarks prepared for today's annual shareholders meeting. Wolf said UAL's board and management ``are committed to using these next few months to deliver the strongest possible United Airlines to its new owners.'' He said he was opposed ``in principle'' to any group borrowing money to buy an airline ``given the cyclical nature of the business and the enormous capital investments required in the industry.'' But he said that if ``leveraging is inevitable, as it was in this case, I believe the preferable course to be employee ownership.'' Wolf reportedly fought the employee buyout plan behind the scenes but ultimately relented. The board had to choose between selling the nation's second-largest airline to its 71,000 employees or facing a proxy fight with UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, that could have ousted the company's directors.

DOC.HEAD: Grain and Soybeans Open Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened slightly lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Pressuring prices is Wednesday's 10-day National Weather Service forecast that calls for warmer and drier-than-normal conditions. Analysts say the ideal planting weather could help nearby corn and soybean prices because of fears of a hot and dry summer. Warm weather at times reduces the amount of land given over to soybeans. Soybean prices also may receive a boost from overall good demand for soybean oil. Wheat futures are being pressured by a decline in the price of spot soft red winter wheat. Pressure on wheat futures also stems from the good growing weather and expected higher yields. At the open, wheat was 3{ cents lower to a \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.67{ a bushel; corn was a \ cent to a { cent lower with May at $23.78\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to a \ cent higher with May at $1.58 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to a { cent higher with May at $6.09\ a bushel. Livestock futures were lower and pork futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hog prices were supported by higher cash prices and firmness in the pork product market. Pork belly futures received some support from steady to higher wholesale prices Livestock futures were pressured by lower cash prices. Live cattle were .02 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 72.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent lower to unchanged with April at 84.20 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent lower to .33 cent higher with June at 62.85 cents a pound; pork bellies were .75 cent lower to .48 cent higher with May at 64 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled mixed in Wednesday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Compaq First-Quarter Profit Rises 10.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Compaq Computer Corp. said Thursday its first-quarter profit rose 10.8 percent due to growth in the company's international business. For the three-month period ended March 31, the Houston-based personeal computer maker earned $92.2 million, or $2.13 a share, compared with earnings of $83.2 million, or $1.95 a share, during the same quarter in 1989. Sales for the 1990 quarter totaled $872.2 million, up 28 percent from the $683 million recorded a year ago. ``Compaq's first-quarter results reflect an extremely strong growth rate in our international business,'' Compaq President Rod Canion said. ``For the first time, our international sales comprised more than half of our revenue. Our international revenue grew 56 percent, fueled primarily by strong European PC (personal computer) market growth and increasing Compaq market share in Europe,'' he said in a statement. Canion said the company's North American revenue increase of 4 percent reflected the sluggish business personal computer market. Compaq in March began shipping its Deskpro 486-25, its highest-performance desktop computer, which is based on the new 80486 microprocessor from Intel Corp. Compaq had delayed distribution of the computer last fall because early verions of the chip were found to be faulty. During the first quarter, Compaq also announced it was reauthorizing Businessland, a major computer store chain, to sell and service the company's products. Compaq's relationship with Businessland had been discontinued in April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA to Propose New Safety Rules in Aftermath of Texas Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department will expedite new safety requirements for the petrochemical industry in an effort to prevent disasters such as last year's Phillips explosion that killed 23 workers in Texas, the agency said today in a report to President Bush. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said its investigation of last October's blast, which injured another 130 workers, demonstrated the need for mandatory safety procedures at plants that store and use highly flammable liquids and chemicals. ``The investigation of the Phillips catastrophe has caused OSHA to take stock and consider a strong course of action to prevent such disasters,'' the report to Bush said. OSHA said that by the end of the summer it would propose requirements that employers implement so-called chemical process safety management plans. Those plans would include analyzing hazards to employees, training workers on safety and developing emergency response procedures, said Assistant Labor Secretary Gerard Scannell, who heads OSHA. Scannell said that most firms in the petrochemical industry already use such fundamental safety procedures, but OSHA's new rules would make them mandatory. OSHA also will consider revising the way it sets priorities for inspections and devoting more attention to the petrochemical industry, Scannell said. Last week, OSHA proposed a $5.7 million fine against Phillips 66 Co. for alleged safety violations at the plant. OSHA's investigation showed that four highly flammable gases escaped from an open valve, forming a huge vapor cloud that traveled through the Pasadena, Texas, plant within seconds because of high pressure. A series of explosions occurred after the cloud came in contact with an unidentified ignition source. Contrary to Phillips' own procedures, as well as standard industry practice, there was no backup protection such as a double valve to protect against valve failure or protect against an untimely valve opening, Scannell said.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists Lose In Octane Cheating
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, ``A consumer,'' to add comment from industry; also moving general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Motorists are losing more than $150 million a year at gas stations that sell low-octane gas at high-octane prices, and the federal government is doing little to stop it, a congressional report said today. The General Accounting Office said a two-year study, which included random testing of retail gasoline in four states, showed widespread mislabeling of gasoline octane levels. The GAO estimated that about 9 percent of gasoline sold nationwide is mislabeled. It said that more than half the samples taken in two large cities last year _ Detroit and St. Louis _ were found to have octane ratings an average of 2.2 or more points below what was posted on the pump. ``What this adds up to is a quiet but dangerous shell-game for consumers,'' said Rep. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., who asked for the study along with Rep. Phillip Sharp, D-Ind. Higher octane gas can prevent damaging engine knock and affect the performance of some cars. In some instances, gas stations were pumping all their gas out of the same tank but selling it as having different octane ratings, said Sharp, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on energy and power. Sharp said he would introduce legislation to give states more enforcement powers over octane cheats. ``A consumer could be paying several cents a gallon extra for quality that is not delivered,'' Sharp told a news conference releasing the report. David Morehead, spokesman for the Petroleum Marketers Association of America, said there have been scattered reports of octane cheating but it is ``absolutely deplored in the industry.'' ``We say go after the cheaters and get them,'' Morehead said, noting that the vast majority of retailers who follow the law are hurt by operators who take extra profits by charging premium prices for regular gas. A 1978 law requires the Federal Trade Commission and the Environmental Protection Agency to enforce compliance with federal petroleum marketing practices. But the GAO study said the agencies, citing lack of funds, have not carried out testing since 1981. The federal law requires uniform yellow and black octane labels on all gasoline pumps. Violators may be fined up to $10,000 for each instance. Mislabeling has been minimal in states that conduct their own tests, said the report by Congress's investigative arm. But in non-testing states visited by GAO investigators, problems were found, mainly at the distribution and retail levels, the report said. One-time testing was conducted in Michigan, Missouri, Oregon and Tennessee, GAO said, and investigators also looked at Indiana, Montana and Washington. Federal standards say regular unleaded gas must have an octane rating of 87, while mid-grade gasolines have ratings of from 89 to 91 and super or premium grades have ratings of 92 to 94. The difference in retail price between the lowest and highest grade ranges up to 20 cents.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower Thursday on London's Stock Exchange, after buying interest dropped off late in the session. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished down 9.5 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,133.6, just above its session low of 2,132.5. Scattered buying interest and a rise in stock-index futures led the market to a session high of 2,145.8 at about midday. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 7.4 points to 1,676.1. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 5.25 points to close at 1,158.65. Volume was 510.9 million shares, up from 392.8 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Earnings Dip, Sales Up 16 percent
DOC.TEXT: Health care products giant Johnson & Johnson on Thursday blamed loan payments in Argentina for a 23.2 percent dip in earnings despite a 16.1 percent rise in sales for the first quarter of 1990. Earnings for the period were $244 million, or 73 cents per share, on sales of $2.84 billion, compared with $317 million, or 95 cents per share, on sales of $2.45 billion for the same period a year ago. The latest results were reduced by a nonrecurring charge of $125 million resulting from paying off an Argentine subsidiary's loan that was growing rapidly because of inflation in that country. Excluding the nonrecurring costs, the company said its earnings would have risen 16.4 percent. ``We are very pleased with the 16 percent increase in sales, especially in the light of the extreme competitive environment in the domestic consumer environment,'' Johnson & Johnson Chairman Ralph S. Larsen said in a statement. ``The increase reflects substantial sales gains from worldwide and professional operations, as well as strong international revenues from our Consumer businesses,'' he said. Larsen said sales of six key products, including a blood screening product for Hepatitis C, increased substantially in the quarter. Johnson & Johnson is the world's largest manufacturer of health care products serving consumer, pharmaceutical and professional markets. It reported 1989 sales of $9.76 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch Signs $100 Million Ad Contract
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Inc. announced on Thursday that it has signed a $100 million advertising contract with the ESPN cable sports network. Officials said the contract, the largest sponsorship commitment ever for cable television, makes the brewer of Budweiser the dominant beer advertiser on the network for another five years. Anheuser-Busch was ESPN's charter advertiser with a one-year, $1.4 million advertising contract when the sports cable network began operations in September 1979. ``Anheuser-Busch was ESPN's first major advertiser and has consistently remained our largest, said Roger L. Werner, ESPN president and chief executive officer. ``We're delighted to extend our relationship, and we trust that ESPN will continue to contribute to Anheuser-Busch's success.'' ESPN reaches nearly 56 million homes, or 61 percent of all U.S. television households. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewer, commands a 42 percent share of the U.S. beer market.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Strike Hurt Hawaii Tourist Count
DOC.TEXT: The 22-day hotel worker strike drove the March visitor count down by 2.5 percent from March 1989, the Hawaii Visitors Bureau reported Thursday. As publicity surrounding the strike increased, so did cancellations, the bureau said. Some 582,000 people visited the Islands last month, a decline of 15,000 from the year before. The HVB had recorded four straight months of increases before March. Some 7,500 employees of 11 hotels walked off the job March 3 in a dispute over pay and benefits. The hotels and Local 5 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union settled the strike on March 24. HVB President Stanley Hong said the strike had the greatest impact on westbound arrivals _ tourists from the mainland United States, Canada and Europe. The number of westbound visitors was down 6.2 percent in March to 408,000, the HVB said. The number of eastbound visitors _ from Japan and the western Pacific region _ still climbed, but not as much as in recent months. Eastbound arrivals increased by 7.3 percent to 173,000, a decline from the double-digit growth recorded during the previous two months.

DOC.HEAD: United, USAir Report First-Quarter Losses, Delta's Profit Down
DOC.TEXT: The parent companies of USAir and United Airlines reported first-quarter losses Thursday, while Delta Air Lines said its profit for the latest quarter dropped 63 percent. UAL Corp., parent of United, said it lost $36.4 million, or $1.68 a share, in the three months ended March 31, primarily due to the settlement of several lawsuits involving its computer reservation system. Without a charge against earnings of $77.5 million due to the settlement, earnings would have been $10.2 million, or 47 cents a share, the Chicago-based company said. UAL reported earnings of $65.4 million, or $3.03 a share, for the first quarter of 1989. UAL reported first-quarter operating revenue of $2.5 billion, compared with $2.3 billion for the same period last year. ``Although we achieved a slight profit for the quarter after excluding the one-time charge for settlement of lawsuits, we are nevertheless disappointed by these results,'' said UAL Chairman Stephen M. Wolf. He said higher fuel costs contributed to the company's poor showing. UAL in March settled a lawsuit filed by Continental Airlines and several other carriers accusing United of unfair competition in the computerized reservations business. The lawsuits, filed in 1985, contended United illegally monopolized or attempted to monopolize the computer reservations business or the air transportation business in various markets. Continental, owned by Texas Air Corp., had sought $336 million in damages, arguing that United programmed its computer reservations system to unfairly favor United flights over its competitors. On April 10, UAL's board approved a $4.38 billion buyout bid for the airline by its unions. USAir Group, the parent of USAir, reported a first-quarter loss of $38 million, or $1.05 a share, blaming it on higher fuel prices and the fact that the peak Easter travel period fell in this year's second quarter. USAir Group, based in Arlington, Va., earned $16 million, or 35 cents a share, in 1989's first quarter. First-quarter 1990 revenue totaled $1.54 billion, up from $1.48 billion for the same period a year earlier. ``Traffic levels through the first quarter were up 8.5 percent, slightly ahead of our projections,'' USAir Chairman and President Edwin I. Colodny said. ``Despite relatively strong passenger traffic, revenue continues to be on the weak side.'' Colodny said several factors boosted last year's first quarter, hurting the comparison with the first quarter of this year: a strike against Eastern Airlines that began in early March 1989, and the peak Easter travel period falling in March last year and April this year. Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines Inc. blamed sharply increased fuel costs for its lower earnings in its third fiscal quarter on sharply increased fuel costs. Profit totaled $31.31 million, or 48 cents a share, for the three months ended March 31, down from $85.02 million, or $1.73 a share, in the same period last year. Operating revenue rose 4 percent, to $2.12 billion from $2.04 billion. Higher fuel prices outweighed strong business traffic, fare increases and increased cargo revenue, said Thomas J. Roeck, senior vice president for finance. Roeck also cited the timing of Easter and the start of the Eastern strike in last year's first quarter as factors that made it difficult to match the results of a year earlier. Eastern is a major competitor of Delta at Atlanta, where both airlines have their main hubs. For the nine months ended March 31, Delta said its net income was $228.69 million, or $4.15 a share, down 15 percent from $270.14 million, or $5.49 a share, during the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 10 percent to $6.34 billion from $5.78 billion.
