DOC.HEAD: Whirlpool's Profit Down 27.5 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. reported Thursday that its first-quarter profit fell 27.5 percent because of the impact of economic troubles on its Brazilian affiliates. Whirlpool, the world's largest appliance maker, has minority interests in Brazilian companies that produce and market appliances and refrigeration compressors. Whirlpool said it had net income of $29.5 million, or 42 cents a share, in the three months ended March 30, down from $40.7 million, or 59 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding a loss of 26 cents a share due to the problems in Brazil, first-quarter earnings would have risen 11 percent, the company said. First-quarter revenue rose 3.8 percent to $1.64 billion from $1.58 billion a year earlier. Chairman David R. Whitwam predicted that economic controls imposed to fight rampaging inflation in Brazil would hurt Whirlpool's operating results into the second quarter, with gradual improvement for the rest of the year. The company manufactures products in 10 countries and markets them in more than 45.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Smoking Resolutions Defeated by Tobacco Company Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: Stockholders of food and tobacco giant Philip Morris Cos. Inc. overwhelmingly rejected two resolutions Thursday aimed against the company's core cigarette products, but supporters of the proposals claimed a symbolic victory. ``We feel we accomplished a great deal getting that kind of a vote,'' the Rev. Michael Crosby said after his proposal calling for Philip Morris to get out of tobacco by the end of the century got 2.2 percent of the vote at the company's annual shareholders' meeting. Another resolution calling on Philip Morris to study the impact of its promotions and advertising on teen-age smoking failed with only 3.5 percent support. ``The point is, we got our issue across,'' said Crosby, who fought a two-year legal battle to get his resolution on the agenda for the meeting at Philip Morris' huge cigarette manufacturing plant here. Hamish Maxwell, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based company, said he could not envision Philip Morris without tobacco, despite growing concerns about the effects of smoking on health and the company's extensive forays into other consumer products. Philip Morris has operations that include Kraft foods and Miller beer, but tobacco ``is our core business,'' Maxwell said. The dissident shareholders said their resolutions addressed profits as well as social concerns. ``This company is going, sooner or later, to be liable for its actions,'' said Crosby, a Catholic priest who works for the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York. ``We are going to lose in the long run.'' Maxwell acknowledged that cigarettes ``are our most controversial product'' but said the company has acted responsibly to health concerns in its development of reduced tar and nicotine cigarettes. He also said warnings about the dangers of smoking are widely publicized. Crosby pressed Maxwell to admit that smoking and sickness have a direct link, but Maxwell said medical research has not gone that far. ``You weasel out of it every time,'' Crosby said. ``I'm not weaseling out of anything,'' Maxwell said. According to company figures, Philip Morris sold 580 billion cigarettes in 1989, including 78 billion cigarettes for export. Its Marlboro brand is the U.S. leader with 26 percent of the market and has 55 percent of the company's overseas tobacco sales. Dr. Alan Blum, founder of the Augusta, Ga.-based DOC News and Views, a publication that bills itself as a journal of medical activism, said Marlboro and other Philip Morris brands are responsible for most of the 1.3 million people who take up smoking each year, many of them teen-agers. Maxwell, however, said overall cigarette consumption dropped about 3 percent in the United States last year and was stable abroad. The company's increased profits from tobacco resulted from taking away business from competitors among adults who already smoke, he said. ``We do not aim our marketing efforts to minors,'' he said. ``In fact, we take active steps to discourage'' youths from smoking. One shareholder who did not identify himself drew applause from the approximately 300 shareholders at the meeting when he said, ``I think these proposals are utter bunk.'' People can freely choose to smoke or not smoke, he said. ``We aren't free when we're addicted, like me, to cigarettes,'' said Crosby.
The stock market was mixed in late trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 10.81 at 2,677.25 with five minutes left to go in the session.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Sun Fails to Overcome Difficult Odds
DOC.TEXT: Notebooks were tossed in the trash and job postings were tacked on the bulletin board Thursday at the St. Louis Sun, the new metropolitan newspaper that abruptly stopped publishing after only seven months of business. The newspaper didn't publish a farewell edition. Its last newspaper, the 213th edition, appeared Wednesday morning. The sudden demise came as a shock to employees, readers, newspaper analysts and others, and it also underscored the nagging slowdown that has hit the newspaper industry. Local and national newspaper advertising around the country grew just 4 percent last year, its smallest increase in more than five years, according to figures provided by the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Daily newspaper circulation has been stagnant at about 62 million for a decade and its been declining the past two years. About the only thing going well for newspaper publishers is that the price of newsprint is about 23 percent lower than last year. ``The newspaper market is in turmoil,'' said Ralph Ingersoll II, chairman and chief executive officer of Ingersoll Publications Co. and editor-in-chief of the Sun. ``This is at least the third such crisis I have personally lived through.'' But Ingersoll, who personally directed the creation of the Sun, which debuted Sept. 25, 1989, said he didn't know what role the industrywide troubles played in determining the Sun's fate. ``I think it had a direct impact,'' said Kenneth Berents, a stock analyst in Baltimore with Alex Brown & Sons Inc. ``It's tough enough to do a startup, but it's almost impossible to do in a bad climate like this.'' When he first set out to bring a second daily newspaper to St. Louis to compete with the 111-year-old St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Ingersoll said he hoped his effort would help invigorate the newspaper industry. And even though the Sun didn't make it, he hasn't ruled out the possibility of trying it again somewhere else. No one else is going to try it, that's for sure. Why? ``First of all, Ingersoll was a maverick and there aren't many mavericks around. Second of all, this is a very unfriendly environment for newspapers right now,'' said Lisa Donneson, a stock analyst in New York for County NatWest USA. At a Wednesday news conference, Ingersoll said the reason the Sun didn't last longer was its failure to sell enough newspapers out of vending boxes and newspaper racks in stores. Ingersoll expected to sell most of the newspapers on a single-copy basis, but soon after the paper started, home-delivery sales outnumbered single-copy sales by a two-to-one margin. That cost the Sun $5 million more than planned. Ingersoll said the newspaper had spent more than $25 million to start up, but he said he didn't know how much of that would be recoverable. Thursday, in the Sun newsroom where windows overlook the Gateway Arch and clocks tell what time it is in Tokyo, some of the newspaper's 194 full-time employees cleaned out their desks and pondered the future. Some showed up in white shirts and ties and talked about job interviews they had just returned from. Some still peppered their sentences with words like ``shocked'' and ``stunned.'' And some talked about Thursday's softball game, the first of the season. ``We're going to play as far as I know,'' said the Sun's Business editor Dan Kadlec, who was in the office with his wife and five-month-old daughter. He left a job at USA Today and moved to St. Louis from New York to work for the Sun. ``I haven't even unpacked,'' he said. Some reporters said they were upset that Ingersoll didn't give the Sun more time to prove itself and more notice of the newspaper's collapse. They said the consensus in the office was that they had two years to try to make it. ``I knew that this newspaper might not be around after two-and-a-half years, but I didn't think he would pull the plug so soon,'' said Ellen Whitford, a general assignment reporter who came to the Sun from Virginia. ``I'm going to start applying for jobs, but the market's pretty bad, so I guess you could say I feel pretty grim at the moment,'' she said. Ingersoll said all employees would be given at least 12 weeks severance pay and efforts would be made to find them jobs at other newspapers in the Ingersoll chain. More than a dozen job listings are already on the office bulletin boards. Meetings were scheduled for Monday and Tuesday to discuss parting benefits.

A late rally in blue chip stocks drove the Dow Jones industrial average to a double-digit gain but the broader market ended mixed. Activity was moderate on Wall Street where some traders marked time ahead of potentially market-moving economic data due Friday. Anxiety about possible interest rate hikes ahead also kept investors on the sidelines. The market got off to a promising start but by late morning the broadly based advance bogged down as prices of long-term government bonds took a beating in the credit market. Some bonds were off as much as $7.50 for each $1,000 in face value in afternoon trading, bringing their yields back above 9 percent. Analysts attributed most of today's scattered stock price gains to ``bargain hunting'' by traders after a week-long slide that lasted through Tuesday's session. But they said rallies have had trouble gaining momentum, daunted by upward pressure on interest rates. The next test of Wall Street's mood was expected to come Friday morning with the Commerce Department's first official estimate of the gross national product for the first quarter of 1990. Economists expect the data to show a modest resurgence in growth, and quite possiby new stirrings of inflation as well. One of the standouts on Wall Street today was Compaq Computer. The stock climbed 4[ to 98[ after the company reported unexpectedly strong first-quarter earnings of $2.13 a share, against $1.96 a year earlier. Ames Department Stores, which today announced it has filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors, ended at 1|, up [. Norton topped the Big Board's list of active issues, falling { to 88\ as more than 2.58 million shares changed hands.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 50 Percent Drop In Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp. said Thursday earnings plunged about 50 percent in the first quarter of 1990, in part because of bad real estate loans and a general softening of the regional economy. For the quarter ended March 31, earnings were $44 million, or 56 cents per share, compared with earnings of $89 million, or $1.23 a share, for the same period a year ago. ``We have experienced a continued weakening in the real estate portfolio and the New England environment, as well as a softening in the overall climate for highly leveraged transactions,'' Chairman and Chief Executive Ira Stepanian said in a prepared statement. Net credit losses were $81 million for the 1990 quarter compared with $29 million for the same period a year ago. Stepanian said the bank's business in Argentina and Brazil had strong earnings during the first quarter, but ``we are cautious about the rest of the year'' because of the volatile economies in those countries. Bank of Boston, New England's largest bank, had assets of $37 billion at the end of the first quarter. The Boston-based bank provides a broad range of financial services to individual, corporate, institutional and governmental customers.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Seek To Curb U.S. Sales Of Nikkei Warrants
DOC.TEXT: Worried about heavy volatility on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Japanese market officials have been pressing to limit U.S. sales of securities pegged to Tokyo's bellwether Nikkei Stock Index. ``They have made their concerns aware to us,'' said Bob Shabazian, a spokesman for the American Stock Exchange, where eight Nikkei put and call warrants trade. The warrants, which some have been blamed for adding to the Tokyo exchange's volatility, are used as a hedge against movements in the 225-share Nikkei index. The warrants give their holders the right to purchase or sell the cash equivalent of the Nikkei index at a certain price on a certain date. Put warrants give the right to sell and call warrants the right to buy. Speculators also use the warrants to bet on the direction of the market, for example, buying put warrants if they believe the Nikkei will decline. As a result, the value of put warrants rises as the Nikkei falls. Since January, the Nikkei has plunged nearly 30 percent in value, raising the demand among investors in the United States and elsewhere for the warrants. In January, the Kingdom of Denmark became the first issuer to list Nikkei put warrants on the Amex. Since then, a number of U.S. investment houses have followed suit, including Goldman Sachs & Co., PaineWebber Group Inc. and Salomon Inc. But American investment houses have agreed to voluntarily halt issuing further warrants at the request of Japanese officials. A spokesperson for Salomon said the firm ``is not going to issue any additional warrants without the approval of Japanese authorities.'' Shabazian said discussions between Amex and Japanese stock exchange officials over the warrants have been ongoing, even before Denmark launched the first. ``We have an information-sharing agreement with (the Japanese),'' Shabazian said. But he added, ``we've had no formal request from them'' to limit trading in the options. In what some market watchers believe could be the last issue for some time, the Financing and Export Credit Institute of the Norwegian Commercial Banks Ltd. issued 7.5 million warrants and raised about $28 million on Thursday. The transaction was managed by Goldman Sachs. A spokesman Goldman Sachs noted that ``having just completed a deal, we're not currently considering another.'' But he added the firm ``always would respect the direction of the American Stock Exchange and, by extension, the Tokyo Stock Exchange.'' Existing warrants would continue to trade until their expiration. The Norwegian warrants, for example, expire in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Reports First Quarter Earnings Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Black & Decker Corp. reported Thursday its first quarter-earnings fell 61.4 percent despite a 76 percent increase in revenue. The company reported it earned $10 million, or 17 cents per share, for the first quarter of 1990, compared with $25.9 million, or 44 cents per share, in the same period last year. Sales rose to $1 billion from $$570 million a year earlier, reflecting contributions from Emhart Corp. acquired in 1989. Operating income rose 148 percent for the period to $108.2 million, from $43.6 million last year. ``Our higher operating income margin, despite a generally sluggish sales environment, attests to Black & Decker's market strength, which has been enhanced by the high-margin product lines acquired from Emhart,'' said Nolan D. Archibald, chairman and chief executive officer. Black & Decker is a leading manufacturer of power tools and other household products.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 509 money market mutual funds fell $816.6 million in the latest week, the fifth-straight weekly decline, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The drop to $387.89 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $1.14 billion drop in fund assets the previous week. That decline originally was reported as $1.25 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group subsequently revised it. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 246 general purpose funds rose $563.3 million to $133.62 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $1.68 billion to $163.64 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds rose $299.8 million to $90.64 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds in the week ended Tuesday was 7.69 percent, unchanged from the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield rose to 7.69 percent from 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, unchanged, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.24 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was 5.05 percent, unchanged. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.95 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, up from 7.91 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.08 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 8.03 percent; 8.10 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 8.06 percent; and 8.14 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.11 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Up
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended April 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,277.5 billion from $3,275.1 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,081.9 billion from $4,073.5 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $810.4 billion from $806 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.1 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,259.2 billion, a 6.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,063.7 billion, up 3 percent, while M1 rose 5.3 percent to an average of $802.4 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $883 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $231 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $296 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $478 million in the two weeks ended April 18, down from $874 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $305.1 billion in the two-week period ended April 18, up from $302 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Generally Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices closed mostly lower Thursday on largely technical factors as the market awaited next week's OPEC meeting. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 19 cents to $18.47 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, adding to a 34 cent drop on Wednesday. Subsequent contract months also declined. The May contract for unleaded regular gasoline fell 1.26 cents to 61.34 cents a gallon, compounding a 1.79 cent plunge in the previous session. Subsequent months also fell Thursday. But home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.67 cent to 53.07 cents a gallon after falling 0.25 cent on Wednesday. The June contract also advanced Thursday, but later months declined. And natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.558 per million British thermal units, up from $1.552 on Wednesday. Analysts said crude oil prices moved lower as traders with large holdings adjusted their portfolios in advance of Wednesday's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries price monitoring committee. The committee is holding a special session to discuss ways of holding down the cartel's production and stopping oil prices from falling. William Byers, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co., said the market is on the defensive as it awaits the OPEC session, and until the meeting ends, trading will be more volatile than usual. Near-term heating oil prices were higher on an increase in demand, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Octane Cheaters May Be Selling One Gas as Regular, Premium and Super Premium
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to add Tennessee to Missouri as state that began octane testing later. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Some service stations pass off regular gasoline as higher-priced super premium, according to a congressional study Thursday that said ``octane cheating'' may be costing motorists $150 million a year. The report by the General Accounting office estimated that 9 percent of gasoline sold nationwide is mislabeled by half an octane number or more. And in several states where pump testing has actually proven mislabeling, the federal government has done little to stop the deception, the report said The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, said motorists who think they are buying premium grades may be losing $150 million a year. But Rep. Philip R. Sharp, D-Ind., who along with Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., released the report, said the study was conservative and losses could reach as high as $600 million through growing mislabeling of octane ratings at the pump. Sharp's estimate is based partly on the fact that the GAO said that more than half the samples taken in two large cities last year _ Detroit and St. Louis _ were found to have octane ratings an average of 2.2 or more points below what was posted on the pump. ``Unfortunately, consumers cannot determine octane ratings visually or in other ways that allow them to know if they are getting what they are paying for,'' the GAO said. Federal law requires that uniform yellow and black labels on gas pumps show the octane rating of gas, and some higher-powered vehicles recommend various levels of octane to avoid that unhealthy ``ping'' or knocking sound in engines. A low octane gas can reduce engine efficiency, mileage and emissions in high-powered engines, the GAO said. Regular unleaded gas is rated at 87, with midgrade unleaded at 89 and premium grades from 91 to 94. Regular leaded gas is rated at 89. The difference in retail price between the lowest and highest grade can range up to 20 cents a gallon. ``A consumer could be paying several cents a gallon extra for quality that is not delivered,'' said Sharp, who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on energy and power. Sharp said he would introduce legislation to give states more enforcement power over octane cheaters. The report said inspectors found in several states that some retail stations were selling gasoline from the same storage tank that was rated at different octane levels. At other stations, 87-octane unleaded regular gasoline was being sold as leaded regular, which should have an 89 rating, because the wholesale price for unleaded was lower, the report said. ``What this adds up to is a quiet but dangerous shell-game for consumers,'' Schumer said. A 1978 law requires the Federal Trade Commission and the Environmental Protection Agency to enforce compliance with federal petroleum marketing practices. But the GAO study said the agencies have not carried out testing since 1981. The report said both agencies generally support the GAO's conclusions and cite lack of funding and staff for their failure to enforce the labeling rules. Violators may be fined up to $10,000 for each instance. Joe Koach, executive director of the 60,000-member Service Station Dealers of America, said he was ``deeply chagrined because this broad-brushes the integrity of America's gasoline marketers.'' Legitimate dealers would not risk their franchises with major oil companies by cheating, and the organization supports stringent enforcement against octane cheaters, Koach said. David Morehead, spokesman for the Petroleum Marketers Association of America, said there have been scattered reports of cheating but it is ``absolutely deplored in the industry.'' Nearly half of the states conduct their own octane tests, and mislabeling has been minimal where testing acts as a deterrent, the GAO study said, But in seven non-testing states visited by GAO investigators, problems were found, mainly at the distribution and retail levels, the report said. Frequent octane mislabeling was found in one-time tests conducted in Michigan, Missouri, Oregon and Tennessee, GAO said, and investigators also found concern about octane cheating from officials interviewed in Indiana, Montana and Washington. In 1989 Michigan tests conducted primarily in Detroit, 51.9 percent of stations had inflated ratings averaging 2.3 octane points, and in St. Louis 52.6 percent had mislabeled an average of 2.2 points, the report said. In 1988 tests conducted by Oregon officials, 21.8 percent of samples were mislabeled and in Tennessee 22.2 percent, the GAO said. States that test generally consider any mislabeling of one-half point or more in the octane rating as a significant violation, the GAO said. States which conduct their own tests and enforcement are Alabama, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Iowa, Louisinaa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Virginia and Wisconsin. Missouri and Tennessee began testing after the GAO inspections were conducted. Michigan, New York and Washington plan to begin octane testing, according to Sharp.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends Higher; Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly higher in dull U.S. trading Thursday after falling in Europe. Gold prices fell in New York after rising in Europe. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $370.60 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, down from $371.25 late Wednesday. The dollar moved in a narrow range in advance of Friday's release of U.S. gross national product data for the first quarter, analysts said. ``It was a corrective uptick,'' said James Chorek, an analyst at Money Market Services in Chicago. ``There wasn't much happening on fundamental ground to move the dollar one way or another.'' Analysts said the dollar got some support late in the day when bond prices dropped, pushing the interest rate on the Treasury's key 30-year bond over 9 percent for the first time since last May. Rising U.S. rates usually bolster the dollar. In Tokyo, where the business day ends as Europe's begins, the dollar fell to a closing 158.77 Japanese yen from 159.25 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar fell to 158.75 yen. By the end of the day in New York, however, the dollar had risen to 159.23 yen from 158.73 yen late Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6340 from $1.6370 late Wednesday. Later, in New York, one pound fetched $1.6342, down from $1.6405 the day before. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6797 West German marks, up from 1.6780 marks; 1.4575 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6355 French francs, up from 5.6345; 1,231.75 Italian lire, up from 1,231.00; and 1.1603 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1608. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6810 West German marks, down from 1.6820; 1.4605 Swiss francs, down from 1.4665; 5.6395 French francs, down from 5.6455; 1.8915 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8970; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,234.00, and 1.1602 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1603. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $372.65 a troy ounce from $371.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal rose to a closing bid of $372.75 from $371.00 bid late Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.92 to close at a bid of $373.03. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $370.50 a troy ounce, down from $370.70 late Wednesday. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.96 a troy ounce from $4.97 bid late Wednesday. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $4.913 a troy ounce, down from $4.919 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Rally in Soybeans Pulls Market Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculation of low soybean exports from South America spurred interest in the U.S. crop. On other markets, precious metals futures mostly were lower; energy futures declined and livestock futures were mixed while pork mostly was higher. Wheat settled 1 cent lower to 2} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 2} cents higher with May at $2.80} a bushel; oats were a 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $1.60\ a bushel; soybeans were 14 cents to 19\ cents higher with May at $6.26\ a bushel. Soybean prices for nearby months reached season highs and later months reached contract highs as commission houses entered the market strongly and the price of Brazilian soybeans surged. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said the Brazilian price rise was an indication that country will not have a lot of soybeans to export. ``The concern of Europeans over delays in South American shipments may step up their interest in the U.S. market,'' he said. Karlin also said concerns about the possibility of hotter-than-normal temperatures through the summer also fueled speculation in soybeans. That concern was sparked by the 10-day National Weather Service forecast released Wednesday that calls for hotter- and drier-than-normal weather. The strength of soybeans spilled into corn and wheat, sending those prices higher. Wheat futures rose despite news that cash prices for soft red winter wheat plunged during the day. Corn prices were boosted by speculative and commercial buying. Precious metals futures traded in a narrow range on New York's Commodity Exchange. ``There is very little buying interest at the moment in gold and silver,'' said Jerry Rothman, an analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York, adding there was little news to spur interest in the market. Rothman said the lack of buying interest may mean prices will be forced even lower, noting that a mild rally Thursday triggered additional selling. Thursday's quiet trading followed Wednesday's frantic session during which platinum tumbled sharply, pulling down gold and silver prices. Gold was 20 cents lower to 10 cents higher with April at $370.50 a troy ounce; silver was .80 cent to 1 cent lower with May at $4.914 a troy ounce; platinum was $1.70 to $2.70 higher with July at $473.90 a troy ounce. Energy prices were lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading as analysts noted the oversupply of crude oil continues weighing on the market. An emergency session of the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroelum Exporting Countries is scheduled to convene May 2 in Geneva to address the slide in crude prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 3 cents to 19 cents lower with June at $18.47 a barrel; heating oil was .25 cent lower to .67 cent higher with May at 53.07 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .35 cent to 1.26 cents lower with May at 61.34 cents a gallon. Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .25 cent lower to .45 cent higher with June at 72.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .45 cert lower to unchanged with April at 84.7 cents a pound; live hogs were .27 cent to .63 cent higher with June at 63.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .33 cent lower to .35 cent higher with May at 63.70 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces Another Round of Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., which has been slashing its work force, announced another round of voluntary cutbacks Thursday and said its overall payroll should be reduced by 2,000 employees by July. Digital has been hurt by weak U.S. computer sales, though the company recently reported its first growth in a year from this sector. Digital said Thursday it would offer voluntary severance to 450 workers out of 644 at a Springfield manufacturing plant, and to 221 workers at a Boxboro plant. The company said it expects more than 150 workers to accept the severance package at these two sites. Digital previously offered severance to 3,800 workers, and 800 accepted. The company expects to have 2,000 people leave the company by July 1. Digital took a $150 million charge in its fiscal third quarter, due mostly to the severance program and other shifting of employees. Analysts have estimated, however, that Digital will eventually cut 5,000 workers from its worldwide payroll of 125,000.

DOC.HEAD: Transamerica's Earnings Dip Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Transamerica Corp. on Thursday reported its first quarter earnings fell slightly. For the latest quarter ended March 31, the financial services corporation reported net income of $70.3 million, or 88 cents per share, compared to $70.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Its first quarter earnings included after-tax gains on investment transactions of $5.2 million. The first quarter 1989 results included investment gains of $19.4 million. ``We achieved strong first-quarter performances at virtually all of our operations,'' said Transamerica Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James R. Harvey. ``We continue to expect 1990 to be another strong year for Transamerica.''

DOC.HEAD: Plans Announced for American Style Suburb In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A housing developer on Thursday announced plans to build an American-style suburban residential complex in Moscow to meet the needs of foreign businessmen frustrated by the Soviet Union's scarce and low-quality housing. The $130-million project will bring a taste of Western comfort to 80 acres of rolling land near two villages of log cabins on the northwest outskirts of Moscow, according to Chris Senie, secretary of Senie Kerschner International Housing Ltd. The project is a joint venture with a collective farm adjacent to the site. The land is being leased from the collective farm. The first of the 528 townhouse units are to be completed in 1991. The development will include amenities such as an indoor swimming pool, a medical clinic, a gymnasium and stores, Senie said. The units will rent for about $50,000 a year on six-year leases, which is comparable to the costs foreign companies pay for comparable housing, if they can find any available, Senie said. Although the complex will have guard patrols and its stores will accept only hard currency, the developers don't want it to be a ``foreign ghetto.'' Twenty percent of the units are to be occupied by Soviet employees of foreign companies. Senie said residents of the adjacent villages will be allowed to use the athletic facilities at times and they will have free access to a lake that borders the project. ``There's no question the project is going to impact their lives greatly,'' he said. The developers also are assisting the collective farm in completing a 60-acre greenhouse complex, Senie said. Companies that have reserved units at the complex include British Airways, Nichimen of Japan and Philips of the Netherlands, Senie said. Eighty percent of the units will be rented for hard currency and the units for Soviets will be rented in rubles. The construction is to be managed by Finn-Stroi of Finland, using Soviet materials where possible and 70 percent Soviet workers, Senie said. Construction costs work out to about $90 a square foot; building such a development in the United States costs about $72 a square foot, he said. Zane Yost, the project's architect, said he hopes the three-story, clapboard-style buildings will demonstrate the latest housing techniques to the Soviets. That he said, could be a reparation for unfortunate housing ideas that the Soviets once learned from the United States. He said he asked a Soviet official one time why so much of the country's post-war housing was in concrete high-rise buildings; the official replied ``because (Americans) told us to do it that way.

DOC.HEAD: Contel Earnings Down Due to Acquisition Costs
DOC.TEXT: Contel Corp. said Thursday its profit for the first quarter declined 16 percent, primarily because of costs associated with its $1.3 billion acquisition of McCaw Cellular Communications properties. The Atlanta-based telephone company said it earned $54 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $64 million, or 40 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1989.Revenue rose 7 percent to $797 million. The McCaw acquisition, which involved cellular telephone operations in Kentucky, Tennessee and Alabama, ``reflects our commitment to pursuing a growth strategy in the personal communications industry,'' said Donald W. Weber, Contel's president and chief executive officer. ``While the costs associated with the acquisition will affect near-term earnings, this investment has very attractive long-term implications,'' he said in a statement. The acquisition was completed Feb. 27. Contel said it had 105,420 cellular phone subscribers on March 31, up from 50,050 on Dec. 31. Contel's cellular communications division recorded a loss of $11 million in the first quarter, mostly because of the acquisition costs, which included interest expense and goodwill amortization, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Proposals Would Hurt Boeing, Major B-2 Subcontractor
DOC.TEXT: Proposals to cut Pentagon aircraft programs would hurt Boeing Co. and some of its suppliers, although it's too early to tell how badly, officials of the aircraft company said Thursday. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday outlined to Congress proposed cuts aimed at saving $34.8 billion through 1997, partly by purchasing fewer B-2 stealth bombers and delaying the start of production of Advanced Tactical Fighters. Boeing already has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the two programs. The company is a major subcontractor to Northrop Corp. on the B-2, with 10,000 employees in the Seattle area working on the project. It's the largest program for Boeing Military Airplanes and one of the most significant for the entire aerospace company, said Military Airplanes spokesman John Kvasnosky. Boeing also has 850 Seattle employees working on an ATF prototype it is developing with Lockheed Corp. and General Dynamics. ``I can't speculate in any detail as to what the longer term effects would be,'' if Cheney's plans for the B-2 are adopted, Kvasnosky said. However, ``It would mean that we would not recognize the buildup and growth we had anticipated when we set out to do this,'' he said. ``Obviously, it will have a financial impact on all the suppliers.'' Boeing corporate spokesman Russ Young said the company was examining what effects Cheney's proposals might have on Boeing employment, but had no immediate estimate. Cheney's proposals would start with fiscal year 1991. Boeing lost $479 million in its defense and space segments last year and blamed the poor performance on technical, cost and scheduling problems. Overall, Boeing had record profits of $4.23 billion on sales of $20.28 billion, mainly due to its booming commercial airplane business. The company reorganized its defense operations and predicted it should do better this year. Planned purchases of B-2s were slowed in 1989 as Congress and the Defense Department studied the need for the radar-evading bomber in light of the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Boeing cited that delay as a reason for reducing its 164,000-person workforce by about 5,000 for 1990. Work is under way up through the eighth B-2, Kvasnosky said, with another seven planes in the pre-production stage. Boeing makes the outboard sections of the wing and the aft section of the fuselage for the tailless bomber. It also makes the fuel system, weapons delivery system and the landing gear. To date, the B-2 has been worth about $4 billion to Boeing, Kvasnosky said, adding that the company has invested about $400 million on its share of the program. Boeing and the other contractors virtually have completed the first two prototype YF22-A ATFs, with the first plane to fly by the end of June. The plane is competing with the YF23-A being built by Northrop and McDonnell Douglas Corp. The Air Force plans to pick a winning contractor for full-scale development by May 1991, with a contract award scheduled two months later. Cheney has suggested ATF purchases be delayed from 1994 to 1996. The number to be bought would remain at 750. The ATF prototypes have been kept under strict security, although the plane is expected to be a heavily computerized, highly maneuverable successor to the Air Force's F-15. The Lockheed team has spent about $600 million on the prototypes, Kvasnosky said, with Boeing's share ``a couple hundred million dollars.'' Boeing is building the wings and the aft section of the ATF fuselage and is installing the engines, he said. It also is producing much of the avionics, including the software. Costs and the number of employees working on ATF have been declining because the production work essentially is done, Kvasnosky said. But if the Lockheed team wins the contract and production is pushed back two years, ``there would be costs associated with keeping the program at the simmer level.''

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Official Confirms Plan, Asks City For Abatements
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. will build a new sport utility vehicle in Toledo if it can resolve with city, state and union officials a number of issues that could cut production costs, a company official said Thursday. The company is looking for an incentives package from the city and state. It also wants to renegotiate a new contract with United Auto Workers Local 12. Chrysler's current contract with Local 12 expires in 1992. ``Frankly, this is the home of the Jeep. Nothing would be more appropriate than to have a new Jeep vehicle located in Toledo,'' said Michael Glusac, Chrysler's executive director of governmental affairs. ``We hope the discussions will eventually make that a reality.'' If agreements are reached, Chrysler also will transfer production of the Jeep Wrangler model to Toledo from Brampton, Ontario, Glusac said in an interview. Chrysler's moves could mean up to 1,600 new jobs at Toledo's two Jeep plants. Under the company's plans, Chrysler would begin producing its new JJ line in July 1993, creating 700 jobs. The JJ is a $500 million joint venture with Renault, a French automaker. Chrysler also would shift vehicle production of the Jeep YJ model to Toledo from Brampton beginning in July 1992, a move that could create 900 new jobs. Glusac said some of the 1,300 employees at the Brampton plant would be offered jobs at other Chrysler plants.

DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Earnings Expected to Be More Than Two-Thirds Lower
DOC.TEXT: First-quarter earnings for the nation's Big Three automakers will be more than two-thirds below last year's profits, analysts said Thursday. The companies are expected to report next week that the drop in earnings was caused mainly by drastic production cuts in the United States and economic troubles in Brazil. A spot check of analysts Thursday showed forecasts that General Motors Corp.'s quarterly earnings would be down about 70 percent from the $1.55 billion the company earned during the first three months of 1989, which was the best quarter GM had since the second quarter of 1984. Ford Motor Co.'s earnings should be down about 75 percent from the $1.64 billion the company earned during the period last year, according to the analysts. Chrysler Corp. may show a marginal increase from the $351 million in profits it posted during the first quarter of 1989, the analysts said. ``The earnings are going to be almost a yawn,'' said John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. ``People have been bracing for the weakened earnings report. The bigger question is when are we going to get the turn.'' Auto company executives and industry analysts have predicted that the first half of the year would be tough and that things would pick up in the second half. ``They'll make more money in the second quarter than they did in the first quarter,'' said analyst David Healy of Barclays-BZW in New York. ``In the second quarter, earnings will still be below last year, but the comparisons won't be as bad as the first quarter.'' A rebound in the second half may be delayed, Kirnan said. ``The (car and truck) sales numbers have certainly gotten back into a sluggish territory and with interest rates continuing to escalate, it may choke off a major turn in second-quarter and second-half earnings of these companies,'' he said. In January, all of the Big Three shut down assembly lines, temporarily laying off thousands of employees, and pushed incentives for purchasers _ both drastic moves to shrink bloated new-car inventories. The inventories were brought back to more manageable levels, which was good for the companies, but the moves apparently clobbered first-quarter earnings. ``A lot of people are saying it will be the toughest quarter of the year,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. Chrysler, which has relied heavily on incentives to sell its cars and trucks, had an aggressive incentive program for its popular minivans during January. That pumped up sales, but incentive costs come directly out of profits, and the No. 3 automaker doesn't have overseas operations to prop up any sag in North American operations. During the past year or so, GM and Ford have relied on their overseas businesses, especially in Europe and South America, to help maintain profit levels for the entire company. That reliance soon may end. ``A lot of people got surprised by the extent of the damage in Brazil,'' Ms. Sudol said. ``Everything is at a standstill in Brazil.'' In March, Brazil's government froze all accounts. Inflation was 4,583 percent annually at the time. On March 26, Ford and West German automaker Volkswagen AG shut down production at their Autolatina joint venture in Brazil and put 2,800 employees on paid leave. Ford spokesman Rex Greenslade said Thursday those workers would be recalled next Wednesday. Ford, in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission before the Brazilian government took economic action, said if current conditions continued, there was potential for a substantial negative effect on the company's earnings. Greenslade declined to comment on whether the employee recall meant that Ford now has more confidence in the Brazilian economic situation.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Narrower Loss in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Debt-burden Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. reported Thursday a smaller loss in the first quarter than a year ago as its revenue rose 14.6 percent. The report of the latest loss comes a day after the publishing and insurance concern, which sold its theme park holdings last year, said it was discussing the possible sale of additional assets. For the three-month period ending March 31, Harcourt reported it lost $78.3 million, or $1.07 per share, compared with a loss of $131.5 million, or $1.80 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $276.9 million from $241.6 million in 1989. Harcourt's insurance division posted first-quarter income from operations of $11.1 million, down from $12.5 million a year earlier. But the company's publishing division had a loss from operations of $28.7 million, compared with a loss from operations of $46.1 million a year earlier. Its overall loss from continuing operations fell to $20.2 million compared with a loss from contining operations of $39.2 million a year earlier. The company has been struggling under a $2 billion debt incurred in May 1987 when it underwent a recapitalization to avert a takeover by British publisher Robert Maxwell. Peter Jovanovich, president and chief executive officer, said late Wednesday that the company has begun preliminary discussions involving the sale of some or all of its existing debt at a discount, or the purchase of ``certain assets of the company by a third party.'' ``HBJ is not for sale,'' Jovanovich said in a statement. ``It is simply premature to speculate as to whether a transaction will occur, and, if one does occur, as to its eventual form or terms.'' The statement followed a report earlier Wednesday that former U.S. Sen. Eugene McCarthy, who has served for a decade on HBJ's board, said discussions had been under way with Tomson Corp. of Canada for a month. Harcourt sold its four Sea World parks and two other theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Cos. for $1.1 billio last September. Analysts said Harcourt needed to sell the parks to help pay off a its debt.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Court Approves Learjet Sale
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved the sale of corporate jet maker Learjet Corp. to Bombardier Inc. of Canada for $75 million in cash. The sale by Integrated Resources Inc. also requires Bombardier to assume liabilities associated with Learjet's continuing operations, including loans outstanding under the company's $38 million line of credit. The deal, which was announced earlier this month, is expected to close around May 31, Integrated said in a statement. The sale was the first major asset disposition outside its major businesses by Integrated, an investment firm that filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in February after defaulting on $1.6 billion in debt. Learjet, founded in the late 1950s, makes three light jets and a medium class model selling for $3.8 million to $7.2 million. It has 2,750 employees and annual sales of more than $250 million. Integrated acquired Learjet in 1987. Bombardier's products include rail transit equipment, snowmobiles and a heavy business jet called Challenger, which is manufactured by its Canadair Group and sells for $14 million to $18 million. The company has plants in Canada, the United States, Austria, Belgium, France, England, Finland and Sweden, and employs 22,500 people. Bombardier's annual business volume is more than 2 billion Canadian dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Partly Dismisses Soybean Suit; Both Sides Claim Victory
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge dismissed one count of a lawsuit Thursday accusing the Chicago Board of Trade of illegally manipulating soybean prices, prompting the exchange and its farm-group adversary to claim victory. The ruling by U.S. District Judge George Marovich means the American Agriculture Movement Inc. cannot sue the Board of Trade based on alleged violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. But it allows the Washington-based farmers group to proceed with three other counts in the lawsuit alleging antitrust violations, breach of fiduciary duty and gross negligence. The lawsuit stems from the Board of Trade's unusual July 11 order last year requiring traders to reduce their holdings in contracts for July delivery of soybeans. The result was a steep drop in soybean prices on the cash and futures markets. The Board of Trade, the world's largest soybean futures market, issued the order to force the Italian company Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A. to reduce its soybean holdings. The exchange said the large holdings threatened to cause a sharp, artificial increase in prices. Ferruzzi has denied it was attempting to corner the soybean market. The American Agriculture Movement filed its class-action lawsuit against the Board of Trade and its officers in November. It contended the emergency order was illegal and caused U.S. farmers to lose more than $100 million on the value of their soybeans. The count dismissed by Marovich _ the first of four counts in the lawsuit _ declared that farmers, like futures brokers and their clients, have legal standing to sue the exchange based on alleged violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Marovich disagreed. The Board of Trade, which had sought to have the entire lawsuit dismissed, said in a statement that Marovich had dismissed ``the major count'' of the complaint. ``We believe that the court's action is further vindication of the propriety of our action,'' said exchange Chairman Karsten Mahlmann. Mahlmann noted that inquiries by the federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the General Accounting Office had found no wrongdoing by the Board of Trade. But John Arens, a lawyer for the American Agriculture Movement in Fayetteville, Ark., said the first count was ``a throwaway.'' Arens said the meat of the lawsuit is in the second count, which accuses the exchange, its officers and their trading firms of conspiring to restrain soybean trading and fix prices. The third count alleges exchange officers breached their fiduciary duties and the fourth count alleges they acted with gross negligence and wanton disregard for market users. Marovich said in his ruling he would entertain a motion from the exchange for a summary judgement, which is similar to a dismissal but which cannot be made until the case is ready to go to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Get Court Approval for Money-Raising Deals
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. received a federal bankruptcy judge's approval Thursday to hire Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and McKinsey & Co. to help devise a reorganization plan. The two retailing arms of Canada's Campeau Corp. also received approval to sell a corporate jet for $3.2 million and to provide data processing for Macy's, the New York-based retailer. Shearson will charge $250,000 a month in fees, plus expenses, to act as financial adviser for an indefinite period, said Cory Lipoff, a lawyer for Federated and Allied. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said he will review the contract 90 days after the retailers file their reorganization plan. The companies have not said when the plan will be filed. McKinsey, a management consulting firm, was hired under a three-month contract beginning May 1 for a fee of $200,000 a month plus expenses, Lipoff said. The advisers are needed to help Federated and Allied come up with a plan to get out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, which they entered Jan. 15. Federated and Allied listed $7.7 billion in debt, much of it acquired when Toronto-based Campeau bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. U.S. Trustee Conrad Morgenstern, who is helping the court administer the reorganization, has complained to Aug that strict oversight procedures are needed to ensure that financial advisers and other professionals do not submit exorbitant bills for their services. Morgenstern said such charges could drain money from the retailers' estates and reduce their worth for creditors. Aug has said he would scrutinize fees to ensure that they are reasonable. Lipoff said the advisers have promised to submit documentation to explain their fee charges and what services were rendered. Aug also approved the sale of a Federated corporate jet, a Lockheed Jetstar II, to an investors' group called W.P.W. Investments Jetstar. Federated announced 10 days before its Chapter 11 filing that it planned to sell off the Jetstar and three other corporate aircraft to reduce expenses and raise cash. The judge also approved contracts under which the retailers will provide data processing and information services to three units of R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. Macy will pay $29 million to Federated and Allied under a deal that will run for one year, with provision for a three-year extension if a long-term deal is not negotiated by then, said Rick Cieri, a lawyer for Federated and Allied. The data processing will support billing and credit operations of Macy's 25-store California division and the San Francisco-based I. Magnin division, which has 29 stores, spokesmen said. The retailers also will provide data processing for Macy's 46-store Northeast division and its New York corporate headquarters, serving programs for billing, credit, payment of vendors and other functions, Cieri said.

DOC.HEAD: Gannett, Entire Newspaper Industry, Mired in Recession, Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: Like the entire newspaper industry, Gannett Co. is mired in a recession that began in the second half of 1989, the chairman of the communications company told shareholders Thursday. Gannett, whose profits grew along with its increasing size for 22 consecutive years since it became publicly traded company, ``managed to report an up quarter, but barely'' in its first quarter earnings report last week, Chairman John J. Curley said. Curley's comments were made against the backdrop of this week's American Newspaper Publishers Association meeting, at which news executives bemoaned a precipitous drop in advertising revenues and an accompanying decline in readership. Most publishers at the Los Angeles meeting attributed the advertising crisis to regional economic troubles, particularly in the Northeast. They said declining auto sales along with a softening in real estate and help-wanted ads contributed to the general downturn. Gannett also has suffered from the downturn in advertising that started in the Northeast, spread to the South and has not yet reached the West Coast, company officials said. They were cautious about prospects for their papers, including USA Today. Still, they said they expect USA Today to turn profitable for the first time in 1990. They also said USA Weekend is approaching profitability and now carries more ads than its main competitor, Parade magazine. But Curley cautioned, ``We won't really know about the retail climate until we find out what happens in May and June.'' He noted that Gannett's stock price rose along with the fortunes of the company in the first half of 1989, then fell when the newspaper business turned down in mid-1989. Still, he said, Gannett remains a good investment for long-term shareholders, with a 17 percent average annual return on a stock purchase since Gannett went public in 1969. Trustees of the Gannett Foundation, whose sole asset is 10 percent of the company's stock, said Wednesday they would put the block up for sale because Internal Revenue Service rules forced them to consider diversifying their holdings. The charitable trust is headed by former Gannett Chairman Allen H. Neuharth. Through a spokesman, Neuharth declined to comment on a Washington Post story that said the proposed sale may indicate a rift between Neuharth and executives who have run the company since he left as chairman in March 1989. Curley gave up using limousines and the corporate suites Neuharth had rented in New York and Washington, and the Post said Neuharth was upset by comments of Gannett executives criticizing his lifestyle while chairman as excessive and wasteful. Curley also declined to comment through his spokeswoman, Sheila Gibbons, although she said of the Post story, ``I think that's overreaching.'' Much of the shareholders meeting was devoted to descriptions of how Gannett is trying to develop new products as Americans find less time to read and show less inclination to do so. Such strategies include buying the city magazine in Rockford, Ill., where Gannett publishes the Register Star newspaper, ``to increase our already strong information and ad picture,'' said Gary L. Watson, president of Gannett's community newspaper division. He said Gannett might buy other such magazines. Watson and other Gannett officials also described how the company had: _published a ``talking phone book'' in Florida with access to news, weather, sports and other information at a toll-free number. _put out advertising guides to luxury real estate, also in Florida. _started upscale lifestyle supplements to attract advertisers in New Jersey and Florida. _published a guide with Pacific Northwest tourist information to be distributed on ferries that sail from Washington state to Alaska. _run specials on its television stations built around special sections in USA Today.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Plans Layoffs Due to Losses at Long Beach Unit
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. will cut 3,000 jobs this summer, mainly administrators and non-production workers, to stem losses at its Douglas Aircraft unit, the company said Thursday. In its first quarter report last week, the St. Louis-based aerospace company said it had an operating loss of $84 million at Douglas Aircraft, twice as big a deficit as in first-quarter 1989. Long Beach-based Douglas is home to the MD-80 jetliner and where the MD-11 jetliner and C-17 cargo plane are being developed. Employment rose from about 15,000 people in 1984 to 50,000 today as orders for the twin-engine MD-80 surged and the other planes were developed. ``The bottom line is, we've got to reduce costs because the performance has not been up to expectations,'' said spokesman John Thom. The layoffs will come primarily from ``staff and support functions as opposed to the production side of things,'' Thom said. ``An examination will get under way soon to see where people are needed, what kind of shifting will take place.'' Thom said the cuts had been under discussion for some time and were not a reaction to Thursday's proposal by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to buy only 120 of the C-17 long-range transport planes instead of the 210 originally planned. The move is designed to save $11.9 billion over the life of the program. The MD-11 and C-17 are nearing the end of their development phases, and some staff reassignments would have been expected in any case. The MD-11 is undergoing flight tests and certifications; the third of the three-engine jumbo jets flew for the first time Thursday. The C-17 will fly in 1991. The company said it would try to transfer some workers who lose their jobs into production slots, but said an undetermined number of people would lose their jobs. Workers not only in Long Beach but in the company's other operations in the United States and Canada will be affected. McDonnell Douglas officials discussed the poor performance at Douglas Aircraft at the company's annual meeting Monday, but made no mention of upcoming layoffs. Fourteen months after a sweeping reorganization in Long Beach, McDonnell officials said they're still waiting for results. ``We are at bottom,'' said John McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer. ``But we really see it as a long-term investment. We did not expect to see results in 1989. I would expect we are not going to see 1990 as bad as 1989.'' Lawrence M. Harris, an aerospace analyst at Bateman, Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles, said that even though the MD-11 and C-17 programs are nearing completion, he's not expecting the problems at Douglas to disappear quickly along with the 3,000 jobs. ``Turnarounds in the aerospace industry rarely occur in just one quarter,'' he said. ``The work in process on a new, complex program like the MD-11 or C-17 is measured in terms of years.''

DOC.HEAD: B-2 Builder Says Proposed Production Cut Will Hurt Subcontractors First
DOC.TEXT: The government's plan to cut production of the Northrop B-2 stealth bomber nearly in half would hurt suppliers first but eventually would stunt Northrop's workforce, the company said Thursday. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday outlined to Congress proposed cuts aimed at saving $34.8 billion through 1997, partly by purchasing 75 B-2 bombers instead of the 132 originally planned and delaying the start of production of Advanced Tactical Fighters. Cheney's proposal, predicated on a view of a diminishing Soviet military threat, helps trim the Pentagon budget by targeting a program in which each aircraft would cost taxpayers $530 million. Northrop employs 12,000 people on the B-2 project, including about 1,700 who work on assembling the radar-evading bomber in Palmdale, Calif. Stealth bomber subcontractors and suppliers across the nation employ 30,000 to 40,000 workers, said Tony Cantafio, a Northrop spokesman. Production of five B-2s was proposed in the fiscal 1991 budget at a cost of $5.5 billion. Under the new plan only two jets would be built that year. ``The immediate effect may be felt by suppliers and subcontractors around the country,'' said Cantafio. ``From an employment standpoint at Northrop, there won't be an immediate effect.'' Northrop still will need to hire several hundred more workers for the Palmdale plant because of prior orders, Cantafio said. However, Cheney's proposal would halve production in peak years to 12 from 24 aircraft. ``Obviously, in the long run we won't build up our employment to the original schedule,'' Cantafio said. Just last Sunday the company ran full-page newspaper advertisements for a B-2 job fair, using a photograph of the ominous-looking flying wing and an appeal to many types of aerospace workers to help ``make history.'' Northrop also has been running television ads focusing on employees talking about their work and featuring famed test pilot Chuck Yeager. Building fewer stealth bombers would reduce the program's projected cost from $75.4 billion to $61.1 billion but would raise the cost of individual planes to more than $800 million, according to Cheney. Northrop also is competing for a role in a new generation aircraft known as the Advanced Tactical Fighter, which will replace the Air Force's F-15. Cheney still wants 750 planes built but would push back purchases two years, from 1994 to 1996. The Northrop spokesman said the impact of that change is minimal because the aircraft is not in full-scale development.

DOC.HEAD: Blue Chip Stocks Advance But Broader Market Finishes Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `One of ...' to CORRECT year-ago figure to $1.95 a share sted 1.96
DOC.TEXT: The stock market ended mixed Thursday despite buying that carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a double-digit gain. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 10.14 to 2,676.58. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 677 up, 764 down and 521 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 141.33 million shares, up from 133.48 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 169.11 million shares. Activity was moderate on Wall Street where some traders marked time ahead of potentially market-moving economic data due Friday. Anxiety about possible interest rate hikes and higher inflation also kept investors on the sidelines. ``I think a lot of investors are looking for something to push them off the fence,'' said Hugh Johnson, a senior vice president at First Albany Corp. The next test of Wall Street's mood was expected to come Friday morning with the Commerce Department's first official estimate of the gross national product for the first quarter of 1990. Economists expect the data to show a modest revival in growth, and quite possiby new stirrings of inflation as well. The market got off to a promising start Thursday but by late morning a broadly based advance bogged down as prices of government bonds took a beating in the credit market. The widely watched 30-year Treasury bond lost $7.50 for each $1,000 in face value, bringing its yield back above 9 percent. The blue chips managed to maintain a modest rally but had trouble gaining momentum, daunted by the upward pressure on interest rates. Analysts attributed most of the scattered stock price gains to buying motivated by upbeat earnings news. One of the standouts on Wall Street was Compaq Computer. The stock climbed 4\ to 98\ after the company reported unexpectedly strong first-quarter income of $2.13 a share, against $1.95 a year earlier. Another star performer was Bristol Meyers Squibb, which jumped 2[ to 54~. Gainers among the blue chips included Procter & Gamble, up 2[ to 70}; DuPont, up 1[ to 37; and Philip Morris, up ] to 42]. Ames Department Stores, which announced it had filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors, ended at 1|, up [. Norton topped the Big Board's list of active issues, falling { to 88\ as more than 2.58 million shares changed hands. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $6.194 billion, or 0.19 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.36 to 182.66. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 1.38 to 387.89, and S&P's 500-stock composite index added 0.89 to 332.92. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market edged 0.05 higher to 421.06. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 344.75, up 0.23.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the yen in thin trading Friday morning and share prices edged higher on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar ended morning trading at 159.10 yen, up 0.33 yen from Thursday's close of 158.77 yen. After opening higher at 159.43 yen, the currency traded in a narrow range between 159.05 yen and 159.47 yen. The Nikkei stock index rose 69.99 points, or 0.23 percent, closing the morning session at 29,494.57. The index shed 139.78 points on Thursday. Currency dealers said the dollar's strength followed its upswing in New York overnight, where the currency was bolstered by rising U.S. long-term interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency. ``There were no especially noticeable movements on the exchange market as many players were making position adjustments,'' said Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Dealers were taking a cautious stance ahead of the scheduled announcement later Friday of the estimated U.S. gross national product for the first quarter. Securities dealers said trading remained thin because of next week's holidays in Japan. Japan's ``Golden Week'' series of holidays begins Saturday and runs through May 6 for most companies. Next week, the stock and currency markets will be open only Tuesday and Wednesday. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 85.85 from Thursday's close of 86.09. That boosted their yield to 7.40 percent from 7.35 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Under Way Over Suspected Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: Police said they are investigating a former president of a finance firm for suspected insider trading, the first such investigation since Japan tightened laws against insider trading last year. A spokesman for the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department on Thursday said the investigation focused on Hironori Mito, 56, former president of Chiyoda Finance, a medium-sized financing firm in Tokyo. Mito is suspected to have acted on inside information in purchasing 7,000 shares of Nisshin Steamship Co., a Japanese shipping operator, in June 1989. The purchase was made a few days ahead of the company's announcement of terms of a new share allotment, said the spokesman, who spoke on condition he not be identified. The police spokesman refused to provide further details, saying only that the investigation had begun. An official of Nisshin Steamship refused to comment. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a major Japanese economic newspaper, quoted Shiro Shikai, chief of the company's general affairs department, as saying that only Chairman Harunori Takahashi and three other top officials had known of the allotment of new shares before the company's official announcement June 16, 1989. It was the first such investigation launched by police since Japan last year enacted a stricter law against benefiting from inside information in the trading of stocks. The United States had pressured Tokyo to bring its law in line with those in other world financial centers. Under the new law, enacted in January 1989, those convicted of insider trading will face up to six months' imprisonment or a fine of up to 500,000 yen, about $3,160. Previous violations were treated as civil offenses, though few cases ever came to light. Police investigators on Wednesday searched five locations, including Mito's home, the offce of Chiyoda Finance and a New Japan Securities Co.'s branch office in Tokyo, where Mito allegedly bought the shares under a woman's name. Police collected an unspecified number of documents, the spokesman said. The Tokyo Stock Exchange and the Finance Ministry investigated the alleged insider trading last June but failed to find evidence of insider trading, according to exchange officials.

DOC.HEAD: Walt Disney Net Up 20 Pct in Record 2nd Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Better results from theme parks, film entertainment and consumer products gave Walt Disney Co. another magical quarter, with profits up 20 percent and sales ahead 26 percent. In its fiscal second quarter ended March 31, Disney earned $178.5 million, or $1.29 a share, on revenue of $1.3 billion, the company reported Wednesday. That compared with earnings of $149 million, or $1.08 a share, on revenue of $1.03 billion in the same quarter a year earlier. The profits and sales figures were the latest in a string of record results for the entertainment conglomerate. Best-ever attendance at the theme parks, combined with higher per capita guest spending and expanded resort operations, boosted revenues and operating income in the division, Disney said. The Disney-MGM Studios attraction in Florida, which opened in May 1989, was a major draw, it added. Theme park operating income rose 14 percent to $194 million and revenue rose 22 percent to $710 million. Home video sales of ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' ``Dead Poets Society'' and ``Turner and Hooch,'' and the theatrical release of ``The Little Mermaid'' and ``Pretty Woman'' led the film entertainment results, Disney said. Growth in international television and home video were key factors, it said. Film revenue increased 30 percent to $469 million, with operating income gaining 40 percent to $58 million. Increased merchandise licensing, the success of ``The Little Mermaid'' sound track and European publishing activities contributed to a 29 percent rise in consumer products revenue to $125 million. Operating income rose 24 percent to $59 million. For the first six months of its fiscal year, Disney said profits rose 19 percent to $353 million and revenue climbed 25 percent to $2.6 billion.
